RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1996

TITLE: Predicting fish population response to instream flows
AUTHORS: Studley, T K; Baldridge, J E; Railsback, S F
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; WATER INFLUX; TROUT; POPULATION DYNAMICS; P CODES; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS
DESCRIPTION: A cooperative research program initiated by Pacific Gas and Electric is described. The goals of the project are to determine if trout populations respond to changes in base streamflows in a predictible manner, and to evaluate and improve the methods used to predict rainbow and brown trout population responses under altered flow regimes. Predictive methods based on computer models of the Physical Habitat Simulation System are described, and predictions generated for four diversions and creeks are tabulated. Baseline data indicates that instream flow assessments can be improved by using guild criteria in streams with competing species and including additional limiting factors (low recruitment, high winter flow, and high stream temperatures) in the analyses.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1996

TITLE: Making an automated monitoring system work at Tolt Dam
AUTHORS: Marilley, J M; Myers, B K
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; SAFETY; ALARM SYSTEMS; PIEZOMETRY; LEVEL INDICATORS
DESCRIPTION: A major upgrade of the dam safety program at Tolt Dam in Seattle, Washington is described. The upgrade was prompted by the age (30 years) of the dam, the addition of a hydroelectric plant, and public concern. The program is based on an automated condition monitoring and advance warning system. The design, implementation, and operating experience of the system are described.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1996

TITLE: Reducing cavitation erosion with natural-draft aeration
AUTHORS: Keith, G O; Jones, R K; March, P A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; OUTLET STRUCTURES; CAVITATION; EROSION; AERATION; TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RINGS; CAST IRON
DESCRIPTION: Technical information is provided on remedial and preventive methods used by the Tennessee Valley Authority to treat cavitation-erosion problems at the Ocoee No. 2 Hydro Plant. Cavitation had severely damaged cast-iron discharge rings on the plant`s hydro units. To eliminate the immediate threat, power agency personnel replaced the heavily eroded rings with new stainless steel parts. As a measure to prevent recurrence of the damage, TVA engineers implemented a plan for aerating the turbine discharges through holes drilled in the area between the runner band and discharge ring. This approach, implemented in 1993, has proven to be an effective an inexpensive method of reducing cavitation without affecting unit performance.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1996

TITLE: Engineers find climbing techniques work well for dam inspections
AUTHORS: O`Shea, M; Graves, A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SPILLWAYS; INSPECTION; DAMS; ROPES; OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY
DESCRIPTION: Climbing techniques adopted by the Bureau of Reclamation to inspect previously inaccessible or difficult to reach features at dams are described. Following the failure of the steel radial-arm gate at Folsom Dam, engineers mounted an effort to reach and inspect the dam`s seven other spillway gates. This close-up examination was performed to: (1) determine the condition of these gates; and (2) gather clues about the failure of the one gate. The access techniques described involved mountaineering techniques, as opposed to high scaling techniques, performed with dynamic and static nylon kermantle ropes.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1996

TITLE: TVA`s auto-venting turbines increase downstream aeration
AUTHORS: March, P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; TURBINES; PERFORMANCE TESTING; WATER RESERVOIRS; AERATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OUTLET STRUCTURES; DISSOLVED GASES; OXYGEN; TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY
DESCRIPTION: Two auto-venting turbines installed at Norris Hydro Plant to increase dissolved-oxygen levels are briefly described. The turbines introduce aeration through the thrust relief openings, the deflector, the trailing edge of each blade, and the periphery of the draft tube. Downstream dissolved-oxygen levels have been increased by up to 5.5 milligrams per liter. Efficiency losses range from 0 to 4 percent, depending on operating conditions and aeration method.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1996

TITLE: Underground pumped storage scheme in the Bukit Timah granite of Singapore
AUTHORS: Wong, I H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; WATER RESERVOIRS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; UNDERGROUND STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE; SINGAPORE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; NUMERICAL DATA
DESCRIPTION: Pumped storage is an energy storage method that involves the pumping of water from a lower reservoir to an upper reservoir during off-peak period using low cost power and releasing of the water from the upper reservoir to produce electricity during peak load period. Because of the very small and relatively flat land area of Singapore, a conventional surface pumped storage plant is not feasible. A pumped storage plant can be constructed here by siting the upper reservoir in one of the many abandoned granite quarries and by placing the lower reservoir and the powerhouse underground in the Bukit Timah granite, which is sound, massive and impervious. The capital costs for a pumped storage plant could be the same as those of an oil-fired plant of a comparable size. When the very high cost of land in Singapore is taken into account, an underground pumped storage scheme for peaking purposes becomes attractive. 7 refs., 4 figs., 3 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Tunnelling and Underground Space Technology; Journal Volume: 11; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1996

TITLE: Giant gate structure in reservoir to cool spawning fish downstream
AUTHORS: Rosenbaum, D B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; INTAKE STRUCTURES; CONSTRUCTION; WATER RESERVOIRS; TEMPERATURE CONTROL; DAMS; SALMON
DESCRIPTION: A Bureau of Reclamation project on Shasta Dam in northern California is highlighted in the article. The project was designed to alleviate power generation losses when reservoir water is released through the dam face, rather than the powerhouse, to provide the cold water required for salmon spawning. Two steel boxes were attached to the dam`s upstream face. The low-level intake is 170 feet high, 130 feet wide, and 50 feet thick, and draws cold water through the bottom. Water flows from the low-level intake box into a larger, temperature control box which contains automatically controlled gates at three levels to let in reservoir water. Colder water can then be conserved for release during salmon spawning season.
RELATION: Journal Name: ENR; Journal Volume: 237; Journal Issue: 14; Other Information: PBD: 30 Sep 1996

TITLE: Political benefits as barriers to assessment of environmental costs in Brazil`s Amazonian development planning: The example of the Jatapu Dam in Roraima
AUTHORS: Fearnside, P M; Barbosa, R I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BRAZIL; DAMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; POLITICAL ASPECTS
DESCRIPTION: Development projects are rapidly changing the landscape in Brazilian Amazonia. Environmental impact assessments have been required since 1986, and the regulatory system is evolving as precedents are set by each new development project. The Jatapu Dam in Roraima provides an illustration of underlying impediments to assessment of environmental costs and to due consideration being given to these assessments when decisions are made. The high priority placed on the dam by the Roraima state government is unexplainable in terms of economic returns. The place of the dam in a long-term political strategy provides the best of several possible explanations, any one of which is incompatible with a {open_quotes}rational{close_quotes} weighing of economic and environmental costs and benefits. A number of lessons can be drawn from the experience of Jatapu apply to development projects in many parts of the world. 49 refs., 5 figs., 3 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environmental Management; Journal Volume: 20; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Sep-Oct 1996

TITLE: The Cotingo Dam as a test of Brazil`s system for evaluating proposed developments in Amazonia
AUTHORS: Fearnside, P M; Barbosa, R I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; DAMS; POLITICAL ASPECTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; BRAZIL
DESCRIPTION: The proposed Cotingo Dam in Brazil`s far northern state of Roraima is examined with the objective of drawing lessons for Brazil`s system of evaluating environmental, social, and financial consequences of development decisions. The Cotingo Dam illustrates the difficulty of translating into practice the principles of economic and environmental assessment. Examination of the financial arguments for the Cotingo Dam indicates that justifications in this sphere are insufficient to explain why the project is favored over other alternatives and points to political factors as the best explanation of the project`s high priority. Strong pressure from political and entrepreneurial interest groups almost invariably dominates decision making in Amazonia. The analysis indicates the inherent tendency of the present system to produce decisions in favor of large construction projects at the expense of the environment and local peoples. The requirements intended to assure proper weight for these concerns, such as the report on environmental impacts (RIMA) and the public hearing, fail to serve this role. Cotingo also provides a test case for constitutional protections restricting construction of dams in indigenous lands. 39 refs., 4 figs., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environmental Management; Journal Volume: 20; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Sep-Oct 1996

TITLE: Possibility of quantitative prediction of cavitation erosion without model test
AUTHORS: Kato, Hiroharu; Konno, Akihisa; Maeda, Masatsugu; Yamaguchi, Hajime
SUBJECT: 42 ENGINEERING NOT INCLUDED IN OTHER CATEGORIES; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; TURBINES; CAVITATION; FORECASTING; CALCULATION METHODS; BUBBLES
DESCRIPTION: A scenario for quantitative prediction of cavitation erosion was proposed. The key value is the impact force/pressure spectrum on a solid surface caused by cavitation bubble collapse. As the first step of prediction, the authors constructed the scenario from an estimation of the cavity generation rate to the prediction of impact force spectrum, including the estimations of collapsing cavity number and impact pressure. The prediction was compared with measurements of impact force spectra on a partially cavitating hydrofoil. A good quantitative agreement was obtained between the prediction and the experiment. However, the present method predicted a larger effect of main flow velocity than that observed. The present scenario is promising as a method of predicting erosion without using a model test.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Fluids Engineering; Journal Volume: 118; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: Sep 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: JFEGA4; ISSN 0098-2202; TRN: IM9708%%318

TITLE: Movement of northern squawfish in the trailrace of a Lower Snake River Dam relative to the migration of juvenile anadromous salmonids
AUTHORS: Isaak, D J; Bjornn, T C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 55 BIOLOGY AND MEDICINE, BASIC STUDIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; FISHES; POPULATION DYNAMICS; PREDATOR-PREY INTERACTIONS
DESCRIPTION: Movements of transmitter-equipped northern squawfish Ptychocheilus oregonensis were monitored in the tailrace of Lower Granite Dam during seasonal migrations of juvenile anadromous salmonids Oncorhynchus spp. in 1992 and 1993. Abundance of northern squawfish with transmitters peaked in July, appeared to be inversely related to river discharge, and occurred after most juvenile salmonids had moved past Lower Granite Dam. Distributions of northern squawfish in the tailrace varied between and within years and shifted in relation to changing flow patterns, water temperatures, and diel cycles, but northern squawfish consistently used low-velocity habitats. Changes in distribution and abundance of northern squawfish in the tailrace suggest that juvenile salmonids migrating in the spring and early summer will be less affected by predation than juveniles migrating later in the summer. Northern squawfish did not concentrate downstream from an infrequently used juvenile bypass outfall, but several individuals were repeatedly found 30 m upstream from the bypass outfall, near the continuous discharge from a large pipe. Northern squawfish habituation to the predictable discharge suggests that predation could become a problem at the bypass outfall if it were used regularly to return juvenile migrants to the river. 40 refs., 8 figs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society; Journal Volume: 125; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Sep 1996
JOURNAL_NAME: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society

TITLE: Making money by improving plant efficiency
AUTHORS: Robitaille, A; Robert, S; Welt, F
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 MATHEMATICS, COMPUTERS, INFORMATION SCIENCE, MANAGEMENT, LAW, MISCELLANEOUS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; EFFICIENCY; G CODES; QUEBEC
DESCRIPTION: Studies showed Hydro-Quebec was losing millions of dollars a year in power revenues because its plants were not operating at ideal efficiency levels. The utility is implementing a computerized water management system for recovering much of that energy through optimum unit loading and by decreasing spillage. This article mainly discusses the development of this software package, GESTEAU, and it also lists several positive effects on hydro plant operation. Most notably was the improvement in plant efficiency.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1996

TITLE: Improving ventilation: Turning a penstock into a `Chimney`
AUTHORS: Chadwick, B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; TURBINE BLADES; MAINTENANCE; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; PENSTOCKS; VENTILATION
DESCRIPTION: This article describes a ventilation method used in the repair of turbine runners at hydroelectric power plants. Welding of the runners produces considerable gases that must be removed from the area for safety reasons. While it is possible to utilize portable ventilating equipment and air packs (if required). By closing the manways to the penstock and opening the manways to the draft tube, an updraft is created which takes the gases away from personnel and out vents in the penstock. This has been used several times at Libby Dam without any need for portable ventilation or breathing equipment.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1996

TITLE: Radar proves its worth in dam rehabilitation
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FOUNDATIONS; NONDESTRUCTIVE ANALYSIS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RADAR
DESCRIPTION: This article outlines the use of radar techniques to survey the masonry structure of White Marble Dam. The survey used a subsurface interface radar, and this equipment displayed a cross-sectional profile of the entire structure, revealing the size and location of any faults. By avoiding the draining and dredging of the upstream pool, it is estimated that this technique saved three months.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1996

TITLE: Using tilting-pad journal bearings in hydroturbine generators
AUTHORS: Abramovitz, S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; JOURNAL BEARINGS; DESIGN; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: The tilting-pad type of journal bearing offers several advantages in the operation of a hydro generator. Understanding how this type of bearing works and the practical aspects of its design and use can be helpful in both plant operations and generator rehabilitation. This article makes a case for such a bearing by describing its design, operation, and application in several configurations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1996

TITLE: How reclamation tests mechanical governors
AUTHORS: Agee, J C; Girgis, G K; Cline, R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 44 INSTRUMENTATION, INCLUDING NUCLEAR AND PARTICLE DETECTORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; SPEED REGULATORS; TESTING; OPERATION
DESCRIPTION: The Bureau of Reclamation has developed its own equipment for testing mechanical-hydraulic governors for hydroelectric generators. The device, called a Permanent Magnet Generator (PMG) Simulator, generates a three-phase voltage that will drive the governor ballhead motor at variable speed. Utilizing this equipment, most traditional governor tests can be completed with the generating unit dewatered. In addition, frequency response testing and other detailed analytical tests can be performed to validate governor models. This article describes the development and design of the equipment, and it also discusses its usage in a case study of events at Glen Canyon Dam.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1996

TITLE: Data collection, analysis supports risk assessment for hydro stations
AUTHORS: Truong, V
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RELIABILITY; DATA ACQUISITION; RISK ASSESSMENT; SYSTEM FAILURE ANALYSIS
DESCRIPTION: This article discusses the effort by Pacific Northwest Laboratories to gather design and operations data on hydroelectric stations with turbine-generator units in excess of 25 MWe featuring both Francis and Kaplan turbines. By analyzing this data, they were able to predict a failure rate or probability for various system components. PNL`s methodology is discussed, and the applicability of the study is also noted.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1996

TITLE: New notch weir system designed to pass shad through Potomac Dam
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; DESIGN; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: This article discusses the design and functional characteristics of a notch and three-weir labyrinth fish passage facility at Little Falls Dam. Most effective at low-head hydroelectric power plants, the weir system will reduce flow velocities to a value thought to be low enough for healthy shad to swim against. It is felt that this system will re-establish the shad population in a 10-mile stretch of the Patomac River near Washington.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1996

TITLE: A retrofit that worked: Upgrading Traengslet Station`s controls
AUTHORS: Andersson, S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; RETROFITTING; MAN-MACHINE SYSTEMS
DESCRIPTION: The design, installation, and operation of an automated control system is described. The system was installed by Stora Power AB in Sweden after an accident damaged the plant. An evaluation found the control system has had a nearly perfect operating record. The HPC 300 control equipment is a distributed system linked via a two-wire local area network, with separate computers for each generating unit, for the water level sensors, for the station, and for the man-machine interface. The control equipment includes turbine governors, autonomous voltage regulators, and synchronizing equipment.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 4; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1996

TITLE: Okumino: Japan`s largest pumped-storage plant enters service
AUTHORS: Kondoh, Hirotsune
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; JAPAN; CONTRACTORS; SPECIFICATIONS
DESCRIPTION: Measures taken during the planning, design, and construction of Chubu Electric`s Okumino Pumped-Storage Plant to reduce capital costs and construction time are described. The project plan, including dams and reservoirs, tunnels, and generating equipment, are outlined. Technical information is tabulated and a list is provided of plant contractors and suppliers. Unique features of the plant are highlighted, including remote operation, a detour waterway, and generator-motor configuration.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 4; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1996

TITLE: Lab tests find fusegates will function in cold climate
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; OUTLET STRUCTURES; STRUCTURAL MODELS; BENCH-SCALE EXPERIMENTS; DAMS; ICE; ARCTIC REGIONS
DESCRIPTION: A laboratory model test program at the Scientific Research Institute of Energy Structures in Moscow is briefly outlined. The program evaluated fusegates for use in Russia`s extreme climatic conditions. The program found that, while fusegates will function in Russia`s cold climates, measures will be needed to protect the fusegates in some instances when ice is present. These measures include ice protection structures for spillways and widening of the distance between adjacent inlet wells in front of fusegates.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 4; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1996

TITLE: RCC: Filling a larger role in hydropower construction
AUTHORS: Cordova, J Y; Toniatti, N B; Maozhen, Y
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; CONCRETES; COMPACTING; ROLLING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: Roller-compacted concrete (RCC) technology and its implications for planning and evaluation of hydropower projects are described. The experience of several project owners with RCC structures that have entered service or are in the construction and planning stage are presented. Lower costs, shortened construction times, and improved project quality are being realized with the use of RCC. Mixture specifications, concrete placement approaches, and dam specifications are outlined.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 4; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1996

TITLE: New tools and techniques for controlling cavitation
AUTHORS: Fulton, E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CAVITATION; ACOUSTIC MONITORING; TURBINE BLADES; EROSION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: This article presents case studies of the use of new tools, techniques, and products for controlling cavitation problems. Acoustic monitoring equipment is highlighted. Mechanical design, installation, and repair methods for cavitation control are also discussed. The use of new alloys and other materials, and welding techniques are described.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 4; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1996

TITLE: An alternative to conventional babbitt metal-lined generator pads
AUTHORS: Puuska, H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; TURBOGENERATORS; BEARINGS; PERFORMANCE; TEFLON; COATINGS
DESCRIPTION: The generator refurbishment of the Imatra Hydroelectric Power Plant Unit 1 in Finland is described. The generator work called for installation of a new cooling system for the generator thrust bearing. The considerations leading to the decision to replace the conventional babbitt metal-lined pads with elastic metal-plastic coated thrust bearing pads and the installation of the new pads are outlined in the article. Results of the trial run are summarized; the end temperature of the unit was more than 20C lower than for units equipped with conventional babbitted bearings.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 4; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1996

TITLE: Performance of two reservoirs during 1994 Northridge earthquake
AUTHORS: Davis, C A; Bardet, J P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; DAMS; EARTHQUAKES; EMBANKMENTS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; SAFETY ANALYSIS; SOILS; LIQUEFACTION; DAMAGE
DESCRIPTION: The 1994 Northridge Earthquake affected two geotechnical structures of the Van Norman Complex, the Los Angeles Reservoir (LAR) and the Power Plant Tailrace, in different ways. Both the Los Angeles Dam and North Dike of the LAR slightly moved and settled, and sustained small superficial cracks. The North Dike underwent a noticeable increase in seepage, without significantly impeding normal reservoir operations. The Northridge Earthquake uplifted and shifted the foundation of the LAR by 30 cm, and provided the authors with a unique example of tectonic effects on embankments. In contrast to the LAR, which performed well, the nearby rolled fill dike of the Power Plant Tailrace slowly failed by piping due to transverse cracks and differential lateral spreading induced by liquefaction. Both case studies yield valuable information about the response of embankments subjected to near-source ground motion.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Geotechnical Engineering; Journal Volume: 122; Journal Issue: 8; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: JGENDZ; ISSN 0733-9410; TRN: IM9646%%342

TITLE: Performance of San Fernando dams during 1994 Northridge earthquake
AUTHORS: Bardet, J P; Davis, C A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; DAMS; EARTHQUAKES; SEISMIC EFFECTS; SOILS; LIQUEFACTION; SAFETY ANALYSIS; RESPONSE FUNCTIONS; SAFETY ENGINEERING; HISTORICAL ASPECTS
DESCRIPTION: The 1994 Northridge and 1971 San Fernando Earthquakes subjected the Lower and Upper San Fernando Dams of the Van Norman Complex in the San Fernando Valley, Calif., to strong near-source ground motions. In 1994, these earth dams, which were out of service and retained only a few meters of water, extensively cracked and settled due to the liquefaction of their hydraulic fill. The Lower San Fernando Dam moved over 15 cm upstream as the hydraulic fill liquefied beneath its upstream slope. The Upper San Fernando Dam moved even more and deformed in a complicated three-dimensional pattern. The responses of the Lower and Upper San Fernando Dams during the 1994 Northridge Earthquake, although less significant than in 1971, provide the geotechnical engineering community with two useful case histories.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Geotechnical Engineering; Journal Volume: 122; Journal Issue: 7; Other Information: PBD: Jul 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: JGENDZ; ISSN 0733-9410; TRN: IM9646%%340

TITLE: Turbulent flow simulation of a runner for Francis hydraulic turbines using pseudo-compressibility
AUTHORS: Arakawa, Chuichi; Qian, Y; Kubota, Takashi
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; TURBULENT FLOW; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; VORTEX FLOW; COMPRESSIBLE FLOW; INCOMPRESSIBLE FLOW
DESCRIPTION: A three-dimensional Navier-Stokes code with pseudo-compressibility, an implicit formulation of finite difference, and a {kappa}-{epsilon} two-equation turbulence model has been developed for the Francis hydraulic runner. The viscous flow in the rotating field can be simulated well in the design flow operating condition as well as in the off-design conditions in which a strong vortex occurs due to the separation near the leading edge. Because the code employs an implicit algorithm and a wall function near the wall, it does not require a large CPU time. It can therefore be used on a small computer such as the desk-top workstation, and is available for use as a design tool. The same kind of algorithm that is used for compressible flows has been found to be appropriate for the simulation of complex incompressible flows in the field of turbomachinery.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Fluids Engineering; Journal Volume: 118; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Jun 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: JFEGA4; ISSN 0098-2202; TRN: IM9634%%28

TITLE: Design and dynamic response characteristics of 400 MW adjustable speed pumped storage unit for Ohkawachi Power Station
AUTHORS: Kuwabara, Takao; Shibuya, Akira; Furuta, Hideo; Kita, Eizou; Mitsuhashi, Keiichi
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; PERFORMANCE; JAPAN; RESPONSE FUNCTIONS; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; PUMPS; OPERATION; SPEED REGULATORS
DESCRIPTION: A 400 MW world`s largest adjustable speed pumped storage unit for Ohkawachi Power Station, the Kansai Electric Power Co., Inc., Japan, was commissioned on Dec. 3, 1993. It can change power in steps of at least 32MW in the generate mode and at least 80MW in the pump mode, within 0.2 s. This paper describes principal design considerations for the control systems of the machine and presents actual performance of the machine with reference to some typical oscillograph charts.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 11; Journal Issue: 2; Conference: 1995 IEEE Power Engineering Society summer meeting, Portland, OR (United States), 23-27 Jul 1995; Other Information: PBD: Jun 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITCNE4; ISSN 0885-8969; TRN: IM9636%%498

TITLE: Development of controlled deposition repair welding procedures at Ontario Hydro
AUTHORS: Lau, T W; Lau, M L; Poon, G C
SUBJECT: 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; 21 NUCLEAR POWER REACTORS AND ASSOCIATED PLANTS; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; LOW ALLOY STEELS; WELDING; CANADA; CANDU TYPE REACTORS; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; FOSSIL-FUEL POWER PLANTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; REPAIR; STEEL-CR2MO; STEEL-CRMO; EQUIPMENT
DESCRIPTION: Ontario Hydro, one of the largest utilities in North America, has an installed generating capacity in excess of 28,000 MW. The generating facilities include a mix of nuclear, fossil-fired, and hydroelectric units. Not unlike other utilities, advanced maintenance welding technology is crucial to maintain the equipment in the most reliable, safe, and economic manner. Since the late 1970s, one focus at Ontario Hydro has been the ability to weld repair heavy section components without postweld heat treatment (PWHT). Temper-bead procedures developed by Ontario Hydro have been used successfully for over a decade to repair carbon steel components. Recently, considerable efforts have been spent to expand the scope of the temper-bead techniques and other self-tempering welding techniques for low-alloy steel, P4 (1.25Cr-0.5Mo) and P5A (2.25Cr-1Mo) materials. To perform successful repairs in these components, it is essential to understand the welding metallurgy of these materials and welding process variables. This paper summarizes the work by Ontario Hydro in non-PWHT weld repair technology with special emphasis on recent developments for Cr-Mo materials.
RELATION: Journal Name: Bulletin - Welding Research Council; Journal Issue: 412; Other Information: PBD: Jun 1996

TITLE: Tailoring a condition-monitoring system to meet specific needs
AUTHORS: Siola, R S; Fritsch, T J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; MONITORING; ON-LINE SYSTEMS
DESCRIPTION: The New York Power Authority and its research partners are completing implementation of an expert on-line condition-monitoring system at the 1,040-MW Blenheim-Gilboa Pumped Storage Station. The system already has helped utility managers diagnose machine imbalances before they caused damage, and is expected to save tens of thousands of dollars each year reduced maintenance expenses, improved operations and avoided losses of revenue.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 35; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Jun 1996

TITLE: Choosing low-voltage switchgear for hydro plants
AUTHORS: Clemen, D M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CIRCUIT BREAKERS; DESIGN; OPERATION; EQUIPMENT PROTECTION DEVICES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: Low-voltage switchgear performs a vital function in distributing power to auxiliary electrical loads within hydropower plants. With careful evaluation, plant owners and engineers can select equipment that provides needed protection and has useful secondary features. This article discusses the desirable features of low-voltage switchgear, including tripping functions, breaker ratings, protective functions, and overall quality.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 35; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Jun 1996

TITLE: Finding turn-to-turn shorts in rotating fields
AUTHORS: Timperley, J E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ROTORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRICAL FAULTS
DESCRIPTION: This article describes methods for finding turn-to-turn shorts in rotors of electrical generators. Locating such shorts can be accomplished by comparing the DC resistance or AC impedance of field coils. The experiences of two utilities with the latter method are discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 35; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Jun 1996

TITLE: Passing fish safely: A closer look at turbine vs. spillway survival
AUTHORS: Heisey, P G; Mathur, P; Euston, E T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; MORTALITY; MONITORING; FISHES
DESCRIPTION: It is often assumed that more fish survive when diverted past hydropower projects via spillways than when passed through turbines. However, results of recent studies show that assumption may be faulty. Fish survival rates at some sites are essentially the same, regardless of the mode of passage. This article discusses problems associated with measuring the survival of fishes and assessing fish mortality at hydro projects. The discussion shows that fish mortality is not substantially improved when diverted via spillways. A method for improving survivability in spillways is noted.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 35; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Jun 1996

TITLE: Statistics of free surface flow through stochastic earth dam
AUTHORS: Fenton, G A; Griffiths, D V
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; HYDRAULIC CONDUCTIVITY; FLUID FLOW; CALCULATION METHODS; EMBANKMENTS; SEALING MATERIALS; GROUND WATER; FLOW MODELS; SITE CHARACTERIZATION
DESCRIPTION: Even though soil is a highly variable material, the analysis of flow through earth dams typically proceeds deterministically and results can sometimes be quite misleading. In fact it is well known that soil permeability varies randomly from point to point in space and an improved earth dam model should incorporate this variability. In this paper the soil permeability in an earth dam of variable geometry is viewed as a weakly stationary spatially random field following a lognormal distribution with prescribed mean, variance, and spatial correlation structure. The mean and variance of the total flow rate through the dam and free surface drawdown are estimated using Monte Carlo simulations. A simplified empirical approach to the prediction of the mean and variance of the flow rate is presented to allow these quantities to be approximated easily and without resorting to simulation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Geotechnical Engineering; Journal Volume: 122; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Jun 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: JGENDZ; ISSN 0733-9410; TRN: IM9646%%338

TITLE: Simulated growth and production of endangered Snake River Sockeye Salmon: Assessing management strategies for the nursery lakes
AUTHORS: Luecke, C; Wurtsbaugh, W A; Budy, P; Gross, H P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SALMON; RESOURCE MANAGEMENT; POPULATION DYNAMICS; COLUMBIA RIVER BASIN; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; FIELD TESTS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION
DESCRIPTION: This document examines the potential of employing a series of lake management strategies to enhance production of endangered Snake River sockeye salmon (Oncorhynchus nerka) in its historical nursery lakes in central Idaho. A combination of limnological sampling, experimentation, and simulation modeling was used to assess effects of lake fertilization and kokanee reduction on growth and survival of juvenile sockeye salmon. Juvenile sockeye salmon from a broodstock of this endangered species are being introduced into the lakes from 1995 to 1998. Results of our analyses indicated that several lakes were suitable for receiving broodstock progeny. Field experimentation and simulation modeling indicated that lake fertilization, coupled with a program of kokanee reduction, provided the management option most likely to enhance the survival of stocked juvenile sockeye salmon. Simulation models that encompass physiological requirements, ecological interactions, and life-history consequences could be used as templates to help develop recovery plans for other endangered fishes. 4 figs., 2 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Fisheries; Journal Volume: 21; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Jun 1996

TITLE: Hydro generator rewinds: Planning for success
AUTHORS: Naeff, H F
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; MAINTENANCE; STATORS; ELECTRIC COILS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: After decades of reliable service, many hydroelectric generators are beginning to show their age. For these generators, unexpected failures, and associated problems stemming from hurried repair and rewinding, can be averted by effective and informed planning. This article reviews a number of tasks, both technical and commercial, associated with a generator rewind project.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: May 1996

TITLE: Revisiting a runner cavitation repair job
AUTHORS: Witman, J K
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; TURBINE BLADES; CAVITATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MAINTENANCE; PROTECTIVE COATINGS
DESCRIPTION: This article reviews the efforts to repair turbine runner cavitation damage. The particular runner was originally repaired in 1990 with the application of a layer of beaded epoxy to areas of severe cavitation on the suction side of the blades on the upper runner. A year later, the runner was inspected, with no damage to the epoxy. In June of 1994, the runner was again inspected, and this and the most recent inspection shows that the epoxy coating is holding up well. The last inspection did show the beginnings on some erosion of the repair material. Based on this long-term series of inspections, maintenance recommendations are set forth.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: May 1996

TITLE: Hungry Horse Dam`s successful selective withdrawal system
AUTHORS: Christenson, D J; Sund, R L; Marotz, B L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INTAKE STRUCTURES; MODIFICATIONS; TROUT; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; MONTANA; TEMPERATURE CONTROL
DESCRIPTION: Remodeled intake structures operating with computer precision at the Bureau of Reclamation`s Hungry Horse Dam hydropower plant in Montana now maintain downstream river water at its natural temperature levels. The intake structure uses a three-stage telescoping gate that allows warmer surface water to overflow and mix with the 38 degree bottom water. Test results from the first months of operation show success in warming the downstream water to its natural temperature, and studies are underway to measure the effect on targeted trout.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: May 1996

TITLE: Get the lead out! removing lead-based paint on hydro plant structures
AUTHORS: Johnson, M L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MAINTENANCE; SURFACE COATING; REMOVAL
DESCRIPTION: This article describes a hydroblasting technology used to remove lead-based surface coatings from the steel associated with the flood gates at the Wirtz Dam. Using this technology and an advanced moisture-cured urethane coating, the Lower Colorado River Authority was able to save more than $250,000 in materials, labor, and waste disposal costs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: May 1996

TITLE: Developing a cost-effective penstock safety program
AUTHORS: Stutsman, R D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PENSTOCKS; SAFETY
DESCRIPTION: In 1991 at the Control Gorge Hydro Power Plant in California, a massive penstock rupture occurred. Water at 580 feet of head poured out. The plant was down for five months, and the ensuing litigation lasted for several years. Consequently, establishing safety procedures for penstocks has taken on more importance. This article describes how to implement a penstock safety program that is simple, flexible, systematic, and cost-effective.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: May 1996

TITLE: Solving a vibration problem in a stator
AUTHORS: McLaughlin, B; Seyler, J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; STATORS; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; MITIGATION; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: As hydro generators age, units with split cores may become susceptible to vibration resulting from degredation of the split packing. Deterioration of the split packing can cause certain core geometries to resonate. In this article, such an event is reviewed, and it suggests that hydro plant owners should consider repacking stator core splits during stator rewinds.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: May 1996

TITLE: Hydro-thermal scheduling by tabu search and decomposition method
AUTHORS: Bai, X; Shahidehpour, S M
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; REAL TIME SYSTEMS
DESCRIPTION: In this paper, an enhanced algorithm for hydro-thermal power scheduling is presented. By applying the tabu search, a decomposition method and taking into account the nonlinearity of time varying starting costs, an effective algorithm is proposed to increase the computing accuracy of the dynamic scheduling process. The proposed approach may start from any traditional scheduling method proposed earlier, and improve the sub-optimal solution by a neighborhood search method. In this regard, additional constraints can be added to the problem formulation which provides a fast scheduling or rescheduling solution to large scale hydro-thermal systems. The results show that the proposed algorithm is efficient and reliable.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems; Journal Volume: 11; Journal Issue: 2; Conference: 1995 IEEE Power Engineering Society summer meeting, Portland, OR (United States), 23-27 Jul 1995; Other Information: PBD: May 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITPSEG; ISSN 0885-8950; TRN: IM9633%%209

TITLE: Genetic aided scheduling of hydraulically coupled plants in hydro-thermal coordination
AUTHORS: Chen, P H; Chang, H C
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; POWER SYSTEMS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; CHINA
DESCRIPTION: Scheduling of hydraulically coupled plants (HCPs) has been reckoned as one of the most difficult parts of the problem of hydro-thermal coordination. This paper presents an efficient approach to the 24-hour ahead generation scheduling of HCPs based on the genetic algorithm (GA). In this paper, the difficult water balance constraints caused by hydraulic coupling are embedded and satisfied throughout the proposed encoding and decoding algorithm. The optimal schedules of both HCPs and thermal units are concurrently obtained within the evolutionary process of artificial chromosomes. Significantly, neither reservoir successive approximation nor hydro-thermal iteration is needed. The proposed approach is applied to an actual utility system of three HCPs and 22 thermal units with great success. Results show that the new approach obtains a more highly optimal solution than the conventional dynamic programming with successive approximation (DPSA) method.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems; Journal Volume: 11; Journal Issue: 2; Conference: 1995 IEEE Power Engineering Society summer meeting, Portland, OR (United States), 23-27 Jul 1995; Other Information: PBD: May 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITPSEG; ISSN 0885-8950; TRN: IM9633%%210

TITLE: Non-uniform composite representation of hydroelectric systems for long-term hydrothermal scheduling
AUTHORS: da Cruz, G Jr; Soares, S
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; BRAZIL; POWER SYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; WATER RESERVOIRS
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents a nonuniform composite representation of hydroelectric systems for use in long-term hydrothermal scheduling. This representation was developed from reservoir operational rules based on optimal reservoir trajectories obtained with a deterministic hydrothermal scheduling algorithm. A test system consisting of 7 large hydroelectric plants of the Southeast Brazilian Power System with 12572 MW of installed power capacity was selected for a case study. Operational cost comparisons with the classical uniform composite representation reveal significant savings.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems; Journal Volume: 11; Journal Issue: 2; Conference: IEEE power industry computer applications conference, Salt Lake City, UT (United States), 7-12 May 1995; Other Information: PBD: May 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITPSEG; ISSN 0885-8950; TRN: IM9633%%169

TITLE: Hydropower generation management under uncertainty via scenario analysis and parallel computation
AUTHORS: Escudero, L F; Garcia, C; Fuente, J.L. de la; Prieto, F J
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; POWER SYSTEMS; SPAIN; THERMAL POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: The authors present a modeling framework for the robust solution of hydroelectric power management problems with uncertainty in the values of the water inflows and outflows. A deterministic treatment of the problem provides unsatisfactory results, except for very short time horizons. The authors describe a model based on scenario analysis that allows a satisfactory treatment of uncertainty in the model data for medium and long-term planning problems. Their approach results in a huge model with a network submodel per scenario plus coupling constraints. The size of the problem and the structure of the constraints are adequate for the use of decomposition techniques and parallel computation tools. The authors present computational results for both sequential and parallel implementation versions of the codes, running on a cluster of workstations. The codes have been tested on data obtained from the reservoir network of Iberdrola, a power utility owning 50% of the total installed hydroelectric capacity of Spain, and generating 40% of the total energy demand.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems; Journal Volume: 11; Journal Issue: 2; Conference: IEEE power industry computer applications conference, Salt Lake City, UT (United States), 7-12 May 1995; Other Information: PBD: May 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITPSEG; ISSN 0885-8950; TRN: IM9633%%166

TITLE: Development risks
AUTHORS: Riedy, M; Desai, S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; INDIA; INTERNATIONAL REGULATIONS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; INVESTMENT; COMMERCIAL SECTOR
DESCRIPTION: Risks associated with hydropower production development in India are discussed in this article. A project prospectus for the development of India`s estimated 84,044 MW(e) hydropower potential is given which accounts for environmental and regulatory concerns. Regulations issued by the Government of Industry regarding private investment in hydropower are outlined, and additional policies which are expected to be instituted are discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; Journal Volume: 26; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1996

TITLE: Hydro automation: Finding the right approach
AUTHORS: Rogers, C S; Webb, J; Grant, J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; SUSQUEHANNA RIVER; CALIFORNIA
DESCRIPTION: Modern automation technology has opened the door to a broad array of opportunities for improving the operations, maintenance, and economics of hydropower and water resource facilities. Using open software architecture, digital processing, and fiber optics communications, today`s systems are capable of doing more things more efficiently at less cost than equipment available just a few years ago. In addition to its capability once installed, the new technology also provides a practical benefit for producers who are planning or implementing an automation project: adaptability. As the experiences of three U. S. hydropower producers show, today`s systems can be adjusted to a variety of applications. This article reviews efforts at three projects: (1) Muddy Run pumped storage, (2) Kerr Dam, and (3) California Water Project.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1996

TITLE: Re-energizing an aged hydro plant
AUTHORS: Steinmetz, W G; Puckett, B R; Torony, J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; RETROFITTING; PLANNING
DESCRIPTION: When the 7.2-MW Berrien Springs hydro project began to experience failures after 90 years of heavy use, the project owners needed a cost-effective approach to restoring the plant`s capability. Their redevelopment plan blends new technology and design innovations to give the facility a productive new life. With state-of-the-art equipment and some innovative engineering, the owners and operators of the Berrien Springs facility are redeveloping their facility. The first half of the redevelopment scheme was completed in late 1995, and the second half is scheduled to be completed by the end of 1996. The new plant includes 12 turbine-generators and the latest in remote control technology.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1996

TITLE: Using ductile iron pipe for penstocks: A new option
AUTHORS: Hurless, R C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PENSTOCKS; RETROFITTING; IRON; DUCTILITY
DESCRIPTION: When choosing the type of material for the penstock at a new project or when repairing or replacing pipe at existing plants, it may pay off to take a look at ductile iron pipe. This type of pipe was used at the Wailuku River hydro project, resulting in a more corrosion resistant, durable, and cost-effective penstock. This article reviews the planning and decision-making that went into this effort, including: (1) material properties, (2) testing, (3) performance under negative pressure conditions, (4) pressure rating, (5) corrosion resistance, (6) seismic effects, (7) installation problems, and (8) economic considerations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1996

TITLE: Using strobe lights, air bubble curtains for cost-effective fish diversion
AUTHORS: McCauley, D J; Navarro, J E; Mountouri, L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; ENTRAINMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FISHES; MITIGATION
DESCRIPTION: Faced with a high, and potentially costly, rate of fish turbine passage, a northern Michigan hydro project owner began investigating the use of behavioral barriers to divert fish away from turbines. Strobe lights, with and without air bubbles, proved to be highly effective, yielding dramatic reductions in the number of fish entrained.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1996

TITLE: Planning a cost-effective gate rehab
AUTHORS: Rudolph, R M; Gundry, J A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SPILLWAYS; CLOSURES; MAINTENANCE; RETROFITTING; PLANNING
DESCRIPTION: Hydropower project owners are devoting increasing attention to the condition and safety of spillway gates and related equipment. With careful inspection and planning, owners can develop a rehabilitation program that improves gate performance and minimizes cost. The July 1995 failure of a spillway gate at Folsom Dam has spurred increased attention on inspection and rehabilitation of gates. This article explains an approach taken by Northern States Power Company in rehabilitating aged gates at its Wisota Dam project. An update on measures being taken in response to the Folsom Dam incident is also included.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1996

TITLE: Innovative system eliminates cooling problems
AUTHORS: Leyland, B W
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; TURBOGENERATORS; COOLING SYSTEMS; SEALS; LEAKS
DESCRIPTION: A system which uses water leaking through runner seals as the cooling water supply for hydroelectric turbine-generator units is briefly discussed. The system configuration is shown and briefly described. Six hydroelectric stations have found the approach to be simple and 100 percent reliable. Compared to a conventional system using pumps and filters, the initial installation cost is 80 percent lower and the maintenance cost is effectively zero.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 4; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1996

TITLE: Lessons learned: Preventing accidents during turbine inspection and repair
AUTHORS: Gordon, J L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; ACCIDENTS; OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY
DESCRIPTION: Two incidents occurring at hydroelectric power plants are briefly described. One incident occurred during a turbine repair, and is described to illustrate that all controls should be blocked and locked when working on a unit. The other incident involved a wicket gate closure during runner blade inspection. A detailed safety check procedure for entering enclosed space is recommended to help prevent accidents.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 4; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1996

TITLE: Small hydro: Prototype governor moves out of the laboratory
AUTHORS: Henderson, D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; ELECTRIC CONTROLLERS; SPEED REGULATORS; POWER RANGE 10-100 KW
DESCRIPTION: A prototype electronic load governor is very briefly described. The governor is designed for electrical generating systems with ratings up to 100 kilowatts at 50 or 60 hertz isolated from grid networks and fed by three-phase, synchronous ac generators. The governor maintains the speed of the set by adjusting an electrical ballast load connected to the generator terminals. A water regulating device is not required. The cost is expected to be about one-tenth that of a speed governor.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 4; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1996

TITLE: Computerized management: A tool for better hydro maintenance
AUTHORS: Farmer, B R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 MATHEMATICS, COMPUTERS, INFORMATION SCIENCE, MANAGEMENT, LAW, MISCELLANEOUS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MAINTENANCE; DATA BASE MANAGEMENT; INFORMATION SYSTEMS; PROGRAM MANAGEMENT
DESCRIPTION: Upgrading of maintenance management systems by the Snowy Mountains Hydroelectric Authority in Australia is outlined in the article. The utility implemented a company-wide computerized system to reduce costs and improve effectiveness. The new system has three primary integrated modules: plant maintenance activity, supply, and finance/accounting. More than 90% of the utility`s hydro plant work is managed through the system. Over 30,000 plant assets have been entered in the Plant Register; most have been associated with master work order that automatically generate preventive maintenance.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 4; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1996

TITLE: Hydroblasting permits safe, cost-effective dam rehabilitation
AUTHORS: Lever, G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; TEXAS; DAMS; PROTECTIVE COATINGS; PAINTS; REMOVAL; LEAD COMPOUNDS; SURFACE TREATMENTS; HYDRAULIC EQUIPMENT; WASTE MANAGEMENT; MAINTENANCE
DESCRIPTION: The cost of using traditional methods to remove lead-based paint from structures subject to strict environmental regulations can be prohibitive, leaving many rehabilitation projects undone. However, alternative methods, including hydroblasting, can reduce debris containment and disposal costs to a tolerable level. This article describes a project which involved the removal of old lead paint and the repainting of a dam situated in a populated recreational area. It details the budgetary, environmental, and public health issues that led to strict specifications and oversight requirements, which saved money and protected the area from lead contamination.
RELATION: Journal Name: Materials Performance; Journal Volume: 35; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: MTPFBI; ISSN 0094-1492; TRN: IM9619%%314

TITLE: Penstock safety: Proactive or reactive
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PENSTOCKS; SAFETY ANALYSIS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; AGE DEPENDENCE; PROGRAM MANAGEMENT; MAINTENANCE; US FERC; REGULATIONS
DESCRIPTION: A significant percentage of the US electrical power generation is from hydroelectric power. This represents hundreds of operating facilities, of which approximately 2/3 are over 50 years old. Historically, the majority of penstock failures have occurred at either new facilities, during its initial years of operation, or at facilities over 50 years old. The purpose of this article is twofold. First it presents economic and practical reasons for an owner to take a proactive role in penstock safety. Not only does it allow them to protect the major investment they have in their hydroelectric facilities, but also protect their employees, the general public, and the environment. Second, this article presents an example of an effective Penstock Safety Program. This example of a program was developed to provide simple, flexible, systematic, and economic methods for development and implementation of a proactive Penstock Safety Program.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Energy Engineering; Journal Volume: 122; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: JLEED9; ISSN 0733-9402; TRN: IM9619%%295

TITLE: Flow behavior around stayvanes and guidevanes of a Francis turbine
AUTHORS: Suzuki, Toshiaki; Nagafuji, Tomotatsu; Komiya, Hiroshi; Shimada, Takako; Kobayashi, Toshio; Taniguchi, Nobuyuki
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; AUGMENTATION; PERFORMANCE; CAPACITY; INCOMPRESSIBLE FLOW
DESCRIPTION: The three-dimensional computation of steady and incompressible internal flows is of interest in numerical simulations of turbomachinery, and such simulations are currently under investigation, from inviscid to viscous flow analyses. First, surface pressure distributions have been measured for the stayvanes and the guidevanes of a Francis turbine. They are presented to verify the numerical results. Second, both inviscid and viscous three-dimensional flow analyses have been made, so as to predict the flow behavior in the same domain. Comparison of the measured pressure distributions to the predicted pressure distributions has been made to study the usefulness of the present simulations. It can be pointed out that a global analysis which includes a runner flow passage, except runner blades, is necessary to predict the three-dimensional flow characteristics and that inviscid flow analysis has the capability of good prediction for flow without separation. Viscous flow analysis gives similar results, though it is necessary to investigate further the improvement of prediction accuracy. Flow characteristics around the stayvanes and the guidevanes are also discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Fluids Engineering; Journal Volume: 118; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Mar 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: JFEGA4; ISSN 0098-2202; TRN: IM9618%%102

TITLE: Evaluation of advanced fuzzy logic PSS on analog network simulator and actual installation on hydro generators
AUTHORS: Hiyama, T; Oniki, S; Nagashima, H
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; POWER SYSTEMS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; POWER CONDITIONING CIRCUITS; FUZZY LOGIC; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents the experimental evaluation of an advanced fuzzy logic PSS on the analog network simulator at the Research Laboratory of Kyushu Electric Power Co., Inc. The proposed power system stabilizer (PSS) is set up by using a personal computer with A/D and D/A conversion interfaces. The personal computer based PSS was set on the analog network simulator to evaluate the effectiveness of the advanced fuzzy logic control scheme, and to provide sufficient data for the actual installation of the proposed PSS on hydro-units in the Kyushu Electric Power System. This paper also describes the actual installation of the proposed PSS on hydro-units in the Kyushu Electric Power System for the long term evaluation of the proposed PSS using its prototypes.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 11; Journal Issue: 1; Conference: 1995 IEEE Power Engineering Society summer meeting, Portland, OR (United States), 23-27 Jul 1995; Other Information: PBD: Mar 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITCNE4; ISSN 0885-8969; TRN: IM9628%%133

TITLE: Analysis of potential impacts to resident fish from Columbia River System Operation alternatives
AUTHORS: Geist, D R; Vail, L W; Epstein, D J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COLUMBIA RIVER; RESOURCE MANAGEMENT; FISHES; POPULATION DYNAMICS; WATER RESERVOIRS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; DAMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: The US Army Corps of Engineers, the US Bureau of Reclamation, and the Bonneville Power Administration initiated the Columbia River System Operation Review (SOR) in 1990. The SOR will assist agencies in comparing the benefits and risks to Columbia River uses and natural resources from alternative strategies for using Columbia River water. Focusing on 14 federal dams within the basin, the agencies are attempting to improve on the efficient and coordinated use of the Columbia River system. An initial screening of all potential strategies of reservoir operation was necessary to reduce the number of possibilities to a limited set for detailed analysis. To that end, the Resident Fish Work Group of the SOR developed spreadsheet models capable of assessing the impacts of different management strategies on resident fish at six storage reservoirs. The models include biological, physical, and hydrological relationships important to resident fish specific to each reservoir. Alternatives that kept the reservoirs near full pool and held stable during the growing season resulted in positive benefits to resident fish at all locations modeled. Conversely, alternatives designed to improve anadromous fish survival with increased instream flow generally had a negative impact on the resident fish in the reservoirs modeled. The models developed for resident fish in the screening analysis phase of the SOR were useful in assessing the relative impact to resident fish from a large number of alternatives. The screening analysis demonstrated that future analytical efforts must consider trade-offs among river uses/resource groups, among reservoirs throughout the basin, and among resident fish species within a reservoir.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environmental Management; Journal Volume: 20; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Mar-Apr 1996

TITLE: An integration of aeromagnetic and electrical resistivity methods in dam site investigation
AUTHORS: Aina, A; Olorunfemi, M O; Ojo, J S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; NIGERIA; DAMS; SITE CHARACTERIZATION; MAGNETIC SURVEYS; DATA ANALYSIS; RESISTIVITY SURVEYS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; AERIAL SURVEYING; GEOLOGY
DESCRIPTION: Aeromagnetic map and electrical resistivity sounding data obtained along eight traverses were examined at two sites across the Katsina-Ala River. The principal goals of this exercise were to define depths to the bedrock, bedrock relief, geologic structures, define the nature of the superficial deposit, and select probable minor and major axes for hydroelectric power dams. The aeromagnetic map shows that the basement rocks trend roughly northeast-southwest, which correlates with the strike of foliation measurements made on rock outcrops along the river channel. A network of cross cutting lineaments, suspected to be faults/fractures that trend approximately northeast/southwest and northwest/southeast, was also delineated from the magnetic map. The depths to the bedrock estimated from resistivity depth sounding data at site 1 generally vary from 1--53.1 m. Depths to the bedrock estimated at site 2 range from 1.9--19.5 m. The superficial deposit varies from clay to sandy clay, to clayey sand (with boulders in places), and to sand and laterite. The bedrock relief is relatively flat and gently undulates along most of the traverses, with an overall dip towards the river channel. Traverses E-F or I-J at site 1 and K-L at site 2 are probable dame axes. These traverses are characterized by relatively thin overburden thicknesses and rock heads dipping toward the river channel, thereby reducing the likelihood of water seepages from the flanks of the proposed dam axes.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophysics; Journal Volume: 61; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Mar-Apr 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: GPYSA7; ISSN 0016-8033; TRN: IM9619%%115

TITLE: Effect of draft tube size on the performance of a cross-flow turbine
AUTHORS: Reddy, H; Seshadri, V; Kothari, D P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; PERFORMANCE; OUTLET STRUCTURES; SIZING; MICRO-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MEDIUM-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CROSSFLOW SYSTEMS; PARAMETRIC ANALYSIS; ENERGY EFFICIENCY
DESCRIPTION: The cross-flow turbine has attracted the attention of several investigators working in the area of microhydroelectric power generation. This type of turbine, although primarily an impulse type, is suitable for operation at low and medium heads. This article describes the effect of using different sizes of draft tubes on the performance of a 5-kW cross-flow turbine. An effort is made to arrive at an optimum size for the particular turbine tested, as the existing draft tube (203 mm) had an adverse effect on the performance at higher heads. The study involved variation of different performance parameters such as output, efficiency, runaway speed, and speed ratio for four different cases, viz., without the draft tube and with three different sizes of draft tubes (203, 250, and 300 mm) in the head range 3--9 m. The investigation shows that a properly sized draft tube enhances the efficiency of a cross-flow turbine over the entire space of its operation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Sources; Journal Volume: 18; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Mar 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: EGYSAO; ISSN 0090-8312; TRN: IM9619%%325

TITLE: Drained sand behavior in axisymmetric tests at high pressures
AUTHORS: Yamamuro, J A; Lade, P V
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SOIL MECHANICS; MEASURING METHODS; SOILS; MATERIALS TESTING; TUNNELS; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; STRESS ANALYSIS; DAMS; UNDERGROUND MINING; BENCH-SCALE EXPERIMENTS; SHEAR PROPERTIES
DESCRIPTION: The results of an experimental study of granular materials at high pressures are presented. Axisymmetric specimens of dense Cambria sand were tested in drained triaxial compression tests between confining pressures of 0.05 and 52 MPa. Drained triaxial extension tests between confining pressures of 0.25 and 52 MPa were also performed. As the confining pressure is increased, it was found that the stress-strain curve, and volumetric and axial strains to failure rapidly increased at a certain stress magnitude. This was shown to be directly related to a rapid increase in particle crushing. Beyond a certain higher value of stress magnitude, the stress-strain curves steepen, and the volumetric and axial strains to failure decrease. This was also shown to be directly related to the cessation of particle crushing and is typified by a zero rate of volume change at failure. The Mohr-Coulomb secant friction angle was found to be related to the rate of volume change at failure, whether the soil was dilatant or highly contractive and subject to large amounts of particle crushing.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Geotechnical Engineering; Journal Volume: 122; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: JGENDZ; ISSN 0733-9410; TRN: IM9616%%183

TITLE: One-dimensional compression of sands at high pressures
AUTHORS: Yamamuro, J A; Bopp, P A; Lade, P V
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SOIL MECHANICS; MEASURING METHODS; SOILS; MATERIALS TESTING; DAMS; STRESS ANALYSIS; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; TUNNELS; UNDERGROUND MINING
DESCRIPTION: A one-dimensional testing apparatus was developed to test soils to axial stresses up to 850 MPa. The apparatus was instrumented with strain gauges such that lateral soil stresses, and therefore K{sub 0}, could be inferred from measured circumferential strains. Three different initial densities of quartz, Cambria, and gypsum sands were tested and it was found that the effect of initial density was eliminated at high stress magnitudes. This stress magnitude was higher for mineralogically harder grains than for softer grains. The inferred values of K{sub 0} for the mineralogically harder Cambria sand was found to be constant at high pressures, but slightly below that indicates by Jaky`s equation. However, the softer gypsum sand indicated increasing values of K{sub 0} as the stress magnitude increased. This apparently was caused by inelastic, viscous flow during shearing.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Geotechnical Engineering; Journal Volume: 122; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: JGENDZ; ISSN 0733-9410; TRN: IM9616%%185

TITLE: Short-term hydro generation and interchange contract scheduling for Swiss Rail
AUTHORS: Christoforidis, M; Awobamise, B; Tong, S; Aganagic, M; Frowd, R J; Rahimi, F A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; 33 ADVANCED PROPULSION SYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; ENERGY MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC RAILWAYS; POWER DEMAND; POWER SYSTEMS
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes the Short-Term Resource Scheduling (STRS) function that has been developed by Siemens-Empros as part of the new SBB/Direktion Kraftwerk (Swiss Rail) Energy Management System. Optimal scheduling of the single-phase hydro plants, single-phase and three-phase energy accounts, and purchase and sale of three phase energy subject to a multitude of physical and contractual constraints (including spinning and regulating reserve requirements), is the main objective of the STRS function. The operations planning horizon of STRS is one day to one week using an hourly time increment.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems; Journal Volume: 11; Journal Issue: 1; Conference: IEEE power industry computer applications conference, Salt Lake City, UT (United States), 7-12 May 1995; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITPSEG; ISSN 0885-8950; TRN: IM9627%%77

TITLE: Mixed-integer programming applied to short-term planning of a hydro-thermal system
AUTHORS: Nilsson, O; Sjelvgren, D
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; PLANNING; OPERATION; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: In this paper a mixed-integer hydro electric power model for short-term planing is presented. The advantage of this model is that the schedules only include points with good efficiency. The planning problem is decomposed into a subproblem for each hydro plant. In order to get smooth schedules the model includes start-up costs for hydro aggregates. The main mathematical methods used in this work are Lagrange relaxation, dynamic programming and network programming. The model is illustrated by a numerical example from a part of the Swedish power system.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems; Journal Volume: 11; Journal Issue: 1; Conference: IEEE power industry computer applications conference, Salt Lake City, UT (United States), 7-12 May 1995; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITPSEG; ISSN 0885-8950; TRN: IM9627%%78

TITLE: Long-term/mid-term resource optimization of a hydro-dominant power system using interior point method
AUTHORS: Christoforidis, M; Aganagic, M; Awobamise, B; Tong, S; Rahimi, A F
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 33 ADVANCED PROPULSION SYSTEMS; 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RESOURCE MANAGEMENT; ENERGY MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC RAILWAYS; POWER DEMAND; POWER SYSTEMS
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes the modeling approach and the solution techniques that were employed in developing the Long-term/Mid-term Resource Scheduling (LMRS) function for the power system of Schweizerische Bundesbahnen (Swiss Railways). LMRS together with the Annual Load Forecast and Annual Maintenance Scheduling functions constitute the Long-term/Mid-term Operational Planning subsystem of Swiss Railways` new Energy Management System.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems; Journal Volume: 11; Journal Issue: 1; Conference: IEEE power industry computer applications conference, Salt Lake City, UT (United States), 7-12 May 1995; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITPSEG; ISSN 0885-8950; TRN: IM9627%%79

TITLE: Using an infuser weir to aerate water releases from hydro plants
AUTHORS: Hauser, G E; Brock, G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DISSOLVED GASES; INFUSION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FLUID FLOW; AERATION; WATER; OXYGEN
DESCRIPTION: The Tennessee Valley Authority is exploring promising new technologies for protecting aquatic resources downstream of hydro plants. One such technology, the infuser weir, can provide effective solutions to two common environmental concerns at hydropower projects: dissolved oxygen depletion and low minimum flows. The concept and design of the infuser weir are discussed in this article, and TVA`s experience with the weir is reviewed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1996

TITLE: Making small hydro work well on a water supply system
AUTHORS: Cowdrey, J M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; WATER UTILITIES
DESCRIPTION: Municipal managers in Boulder, Colorado, installed hydroelectric generating facilities to take advantage of high heads and excess pressures on the city`s water supply system. In ten years of operation, the city has learned some important lessons about how such systems should be designed and operated. This article lists and discusses many of the lessons learned in this ten year period.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1996

TITLE: Eliminating power swings at maximum load
AUTHORS: March, P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; MEDIUM-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PENSTOCKS; POWER GENERATION; RESONANCE; CONTROL; VARIATIONS
DESCRIPTION: Power swings, manifested by slow, fairly regular oscillations in a hydro plant`s indicating meters, are a common problem with Francis and propeller type generating units. This article explores the experiences of one utility in addressing this problem.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1996

TITLE: The changing electricity supply market: New challenges, opportunities for hydro
AUTHORS: Sikora, C S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; US FERC; REGULATIONS; ELECTRIC POWER INDUSTRY; DEREGULATION; POWER DISTRIBUTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER
DESCRIPTION: Understanding the way electricity markets are evolving in response to regulatory and economic changes is crucial for hydro professionals as they work to turn challenges facing hydroelectric power into opportunities. The hydro industry must prepare for the competitive business environment that lies ahead. In particular, the industry must become aware of changes taking place in the markets for, and regulation of, its product. This article provides an overview of FERC`s mega-NOPR, examples of electricity regulation restructuring efforts by states, and a perspective on the implications for hydro.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1996

TITLE: Turning gear helps with turbine-generator maintenance
AUTHORS: Brittain, T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; ROTATION; MAINTENANCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: Hydroelectric turbine-generating units generally are rotated by hand during maintenance activities. Since that wastes time and present both safety and power problems in large facilities, one utility has designed a turning gear. This article describes the design and opeation of such a gear.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1996

TITLE: On-line monitoring: Improving hydro maintenance and operations
AUTHORS: Byers, W
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EXPERT SYSTEMS; ON-LINE MEASUREMENT SYSTEMS; MONITORING
DESCRIPTION: Expert monitoring systems provide plant owners and operators with a means of judging the condition of hydropower equipment before problems arise. The systems also produce information that can be used to maximize efficiency and output and minimize costs. This article is a discussion of such on-line systems. Technical advances providing the basis for these systems and general applications of these systems are reviewed. Specific applications at the Hausling pumped storage project and the Itaipu hydroelectric project are discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 4; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1996

TITLE: Seismic rehabilitation of earth dams
AUTHORS: Marcuson, III, W F; Hadala, P F; Ledbetter, R H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; RETROFITTING; SAFETY ENGINEERING; SAFETY ANALYSIS; RISK ASSESSMENT; SITE CHARACTERIZATION
DESCRIPTION: The purpose of this paper is to present methods available for engineered remediation of seismically deficient earth dams (not including tailings dams), to review their strengths and weaknesses, to present case histories of the application of these methods, and to draw conclusions about the state of practice. A survey of completed and active rehabilitation projects was made. This survey identified 30 dams with engineering fixes and 22 with operational fixes. Data was obtained and is presented in tabular form for 36 dams.
