Of these dams, 13 had seismically deficient foundations, 15 had deficient embankments, and 8 had deficiencies in both embankment and foundations. Synopses of case histories are presented for John Hart Dam, Sardis Dam, Mormon Island Auxiliary Dam, and Pleasant Valley Dam.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Geotechnical Engineering; Journal Volume: 122; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jan 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: JGENDZ; ISSN 0733-9410; TRN: IM9616%%187

TITLE: Constitutive relations for partially saturated soils containing gas inclusions
AUTHORS: Pietruszczak, S; Pande, G N
SUBJECT: 42 ENGINEERING NOT INCLUDED IN OTHER CATEGORIES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SOILS; MATERIALS TESTING; SOIL MECHANICS; OFFSHORE PLATFORMS; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; DAMS; MEASURING METHODS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES
DESCRIPTION: This paper is concerned with a mathematical description of the undrained response of partially saturated soils having a continuous liquid phase (water) and a gas in the form of discrete bubbles. Two types of soil structures are considered. First is the case in which the gas inclusions, of size much smaller than the average particle size, are entrapped in the water phase. Second is the case in which the comparatively larger gas bubbles are embedded in the saturated soil skeleton. The fluid phases are assumed to be separated by boundaries across which discontinuities in pressure exist due to surface tension. The soil is treated as a three-phase composite medium and the mechanical properties are described in terms of average stress/strain measures in all constituents. The mathematical formulation incorporates the average pore/bubble size as an independent material parameter governing the mechanical response.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Geotechnical Engineering; Journal Volume: 122; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jan 1996
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: JGENDZ; ISSN 0733-9410; TRN: IM9616%%188

TITLE: Fuzzy learning decomposition for the scheduling of hydroelectric power systems
AUTHORS: Saad, M; Bigras, P; Turgeon, A; Duquette, R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; DYNAMIC PROGRAMMING; QUEBEC; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NEURAL NETWORKS
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents a nonlinear multivariable fitting model to decompose the optimal policies obtained by dynamic programming of a unique aggregated reservoir. The nonlinear functions are generated using radial basis functions (RBF) neural networks. In this method the potential energy of all the reservoirs in the hydropower system is added to form one equivalent reservoir. The operating policy of the equivalent reservoir is determined by stochastic dynamic programming, and finally the operating rules of each reservoir are determined using RBF neural networks. To improve the multivariable representation of the data, a series of piecewise RBF neural networks is determined using clustering analysis. A fuzzy clustering approach is used to determine the RBF`s parameters. This approach has the advantages of being fast and simple to implement with well-established convergence properties. It also has a good representation of the covariance matrix, since all the data belong to all the classes at the same time with different membership grades. A comparison with the back propagation learning and principal components techniques is also reported for Quebec`s La Grande River installations. As a result, the proposed approach gives satisfactory operating rules compared with principal component analysis, and the CPU time is reduced by a factor of 15 to 20 compared with the back propagation technique.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resources Research; Journal Volume: 32; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jan 1996

TITLE: Pumped storage: Surge in the southeast
AUTHORS: Hunt, J M; Hunt, R T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; USA; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT
DESCRIPTION: In the past decade, there has been a surge of interest by independent power producers (IPPs) in developing pumped storage hydropower projects. However, of the 100 applicants for preliminary permits for pumped storage projects, only nine submitted license applications for development and none have been built. Two large pumped storage projects proposed by IPPs, Summit in Ohio and Mount Hope in New Jersey, received their Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) licenses in record time.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; Journal Volume: 26; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jan-Feb 1996

TITLE: Response of spawning lake sturgeons to change in hydroelectric facility operation
AUTHORS: Auer, N A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; RIVERS; FLOW RATE; VARIATIONS; FISHES; REPRODUCTION
DESCRIPTION: Spawning of lake sturgeon Acipenser fulvescens was documented from 1987 to 1992 below the Prickett hydroelectric facility on the Sturgeon River, a tributary to Portage Lake, Michigan. Lake sturgeons were captured at the spawning site with dip nets during periods of reduced flow. A change in the spawning characteristics of the population was noted that corresponded to a changed in the operation of the hydroelectric facility. In 1987 and 1988 the facility operated in a peaking mode, which resulted in large daily fluctuations in river flows. The years 1989 and 1990 were years of transition, and in 1991 and 1992 the facility released near run-of-the-river (ROR) flows. Under near-ROR flows, which were more natural, adult lake sturgeons spent 4-6 weeks less at the spawning sites, 74% more fish were observed, weights were greater due to a 68% increase in number of females, and fish had increased reproductive readiness. The change in flow regime was the result of a Federal Energy Regulatory Commission relicensing action. The positive response observed in lake sturgeon spawning activity that resulted from the change of facility operation to near-ROR flows should be beneficial to the survival and perpetuation of this population. Similar results may be experienced in other lake sturgeon waters affected by manipulated flow regimes. 28 refs., 5 figs., 6 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society; Journal Volume: 125; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jan 1996
JOURNAL_NAME: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society

TITLE: Hydro pacts revamp operations and market strategies
AUTHORS: Pospisil, R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; MARKETING; US FERC; COST; RESOURCE CONSERVATION; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS
DESCRIPTION: As competition accelerates in the electricity sector, electric power companies are looking to reap competitive benefits from their existing hydroelectric powerplants - which provide low-cost power and reduce outlays for air-pollution control equipment and strategies. However, most hydro plants owned by investor-owned utilities are scheduled for relicensing over the next two decades by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) - a process that can take five to seven years, requires extensive studies, and often involves contentious litigation - an ordeal that can dampen a hydro project`s market advantage. But, with competitive forces nipping at their heels, hydro utilities are working hard to avoid the delay and expense of the relicensing process. And in some cases, to expedite the renewal process, utilities are reaching settlements with environmental advocates, recreational groups, and public agencies that change the way they operate powerplants. This paper discusses these issues and some specific cases.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electrical World; Journal Volume: 210; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jan 1996

TITLE: Hydro in a competitive industry: What does the future hold?
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; COMPETITION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; FORECASTING; COST ESTIMATION; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; ENERGY EFFICIENCY
DESCRIPTION: The electricity utility industry in North America is undergoing dramatic changes. All utilities are finding that they must reevaluate the ways they have traditionally operated. In order to gain perspective on how industry leaders are delight with today`s challenges, Hydro Review brings you the views of the top executives of ten leading North American utilities having significant stakes in the hydro business. They address the questions about the most traditional of generating resources - hydro - and where it can continue to be cost-effective, efficient, and environmentally responsible in the competitive marketplace of today.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 16; Journal Issue: 8; Other Information: PBD: Jan 1996

TITLE: North American hydro: Successfully blending old methods with new strategies
AUTHORS: Byers, W
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; SECTORAL ANALYSIS; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; RENEWABLE RESOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: Hydropower producers and suppliers are responding to the challenges of a changing power market with adaptability and creativity. Project development continues, as hydro companies turn to new partnerships and new business approaches that maximize the potential of U.S. and Canadian hydro resources. This article discusses highlights of the 1995 hydro business year and some of the trends important in 1996.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 16; Journal Issue: 8; Other Information: PBD: Jan 1996

TITLE: Improved fishway designed for project with high head variation
AUTHORS: Wu, Sue-Jen; Hsieh, Gwo-Jeng
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; DESIGN; ASIA
DESCRIPTION: Increasingly, fish passage facilities are being used for mitigating the effect of a dam on a river. In Asia, traditional approaches for fish protection can be relatively expensive. This is especially true at projects with high variations in the headwater, as it generally is difficult to design a fishway for such projects that are both economic and do not require manual operation. Two categories of fishways usually are used at projects with varying elevations of headwater. One is the vertical slot-type fishway, which features a series of baffles with slots and orificies. When headwater variation is extremely high, only the second category, the mechanical fishway, is applicable.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 3; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Aut 1995

TITLE: Retooling a national power system with hydro technology
AUTHORS: Radulov, L; Kanev, K D; Hirota, Tatsuya
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BULGARIA; ELECTRIC POWER; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; DESIGN
DESCRIPTION: Modernizing the Bulgarian economy requires an adequate and responsive supply of electricity. Having an aging thermal-based generating system, the country`s energy policy-makers committed to development of a state-of-the-art pumped-storage plant. The Chaira project is helping Bulgaria`s utility meet the requirements of a modern power grid.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 3; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Sum 1995

TITLE: Meeting hydropower challenges with turbine technology
AUTHORS: Byers, W
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; DESIGN
DESCRIPTION: Changing economics are pressing hydroelectric producers to seek ways of generating more power at less cost from available water resources. Computer technology, advanced manufacturing approaches, and new materials have become tools by which power producers and equipment manufacturers are meeting the challenge. A critical component of hydropower, the turbine, has been affected by state-of-the-art technology in efficiency, flexibility and durability. This article surveys manufacturers and uses on examples.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 3; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Sum 1995

TITLE: Making effective, economical dam safety decisions
AUTHORS: Kuperman, S C; Re, G; Canholi, A P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; SAFETY ANALYSIS; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; BRAZIL; RESOURCE MANAGEMENT
DESCRIPTION: An effective program of dam safety requires sound technical information, careful evaluation, and well-planned expenditures of manpower and money. One Brazilian water resource company developed a systematic program for comparing its dams and targeting safety resources where they are most needed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 3; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Aut 1995

TITLE: Optimizing unit allocation: The Norwegian experience
AUTHORS: Browne, M M; Vinnogg, L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EFFICIENCY; LOAD MANAGEMENT; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; NORWAY
DESCRIPTION: Advancing computer technology holds potential for optimizing generation from hydropower plants. With reliable data, computer-based models can accurately simulate plant operations and provide operators with a basis for more efficiently distributing load among individual generating units. While the per-unit production increases sometimes are small, the accumulated economic benefits often are substantial.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 3; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Aut 1995

TITLE: Accommodating environmental, social issues in project planning
AUTHORS: Fau, J P; Labelle, L; Lara, H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; COLOMBIA
DESCRIPTION: The Calima III hydro project in Colombia presented its owners with a delicate mixture of technical, economic, environmental, and social challenges. To balance the many factors, and avoid problems that had plagued a predecessor project, planners implemented a comprehensive approach for identifying and resolving issues.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 3; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Spr 1995

TITLE: Cooperating in small hydro worldwide
AUTHORS: Vansant, C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION; RURAL AREAS; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER
DESCRIPTION: Through the development of small hydro projects, electrification can be extended to many people throughout the world who now live without electricity. A new international small hydro network will coordinate among organizations and individuals interested in extending electricity to those now deprived of its benefits. The article includes a discussion of China`s role and the role of the UN.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 3; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Spr 1995

TITLE: Hydro control technology: Making plants more efficient, effective
AUTHORS: Byers, W
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; AUTOMATION; EFFICIENCY
DESCRIPTION: Hydropower project owners and equipment suppliers are using digital computer technology and fiber-optic networks to enhance plant control and operations. The new systems provide a flexible, adaptable, and capable tool for maximizing productivity.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 3; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Aut 1995

TITLE: Operating, protecting pumps installed as turbines
AUTHORS: Heninger, L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PUMPS; DESIGN; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; WATER SUPPLY
DESCRIPTION: Pumps can be used as turbines to generate power at small hydro sites. In order to make use of the potential, the project owner must carefully evaluate the site design and ensure appropriate tests and protective equipment are implemented.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 3; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Aut 1995

TITLE: Reviewing O&M approaches in New Zealand and Australia
AUTHORS: Barnes, M J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MAINTENANCE; MANAGEMENT; AUTOMATION
DESCRIPTION: Hydropower producers throughout the world are being challenged to make their existing plants operate more reliably and efficiently ...and more often... than ever before. In the countries of New Zealand and Australia, hydro operators are answering that challenge through improved operations and maintenance including condition-based monitoring, predictive plant maintenance, computerized remote operations, maintenance management systems. Topics covered include the following: strategy for condition monitoring, completing an automation remote control project, implementing maintenance management systems.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 3; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Spr 1995

TITLE: Managing the risks of a more private hydro market
AUTHORS: Hurst, P A.D.
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; LEGAL ASPECTS; HAZARDS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OWNERSHIP
DESCRIPTION: The trend toward increasing private involvement in hydropower ownership and finance is changing the balance of critical issues for successful projects. The completion and long-term viability of a project now can depend as much on issues of risk management and legal security as on engineering and mechanical design. A prudent project owner can minimize the new uncertainties by identifying potential issues early in the planning process and developing sound management strategies.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 3; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Spr 1995

TITLE: Ideas in action: Solving a cavitation mystery
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; AUSTRALIA; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; TURBINE BLADES; EROSION; REPAIR; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER
DESCRIPTION: Cavitation caused significant erosion from 1985 through 1990 on turbine runners at the 970-MW Murray 1 Power Station operated by Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority (SMHEA) in Australia. The problem was perplexing because no obvious cause could be found. Investigation eventually showed the problems stemmed form the runners sagging slightly from the correct height. Corrective measures, which included adjustment of runners and new control settings for the units, appear to have relieved the cavitation. The adjustments also reduced stress on the unit thrust-bearings, eliminating a future maintenance headache.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 3; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Spr 1995

TITLE: Finding hydro`s role in an evolving power system
AUTHORS: Filho, A V
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BRAZIL; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ELECTRIC POWER; HYDROELECTRIC POWER
DESCRIPTION: Like power agencies in much of the world, Brazil`s system planners are balancing a complex group of economic, social, and environmental factors as they guide development of the nation`s vast hydropower resources. Planners at the national utility Electrobras have devised several strategies for meeting today`s challenges.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 3; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Sum 1995

TITLE: Putting pumps to work for generation at small hydro sites
AUTHORS: Heninger, L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPS; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: Pumps can be used as turbines to provide a low-cost and easily adapted equipment alternative for power generation at small hydropower sites. This article, Part 1 of a two-part series, provides guidelines for evaluating use of a pump at a specific site.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 3; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Sum 1995

TITLE: Looking ahead: Trends in hydro business opportunities
AUTHORS: Byers, W
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; POLITICAL ASPECTS; BRAZIL; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; INDIA; TURKEY
DESCRIPTION: Changing government policies and economic forces are presenting new opportunities and challenges for hydropower developers and suppliers. To highlight some of the trends, HRW examines the business picture in three key countries: India, Brazil, and Turkey. Indian utilities have nearly 24,000 megawatts (MW) of installed hydro capacity, almost one-fourth of the country`s generating capability. Hydro plants produced almost 70 million megawatt-hours of electricity in 1993, an increase of nearly 40 percent from ten years before. Growth shows in installed power generation capacity for all generations resources, including hydro, in India from 1950 to 1992. Experts estimate another 40,000 to 100,000 MW of hydro could be developed in India, based on today`s economics and technology. There is a significant interest among Indian energy planners and prospective project developers in turning the country`s hydro potential into reality. Hydropower has played an important role in Brazil`s economy during this century. Electricity provided the primary fuel for a remarkable 600 percent expansion of the Brazilian economy in the 1970`s and 1980`s- and in Brazil, electricity means hydro. Hydro accounted for more than 97 percent of the 250 million megawatt-hours (MWH) of electricity Brazilians consumed in 1994. Brazilian energy planners believe the outlook for future growth in hydro generating reserves is as bright as its past. Economic reforms and a strong commitment by the national government to water resources development have sparked new interest in Turkey as a source of substantial hydropower business opportunities. Among other developments, new tenders are scheduled for elements of the huge Southeastern Anotolia Project (GAP). The Turkish government also has initiated a new private power development program that will include an initial group of six hydro projects.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 3; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: 1995

TITLE: Sharing hydropower information through books and publications
AUTHORS: Fulton, E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; INFORMATION
DESCRIPTION: HRW summarizes several books and publications by hydro professionals that educate, instruct, or assist colleagues throughout the world as they work toward meeting today`s hydro`s challenges and pursuing opportunities.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 3; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: 1995

TITLE: Salmon v. hydropower in the Columbia Basin: The time for action is now
AUTHORS: Young, S P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POLLUTION REGULATIONS; SALMON; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; DAMS; WATER RESERVOIRS; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; COLUMBIA RIVER; ENDANGERED SPECIES; POWER GENERATION; LEGISLATION; DECISION MAKING; LEGAL ASPECTS
DESCRIPTION: Salmon in the Columbia River Basin are fighting for their lives. Hydropower, among other things, is threatening the peace and safety of the once unencumbered spawning waters of the Columbia and Snake Rivers. And while the salmon/hydropower debate has been raging for some time, recent events have turned the heat up more than ever. After attempting various plans to help save the fish from the hazards of industrialization, the government finally listed some of the salmon as endangered in 1991. The listing gave the fish fighting power which they had not had before, but also created a serious conflict. The hydropower which is blamed for depleting the salmon numbers creates much of the energy for the northwestern United States. If the hydropower is altered to save the fish, energy rates will rise dramatically. Debates rage throughout Idaho, Washington, Oregon, and Montana, as well as in Washington D.C., about what should be done. The United States Congress has created the Northwest Power Planning Council (Council) to remedy the situation. The Council`s mandate is to save the fish, while ensuring an adequate and economical power supply for the region. The Council was created in 1980, and at that time crafted a program which has been amended several times. The most recent amendment occurred in 1992 in response to the endangered listing. Environmental groups looked at the 1992 amendments and immediately filed suit, claiming that the amendments were not good for the fish. In Northwest Resource Information Center, Inc., v. Northwest Power Planning Council, the Ninth Circuit held for the environmentalists, claiming that the Council had failed to listen to the environmental voices.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Energy, Natural Resources amp Environmental Law; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: 1995
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of Energy, Natural Resources amp Environmental Law

TITLE: Renewable energy resources of Karelia: Evaluation and prospects for utilization
AUTHORS: Sidorenko, G I; Borisov, G A; Lazareva, Yu G; Mitrukova, I V
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 09 BIOMASS FUELS; 17 WIND ENERGY; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; RUSSIAN FEDERATION; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: This article explores the development of hydroelectric power sources and renewable energy sources in the Republic of Karelia in the Russian Federation. Numerical data is presented to show that the economic potential of the channel discharge of Karelia is 6.6 billion kWh, and the same potential in the rivers banned for energy utilization is 1.7 billion kWh. Similarly, the estimated wind energy resources are 10-60 billion kWh. It was estimated that there are also 2.85-4.45 millions tons of biomass fuel available.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 6, 5-8(Jun 1995)

TITLE: Hydropower and nontraditional types of utilization of renewable energy resources
AUTHORS: Fedorov, M P
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER
DESCRIPTION: Has the moment come for a more serious attitude toward nontraditional energy in renewable sources? The answer to this question lies in the rates of utilization of organic and nuclear fuel as well as in the possibilities of improvement of the energy installations using renewable resources. The experience of the last century shows that the technological progress covers periods of several decades. Consequently, we today must focus our attention on the middle of the next century, which is connected with the possibility of the exhaustion of organic fuels.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 6, 4(Jun 1995)

TITLE: Operating regimes of combined small hydroelectric plants-biomass energy installation systems for Karelian conditions
AUTHORS: Aref`ev, N V; Uvarov, V N
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 09 BIOMASS FUELS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; RUSSIAN FEDERATION; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; BIOMASS
DESCRIPTION: This article explores the concept of using small hydroelectric plants to supply the base load and biogas installations to meet peak load demand in the Karelian region of the Russian Federation. There are a number of small hydro plants under development in the region, but since reservoirs are not constructed in the region, their output is limited by stream flow and is not adequate to supply the base load needs. The time-dependent energy needs of a large collective farm is used as an example, with the biogas installation being fueled from the organic refuse from the collective itself. It is felt that the optimal combination of energy installations for the area is the hydroelectric/biogas installation for remote customers.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 6, 9-11(Jun 1995)

TITLE: Identifying a hydraulic-turbine model from measured field data
AUTHORS: Trudnowski, D J; Agee, J C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SPEED REGULATORS; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; RESPONSE FUNCTIONS
DESCRIPTION: An approach is proposed for identifying hydraulic-turbine model parameters from measured response data. The frequency response from the turbine-gate position to the machine power is measured at given steady-state operating conditions, and a structured model is fitted to the response. The fitting process is based on a nonlinear optimization method that provides numerical robustness. This approach allows one to fine tune and validate existing models or to identify a model without initial theoretical analysis. Theoretical development of the approach is discussed and results are presented for a 115-MVA unit at the Mt. Elbert pumped-storage powerplant operated by the Bureau of Reclamation.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 4; Conference: 1995 IEEE Power Engineering Society summer meeting, Portland, OR (United States), 23-27 Jul 1995; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITCNE4; ISSN 0885-8969; TRN: IM9625%%227

TITLE: Analysis of in-service aged stator bars
AUTHORS: Morin, R; Novak, J P; Bartnikas, R; Ross, R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; ELECTRICAL INSULATION; ELECTRICAL PROPERTIES; SERVICE LIFE; STATORS; TURBOGENERATORS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES
DESCRIPTION: Stator bars subjected to operating stresses for 7 and 22 year periods were retrieved from a hydro-generator to undergo short term electrical diagnostic tests in order to determine whether any significant aging of the insulation had taken place. The ac breakdown voltage (U{sub bk}), partial discharge inception voltage (PDIV), the maximum charge ({Delta}Q{sub m}) and total apparent charge (TAC) transfer of the partial discharges, tan{delta} and tan{delta} tip-up comprised the measured quantities statistically evaluated in the diagnostic test procedure. The ac breakdown voltage, PDIV and {Delta}Q{sub m} were found to exhibit a systematic trend with in-service time, thereby suggesting the occurrence of aging effects. That is, both the ac breakdown voltage and the PDIV were characterized by a decrease with time in-service, while the {Delta}Q{sub m} value exhibited an increase. However, no definite behavior was evinced by the TAC, tan{delta} and tan{delta} tip-up values. The significance of the diagnostic test results is discussed in terms of Weibull statistics and the partial discharge behavior with time.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 4; Conference: Winter meeting of the IEEE Power Engineering Society, New York, NY (United States), 29 Jan - 2 Feb 1995; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITCNE4; ISSN 0885-8969; TRN: IM9625%%213

TITLE: Use of a static frequency converter for rapid load response in pumped-storage plants
AUTHORS: Magsaysay, G; Fostiak, R J; Schuette, T
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; FREQUENCY CONVERTERS; ELECTRIC CONTROLLERS; ELECTRIC MOTORS; FREQUENCY CONTROL
DESCRIPTION: Most pumped-storage plants have the capability to operate as synchronous condensers. As such, they can be brought on line very quickly to support system load requirements. However, one of the effects of making a rapid transition from synchronous condenser operation to turbine/governor operation is an initial reverse power flow into the machine. This reverse power flow can be very undesirable at a time when the system is calling for load support. On weak or isolated systems, this reverse power flow can lead to objectionable voltage and frequency dips in the system. With the proper utilization of a static frequency converter (SFC) and its associated controls and auxiliary switchgear systems, the reverse power flow resulting from a transition from synchronous condenser operation can be eliminated. This paper will describe the method by which an SFC system can be used to make this rapid load response in pumped-storage plants without incurring a reverse power flow and to provide additional instantaneous short term power to support the grid.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 4; Conference: 1995 IEEE Power Engineering Society summer meeting, Portland, OR (United States), 23-27 Jul 1995; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITCNE4; ISSN 0885-8969; TRN: IM9625%%217

TITLE: Neural-net based coordinated stabilizing control for the exciter and governor loops of low head hydropower plants
AUTHORS: Djukanovic, M; Novicevic, M; Dobrijevic, D; Babic, B; Sobajic, D J; Pao, Y H;
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; EXCITATION SYSTEMS; NEURAL NETWORKS; CONTROL THEORY
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents a design technique of a new adaptive optimal controller of the low head hydropower plant using artificial neural networks (ANN). The adaptive controller is to operate in real time to improve the generating unit transients through the exciter input, the guide vane position and the runner blade position. The new design procedure is based on self-organization and the predictive estimation capabilities of neural-nets implemented through the cluster-wise segmented associative memory scheme. The developed neural-net based controller (NNC) whose control signals are adjusted using the on-line measurements, can offer better damping effects for generator oscillations over a wide range of operating conditions than conventional controllers. Digital simulations of hydropower plant equipped with low head Kaplan turbine are performed and the comparisons of conventional excitation-governor control, state-space optimal control and neural-net based control are presented. Results obtained on the non-linear mathematical model demonstrate that the effects of the NNC closely agree with those obtained using the state-space multivariable discrete-time optimal controllers.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 4; Conference: 1995 IEEE Power Engineering Society summer meeting, Portland, OR (United States), 23-27 Jul 1995; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITCNE4; ISSN 0885-8969; TRN: IM9625%%226

TITLE: Production of the greenhouse gases CH{sub 4} and CO{sub 2} by hydroelectric reservoirs of the boreal region
AUTHORS: Duchemin, E; Lucotte, M; Canuel, R
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; GREENHOUSE GASES; EMISSION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; WATER RESERVOIRS; QUEBEC; METHANE; CARBON DIOXIDE; AIR-WATER INTERACTIONS
DESCRIPTION: The purpose of this study was to estimate soil-water interface (benthic) and air-water interface emissions and flux of methane (CH{sub 4}) and carbon dioxide (CO{sub 2}) at two hydroelectric reservoirs in Quebec, Canada. Data were collected over 2 years at 11 sampling stations during ice-free seasons. The recorded emission fluxes were compared to water column depth, type of flooded soil, inundation history, and wind exposure. Most of the benthic fluxes measured for both gases were similar to those measured at the air-water interface. Unusual sampling conditions (e.g., strong winds, water columns less than one meter deep, or flooded peatland mats floating at the surface) resulted in above average emission fluxes. Preliminary analyses indicate that these higher emissions may be an important factor in calculating atmospheric emissions for large reservoirs. Emission fluxes at the water-air interface were determined to be controlled by molecular diffusion. Concentration profiles of the dissolved gases clearly demonstrated that oxidation and/or horizontal advection are controlling factors of atmospheric release. Neither benthic emission nor soil type appeared to control emissions of methane or carbon dioxide from the reservoirs. By rough approximation, it was proposed that hydroelectric reservoirs emit greenhouse gases on a much smaller scale than conventional thermal power plants producing equivalent amounts of energy. 51 refs., 2 figs., 3 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Global Biogeochemical Cycles; Journal Volume: 9; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1995

TITLE: Software-based governor control helps manage power swings
AUTHORS: Bauman, T A; Stead, D P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 MATHEMATICS, COMPUTERS, INFORMATION SCIENCE, MANAGEMENT, LAW, MISCELLANEOUS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; SPEED REGULATORS; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FLOW RATE; CONTROL
DESCRIPTION: Severe power swings occurring when water flow increases to impulse turbines at the 120-MW Bradley Lake Project in Alaska are managed by an innovative governor control scheme. To control severe power swings occurring when water flow increased to the impulse turbines at the Bradley Lake Project near Homer, Alaska, the plant`s governor was reprogrammed. This reprogramming was made possible owing to the use of state-of-the-art digital electronics. The new control scheme, which focuses on using the total flow of water ot the turbine rather than manipulating individual needle positions, is an appropriate solution for other high-head hydroelectric plants with impulse turbines encountering similar problems.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 14; Journal Issue: 7; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1995

TITLE: Sticky Wickets: Monitoring movement of cracks in concrete structures
AUTHORS: Tockstein, C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CRACK PROPAGATION; MONITORING; REINFORCED CONCRETE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DAMS
DESCRIPTION: Surface cracks in concrete are commonplace, but cracks that grow can be a problem. In civil structures such as a dam or power plant, if an expanding crack goes unnoticed, it carries the potential for disaster. However, detecting expansion in cracks in concrete is difficult because cracks move much like glaciers-very slowly. One simple device, a relative block movement detector invented by the author while an engineer at the Tennessee Valley Authority, can measure contraction, expansion, and movement. A second simple instrument for detecting movement, of less certain origin, is called a {open_quotes}ball-in-a-box{close_quotes} device. The relative block movement detector can monitor movement at the joint of two poured slabs, such as in the roadway of a dam. A clamping mechanism is bolted to one side of a crack, holding a bar that extends across the crack into the center of a square box bolted on the other side of the crack. The position of the bar provides a measure of any movement of two slabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 14; Journal Issue: 7; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1995

TITLE: Solutions for anchoring steel to underwater concrete superstructures
AUTHORS: Riddle, W H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; CONSTRUCTION; STRUCTURAL BEAMS; FASTENING; CONCRETES; ANCHORS
DESCRIPTION: Engineers at a South Carolina hydro project developed a solution for attaching temporary steel stoplog slots to submerged concrete. The technique has wide applications in fastening steel members to underwater concrete superstructures. Structural repairs to hydroelectric plants constructed 50 to 100 years ago have become commonplace. However, environmental and social changes occurring over the past few decades require repair methods that the original builders would never have though necessary. This was the case at the 206-MW Saluda Hydroelectric Project in South Carolina.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 14; Journal Issue: 7; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1995

TITLE: Machine dynamics notebook: Monitoring air gap prevents generator damage
AUTHORS: Bissonnette, M; Pollock, B; Goodeve, E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ROTORS; STATORS; MONITORING
DESCRIPTION: Dynamics air gap monitoring is the process of measuring the distance between the rotor and the stator on a hydroelectric generator while the unit is operating. A number of hydro plant owners use dynamic air gap monitoring, primarily to avoid the potentially costly consequences of air gap failure (rotor-to-stator contact, or rubbing). A serious air gap failure will result in lost revenue from lost generation, and, in large units greater than 20 MW, can cost owners who must purchase and install replacement equipment several million dollars.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 14; Journal Issue: 7; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1995

TITLE: Role of topography and anisotropy when selecting unlined pressure-tunnel alignment
AUTHORS: Amadei, B; Pan, E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TUNNELS; DESIGN; STRATA CONTROL; STRESS ANALYSIS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PRESSURE MEASUREMENT; ROCK MECHANICS; SITE CHARACTERIZATION
DESCRIPTION: This paper shows how analytical solutions, proposed by the writers to predict in-situ stresses in rock masses with smooth and irregular topographies, can help in the selection of the alignment of unlined pressure tunnels near slopes and valley walls. The proposed methodology can be applied to ridges and valleys in isotropic or anisotropic rock masses subject to gravity or to combined gravitational and tectonic loading. The analytical solutions are two-dimensional and assume plane or generalized plane strain. They can be used to substitute existing design charts for pressure tunnels based on the finite-element method. It is found that the safe alignment of unlined pressure tunnels depend greatly on the extent of tensile regions in valley walls, which itself depends on parameters such as valley geometry, the degree of rock anisotropy, the orientation of the planes of rock anisotropy, and the in-situ loading conditions (gravity, gravity and tectonic).
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Geotechnical Engineering; Journal Volume: 121; Journal Issue: 12; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: JGENDZ; ISSN 0733-9410; TRN: IM9606%%112

TITLE: State of the dam at the Zeya hydroelectric station with consideration of the geodynamic effect
AUTHORS: Marchuk, A N; Dudchenko, L N; Bolgov, V V
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FOUNDATIONS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; DAMS; DEFORMATION; DISPLACEMENT RATES; STRESSES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DIAGRAMS
DESCRIPTION: The buttress dam of the Zeya hydroelectric station has already been operating successfully for 20 years under complex climatic, geological, and seismological conditions. Additional difficulties are created by some uncertainty of the interaction of the structure with the geological environment subjected to tectonic movements. The seismotectonic conditions of the region of the Zeya reservoir are determined by proximity to the boundary of two large structural zones with a different character of tectonic movements: regions of the uplift of the Tukuringra-Soktokhan Range and the downwarping Amur-Zeya Plateau. This boundary is represented by the Pkan fault located about 1 km from the dam on the downstream side.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Nov 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 5, 8-15(May 1995)

TITLE: Routine instrumental monitoring - a guarantee of dam safety
AUTHORS: Kheifits, V Z
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; MONITORING; SAFETY; MEASURING METHODS
DESCRIPTION: Several thousand hydraulic barrier structures (dams, embankments, ash dumps, and others) are presently operating in the former territory of the USSR. Most of them have been operating for several decades. The rate of failures (incidents, emergency situations) of analogous structures, according to foreign statistical data, reaches 2 x 10{sup {minus}3}/yr. In countries of the Commonwealth of Independent State (CIS) the condition of several tens of the 400 large hydraulic structures of hydropower developments does not completely meet the requirements of safe operation. On average from four to six incidents and damages (failures) are recorded on these structures annually. Failures of large dams in our country and abroad have led to the loss of lives and to material losses. Thus, the failure of the Teton dam in 1976 (USA) took the lives of 11 persons and caused $1 billion of damage. Breakthrough of the 15-m dam of the Kiselevsk hydro development in the Urals in 1993 took 19 lives and caused considerable damage.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Nov 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 5, 19-22(May 1995)

TITLE: Method of calculating varying discharges in branch canals with bilateral division of the flow
AUTHORS: Markova, N E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; INLAND WATERWAYS; FLUID FLOW; CALCULATION METHODS; IRRIGATION
DESCRIPTION: When operating an inter- and intrafarm irrigation system consisting of a multitude of canals branching one from another, it is necessary rather often to deal with varying lateral withdrawal of water. We will give a calculation of the region of division of the flow located on the main canal of the irrigation system.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Nov 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 5, 28-29(May 1995)

TITLE: Standardization of wave loads on river structures
AUTHORS: Tsypin, V Sh
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FOUNDATIONS; WAVE FORCES; BUILDINGS; NUMERICAL DATA; RIVERS
DESCRIPTION: The standard requirements of designing river structures with respect to a probabilistic estimation of hydrometeorological parameters substantially lag behind the available research and development results. Determination of wave loads and effects is no exception. In most cases it is required to examine these effects to transport structures (particularly on bridge crossings) in combination with the effect of floods (i.e., as combinable events). An analysis of numberous series of annual maxima of water discharges and wind speeds during passage of floods in the same years and for the same site on rivers in various regions of Russia made it possible to obtain a design probability of a storm within 25-30%.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Nov 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 5, 32-33(May 1995)

TITLE: Who are the owners of a reservoir?
AUTHORS: Glukhan`kov, V P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; WATER RESERVOIRS; MANAGEMENT; OWNERSHIP; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS
DESCRIPTION: Reservoirs of large hydroelectric stations are multipurpose objects. However, the directors of hydrostations are not engaged in the operation of reservoirs and do not bear any expenses on their provision with amenities, receiving at the same time a large part of the profit from creation of the reservoir. River transport of various types of ownership, having received a deepwater, guaranteed, and save waterway, using its advantages compared with a natural river route, does not bear any expenses on providing facilities and improving the ecology of the water body.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Nov 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 5, 46-47(May 1995)

TITLE: Adjusment of the loads between segments in the hydraulic thrust bearing of a turbine-generator unit
AUTHORS: Zakharov, A A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BEARINGS; REPAIR; MAINTENANCE; DYNAMIC LOADS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; NUMERICAL DATA
DESCRIPTION: One of the most important stages in the assembly and repair of the thrust bearing of a turbine-generator unit is adjustment of the load on the segments. The generally accepted method of adjusting the loads between segments in a hydraulic thrust bearing is based on measuring the axial deformation of the elastic chambers of indicators and equalizing it. Here it is assumed that sagging of the chambers is plane-parallel. Certain problems that occurred when lining the bearings with Babbitt segments, for example, a decrease of sagging of the chambers with time from 0.2-0.3 mm to almost zero, i.e., an apparent increase of rigidity of the chambers, compelled doubting this.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Nov 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 5, 30-32(May 1995)

TITLE: Water transport and power network (WTPN) of the Russian federation
AUTHORS: Belyakov, A A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FUELS; MARITIME TRANSPORT; RUSSIAN FEDERATION; RIVERS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PLANNING
DESCRIPTION: A decline in production in recent years arrested the growth of shipping by all modes of transportation. Simultaneously, financing of not only their development but also maintenance in an operable state decreased markedly. The expected economic upturn requires timely planning of measures to increase the efficiency and reliability of the transport complex under new economic conditions and in connection with this for its most advisable investment.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Nov 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 5, 41-45(May 1995)

TITLE: Safety of hydraulic structures: Some results of calculating the social risk related to transformation of the river channel in the lower pool of a hydro development
AUTHORS: Ivashintsov, D A; Stefanishin, D V; Veksler, A B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; RIVERS; EROSION; WATER RESERVOIRS; MANAGEMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DIAGRAMS; NUMERICAL DATA; SOCIAL IMPACT
DESCRIPTION: Some of the characteristic types of hazards related to the construction and operation of hydraulic structures and which the occurrence of various undesirable consequences (phenomena, processes) is possible in the {open_quotes}hydro development-environment{close_quotes} system, ultimately leading to an increase of social tension. The experience of many operating hydro developments show that for lower pools, a decisive circumstance is the accuracy of predicting transformation of the channel, with the consequence of an error being the uncontrollable disturbance of the balance of erosion in the river channel and valley and development of degradational processes in the lower pool. One such problem is examined in this article.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Nov 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 5, 4-8(May 1995)

TITLE: Experience in using geophysical methods for reconstructing hydraulic structures in cities
AUTHORS: Aleshin, A S; Zhigalin, A D; Kaganov, G M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FOUNDATIONS; MONITORING; DAMS; GEOPHYSICS
DESCRIPTION: The use of geophysical methods during surveys for hydraulic structures and for monitoring the state of these structures during operation became everyday practice long ago. A number of advantages of geophysical methods-namely, mobility, relatively low cost, and, the main thing, high reliability of the information obtained-help them to gain prestige among both builders and operators who have broad experience in working on large hydraulic structures.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Nov 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 5, 16-19(May 1995)

TITLE: Reliability of concrete in the main structures of the Boguchany hydroelectric station
AUTHORS: Lyadov, Yu D; Semenok, S N; Sukhotskaya, S S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CONCRETES; RELIABILITY; FOUNDATIONS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DIAGRAMS; NUMERICAL DATA
DESCRIPTION: At the construction site of the Boguchany hydroelectric station more than half of the entire volume of concrete is being placed in the main structures. The stage related to the construction of the headwall of the water intakes and pressure conduits, formation of the downstream face, transfer of the diverted flow to the permanent bottom outlets, and start of concreting operations on the hydrostation powerhouse is coming.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Nov 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 5, 22-28(May 1995)

TITLE: Recovery of a warmwater fish assemblage after the initiation of a minimum-flow release downstream from a hydroelectric dam
AUTHORS: Travnichek, V H; Maceina, M J; Bain, M B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISHES; SPECIES DIVERSITY; POPULATION DYNAMICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; RIVERS; FLUCTUATIONS; FLOW RATE
DESCRIPTION: Artificial fluctuations in streamflow caused by hydroelectric power dams can degrade fish habitat and reduce the abundance and diversity of riverine fish faunas. Increased minimum water releases and reduced fluctuations in discharge may mitigate these effects. In this study, we compared shoreline fish abundance and diversity before and after an enhanced flow regime was implemented on the Tallapoosa River (Alabama) downstream of a hydroelectric dam. Before the minimum-flow regime, only eight species of fish were collected 3 km downstream from the dam, and all were classified as macrohabitat generalists. After the minimum flow was initiated, species richness 3 km below the dam more than doubled, and over half of the species collected were classified as fluvial specialists. Fish community response to the enhanced flow was not as great at a site 37 km downstream from the dam, where species richness was similar between the two periods. However, more species classified as fluvial specialists were collected after the minimum flow regime than before enhanced flows at this site. Additionally, relative abundance of species classified as fluvial specialists increased from less than 40% of fish collected before enhanced flows to over 80% after minimum flows began. Our results suggest that the enhanced flow regime provided conditions supporting a relatively abundant and diverse fish assemblage more reflective of a riverine system. 40 refs., 2 figs., 2 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society; Journal Volume: 124; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Nov 1995
JOURNAL_NAME: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society

TITLE: Differences in the dynamics and potential production of impounded and unimpounded white sturgeon populations in the lower Columbia River
AUTHORS: Beamesderfer, R C.P.; Rien, T A; Nigro, A A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COLUMBIA RIVER; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; FISHES; POPULATION DYNAMICS; WATER RESERVOIRS; FISHERIES; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS
DESCRIPTION: White sturgeons Acipenser transmontanus were sampled in three lower Columbia River reservoirs from 1987 to 1991 to describe population dynamics, the ability of these stocks to sustain harvest, and differences among reservoir and unimpounded populations. Significant differences were observed among reservoirs in white sturgeon abundance, biomass, size composition, sex ratio, size of females at maturity, growth rate, condition factor, and rate of exploitation. No differences among reservoirs were detected in fecundity, natural mortality rate, or longevity, in part because of sampling difficulties. Recruitment rates and densities in reservoirs were inversely correlated with growth rate, condition factor, and size of females at maturity. Differences in population dynamics resulted in substantial differences in sustainable yields. Maximum yields per recruit were predicted at annual exploitation rates between 5 and 15%. Most characteristics of reservoir populations were less than or equal to optima reported for the unimpounded lower river; as a result, yield per recruit, reproductive potential per recruit, and the number of recruits were less in reservoirs than in the unimpounded river. Comparisons with pristine standing stocks suggest that the unimpounded river may approximate preimpoundment conditions for white sturgeon. We conclude that potential yield from impounded populations has been reduced by dam construction, which restricts populations to river segments that may not include conditions optimal for all life stages. Alternatives for enchancement of reservoir populations might include improved passage at dams, increased spring flow to improve spawning success, transplants from productive populations, hatchery supplementation, and more intensive harvest management. 54 refs., 7 figs., 7 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society; Journal Volume: 124; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Nov 1995
JOURNAL_NAME: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society

TITLE: A multiobjective approach to the short-term scheduling of a hydroelectric power system
AUTHORS: Lyra, C; Ferreira, L R.M.
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BRAZIL; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; POWER GENERATION; PLANNING; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; COOPERATION; POWER SYSTEMS
DESCRIPTION: This paper is concerned with the short-term scheduling of the Iguacu River hydroelectric power system, in Southern Brazil. The system comprises four plants with an unusual high coupling, held by two different utilities. Even though government regulations established operation guide lines, utilities have their own interests. A multi-objective framework is adopted to study the operation of the system. Dynamic programming is used to find optimal solutions, with an implementation based on the concept of differential dynamic programming. A case study shows the possibility of obtaining energetic gains with the adoption of non-conventional operation rules and the need of negotiation to avoid wasting energy.

TITLE: Modeling the dynamic equilibrium of objects weakened by thin low-strength inclusions
AUTHORS: Skopetskii, V V; Deineka, V S; Marchenko, O A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 16 TIDAL AND WAVE POWER; DAMS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SHEAR PROPERTIES; ALGORITHMS; FINITE ELEMENT METHOD; BOUNDARY-VALUE PROBLEMS
DESCRIPTION: Successful development of hydroelectric power as well as the use and protection of the resources of the Azov/Black Sea basin require formulation and solution of design and control problems for hydroengineering and coastal constructions. The authors have developed two-dimensional mathematical models of dynamic equilibrium of various hydroengineering and coastal constructions with weak thin sections of natural or artificial origin (low-strength inclusions, cracks, technological seams), where shearing strength conditions must be considered. These models are applicable to objects whose dynamic characteristics can be fully described by considering their profile cross-sections (dams, coastal slopes, wave breakers). The weak thin sections are modeled by cuts with appropriate contact conditions. Finite-element algorithms have been developed for solving the corresponding initial-boundary-value problems, and a model example has been solved.

TITLE: Hydrothermal scheduling via extended differential dynamic programming and mixed coordination
AUTHORS: Tang, J; Luh, P B
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; INTERCONNECTED POWER SYSTEMS; CAPACITY; SUPPLY AND DEMAND; POWER DEMAND
DESCRIPTION: This paper addresses short-term scheduling of hydrothermal systems by using extended differential dynamic programming and mixed coordination. The problem is first decomposed into a thermal subproblem and a hydro subproblem by relaxing the supply-demand constraints. The thermal subproblem is solved analytically. The hydro subproblem is further decomposed into a set of smaller problems that can be solved in parallel. Extended differential dynamic programming and mixed coordination are used to solve the hydro subproblem. Two problems are tested and the results show that the new approach performs well under a simulated parallel processing environment, and high speedup is obtained. The method is then extended to handle unpredictable changes in natural inflow by utilizing the variational feedback nature of the control strategy. A quick estimate on the impact of an unpredictable change on total cost is also obtained. Numerical results show that estimates are accurate, and unpredictable change in natural inflow can be quickly and effectively handled.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 4; Conference: Winter meeting of the IEEE Power Engineering Society, New York, NY (United States), 29 Jan - 2 Feb 1995; Other Information: PBD: Nov 1995

DESCRIPTION: An early warning system can provide a relatively low-cost method for addressing dam safety issues. TITLE: Unsteady flowfield and torque predictions during the rotation of the guidevanes of hydraulic turbine
AUTHORS: Papantonis, D E; Pothou, K P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; UNSTEADY FLOW; CALCULATION METHODS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; VORTEX FLOW
DESCRIPTION: In the present work, the numerical prediction of the steady as well as of the unsteady flowfield through the cascade of guidevanes of a reaction turbine is examined. The unsteadiness of the flow results from the rotation of the guidevanes around their pivot. The applied numerical procedure is based on the coupling of the boundary element and the vortex particle method and is supplemented by two different procedures for the evaluation of the viscous-inviscid interaction and the boundary layers developed on the vanes. The cinematic conditions at every point of the flowfield are calculated first; however, special attention is paid to the prediction of the torque acting on the cascade and, namely, the variation of the torque during the rotation of the guidevanes, as compared with the torque corresponding to the steady state.

TITLE: Preliminary investigation of the use of air injection to mitigate cavitation erosion
AUTHORS: Arndt, R E.A.; Ellis, C R; Paul, S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CAVITATION; MITIGATION; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; EROSION; EROSION CONTROL
DESCRIPTION: This project was initiated as part of a new research and development focus to improve hydropower generation. One aspect of the problem is severe cavitation erosion which is experienced when hydroturbines are operated at best power or in spinning reserve. Air injection has been used successfully to minimize or eliminate cavitation erosion in other applications. Thus, an investigation was initiated to determine whether or not air injection would be an effective solution for turbine erosion problems. A specially instrumented hydrofoil of elliptic planform and a NACA 0015 cross section was tested at flow velocities up to 20 m s{sup {minus}1}, at various values of cavitation index. Although pit sizes were measured on a soft aluminum insert, pitting rate was not measured directly but was inferred from direct measurement of impulsive pressures on the surface of the hydrofoil and by monitoring accelerometers mounted at the base of the hydrofoil. Cavitation noise was also measured by a hydrophone positioned in the water tunnel test section. Air was injected through small holes in the leading edge of the foil. Air injection was found to be very effective in minimizing erosion as inferred from all three cavitation erosion detection techniques.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Fluids Engineering; Journal Volume: 117; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: Sep 1995

DESCRIPTION: In this article, the authors have described some results of the application of structural invariants for solutions of different management problems, including diagnosis of the technical state of elements of the electric equipment of electric power plants. It is shown that the procedure for construction of the SFM of a management system can be extended to diagnosis problems, without substantial difficulties. DESCRIPTION: This article discusses the development of a data bank system at the B. E. Vedeneev VNIIG Institute. The system consists of as many as 10 interacting data banks, most of which have been tested under field conditions. A brief discription is provided for each of the following data bases: (1) Certified parameters of Hydroelectric Plants of the world, (2) Certified parameters for thermoelectric plants in Russia, (3) Technical parameters of cooler-reservoirs of thermoelectric plants of Russia, (4) Equipment data bank for hydroelctric plants, (5) Information-analytical system of collection, storage, and processing of field observations, (6) World-wide data bank for the failure of hydroelectric plants, (7) Data bank for normative-technical documentation, (8) Data bank for normative-technical documentation of the operation of both hydro and thermal energy projects, (9) Data bank for documentation on anticorrosion protection of energy equipment, and (10) Data bank for scientific-technical achievements in the energy branch.

TITLE: Effect of Kima drain wastewaters on Nile river waters
AUTHORS: Soltan, M E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; DAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; NILE RIVER; CONTAMINATION; METALS; ECOLOGICAL CONCENTRATION; INORGANIC COMPOUNDS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EGYPTIAN ARAB REPUBLIC
DESCRIPTION: The influence of industrial and domestic wastewaters discharged from the Kima drain (Aswan, Egypt) on the quality of the Nile River waters is described by measuring the concentrations of inorganic nonmetals (free CO{sub 2}, CO{sub 3}{sup 2-}, HCO{sub 3}{sup {minus}}, OH{sup -}, Cl{sup -}, SO{sub 4}{sup 2-}, PO{sub 4}{sup 3-}, NO{sub 2}{sup -}, NO{sub 2}{sup -}, NO{sub 3}{sup -}, SiO{sub 2}, COD, DO and pH value), metals (Al, Ca, Cd, Cr, Cu, Fe, Mg, Mn, Pb, and Zn), and the physical parameters (cond., T{degrees}C, SS, and DS). Kima drain wastewaters exhibit high concentrations of dissolved salts, particularly close to where the waste of the Kima factory enters, but decrease substantially near the end of the Kima drain. The reason is the dilution factor, aeration, sedimentation, oxidation reductions, and the biochemical effects. A slight increase of the dissolved solids (DS) in the Nile river water at the Kima drain does not effect the Nile river water quality, as the regeneration of the Nile water continuously (the Nile River receives 200 Mm{sup 3}/d of fresh water from the High Dam Lake) prevents the accretion of the concentrations of metals and anions. Statistical analysis of the database exhibits positive, good, and interesting correlation coefficient values. 28 refs., 2 figs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environment International; Journal Volume: 21; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: 1995

TITLE: An experimental investigation of the flow through an axial-flow pump
AUTHORS: Zierke, W C; Straka, W A; Taylor, P D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMP TURBINES; INCOMPRESSIBLE FLOW; TURBULENT FLOW; ROTORS; TURBINE BLADES
DESCRIPTION: The high Reynolds number pump (HIREP) facility at ARL Penn State has been used to perform a low-speed, large-scale experiment of the incompressible flow of water through a two-blade-row turbomachine. The objectives of this experiment were to provide a database for comparison with three-dimensional, turbulent flow computations, to evaluate engineering models, and to improve the physical understanding of many of the phenomena involved in this complex flow field. This summary paper briefly describes the experimental facility, as well as the experimental techniques--such as flow visualization, static-pressure measurements, laser Doppler velocimetry, and both slow- and fast-response pressure probes. Then, proceeding from the inlet to the exit of the pump, the paper presents highlights of experimental measurements and data analysis, giving examples of measured physical phenomena such as endwall boundary layers, separation regions, wakes, and secondary vortical structures. In conclusion, this paper provides a synopsis of a well-controlled, larger scope experiment that should prove helpful to those who wish to use the database.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Fluids Engineering; Journal Volume: 117; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: Sep 1995

TITLE: Surface roughness effects on induced flow and frictional resistance of enclosed rotating disks
AUTHORS: Poullikkas, A
SUBJECT: 42 ENGINEERING NOT INCLUDED IN OTHER CATEGORIES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CENTRIFUGAL PUMPS; FRICTION; ENERGY LOSSES; CALCULATION METHODS; ROUGHNESS
DESCRIPTION: Disk friction losses in a pump are caused by the fluid flow in the gap between the impeller and the casing wall. The classical method of determining these losses is by using a thin plain disk rotating in a close fitting close casing. Rotating disks can be classified in two broad categories: (1) Free disk, a disk which rotates in a fluid mass of infinite extent and initially at rest. When the disk is rotating fluid is drawn axially toward the disk and is centrifuged off its periphery as a spinning boundary layer. There is no angular momentum in the approach flow so the friction torque is equal to the angular momentum cast off in the boundary layer. (2) Enclosed disk, a disk which rotates within a chamber of finite dimensions. When the disk is rotating the whirling flow cast off its periphery eventually returns to the disk retaining some of its angular momentum. For this reason the friction torque on enclosed disks is less than that on free disks. This investigation concerns the latter case which includes the kinds of conditions encountered in centrifugal machinery where problems of disk friction torque and power loss are related to the circulation and secondary flows induced by the rotating elements.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Fluids Engineering; Journal Volume: 117; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: Sep 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: JFEGA4; ISSN 0098-2202; TRN: IM9546%%137

TITLE: Experience with computer-aided graphical analysis of sudden-short-circuit oscillograms of large synchronous machines
AUTHORS: Kamwa, I; Pilote, M; Viarouge, P; Mpanda-Mabwe, B; Crappe, M; Mahfoudi, R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; TURBOGENERATORS; ELECTRICAL FAULTS; NUMERICAL ANALYSIS; DIAGNOSTIC TECHNIQUES; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; COMPUTER CALCULATIONS
DESCRIPTION: In a companion paper, computer programs are proposed of automating the analysis of sudden-short-circuit oscillograms in accordance with present IEC and IEEE standards. In this paper, the authors will further illustrate the capabilities of computer-aided graphical methods with a view to their incorporation into modern testing practices. Using synthetic short-circuit data obtained from an exact solution of the network equations of known machines, it is first shown that use of the proposed software leads to satisfactory parameters in a number of realistic situations, including those where sub-subtransient effects are present. When faced with real data, it is shown that pre-filtering, without phase distortion, is often necessary and some useful tools are suggested for carrying this out. A thorough investigation of the automatic graphical method applied to three machines, differing widely in design, suggests that the new software is robust enough to be used on a regular basis, either in the field or in the design office. Using the Takeda and Adkins K-factor, derived graphically from the field current oscillogram, even a full second-order network is possible, matching the underlying phenomena, as seen from both the rotor and stator.
