TITLE: The transient and qualitative performance of a self-excited single-phase induction generator
AUTHORS: Ojo, O
SUBJECT: 17 WIND ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; INDUCTION GENERATORS; PERFORMANCE; WIND TURBINES; TURBOGENERATORS; RESPONSE FUNCTIONS
DESCRIPTION: The modeling and transient performance of a single-phase induction generator with series or parallel connected load is the theme of this paper. The system of equations are expressed in terms of flux linkages and includes the effect of magnetizing flux linkage saturation. Generator self-excitation and voltage collapse phenomena are simulated. The balance of the paper deals with the qualitative behavior of the generator using concepts of harmonic balance and system bifurcation.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 3; Conference: Winter meeting of the IEEE Power Engineering Society, New York, NY (United States), 29 Jan - 2 Feb 1995; Other Information: PBD: Sep 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITCNE4; ISSN 0885-8969; TRN: IM9601%%30

TITLE: Computer software to automate the graphical analysis of sudden-short-circuit oscillograms of large synchronous machines
AUTHORS: Kamwa, I; Carle, H; Pilote, M; Viarouge, P; Mpanda-Mabwe, B; Crappe, M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; TURBOGENERATORS; ELECTRICAL FAULTS; NUMERICAL ANALYSIS; DIAGNOSTIC TECHNIQUES; HYDRAULIC TURBINES
DESCRIPTION: Computer programs based on the IEEE Std-115 graphical procedure have been developed to automate the analysis of digitized sudden-short-circuit oscillograms. Using a number of basic building blocks widely available in commercial spreadsheet and matrix analysis software, it has proved possible to develop a new approach combining graphic displays and interactive processing. This allows a relatively inexperienced user to execute a full analysis and calculate reactances and time constants in less than three hours, starting from the raw data. Upper and lower peak time-constant envelopes are fitted using high-order polynomials or spline interpolation procedures. The latter are then used in compliance with IEEE and IEC recommendations to determine numerical values of T{prime}{sub d}, T{double_prime}{sub d}, x{prime}{sub d}, x{double_prime}{sub d} and T{sub a} by graphical and heuristic reasoning. Initially, simulated data was used to validate the new software and assess the effect of different time-scale decoupling windows on the parameter estimates. Despite its simplifying hypotheses and other inherent pitfalls discussed in the article, the present graphical method, the authors believe, should continue to be used, particularly as it is simple and fast enough to be applied directly in the field for test validation, or quick initialization of more advanced estimation procedures.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 3; Conference: Winter meeting of the IEEE Power Engineering Society, New York, NY (United States), 29 Jan - 2 Feb 1995; Other Information: PBD: Sep 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITCNE4; ISSN 0885-8969; TRN: IM9601%%25

TITLE: Analysis of self-excited induction generators using an iterative method
AUTHORS: Chan, T F
SUBJECT: 17 WIND ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; INDUCTION GENERATORS; NUMERICAL ANALYSIS; WIND TURBINES; TURBOGENERATORS; RESPONSE FUNCTIONS
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes the steady-state analysis of self-excited induction generators (SEIG) using an iterative method. By considering the conductances connected across the air gap nodes, an iteration procedure is developed of the determination of the self-excited per unit frequency, which enables the equivalent circuit to be completely solved. The proposed method involves only simple algebraic calculations, but the accuracy is good an convergence is rapid. The method is subsequently extended to include core loss effects and the analysis of SEIG with series capacitance compensation. Very good agreement between experimental and computed results has been obtained on a 2-kW laboratory machine.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 3; Conference: Winter meeting of the IEEE Power Engineering Society, New York, NY (United States), 29 Jan - 2 Feb 1995; Other Information: PBD: Sep 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITCNE4; ISSN 0885-8969; TRN: IM9601%%31

TITLE: Minimum airgap flux linkage requirement for self-excitation in stand-alone induction generators
AUTHORS: Ojo, O
SUBJECT: 17 WIND ENERGY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; INDUCTION GENERATORS; EXCITATION SYSTEMS; DESIGN; WIND TURBINES; TURBOGENERATORS
DESCRIPTION: A minimum airgap flux linkage is required for the self-excitation and stable operation of an isolated induction generator feeding an impedance load. With the aid of bifurcation theory, it is sown that the minimum airgap flux linkage requirement is the value at which the derivative of the magnetizing inductance with respect to the airgap flux linkage is zero. This minimum airgap flux linkage determines the minimum or maximum load impedance and minimum excitation capacitance requirements. This result is demonstrated using single-phase and three-phase induction generators.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 3; Conference: Winter meeting of the IEEE Power Engineering Society, New York, NY (United States), 29 Jan - 2 Feb 1995; Other Information: PBD: Sep 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITCNE4; ISSN 0885-8969; TRN: IM9601%%29

TITLE: Design of a three-phase self-excited induction generator
AUTHORS: Faiz, J; Dadgari, A A; Horning, S; Keyhani, A
SUBJECT: 17 WIND ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; INDUCTION GENERATORS; COMPUTER-AIDED DESIGN; WIND TURBINES; RESPONSE FUNCTIONS; CAPACITY
DESCRIPTION: The main goals in the design of a self-excited induction generator (SEIG) are minimizing the rotor resistance and increasing the flux density until the magnetic circuit of the generator saturates. In this paper, a computer design package was developed in order to investigate the best way to obtain these goals. By reducing the stator core length by 40%, the frequency regulation ad the voltage drop were reduced. The frequency regulation decreased from 10% to 4% and the voltage drop decreased from 30% to 6%. In addition, voltage and frequency regulations in the standard ranges were obtained in the present design without any regulation devices.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 3; Conference: Winter meeting of the IEEE Power Engineering Society, New York, NY (United States), 29 Jan - 2 Feb 1995; Other Information: PBD: Sep 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITCNE4; ISSN 0885-8969; TRN: IM9601%%33

TITLE: A utility perspective on under-excitation limiters
AUTHORS: Berube, G R; Hajagos, L M; Beaulieu, R E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; TURBOGENERATORS; EXCITATION SYSTEMS; POWER SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC CONTROLLERS; STABILITY; MATHEMATICAL MODELS
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents a brief review of Ontario Hydro`s perspective and experience with Under Excitation Limiters (UELs). The purpose of the UEL is reviewed along with the results of field testing and modeling. It is concluded that users of these devices must define the dynamic performance requirements of the limiters, by examining the purpose of their installation, and then setting and testing them accordingly.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 3; Conference: Winter meeting of the IEEE Power Engineering Society, New York, NY (United States), 29 Jan - 2 Feb 1995; Other Information: PBD: Sep 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITCNE4; ISSN 0885-8969; TRN: IM9601%%35

TITLE: Vital sign: Big-dam construction is on the rise
AUTHORS: Gardner, G; Perry, J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; DAMS; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; POLITICAL ASPECTS; ASIA
DESCRIPTION: This article discusses the increasing construction of big, rather than small, dams in Asia because of growing demand for electricity and irrigation. Dams are a symbol of modernity and a source of national prestige partly because they are a multipurpose tool of development. However, in the past two decades, it has become clear that dams have serious costs as well as benefits. The problems are outlined in the article, along with comments about the involvement of the world bank and the future of dams.
RELATION: Journal Name: World Watch; Journal Volume: 8; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Sep-Oct 1995

TITLE: Global warming of the climate and hydropower engineering
AUTHORS: Reznikovskii, A M; Rubinshtein, M I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER GENERATION; CLIMATIC CHANGE; HYDROLOGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; FORECASTING; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; FUEL CONSUMPTION; USSR; ATMOSPHERIC PRECIPITATIONS; RUNOFF
DESCRIPTION: Global warming and associated with it, changes in the amount and annual distribution of precipitation and river runoff in different regions of Russia and the former USSR, can significantly influence operating conditions, indices, and parameters of hydropower stations. Results of water-power calculations, based on many-year hydrological series and concerning the power generation at the main chains of hydropower stations under conditions of global warming, show that an increment of power generation at hydropower stations in these conditions is less by 2.5 - 6.0% than the runoff increment. With some precaution, we may assume that the overall increase in mean annual power generation reaches 60 billion kW h by 2020. Problems related to the impact of global climate warming on the hydropower engineering are discussed. Possible changes in electric-power generation at hydropower stations, as well as in fuel consumption in energy systems of Russia and other countries of the former USSR, are assessed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resources; Journal Volume: 22; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Sep-Oct 1995; TN: Translated from Vodnye Resursy; 22: No. 5, 535-543(1995)

TITLE: Verification of limiter performance in modern excitation control systems
AUTHORS: Girgis, G K; Vu, H D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC CONTROLLERS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; TURBOGENERATORS; EXCITATION SYSTEMS; POWER SYSTEMS; STABILITY
DESCRIPTION: Modern excitation systems include devices for controlling or limiting machine terminal voltage (overvoltage limiters), volts per hertz ratio (V/Hz limiters), maximum machine field current (overexcitation limiters), and the reactive load absorbed by the machine (underexcitation limiters). Functional testing of these limiters before they are placed into commercial service is recommended. The Bureau of Reclamation routinely performs functional testing to determine the actual settings and operational characteristic of these limiters as part of excitation system commissioning tests on its hydroelectric generators. This paper will discuss the purpose and practice of functionally testing these limiters.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 3; Conference: Winter meeting of the IEEE Power Engineering Society, New York, NY (United States), 29 Jan - 2 Feb 1995; Other Information: PBD: Sep 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITCNE4; ISSN 0885-8969; TRN: IM9601%%36

TITLE: Navigation lock sets new standards: Cost-cutting legacy
SUBJECT: 42 ENGINEERING NOT INCLUDED IN OTHER CATEGORIES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; INLAND WATERWAYS; EXCAVATION; NAVIGATION; DAMS; COST; CIVIL ENGINEERING; POLLUTION ABATEMENT; WEST VIRGINIA
DESCRIPTION: A navigation lock under construction in West Virginia broke ground itself in a big way, but its greatest imprint will be vast cost savings elsewhere. That will amount to many hundreds of millions of dollars as design innovations developed during its construction are applied elsewhere. The project also taught the Army Corps of Engineers a stern lesson on how to handle-or avoid-a serious, unexpected toxic waste problem. Correcting that situation held up the lock work. The twin Winfield Locks and Dam on the Kanawha River are the busiest in the U.S. inland waterway system, registering well over 20,000 lockages a year. Heaviest traffic is barge tows coming down from the heart of West Virginia`s low-sulfur coal mining area into the Ohio River. Each 56x360-ft chamber can accomodate only one modern jumbo barge at a time, says Mark D. Kessinger, a civil engineer with the Army Corps of engineers` Huntington district. Typical five-barge tows are broken up and usually take three-and-a-half hours to lock through, even with helper boats. Under adverse conditions, that may be five hours. And often several tows wait in line for as long as 24 hours to make the 28-ft lift or drop. The Corps says that equates to a loss in benefits to shippers of $17 million a year. Its new 110x800-ft lock on the landside of the two existing ones will handle entire tows, three jumbo barges long by three wide. Phased construction of the $277-million lock began in 1990, but has been delayed a year and a half by discovery of contamination on the newly acquired portion of the site.
RELATION: Journal Name: ENR; Journal Volume: 235; Journal Issue: 7; Other Information: PBD: 14 Aug 1995

TITLE: Conventional and modern seismic investigations for rock quality determination at a dam site -- A case history
AUTHORS: Louis, J; Papadopoulos, T; Drakatos, G; Pantzartzis, P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; FOUNDATIONS; SITE CHARACTERIZATION; SEISMIC SURVEYS; DATA ANALYSIS; GREECE; GEOLOGIC FORMATIONS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: Refraction seismics and modern tomographic surveys were employed at the Platanovrissi dam site on the Nestos river in northern Greece in an effort to investigate the dynamic elastic properties and rockmass condition of gneiss-schist outcropping in the area under investigation. Six seismic refraction traverses were run on the ground surface, inside the exploratory tunnels and between tunnels and the ground surface. The results provided information about the low-velocity surface layer parameters and the stress relief zones on the walls of all the tunnels in which seismic tomography tests were performed. Ultrasonic tests, conducted both in situ and in the laboratory, enabled the determination of the ratio V{sub P}/V{sub S} and the Poisson`s ratio calculation. From the tomography data analysis and the geological interpretation of the results, three main velocity zones, ranging between 3,500 and 4,000, 3,000 and 3,500 and less than 3,000 m/s, were detected in each tunnel. High-velocity zones were found to be compatible with the hard rockmass of gneiss-schist material, while moderate velocities are closely related to jointed and fractured zones. Finally, low-velocity zones were well correlated with weathered gneiss-schist material.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophysical Prospecting; Journal Volume: 43; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: GPPRAR; ISSN 0016-8025; TRN: IM9552%%231

TITLE: Development of fish habitat for mitigation below hydro diversions
AUTHORS: Goldberg, H; Rublee, B; Mitchell, A C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BRITISH COLUMBIA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; SALMON; HABITAT; WATER POLICY; WATER USE; RESOURCE CONSERVATION
DESCRIPTION: In 1987 the Government of Canada, the Province of British Columbia, and Alcan Aluminum Ltd. entered into a tripartite agreement establishing a program of measures to conserve chinook (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha) and sockeye (Oncorhynchus nerka) salmon stocks in the Nechako River. Large-scale applications of habitat measures are planned to manage the risks caused to chinook salmon by potential reductions in habitat quality associated with the reduction of flows. The reduction of flows result from the planned diversion of an additional portion of the upper Nechako River drainage. Experimental placements of debris structures and channel modifications were conducted from 1988 to 1993. Juvenile chinook salmon highly colonized debris structures, particularly the sweepers and rail-debris catchers installed in 1991, and fry density was similar to sparse natural debris cover. Channel modifications, point bars, and a side channel were durable, but were not as well utilized by young chinook. Physical assessment indicated that durability was medium to high where debris catchers and bundles withstood peak flows of 250--283 m{sup 3}/s.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Energy Engineering; Journal Volume: 121; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1995

TITLE: Effectiveness of water release as mitigation for hydroelectric impacts to fish
AUTHORS: Lewis, A F; Mitchell, A C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; FISHES; POPULATION DENSITY; HABITAT; WATER INFLUX; WATER RESERVOIRS; RESOURCE MANAGEMENT; LEVELS
DESCRIPTION: Utility companies release water to mitigate the effects of hydroelectric projects on fish habitats. Utility companies, government agencies, and research communities in Canada, the US, Europe, New Zealand, and Australia were surveyed as part of a Canadian Electrical Association study to evaluate the effectiveness of water release as a mitigation. Respondents identified only 28 projects in which water was released specifically to protect fish habitats. Fewer than half of these projects (12) were judged as being effective. Six case histories with preimpact assessment and postimpact monitoring were reviewed. In four cases fish habitat or fish populations or both were maintained; in two cases they were not. The effectiveness of water release differed among rivers and fish species, and was greatest when designed to meet the habitat requirements of each life-history stage. A review of the literature did not support the theory that a particular fraction of the mean annual flow provides the bet fish habitat. Although smaller changes in the flow regime had smaller effects, increasing minimum flows above those historically observed did not necessarily increase fish production.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Energy Engineering; Journal Volume: 121; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1995

TITLE: Analyses of flow modification on water quality on Nechako River
AUTHORS: Mitchell, A C; James, C B; Edinger, J E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BRITISH COLUMBIA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; SALMON; BIOLOGICAL STRESS; RIVERS; TEMPERATURE CONTROL; FLOW RATE; AMBIENT TEMPERATURE; WATER RESERVOIRS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS
DESCRIPTION: Alcan Smelters and Chemicals Ltd. initiated construction of the final phase of the Kemano Completion Project in north-central British Columbia to divert additional water from the Nechako Reservoir to the existing powerhouse. The Nechako Reservoir was created by the construction of the Kenney Dam in Nechako Canyon, a natural barrier to salmon migration. The Nechako River downstream of Nechako Canyon supports important runs of sockeye and chinook salmon. This additional diversion of Nechako River flow creates the potential of high water temperatures and increased thermal stress to migrating sockeye salmon enroute to their spawning grounds in Nechako River tributaries. To achieve specific downstream water temperature objectives during sockeye salmon migration each summer, a two-level outlet facility adjacent to Kenney Dam is to be constructed to release cooling water at 10 C to the Nechako River. Results of mathematical modeling of Nechako River water temperatures show that, based on specified design criteria, a maximum Kenney Dam release of 167 m{sup 3}/s at 10 C would be required to meet the downstream water temperature objectives.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Energy Engineering; Journal Volume: 121; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1995

TITLE: Reservoir drawdown: Case study in flow changes to potentially improve fisheries
AUTHORS: Wik, S J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COLUMBIA RIVER BASIN; WATER RESERVOIRS; LEVELS; SALMON; POPULATION DENSITY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; HABITAT
DESCRIPTION: Salmon populations in the Columbia River Basin have declined, and several species are now protected under the Endangered Species Act. Many factors have contributed to the decline, including overharvest, loss of habit, degradation of water quality, and construction of dams. Many measures have been implemented to reduce the impact of the dams, but additional measures are being considered. Lowering water-surface elevations behind four lower Snake River dams has been proposed as a measure to improve juvenile salmonid survival. The Corps of Engineers has determined preliminary costs, schedules, and required modifications for several drawdown alternatives. Initial estimates of the ability of this type of operation to improve salmonid survival are controversial.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Energy Engineering; Journal Volume: 121; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1995

TITLE: Main causes, signs, and consequences of aging of concrete dams
AUTHORS: Durcheva, V N; Puchkova, S M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; SERVICE LIFE; STABILITY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: This article examines aging mechanisms, indications of aging, and consequences of aging of concrete dams. The aging process is a time factor causing irreversible phenomena leading to a decrease in the original reliability margins of hydraulic structures. The rate of aging depends on the quality of the designs, technology of construction, and operating conditions. The effects of aging are determined both visually and instrumentally. When analyzing these on-site data, it is necessary to establish the cause-effect relations among changes in the parameters controlling the loads and scheme of static behavior of the dam-foundation system. Only after analyzing the causes of the change in former stress, strain, and seepage states of hydraulic structures can the reliability margins be estimated and repair and restoration works be recommended.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 2, 9-10(Feb 1995)

TITLE: Effect of opening of joints on the behavior of concrete dams during operation
AUTHORS: Vovkushevskii, A V; Trapeznikov, L P; Sheinker, N Ya; Ginzburg, S M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; EXPANSION JOINTS; STABILITY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; T CODES; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: The present work presents the results of studies of the effect of thermal opening of joints on the downstream face on opening of the contact joint and was carried out for the example of the dam of the Bratsk hydroelectric station. Theoretical investigations confirmed considerable opening of the contact joint both in nonoverflow and in powerhouse sections. Other conditions being equal, the length of the zone of opening of the contact joint in the powerhouse sections is 2-3 meters greater than in the nonoverflow sections. In the winter period, the zone of opening in the powerhosue sections reaches the grout curtain, while in the summer period, the opening is about half as much. Such opening of the joint, together with decompressions of the foundation, leads to an increase in the uplift pressure, increase of seepage discharges, and decrease of safety against shearing. Calculations showed that the zone of opening of the contact joint can be followed by a closed joint zone with displaced surfaces (sliding zone). The size of the zone depends on many factors and requires further refinements, but in any event, this zone can completely enter the second column.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 2, 11-13(Feb 1995)

TITLE: Portable automated system for collecting, storing, and processing on-site observations for evaluating the operating safety of hydro developments
AUTHORS: Nekrasov, Yu D; As`kov, V L; Dobrynin, S N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 MATHEMATICS, COMPUTERS, INFORMATION SCIENCE, MANAGEMENT, LAW, MISCELLANEOUS; DATA ACQUISITION; PORTABLE EQUIPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTER ARCHITECTURE; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: This article briefly describes a PC-based portable data acquisition system for use at hydroelectric power plants or at other facilities where on-line monitoring systems do not exist. In this system, the individual observations from sensors are formed into an individual file and rewritten on a magnetic cassette in a PC through an RS-232 interface or a Stok-2 interface. For sensor data that is not digital, a 32 channel analog-to-digital converter is used, but the number of channels can be expanded.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 2, 20-21(Feb 1995)

TITLE: Nondestructive testing methods as an integral part of diagnosing hydraulic structures
AUTHORS: Dubovik, L Ya; Shtengel`, V G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 42 ENGINEERING NOT INCLUDED IN OTHER CATEGORIES; DAMS; NONDESTRUCTIVE TESTING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: This article is brief review of the applicability of nondestructive testing techniques to hydroelectric power plants. Based on Russian experience, it is recommended that such techniques be utilized for: (1) constant or periodic monitoring of the physical state of the structural members, (2) acceptance monitoring, and (3) monitoring prior to certain repair activities or after certain emergency situations. It is also recommended that the monitoring be performed on: (1) structures located in parts of dams and powerhouses adjacent to the upstream faces and located below the upper pool level, and undergroud or embedded structures below the water table, (2) exterior and water-conveying members of the dam, and (3) general structural members.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 2, 28-29(Feb 1995)

TITLE: Experience in operating earth dams of the NIVA cascade of the Kola Regional Power administration constructed in 1930-1960
AUTHORS: Nosova, O N; Margolina, O G; Sergeeva, N S; Egorova, L G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; MONITORING; EMBANKMENTS; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: This article discusses Russian experiences in monitoring earth-filled dams of the Niva region. These are low and medium head facilities in operation from 30 to 60 years. As shown by the experiences of long-term operation of earth structures in this area and on embankments being constructed by the method of dumping soil into water, it is necessary to impose more stringent requirements with respect to determining the steepness of these slopes to increase their stability, as is done when the structures are constructed dry. To organize successful monitoring of seepage processes in the investigated structures having substantial anisotropy of the soil, special recommendations of the disposition of piezometers under such specific conditions should be worked out. Recommendations on the disposition of piezometers under conditions of a noticeable effect of the groundwater regime of the surrounding territory on the seepage regime of the hydro development should be worked out accordingly. Since the calculations made in the work, as a result of which instability of many slopes was detected, are not always confirmed by practice, it is advisable to correct the method of such calculations with consideration of the characteristics of the formation of the seepage flow in the downstream shoulder of dams with pronounced anisotropy of the soil.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 2, 37-41(Feb 1995)

TITLE: Use of underwater technology in on-site inspections (and investigations) of hydraulic structures
AUTHORS: Pokhabov, V I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; DIVING OPERATIONS; INSPECTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: This article is a discussion of Russian experiences with diving operations used for the inspection of dams and hydroelectric power plants. The author concludes that: (1) the use of SCUBA and helmet-diving equipment is advisable when inspecting facilities at depths to 20 meters, (2) the use of helmet-diving equipment is advisable when working at depths from 20 meters to 45 meters, and (3) diving chambers are advisable when working at depths in excess of 45 meters.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 2, 30-32(Feb 1995)

TITLE: Criteria for evaluating the operational-capability life of aging concrete dams
AUTHORS: Antonov, S S; Sudakov, V B; Karavaev, A V
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SERVICE LIFE; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; DAMS; STABILITY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: This article discusses the aging mechanisms, both internal and external, for concrete dams and develops a simple mathematical relationship for determining the safe operational lifetime of the structure. The calculations made at the All-Russian Hydraulic Institute demonstrate the rationality of the basic positions of the approach. At present, refinements and simplifications are being introduced in the calculation method proposed and mathematical model created. These refinements will make possible wide use of the method.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 2, 5-8(Feb 1995)

TITLE: Lessons from failures of concrete dams on rock foundations
AUTHORS: Kalustyan, E S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; FAILURES; FOUNDATIONS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONCRETES; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: In this article, problems related to failures of concrete dams on rock foundations are examined. It is shown that the failures are due to the characteristics of their static behavior relative to earth dams and to the fact that the majority of their failures are related to the foundations. Failure analysis is conducted and the mean time between failures is calculated. Historical data on a number of failures are presented, and the mechanisms of these failures are discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 2, 13-17(Feb 1995)

TITLE: Comprehensive system of data banks for analytical-information support of reliability and safety of hydraulic structures
AUTHORS: Dobrynin, S N; Tikhonova, T S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 MATHEMATICS, COMPUTERS, INFORMATION SCIENCE, MANAGEMENT, LAW, MISCELLANEOUS; INFORMATION; MANAGEMENT; DAMS; RELIABILITY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: This article describes the development of a comprehensive analytical information system for the reliability and safety of dams and hydroelectric power plants. This information system was created at the All-Russian Hydraulic Engineering Institute, and it consists of a number of interrelated data bases accessible with a personal computer with a 386 microprocessor. Also including data bases on thermal power plants, the system includes: (1) Certificate parameters of world hydroelectric plants, (2) Certificate parameters of important Russian thermal power plants, (3) Technical parameters of cooling ponds of Russian thermal power plants, (4) Technical data of hydroelectric power equipment, (5) World-wide data on failures and accidents at hydroelectric power plants, (6) Technical standards, (7) Operating regulations, (8) Corrosion protection, and (9) Scientific and technical achievements.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 2, 18-20(Feb 1995)

TITLE: Production prototype of an engineering seismometric observation system
AUTHORS: Khrapkov, A A; Ivanov, I V; Levelev, A G; Dashevskaya, E N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 44 INSTRUMENTATION, INCLUDING NUCLEAR AND PARTICLE DETECTORS; 99 MATHEMATICS, COMPUTERS, INFORMATION SCIENCE, MANAGEMENT, LAW, MISCELLANEOUS; SEISMIC DETECTORS; DESIGN; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; ANALOG-TO-DIGITAL CONVERTERS; PERSONAL COMPUTERS; DATA ACQUISITION SYSTEMS; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: This article describes the ongoing development of an observation and data collection system for seismic effects parameters at hydroelectric power plants. The field sensors and their placement are discussed in considerable detail, as are the means of communicating, processing, and storing the data from the sensors. An operating prototype has been developed and tested, with satisfactory resolution of basic problems. In the prototype, there are two eight-channel digital operating stations. Transducers of types A1632m and A1612 have been successfully tested. A check of the ADC measuring board confirmed the possibility of measurments in the 120-dB dynamic range. The data transfer system was tested with good performance, and the prototype is presently ready to take to the field.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 2, 21-28(Feb 1995)

TITLE: Experience in operating the dam of the Vilyui hydroelectric station I-II on the Vilyui river
AUTHORS: Ovdienko, N A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; DAMS; MONITORING; RELIABILITY; EMBANKMENTS; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: This article discusses Russian experiences in the monitoring and operation of the earth-rock fill dam associated with the Vilyui hydroelectric power plant. Monitoring of the following is noted: (1) temperature and moisture regime of the downstream shoulder and diaphragm of the dam, (2) dam settlements, and (3) operational reliability of the dam. Data from their monitoring efforts is presented.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 2, 33-36(Feb 1995)

TITLE: Experience in operating the stilling basin of the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydroelectric station
AUTHORS: Efimenko, A I; Susloparov, V A; Bukhanov, V V; Rubinshtein, G L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; TURBULENCE; MITIGATION; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: This article describes the construction and operation of a facility to dissipate the energy of the discharge from a high-head hydroelectric power plant. The Sayano-Shushenskoe hydro facility uses a hydraulic pump on a concrete platform with a baffle wall in a stilling basis. In this discussion, considerable attention is given to the stability and reliability of the platform, which operates under severe operating conditions. The provisions of reliability of this platform require observance of the rules of operating outlets, of careful monitoring of the operation of the outlets, the use during operation of the outlets of pumping the seepage waters of the drainage in the zone of the basin, and finally, the placement of diffusion blocks which make it possible to reduce by more than half the extreme values of the characteristics of the action of the discharge on the platform.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 2, 42-47(Feb 1995)

TITLE: Problems of improving the quality of hydraulic tunnel linings and preventing their damage during operation
AUTHORS: Mostkov, V M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SURFACE COATING; DAMAGE; TUNNELS; RUSSIAN FEDERATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: This article examines Russian experiences with the quality of surface coatings of tunnels at hydroelectric power plants and efforts to prevent coating damage during operation. The majority of linings of hydraulic tunnels during their operation receive various damages---considerable leaks of water from the tunnels are observed, the working and technical joints open and large cracks form in the linings, the surface roughness increases, and the linings are destroyed in individual sections of the tunnel. As a result, the capacity of the hydroelectric station decreases, and in individual cases, emergency situations related to loss of stability of the tunnels and sliding of the mountain slopes are created. The major damage modes are discussed in detail in this article.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 29; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 2, 49-53(Feb 1995)

TITLE: Electric-energy storage hinges on three leading technologies
SUBJECT: 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COMPRESSED AIR ENERGY STORAGE; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; PUMPED STORAGE; ELECTRIC BATTERIES; POWER SYSTEMS; OFF-PEAK ENERGY STORAGE
DESCRIPTION: Electricity, unlike other forms of energy, cannot be stored for later use. But it can be stored as hydraulic, mechanical, or electrochemical energy. This article examines the importance of energy storage to a competitive environment and the technologies that are, or soon will be, available to meet the need. Pumped-storage hydroelectric, batteries and, to a less extent, compressed-air energy storage (CAES), are the clear leaders. Each has a defined capacity range where it makes commercial sense.
RELATION: Journal Name: Power (New York); Journal Volume: 139; Journal Issue: 8; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: POWEAD; ISSN 0032-5929; TRN: IM9543%%126

TITLE: A flexible active and reactive power control strategy for a variable speed constant frequency generating system
AUTHORS: Tang, Y; Xu, L
SUBJECT: 17 WIND ENERGY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER FACTOR; CONTROL; WIND POWER PLANTS; ENERGY EFFICIENCY; PERFORMANCE; INDUCTION GENERATORS
DESCRIPTION: Variable-speed constant-frequency generating systems are used in wind power, hydro power, aerospace, and naval power generations to enhance efficiency and reduce friction. In these applications, an attractive candidate is the slip power recovery system comprising of doubly excited induction machine or doubly excited brushless reluctance machine and PWM converters with a dc link. In this paper, a flexible active and reactive power control strategy is developed, such that the optimal torque-speed profile of the turbine can be followed and overall reactive power can be controlled, while the machine copper losses have been minimized. At the same time, harmonics injected into the power network has also been minimized. In this manner, the system can function as both a high-efficient power generator and a flexible reactive power compensator.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Jul 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITPEE8; ISSN 0885-8993; TRN: IM9551%%196

TITLE: Rerouting fish {open_quotes}traffic{close_quotes} in the Columbia River Basin
AUTHORS: Christensen, P J; Wielick, R G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; DESIGN; OPERATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COLUMBIA RIVER; IMAGES
DESCRIPTION: Grant County PUD is testing a prototype downstream fish bypass system at Wanapum Dam that promises to be more effective than screens. If successful at diverting juvenile salmon away from turbine intakes, the concept could be applied at other hydro facilities facing fish passage challenges. The tested method---an attraction flow system---is an alternative to screens. In this system, entrances are strategically located above turbine intakes. This takes advantage of the natural tendency for juvenile salmonids to occupy the upper portion of the water column as they move downstream. Fish attracted to the channel by the water flow into the slots are passed to the tailrace, thus avoiding the turbines.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 14; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Jul 1995

TITLE: Using computational tools for hydraulic design of hydropower plants
AUTHORS: Song, C; Chen, X; He, J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PENSTOCKS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; INTAKE STRUCTURES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; DESIGN
DESCRIPTION: Using advanced computational fluid dynamics, designers of hydroelectric facilities can now directly calculate detailed flow quantities, including energy loss and efficiency of the entire plant, with minimal need for model calibration. The large eddy simulation (LES) method is the most advanced computational fluid dynamic tool available. The LES method calculates all of the large-scale turbulent eddies directly as a function of space and time. The paper reports on this method and some applications. Specific applications discussed include: (1) Francis turbine runner, (2) Draft tube, (3) Pump-turbine runner, (4) Penstock bifurcations, (5) Water intake, and (6) Total system modeling.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 14; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Jul 1995

TITLE: Obtaining the right large power transformer for a hydro plant
AUTHORS: Clemen, D M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; TRANSFORMERS; TESTING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: Transformer efficiency and reliability are important factors in determining the productivity of a hydroelectric generating plant. A well-supervised testing program can help plant owners and engineers improve the quality of equipment installed at their plant. This paper addresses such a program as applied to the selection of the generator step-up, or main power, transformer at a hydroelectric generating station.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 14; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Jul 1995

TITLE: High-tech underwater maintenance increases safety, reduces costs
SUBJECT: 22 NUCLEAR REACTOR TECHNOLOGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FUEL STORAGE POOLS; MAINTENANCE; COOLING TOWERS; SCREENS; INTAKE STRUCTURES; DAMS; ALARA; SHIELDING; UNDERWATER OPERATIONS; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; FOSSIL-FUEL POWER PLANTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: This article describes how, using new inspection technologies and highly-trained divers, diving contractors provide much-needed services to power plants. It is a virtual certainty that any power generating facility using cooling water for its processes will eventually require underwater maintenance. Since the first days of large-scale electric generation, underwater maintenance projects have involved some form of diving activity. In the days of the hard-hat divers, the technology was primitive and the hazards even more significant. Consequently, project engineers would plan diving operations very carefully, and diving was viewed as a method of last resort. Fortunately, improvements in diving technology have removed much of the worry over worker safety and cost issues. Power plants routinely employ independent diving companies to provide maintenance, repair and inspection services. Nuclear fuel pool diving, cooling tower cleaning and maintenance, dam surveillance, and intake screen maintenance and inspection are just a few of the jobs carried out by specialized diving contractors.
RELATION: Journal Name: Power Engineering (Barrington); Journal Volume: 99; Journal Issue: 7; Other Information: PBD: Jul 1995

TITLE: Great river potential
AUTHORS: Anderson, J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; INDIA; RIVERS; MONSOONS; ELECTRIC POWER INDUSTRY; COMMERCIALIZATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; POWER POTENTIAL; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: Summer monsoons in India`s south and snow melt from the northern mountains seasonally change the levels of India`s many great rivers. For private developers, India`s power sector has fluctuated much like its rivers, between positive progress and uncertainity. Though not without its challenges, the Indian market for hydropower development offers tremendous potential over the next several decades. Developers willing to patiently wade through the current discussions regarding alternatives to counter guarantees will likely find India`s hydropower environment - encouraged by government and State Electricity Boards - a hopeful environment in which to work.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; Journal Volume: 25; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Jul-Aug 1995

TITLE: Indochinese power progress
AUTHORS: Hennagir, T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; ASIA; RIVERS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ELECTRIC POWER INDUSTRY; COMMERCIALIZATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; POWER POTENTIAL; DAMS; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES
DESCRIPTION: Fifty years ago, U.S. engineers, fresh with the new-found success of building North America`s landmark dam projects, first considered building a series of multipurpose hydro-electric dams along the ancient Southeast Asian Mekong River descending from Tibet`s snowy plateau to the warm waters of the South China Sea. Recent transmission interconnection agreements such as those between Laos and Thailand and the incorporation of international partnering agreements for power project development are helping to reshape electric industry relationships throughout the region of the Mekong. Former economic pragmatism is being rapidly replaced by a general movement toward positive market forces. Progress continues as international players bring a varied assortment of financial packages and models to the project development table.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; Journal Volume: 25; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Jul-Aug 1995

TITLE: Financing recreational mitigation
AUTHORS: Hennagir, T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; RECREATIONAL AREAS; FINANCING
DESCRIPTION: Recreational resource area mitigation remains an important operational requirement for hydropower project owners, especially in the western United States. Increasingly, producers of electric capacity must accommodate a rapidly growing demand for public recreation, providing opportunities in accordance with Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) relicensing requirements.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; Journal Volume: 25; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Jul-Aug 1995

TITLE: The new project paradigm
AUTHORS: Seeley, R S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ENGINEERING; ELECTRIC POWER; FINANCING; INVESTMENT; COST
DESCRIPTION: Engineering consulting firms face a new paradigm in global independent hydropower projects. It differs markedly from the classical approach in which international financial institutions such as the World Bank have funded such projects. Financing these traditional projects included recovering costs during a 50 year period and paying low interest rates. In contrast, an independent hydropower project takes a hard economic analysis and seeks a purely economic goal. Private developers want a faster and higher return on investment, typically 20%, which raises financing costs and power rates. These pressures have engineering firms grabbing at competitive solutions in their role with projects. This includes scaling down engineering, sourcing globally, networking with vendors and suppliers around the world, and forming alliances, among other ways of upping cost effectiveness. Overall, the costs of hydropower projects are declining as engineers learn to execute projects more cost effectively.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; Journal Volume: 25; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Jul-Aug 1995

TITLE: Utilities incorporate to develop and protect projects
AUTHORS: Hansen, T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; PUBLIC ENTERPRISES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; FINANCING; ELECTRICITY; RESELLERS; POWER TRANSMISSION; NATIONAL GOVERNMENT
DESCRIPTION: Several Western electric utilities are banding together to develop and protect their interests in regional power projects that deliver federal power. The primary focus of the newly formed entity, Western States Power Corp., will be on federal hydroelectric generation and transmission facilities in the West. Utilities served by the Western Area Power Administration (WAPA) formed the corporation as a vehicle to provide funding for the construction of hydropower genration. This would take the financial burden off the federal government. The corporation has submitted to the US Department of the Interior and WAPA, a proposal to finance the construction of the hydropower generation facilities on the DIamond Fork pipeline in Utah. The federal government would own and operate the proposed $48 million project, which would produce approximately 56.5 MW. WAPA would market the electricity.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electric Light and Power; Journal Volume: 73; Journal Issue: 7; Other Information: PBD: Jul 1995

TITLE: Design of a robust adaptive controller for a water turbine governing system
AUTHORS: Malik, O P; Zeng, Y
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; CONTROL SYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SPEED REGULATORS; STABILITY
DESCRIPTION: The prospective of parameter space methods for robust control and an algorithm for a robust controller based on a pole shifting adaptive control technique are presented in this paper. Mathematical development of the robust adaptive controller algorithm, calculation procedure and results of simulation studies when applied to a water turbine governing system are described in this paper.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 2; Conference: 1994 Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers/Power Engineering Society (IEEE/PES) summer meeting, San Francisco, CA (United States), 24-28 Jul 1994; Other Information: PBD: Jun 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITCNE4; ISSN 0885-8969; TRN: IM9538%%77

TITLE: Efficiency based optimal control of Kaplan hydrogenerators
AUTHORS: Schniter, P; Wozniak, L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; SPEED REGULATORS; CONTROL; CONTROL SYSTEMS; POWER DEMAND; OPTIMIZATION
DESCRIPTION: This paper investigates an optimal strategy for controlling the speed response of Kaplan hydrogenerating systems to decreases in load. Typically, primary control gates restrict to redirect water through the turbine to stabilize and transfer the system to operating point demand. The adjustable turbine blade angle is used to return to maximum operating efficiency at the new load level. The over-speed reduction is limited by the conduit`s ability to withstand the over-pressure caused by the flow restriction at the turbine. A control scheme using gates and blades simultaneously and independently is developed. The initial action of the proposed control moves the gates and blades in opposite directions at maximum rates in an effort to reduce efficiency without altering flow, thus quickly decreasing the generated power while affecting the pressure minimally. The final control action moves the gears and blades simultaneously to restore maximum efficiency operation at the new power level demand. Similarities are found when comparing the efficiency based control to the Bang-bang and Linear Quadratic Regulator results of optimal control theory, though attempting to apply either of these methods directly to this problem is impractical. Simulation results show that the proposed scheme outperforms the traditional gate-dominant control in minimizing turbine over-speed and speed settling time under prescribed load change and conduit pressure limits. However, in its present form, the design is found to be more sensitive to system nonlinearities than its conventional counterpart.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 2; Conference: 1994 Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers/Power Engineering Society (IEEE/PES) summer meeting, San Francisco, CA (United States), 24-28 Jul 1994; Other Information: PBD: Jun 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITCNE4; ISSN 0885-8969; TRN: IM9538%%76

TITLE: An integral criterion for appraising the overall quality of a computer-based hydroturbine governing system
AUTHORS: Luqing, Ye; Weidong, Li; Zhaohui, Li; Malik, O P; Hope, G S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; PERFORMANCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; STABILITY
DESCRIPTION: In this paper, an integral criterion is developed for overall analysis and appraisal of the performance, reliability and economy of a computer-based control system. A concept of performability is discussed, and the economic optimality is based on the overall benefits from the manufacturer to the user. A case study for a hydroturbine governing system is given. A comparison between different system configurations shows that it is helpful and beneficial to select a system possessing high indices and excellent quality.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 2; Conference: 1994 Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers/Power Engineering Society (IEEE/PES) summer meeting, San Francisco, CA (United States), 24-28 Jul 1994; Other Information: PBD: Jun 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITCNE4; ISSN 0885-8969; TRN: IM9538%%80

TITLE: Modelling and stability of a hydro plant with two surge tanks
AUTHORS: Vournas, C D; Papaioannou, G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; STABILITY; HYDRAULIC ACCUMULATORS; POWER SYSTEMS; HYDRAULICS; TRANSIENTS
DESCRIPTION: This paper deals with the modelling and the stability analysis of a hydroelectric power plant with two surge tanks placed upstream and downstream of the turbine. The interaction of the two surge tanks is investigated and the system is simulated for the case of sudden opening or closure of the turbine gates. The stability of the frequency control loop is assessed by using small signal analysis based on linearization. The above procedures have been applied to a real situation and proved to be extremely useful for preliminary design purposes.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 2; Conference: 1994 Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers/Power Engineering Society (IEEE/PES) summer meeting, San Francisco, CA (United States), 24-28 Jul 1994; Other Information: PBD: Jun 1995

TITLE: An analysis of single-phase self-excited induction generators: Model development and steady-state calculations
AUTHORS: Ojo, O; Bhat, I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 17 WIND ENERGY; INDUCTION GENERATORS; EXCITATION SYSTEMS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; WIND POWER PLANTS; CALCULATION METHODS
DESCRIPTION: The need for alternative and renewable energy sources for utility and autonomous applications especially in remote places has focused attention on the use of electric generators connected to a source of mechanical power such as wind and minihydro turbines. In particular, induction and reluctance generators have great potential. The modeling and steady-state performance of single-phase induction generators based on the principles harmonic balance is set forth in this paper. Magnetizing flux linkage saturation and flux dependent core loss resistances are included. Experimental results are provided to justify analytical approach and steady-state calculations.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 2; Conference: 1994 Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers/Power Engineering Society (IEEE/PES) summer meeting, San Francisco, CA (United States), 24-28 Jul 1994; Other Information: PBD: Jun 1995

TITLE: Optimal sequencing site of hydro-power stations
AUTHORS: Hayashi, T; Yoshino, F; Waka, R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SITE SELECTION; RIVERS; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; OPTIMIZATION; MOUNTAINS; CALCULATION METHODS; POWER GENERATION; EXPERIMENTAL DATA
DESCRIPTION: At the first stage of a hydro-power survey of a river, it is important to select the optimal hydro-power site. The most important condition to be satisfied is to determine the optimal site where the greatest and most economical amount of hydro-energy can be obtained. This paper proposes a new method in which the optimal arrangement of the hydro-power stations is determined by a computational operation using discrete data at points along the river such as the drainage area, altitude, and distance along the river channel as obtained from topographical maps instead of drawing on engineers` experiences and the intuitions of experts. The results by this method are then compared with data on existing hydro-power stations and the results planned by expert engineers to show that this new computational method is superior.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Energy Resources Technology; Journal Volume: 117; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Jun 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: JERTD2; ISSN 0195-0738; TRN: IM9533%%418

TITLE: Diagnostic system monitors gearboxes at hydro plant
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; GEARS; MONITORING; MAINTENANCE
DESCRIPTION: This article describes how, by applying real-time, tooth-by-tooth vibration ``imaging,`` this system detects gear-tooth defects -- such as pitting and cracking. To keep Swan Falls hydroelectric generating station in service, Idaho Power Co constructed a new two-unit, open-pit-turbine powerhouse. Swan Falls, Kuna, Idaho, the oldest on the Snake River, services southern Idaho and parts of Oregon -- one of 17 hydroelectric plants maintained by the utility. The hydro units use speed increasers (gearboxes) so higher-speed generators are possible. To monitor these gearboxes, engineers at Swan Falls required a continuous on-line predictive maintenance system. The system monitors the planetary step-up gearboxes in the two main 12.5-MW pit turbine/generators. In some Idaho Power plants with a similar hydro turbine/generator design, the gearboxes have experienced major failures, leading to hundreds of thousands of dollars in collateral damage.
RELATION: Journal Name: Power (New York); Journal Volume: 139; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Jun 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: POWEAD; ISSN 0032-5929; TRN: IM9540%%162

TITLE: Environmental impact assessment in practice: A gender critique
AUTHORS: Kurian, P A;
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; INDIA; DAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY
DESCRIPTION: The author evaluates the extent to which environmental impact assessment (EIA) as conceptualized by EIA systems is a gendered process. Through a discourse analysis of in-depth interviews with bureaucrats, technocrats, and activists involved with the Sardar Sarovar dam project in India, the author examines the practice of EIA in a Third World country. She uses a theoretical framework, informed by a theory of gender, to evaluate the interviews. In practice, EIA is marked by gender biases that ignore the gender-specific nature of impacts. Such biases distort the impact assessment process, making environmental sustainability difficult, if not impossible, to achieve.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environmental Professional; Journal Volume: 17; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Jun 1995

TITLE: Using stereoscopic images to improve maintenance of turbines, structures
AUTHORS: Morin, L; Richer, Y; Rivest, M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 42 ENGINEERING NOT INCLUDED IN OTHER CATEGORIES; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; MAINTENANCE; NONDESTRUCTIVE ANALYSIS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; IMAGES
DESCRIPTION: The demanding economics of the electric power industry provide strong incentive to extend the life of existing hydropower structures and equipment. Though many maintenance and repair tools are available, their successful use often depends on accurate evaluation of the condition of hydro project features. A new imaging technology can provide hydro personnel with accurate information with substantially less time and expense than traditional methods.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 14; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: May 1995

TITLE: Managing water temperatures below hydroelectric facilities
AUTHORS: Johnson, P L; Vermeyen, T B; O`Haver, G G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONTROL; RIVERS; AMBIENT TEMPERATURE; FISHES
DESCRIPTION: Due to drought-related water temperature problems in the Bureau of Reclamation`s California Central Valley Project in the early 1990`s, engineers were forced to bypass water from the plants during critical periods. This was done at considerable cost in the form of lost revenue. As a result, an alternative method of lowering water temperature was developed and it has successfully lowered water temperatures downstream from hydroelectric facilities by using flexible rubber curtains. This innovative technology is aiding the survival of endangered fish populations. This article outlines the efforts and discusses the implementation of this method at several hydroelectric facilities in the area.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 14; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: May 1995

TITLE: Cost-effectiveness analysis for complex managed hydrosystems: An application to the Columbia River Basin
AUTHORS: Paulsen, C M; Wernstedt, K
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 55 BIOLOGY AND MEDICINE, BASIC STUDIES; SALMON; ENDANGERED SPECIES; ANIMAL BREEDING; OPTIMIZATION; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; COLUMBIA RIVER BASIN
DESCRIPTION: The Columbia River Basin, one of the world`s most complex developed hydropower systems, is also the spawning area for over 100 stocks of salmon, 3 of which have recently been listed under the US Endangered Species Act. Electricity ratepayers in the basin have spent over a billion dollars since 1980 to increase salmon population. This paper describes simulation and optimization models developed to analyze the cost-effectiveness of salmon recovery measures, as required by the 1980 Northwest Power Planning Act. The results suggest that the combination of optimization and simulation is useful for analyzing the system-wide cost-effectiveness of mitigation measures. 15 refs., 2 figs., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Environmental Economics and Management; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: May 1995
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of Environmental Economics and Management

TITLE: Where have all the rivers gone?
AUTHORS: Postel, S
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; RIVERS; GLOBAL ASPECTS; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; DAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; IRRIGATION; FLOOD CONTROL; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: This article examines the decline of the major rivers of the world, some so constricted that the water no longer reaches its natural destination. The result is now, and could be even greater in the future, a failure of ecosystems and economies. The human interferences which have lead to decline of rivers are discussed: irrigation, large-scale hydroelectric power; flood control. The increasing ecological problems and economic problems from both fisheries devastation and from environmental effects such as shrinking supplies of surface water in lakes and wetlands are detailed. Rivers highlighted in the article include the Colorado, the Nile, the Ganges and the Yellow River. Solutions are also discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: World Watch; Journal Volume: 8; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: May-Jun 1995

TITLE: Surface impedance method applied to the prediction of eddy currents in hydrogenerator stator end regions
AUTHORS: Silva, V C; Marechal, Y; Foggia, A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; STATORS; EDDY CURRENTS; ENERGY LOSSES; THREE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; FINITE ELEMENT METHOD
DESCRIPTION: A three-dimensional finite-element analysis is employed to investigate the losses of hydrogenerator stator end regions by using surface-impedance boundary conditions. The three-dimensional complexity of the end-winding geometry is fully taken into account by the model. The purpose of this work is also to evaluate the eddy-current paths allowing for slits in the stator teeth and their effectiveness in reducing stator core-end losses. The methodology was applied to the stator core of a 52-pole 300-MVA hydrogenerator in two different cases: (1) with non-slit teeth; (2) with fully slit teeth. It may also be extended to large turbogenerators end regions.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Magnetics; Journal Volume: 31; Journal Issue: 3Pt1; Conference: CEFC `94: 6th biennial Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers (IEEE) conference on electromagnetic field computation, Grenoble (France), 5-7 Jul 1994; Other Information: PBD: May 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: IEMGAQ; ISSN 0018-9464; TRN: IM9527%%178

TITLE: Advanced pumped storage hydroelectric power may reduce NO{sub x} and VOC emissions
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; NITROGEN OXIDES; EMISSION; PUMPED STORAGE; USES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ENERGY STORAGE; OZONE; AIR POLLUTION ABATEMENT
DESCRIPTION: As a severe ozone nonattainment area, the New York/New Jersey metropolitan area faces the difficult challange of reducing emissions of nitrogen oxides (NO{sub x}) and volatile organic compounds (VOCs), the primary precursors of ground-level ozone. An ambitious, $2.4 billion undertaking, known as the Mt. Hope project, may help the metropolitan area - and the entire Mid-Atlantic Ozone Transport Region (OTR) - attain ozone compliance. The project includes a new 2,000-MW electricity storage facility, which would allow thermal power plants in the region to run more efficiently and reduce NO{sub x} and VOC emissions, especially at times of critical ozone levels. The Mt. Hope project is the subject of a recent study that analyzed, potential reductions in ozone precursors from project implementation. According to the study, NO{sub x} emissions could be reduced by up to 50 tons per day and $91 million per year could potentially be saved if the project is implemented. Advanced pumped storage (APS) improves significantly on the conventional method. The Mt. Hope project, for example, is expected to consume only 22% more electricity than it generates. APS facilities are designed to switch from power-receiving to power-generating modes frequently in response to demand - up to 20 times a day in the Mt. Hope design. 1 ref., 1 fig.
RELATION: Journal Name: Air Pollution Consultant; Journal Volume: 5; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: May-Jun 1995

TITLE: Factors affecting the homing of fall chinook salmon from Columbia River hatcheries
AUTHORS: Pascual, M A; Quinn, T P; Fuss, H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 55 BIOLOGY AND MEDICINE, BASIC STUDIES; COLUMBIA RIVER; FISHERIES; SALMON; REARING; MIGRATION; ADULTS; POPULATION DYNAMICS
DESCRIPTION: Straying results in an exchange of individuals between wild and hatchery salmon populations and is important because it could affect their genetic differences. Understanding what factors affect straying could help in the development of procedures for controlling the influence of specific stocks on nearby populations. We explore the effects of release date and the transportation of juvenile chinook salmon Oncorhynchus tshawytscha on straying by adults from two Columbia River hatcheries. Early and late releases from Washougal Hatchery produced much higher straying levels than intermediate release dates, and this pattern was consistent among brood years. Fish reared at Grays River Hatchery and released from Washougal Hatchery strayed significantly more than local fish of the same brood year and release data. Our results and those from previous studies indicate that the sequence of imprinting events is characterized by the combination of the time at which the fish experience given locations and the physiological state of the fish at that time. Changes in release date and transportation disrupt the sequence and timing of these events, with varying effects on homing. Hatchery rearing and release techniques can sometimes be modified to control straying and minimize the impact of hatchery fish on other hatchery and wild stocks. 46 refs., 5 figs., 4 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society; Journal Volume: 124; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: May 1995
JOURNAL_NAME: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society

TITLE: Technical clarity in inter-agency negotiations. Lessons from four hydropower projects
AUTHORS: Burkardt, N; Lamb, B L; Taylor, J G; Waddle, T J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; WATER RESOURCES; PLANNING; WATER POLICY; NEGOTIATION; LICENSING PROCEDURES; LICENSING REGULATIONS
DESCRIPTION: We investigated the effect of technical clarity on success in multi-party negotiations in the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) licensing process. Technical clarity is the shared understanding of dimensions such as the geographic extent of the project, range of flows to be considered, important species and life stages, and variety of water uses considered. The results of four hydropower licensing consultations are reported. Key participants were interviewed to ascertain the level of technical clarity present during the consultations and the degree to which the consultations were successful. Technical clarity appears to be a prerequisite for successful outcomes. Factors that enhance technical clarity include simple project design, new rather than existing projects, precise definition of issues, a sense of urgency to reach agreement, a sense of fairness among participants, and consistency in participation. Negotiators should not neglect the critical pre-negotiation steps of defining technical issues and determining appropriate studies, deciding how to interpret studies, and agreeing on responses to study results. 15 refs., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resources Bulletin; Journal Volume: 31; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1995

TITLE: Parametric study on performance of cross-flow turbine
AUTHORS: Joshi, C B; Seshadri, V; Singh, S N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; PERFORMANCE; PARAMETRIC ANALYSIS; CROSSFLOW SYSTEMS; TURBINE BLADES; NOZZLES; ENERGY EFFICIENCY; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: In the present experimental study, the effect of blade number, nozzle entry arc, and head on the performance characteristics of a cross-flow turbine have been investigated. It has been observed that the efficiency of the turbine increases with increase in blade number, nozzle entry arc, and head. The present investigation has also shown that there is an optimum number of blades for a given nozzle entry arc beyond which the performance of the cross-flow turbine deteriorates. It has also been shown that cross-flow turbines at higher heads do not behave as pure impulse turbines.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Energy Engineering; Journal Volume: 121; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: JLEED9; ISSN 0733-9402; TRN: IM9521%%270

TITLE: Lotung downhole array. 2: Evaluation of soil nonlinear properties
AUTHORS: Zeghal, M; Elgamal, A W; Tang, H T; Stepp, J C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 58 GEOSCIENCES; EARTHQUAKES; MONITORING; TAIWAN; DAMS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; EMBANKMENTS; SOILS; RESPONSE FUNCTIONS; WAVE PROPAGATION; STRESS ANALYSIS; SEISMIC S WAVES; PORE PRESSURE
DESCRIPTION: The characteristics of soil response during earthquake excitations, at a site in Lotung, Taiwan are identified using the Lotung large scale seismic test (LSST) data. A technique is developed to evaluate soil shear stress-strain histories directly from the free-field downhole accelerations. These histories are used to estimate variation of soil shear moduli and material damping characteristics with shear strain amplitude, and to assess the effects of pore pressure buildup. Soil stiffness properties are found to compare satisfactorily with those obtained through laboratory tests conducted by the University of California, Davis; the National Taiwan University; and the University of Texas at Austin. Pore pressure buildup appears to be accompanied by a reduction in soil stiffness. The information obtained in this study demonstrates that downhole accelerometer and pore pressure arrays offer a direct effective means of evaluating seismic soil properties.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Geotechnical Engineering; Journal Volume: 121; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: JGENDZ; ISSN 0733-9410; TRN: IM9519%%60

TITLE: Economic and biological analysis to aid system planning for salmon recovery in the Columbia River Basin
AUTHORS: Wernstedt, K; Paulsen, C M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COLUMBIA RIVER BASIN; DAMS; SALMON; POPULATION DYNAMICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; LIFE CYCLE; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; MITIGATION
DESCRIPTION: Runs of salmon in the Columbia Basin in the north-western United States have declined dramatically over the past 50 years, due to hydropower development, habitat degradation, over-harvest and other causes. This article describes a suite of models that analyze the biological effectiveness and financial costs of strategies designed to meet harvest and escapement goals for nearly 80 stocks of salmon simultaneously. Results suggest that finding a cost-effective solution requires that all aspects of the salmon life-cycle must be analyzed simultaneously. Policy implications and difficulties in using this modeling approach to inform regional decision-making also are discussed. 19 refs., 5 figs., 3 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Environmental Management; Journal Volume: 43; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1995

TITLE: Tools for maximizing hydropower generation while minimizing water use
AUTHORS: Liddell, V J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; POWER GENERATION; OPTIMIZATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DIAGRAMS
DESCRIPTION: Today`s licensing requirements, environmental regulations, and competitive economics make it critical that hydropower producers maximize power production from available water. Plant operators often can use existing data on plant efficiency and water use as a basis for optimizing water consumption and power output from their facilities.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 14; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1995

TITLE: Hydropower automation: The future is now
AUTHORS: Doyle, D J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; AUTOMATION; CONTROL SYSTEMS
DESCRIPTION: Hydro plants that have not yet automated will soon be in the minority. While the degree and sophistication of automation varies, appropriate technology has become more accessible and affordable. This article is a review of the trend toward automation, a discussion of the technical aspects, and the application/results on automation at a particular power plant.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 14; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1995

TITLE: Water velocity and migration of juvenile salmon: Is faster necessarily better?
AUTHORS: McNeil, W J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SALMON; MIGRATION; RIVERS; VELOCITY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: A theory not completely proven is being used as the basis for policies on flow management/salmon protection in the Columbia and Snake rivers in the Pacific Northwest. More debate on the issue is warranted, especially in light of the dramatic economic impacts of these policies.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 14; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1995

TITLE: Regularities of siltation of reservoirs and ponds
AUTHORS: Lapshenkov, V S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; WATER RESERVOIRS; FLUID FLOW; SEDIMENTATION; BIOMASS; CAPACITY; DEPOSITS; SEDIMENTS; PONDS; SILT; VELOCITY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COOLING PONDS
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes a mathematical model for siltation of reservoirs and ponds. It is shown from the model that small reservoirs and ponds, to a considerable extent lose a capacity as a result of accumulation of biomass and deposition of sediments from reworking of banks. But these deposits affect the increase of the current velocities and the transporting capacity of the flow, just as the deposition of ordinary river sediments. An analysis was performed on the settling pond of the Shaarikhan hydrostation and the headrace canal of the Perepadnaya hydrostation.

AUTHORS: Marchuk, A N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; MONITORING; SITE SELECTION; TECTONICS; STRESSES; STRAINS; DEFORMATION; ROCKS
DESCRIPTION: Since 1991 the O.Yu. Shmidt Institute of the Physics of the Earth, Russian Academy of Sciences, jointly with the All-Russian Hydraulic Engineering Research Institute has been conducting systematic comprehensive investigations of the geodynamic effect on large dams, including seismicity, by means of monitoring and measuring equipment. An expert analysis of data on 11 dams were carried out.

AUTHORS: Karavaev, A V
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; BUILDING CODES; DESIGN; REINFORCED CONCRETE; STANDARDS
DESCRIPTION: Development of Russian building codes with respect to the design of concrete and reinforced-concrete dams was completed in June 1993. This report presents the main standards of the codes.
