TITLE: Calculation of emptying inclined pipelines with consideration of unsteady-state effects
AUTHORS: Borovkov, V S; Konyukhov, D S
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 MATHEMATICS, COMPUTERS, INFORMATION SCIENCE, MANAGEMENT, LAW, MISCELLANEOUS; PIPELINES; FLUID FLOW; MONITORING; CALCULATION METHODS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; HYDRAULICS; VELOCITY; INCLINATION
DESCRIPTION: Hydraulic calculation of emptying conduits of hydroelectric and pumped-storage stations, pipelines of thermal and nuclear power stations, and sections of oil pipelines is related to monitoring emergency situations and for this reason should be carried out most accurately. Fluid flow in a an inclined pipeline is affected by inertial forces, consideration of which complicates the hydraulic calculation. This paper describes a calculation method for the emptying of pipelines.

TITLE: Navigating the hydro market in Latin America
AUTHORS: Yermoli, C A
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; LATIN AMERICA
DESCRIPTION: The governments of most Latin American countries have yet to establish clear policies about the future ownership of existing generation assets, but they do expect future capacity to be largely developed by the private sector. There were at one time plans for many government-financed hydro projects in the area, but these projects produced much paper and little electricity. Present trends will take the area toward independent power projects, both hydro projects and thermal power projects. This article is a review of those present trends.
RELATION: Journal Name: Fortnightly; Journal Volume: 133; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: 15 Mar 1995

TITLE: Downstream ecological effects of dams: A geomorphic perspective
AUTHORS: Ligon, F K; Dietrich, W E; Trush, W J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS; POPULATION DYNAMICS; SPECIES DIVERSITY; RIVERS; GEOMORPHOLOGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SALMON
DESCRIPTION: The damming of a river changes the flow of water, sediment, nutrients, energy, and biota, interrupting and altering most of a river`s ecological processes. This article discusses the importance of geomorphological analysis in river conservation and management. To illustrate how subtle geomorphological adjustments may profoundly influence the ecological relationships downstream from dames, three case studies are presented. Then a geomorphically based approach for assessing and possibly mitigating some of the environmental effects of dams by tailoring dam designed and operation is outlined. The cases are as follows: channel simplification and salmon decline on the McKenzie River in Oregon; Channel incision and reduced floodplain inundation on the Oconee river in Georgia; Increased stability of a braided river in New Zealand`s south island. 41 refs., 10 figs., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Bioscience; Journal Volume: 45; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: Mar 1995

TITLE: Evaluation of partial discharge detection techniques on hydro-generators in the Australian Snowy Mountains Scheme -- Tumut 1 case study
AUTHORS: Simpson, J W.L.; Tychsen, R C; Su, Q; Blackburn, T R; James, R E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; AUSTRALIA; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; MAINTENANCE; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; ELECTRIC DISCHARGES; MONITORING; ELECTRIC COILS; INSTALLATION; RETROFITTING
DESCRIPTION: An evaluation of partial discharge detection techniques used on the Unit 3 hydro generator stator windings at Tumut 1 Power Station in the Snowy Mountains Scheme of Australia is presented. Measurements were made with an RF slot probe, Robinson ERA Model 5 detector, Ontario Hydro PDA-H detector and a recently developed partial discharge site location (PDSL) system before and after removal of coils. Good agreement was found between all methods with the PDSL system achieving high accuracy in identifying individual high discharging coil sides.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 1; Conference: 1994 Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers (IEEE)/Power Engineering Society (PES) winter meeting, New York, NY (United States), 30 Jan - 3 Feb 1994; Other Information: PBD: Mar 1995

TITLE: Generator winding I{sup 2}R losses and harmonic interference under variable frequency operation of an HVDC unit-connection scheme
AUTHORS: Pang, C X; Tarnawecky, M Z
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; DC SYSTEMS; HARMONICS; AC SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; POWER LOSSES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRIC COILS; ELECTRIC FILTERS
DESCRIPTION: Variable frequency operation of an HVDC unit-connection scheme may affect the generator winding I{sup 2}R losses, and may cause harmonic interferences on both the AC and DC system. The purpose of this research is to determine the magnitudes of generator winding I{sup 2}R losses under ascertain frequency range so as to improve the efficiency of the hydro unit operation at non-rated head and output power. The generator winding additional I{sup 2}R losses and harmonic interference, are investigated by using the EMTDC program and other subordinate programs. The overall study shows that the generator winding power losses will be increased as the operating frequency decreases under the condition of a fixed generator output. The magnitude of increased losses, though, will not exceed 8--10% of generator total winding I{sup 2}R losses under normal system operating conditions. Harmonic interference, on the other hand, will become more severe in both the AC and DC systems, as compared to fixed frequency operation. Active or on line tuning harmonic filters may be considered for a particular variable frequency operation scheme being implemented.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 1; Conference: 1994 Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers/Power Engineering Society (IEEE/PES) summer meeting, San Francisco, CA (United States), 24-28 Jul 1994; Other Information: PBD: Mar 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITCNE4; ISSN 0885-8969; TRN: IM9520%%486

TITLE: Design of an optimal robust governor for hydraulic turbine generating units
AUTHORS: Jiang, J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; SPEED REGULATORS; TURBOGENERATORS; DESIGN; PERFORMANCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; MATHEMATICAL MODELS
DESCRIPTION: Design and analysis of a hydraulic turbine generator governor using optimal robust control methodology are presented. The approach is unique in the sense that the nonlinear characteristics of the turbine are first modeled as multiplicative uncertainties, and an optimal robust governor is designed by taking into account such uncertainties explicitly. The advantage of this approach is that the designed governor will guarantee the stability and the performance of the speed control loop for the entire turbine operating range. The performance of the new governor is shown to be superior to that of the conventional PID controller during large load disturbances. The resulting governor is only a third order. Hence, it has the same level of complexity as any other electrical-hydraulic governor in use today.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 1; Conference: 1994 Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers/Power Engineering Society (IEEE/PES) summer meeting, San Francisco, CA (United States), 24-28 Jul 1994; Other Information: PBD: Mar 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITCNE4; ISSN 0885-8969; TRN: IM9520%%491

TITLE: Past, present, and future concepts in large river ecology: How rivers function and how human activities influence river processes
AUTHORS: Johnson, B L; Richardson, W B; Naimo, T J
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; RIVERS; ECOLOGY
DESCRIPTION: This article reviews the current concepts on how flowing water, or lotic, systems function and suggest ways to expand these concepts to increase understanding of large river systems. Topics covered include the following: past and present approaches to physical and biological concepts of stream organization; the river-continuum concept; the flood-pulse concept; deficiencies of the current hypotheses (linear versis hierachical, physical verses biological control, equilibrium versus disequilibrium); future directions for large river research. 63 refs., 4 figs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Bioscience; Journal Volume: 45; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: Mar 1995

TITLE: What`s at stake in the Pacific Northwest salmon debate? Jobs, hydropower, agriculture, fish harvests...species survival
AUTHORS: Gillis, A M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SALMON; POPULATION DYNAMICS; HABITAT; DAMS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; FISHERIES; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: This article highlights the debate about the pacific salmon in the Pacific Northwest. The population levels of all salmonid species are down precipitously, with some listed as endangered, but no one has come up with a salmon restoration plan that is perceived to be both effective and painless to all the human parties with a vested interest. The Salmon issue touches everyone in the region directly or indirectly. Discussed are the following general topics: devising a plan for the salmon and the politics of planning and the problem of how the four fundamental areas, hydropower, habitat, hatcheries, and harvest, need to be prioritized.
RELATION: Journal Name: Bioscience; Journal Volume: 45; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: Mar 1995

TITLE: Can large rivers be restored? Most restoration projects are only attempts to rehabilitate selected river sections to a predetermined structure and function
AUTHORS: Gore, J A; Shields, Jr, F D
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; RIVERS; REMEDIAL ACTION; BIOLOGICAL RECOVERY
DESCRIPTION: Riverine ecosystems are remarkably resilient in their ability to recover from physical and chemical disturbances. If the disturbance occurs as a pulse, recover to the ecosystems`s original condition often occurs. However, if the disturbance is sustained and causes complete loss of critical habitat elements, ecological integrity cannot be maintained. Because running water ecosystems are so intimately tired to physical, chemical, and biological processes that occur throughout the catchment restoration is a complex and difficult task. Restoration and rehabilitation projects on small streams and rivers have been common practice for many years; however, restoration and rehabilitation projects for large river systems are far less common, and there is little ability to predict success or monitor recovery. Renewal of physical and biological interactions between the main channel, backwaters, and flood plains is central to rehabilitation. This article discusses the following topics in some detail: River channel manipulations; Backwater treatments; riparian zone and floodplain alterations; flow regulation; predicting recovery rates. 66 refs., 6 figs. 2 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Bioscience; Journal Volume: 45; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: Mar 1995

TITLE: Elkhorn ruling boosts state authority
AUTHORS: Beecher, H A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; WATER QUALITY; REGULATIONS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; STREAMS; FLOW RATE; SALMON; ECOLOGY
DESCRIPTION: On 31 May 1994, a landmark U.S. Supreme Court decision expanded state authority to establish conditions to protect water quality and included stream flows, aesthetics, and, potentially, other elements in a broad definition of water quality. Called the {open_quotes}Elkhorn case{close_quotes} the Supreme Court ruled that the state of Washington Department of Ecology has authority to set instream flows for fish (primarily steelhead, chinook, and coho salmon) as a condition of a Water Quality Certification (WQC) issued by the state under Section 401 of the federal Clean Water Act (CWA). The case surrounded the petitioners (applicants) proposed building of the Elkhorn Hydroelectric Project on the Dosewallips River, Washington. The project would have consisted of a dam near the boundary of Olympic National Park and a pipeline to carry diverted water around a 1.2-mile bypass reach to a powerhouse at Olympic National Forest`s Elkhorn Campground.
RELATION: Journal Name: Fisheries; Journal Volume: 20; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: Mar 1995

TITLE: Adaptive speed control of hydrogenerators by recursive least squares identification algorithm
AUTHORS: Bonnett, S C; Wozniak, L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBOGENERATORS; SPEED REGULATORS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RESPONSE FUNCTIONS; FOURIER TRANSFORMATION; HYDRAULIC TURBINES
DESCRIPTION: An inherent challenge to hydrogenerator speed regulation is the nonlinear and time varying nature of the process. When a fixed gain controller is used to regulate such a process, globally stable system response can be achieved only at the expense of degraded off design-point performance. This paper considers the application of an adaptive control methodology that allows the controller gains to automatically adjust to changing process variables and thereby provide uniform closed loop response over a wide range of operating conditions. Preliminary findings derived from a calculated plant model, and a standard recursive identification technique, indicate that the adaptive system provides desirable dynamic response despite changes in system operating dynamics, maintaining stable operation in situations where constant gain schedules fail.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 1; Conference: 1994 Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers/Power Engineering Society (IEEE/PES) summer meeting, San Francisco, CA (United States), 24-28 Jul 1994; Other Information: PBD: Mar 1995

TITLE: The future of renewable energy industries
AUTHORS: Silverman, M; Worthman, S
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; 17 WIND ENERGY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 14 SOLAR ENERGY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 09 BIOMASS FUELS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; BIOMASS; PHOTOVOLTAIC CONVERSION; WIND POWER; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; SOLAR THERMAL CONVERSION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; FORECASTING; USA; ECONOMICS; ENERGY RECOVERY; REFUSE DERIVED FUELS; ENERGY POLICY; INVESTMENT
DESCRIPTION: Investment and innovation in renewable energy - a key element of any long-term energy strategy - will not occur unless developers and investors perceive the industry to be attractive over time. The long-term attractiveness of renewable energy industries should be maintained, for the sake of jobs, energy security, the environment, and our international competitiveness.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electricity Journal; Journal Volume: 8; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Mar 1995

TITLE: Decentralized planning of hydroelectric power systems
AUTHORS: Binato, S; Pereira, M V.F.
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; CAPACITY; POWER SYSTEMS; MARGINAL-COST PRICING; POWER DEMAND
DESCRIPTION: This paper discusses the application of marginal cost concepts to the expansion planning of hydroelectric systems. It is shown that the renumeration of hydroelectric plants should not be based on their energy production, as this leads to excessive revenues for the plant owner, and distorts the dimensioning of upstream reservoirs. In order to produce the adequate economic signals, it is necessary to separate the contributions of turbines and reservoirs. Examples from the Brazilian power system are presented and discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems; Journal Volume: 10; Journal Issue: 1; Conference: 1994 Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers/Power Engineering Society (IEEE/PES) summer meeting, San Francisco, CA (United States), 24-28 Jul 1994; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1995

TITLE: Integrated renewable energy systems
AUTHORS: Ramakumar, R
SUBJECT: 09 BIOMASS FUELS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 14 SOLAR ENERGY; 17 WIND ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; MEETINGS; RURAL AREAS; ENERGY DEMAND; REMOTE AREAS; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; ENERGY EFFICIENCY
DESCRIPTION: Utilization of several manifestations of solar energy in tandem by means of integrated renewable energy systems (IRES) to supply a variety of energy and other needs has the potential to energize (in contrast to electrification) remote rural areas in a cost-effective manner. Such actions can dramatically improve the quality of life for hundreds of millions of people living in remote villages in the continents of Asia, Africa, and Latin America. The environmentally benign nature of renewable resource utilization and the potability of exploiting locally available resources with the consequent growth of job opportunities are some of the many benefits that can accrue by the deployment of IRES. Even small amounts of energy can be very beneficial in remote rural areas of developing countries with no grid connection as compared to the massive urban sprawls in both developed and developing countries. A concerted global effort in this direction can build the much-needed market potential for renewables now, resulting in future cost reductions. Summaries of the three panel session presentations are assembled here for the readers of the IEEE Power Engineering Review: Designing an Integrated Renewable Energy System, by K. Ashenayi, The University of Tulsa, Tulsa, Oklahoma; Africa-1000: Water in Thousands of Villages, by C. Kashkari Founder, Africa-1000, The University of Akron, Akron, Ohio; Renewables in Mexico, by J. Gutierrez-Vera, Energia Del Siglo 21, Mexico D.F.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Power Engineering Review; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: IPERDV; ISSN 0272-1724; TRN: IM9519%%10

TITLE: Dynamic response of concrete-faced rockfill dams to strong seismic excitation
AUTHORS: Uddin, N; Gazetas, G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; RESPONSE FUNCTIONS; STRESS ANALYSIS; CALCULATION METHODS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RISK ASSESSMENT; FAILURES
DESCRIPTION: A dynamic plane-strain finite-element study of the response of a typical 100-m-tall concrete-faced rockfill (CFR) dam to strong seismic shaking is presented. The rockfill is modeled as an equivalent-linear material, whose strain-dependent shear modulus is proportional to the square root of the confining pressure. Coulomb`s friction law governs the behavior of the interface between face slab and dam, and slippage is allowed to occur whenever the seismic shear tractions exceed the pertinent frictional capacity. Two sets of historic accelerograms, with peak ground accelerations (PGA) of about 0.40g and 0.60g, respectively, are used as excitation. Numerical results highlight key aspects of the seismic response of CFR dams with emphasis on the internal forces developing in the slab. It is shown that slab distress may be produced only from axial tensile forces, developing due mainly to the rocking component of dam deformation. For the 0.60g shaking tensile stresses that are much higher than the likely tensile strength of concrete develop in the slab. The presented results do not account for potentially detrimental three-dimensional (3D) narrow-canyon effects.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Geotechnical Engineering; Journal Volume: 121; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1995
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: JGENDZ; ISSN 0733-9410; TRN: IM9520%%115

TITLE: Aligning vertical shaft hydro units
AUTHORS: Cline, R A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; VERTICAL AXIS TURBINES; MECHANICAL SHAFTS; ALIGNMENT
DESCRIPTION: To prevent equipment failures resulting from misaligned shafts, U.S. Bureau of Reclamation hydro personnel use standard procedures for aligning vertical shaft hydro units after maintenance. The procedures rely on traditional approaches to shaft alignment, as well as on newer, laser-based technologies.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 14; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1995

TITLE: Examining the benefits and costs of fish passage and protection measures
AUTHORS: Cada, G F; Francfort, J E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS
DESCRIPTION: Using 16 U.S. hydroelectric projects as case studies, researchers have determined that fish passage/protection mitigation measures are generally effective. What`s missing are better ways of correlating the wide-ranging costs of these measures with increased value of the fishery resource.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 14; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1995

TITLE: Using a computer spreadsheet for calculating turbine performance
AUTHORS: Howe, J C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; PERFORMANCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTER CALCULATIONS
DESCRIPTION: In today`s competitive electricity market, power producers building new hydro plants or rehabilitating existing ones must select equipment offering optimal performance. Using a simple computer spreadsheet, hydro plant owners and engineers can quickly and inexpensively determine the optimal turbine size and specification for a particular site.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 14; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1995

TITLE: Conservation of water resources problems of small rivers in Russia
AUTHORS: Koronkevich, N I; Eliseev, D A; Yasinskii, S V
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; RUSSIAN FEDERATION; WATER RESOURCES; RIVERS; RESOURCE MANAGEMENT
DESCRIPTION: This article briefly discusses a number of issues associated with resource development around small rivers in countries of the Russian Federation. Small rivers usually include those with a drainage area up to 2000 cubic kilometers or length not to exceed 100 kilometers The problems of small rivers are among the key problems of hydrology, ecology, and water management, and the unfavorable situations are expressed mainly in pollution by domestic and industrial waste waters. Additionally, the water regime of small rivers has deteriorated due to irrational clearing of forests, ill-considered irrigation, and excessive plowing of the teritory. These problems and efforts to correct them are discussed in this article.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 8; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 8, 1-5(Aug 1994)

TITLE: Dynamics of the Ili delta with consideration of fluctuations of the level of Lake Balkhash
AUTHORS: Abdrasilov, S A; Tulebaeva, K A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; RIVER DELTAS; HYDROLOGY; WATER RESOURCES; RESOURCE MANAGEMENT; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: This article examines the dynamics of the Ili delta region of Russia, with consideration of the fluctuations of the level of Lake Balkhash. Level fluctuations over a period of approximately 700 years are reviewed, and numerical data is presented. It is shown that the dynamics of the delta region affect both the amplitude and duration of the cycle of fluctuations of the lake level. In particular, the phase of the delta cycle that started cuts off the peak of the maximum ordinate of the level at the end of the tranasgressive period reduces still more the minimum elevations of the lake level at the end of the regressive period. It also accelerates the time of occurence of individual phases of the intrasecular cycle.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 8; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 8, 9-12(Aug 1994)

TITLE: Hydraulic resistance of vegetated channels
AUTHORS: Borovkov, V S; Yurchuk, M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; RIVERS; HYDROLOGY; PLANT GROWTH; DIAGRAMS; FLOW MODELS; RUSSIAN FEDERATION; EXPERIMENTAL DATA
DESCRIPTION: Vegetation of river and canal channels can have serious consequences of a hydraulic nature. For example, vegetation of canals protects the bed and side slopes of canals from erosion, increases the non-eroding velocities in the canal, and can serve as a cheap method of stabilizing the slopes of hydraulic structures. On the other hand, vegetation can reduce the channel capacity. As a result, a prediction of changes in the hydraulic elements of flows in connection with the degree of vegetation of its channel is necessary for improving methods of hydraulic calculations of vegetated canals. This article reports on experimental investigations on two hydraulic flumes in which artificial methods and naturally grown wheat were utilized to simulate the vegetation. An analytic method is presented to calculate the flow resistance, and the results are compared to the experimental data with excellent agreement.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 8; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 8, 16-19(Aug 1994)

TITLE: New theoretical and methodological aspects of the organization of water-resources management
AUTHORS: Kravchuk, V S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; WATER RESOURCES; RESOURCE MANAGEMENT; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: The scientific principles of a study of the problem of the organization, planning, and management of water resources are in the stage of creative search, and with respect to many theoretical and methodological problems, specialists still do not have a unified viewpoint. Success in improving water-resources management will depend largely on an analysis of preceding experience in creating water-resources utilization systems, scientific knowledge of economic conflicts, construction of an appropriate theory, formulation of the taks and goals of management, finding the levers and tools for accomplishing them, and consideration of system-forming factors.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 8; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 8, 22-23(Aug 1994)

TITLE: Effect of economic activity on the hydrologic regime an dynamics of the Ili delta
AUTHORS: Kipshakbaev, N K; Abdrasilov, S A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; WATER RESOURCES; RESOURCE MANAGEMENT; RIVER DELTAS; HYDROLOGY; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: This article considers the hydrologic effects in the Ili delta region in Russia. The delta region is described, as are the effects of discharge from the Kapchagai hydroelectric power plant, flooding, sedimentation, runoff, and icing.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 8; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 8, 5-8(Aug 1994)

TITLE: Determination of backwaters and local head losses at stream junctions
AUTHORS: Altunin, V S; Mukhamedov, D A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; RIVERS; HYDROLOGY; JUNCTIONS; DIAGRAMS; RUSSIAN FEDERATION; FLOW MODELS
DESCRIPTION: When designing and operating junctions of natural and articial streams, an important consideration is an estimation of the backwaters occuring in the upper stretch of the main channel and tributary as a result of joining open-channel flows. Laboratory investigations were carried out on a large experimental device at the Central Asian Irrigation Research Institute to determine this. The junction of two rectangular horizontal plumes was constructed on this device. The investigations showed that the joining of two open channel flows is accompanied by alternate squeezing of one flow by the other, as a result of which considerable deformation of the water surface occurs. Backwaters occur in the upper stretch of the main channel and in the tributary, and transverse slants of the water surface form at the junction below it.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 8; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 8, 13-15(Aug 1994)

TITLE: Characteristics of hydraulic calculation of nonuniform motion
AUTHORS: Tarasov, V K; Sazonova, M Yu; Zhigunova, O B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; RIVERS; HYDROLOGY; TURBULENT FLOW; RUSSIAN FEDERATION; ANALYTIC FUNCTIONS
DESCRIPTION: This article examines certain characteristics of hydraulic calcuation methods as applied to nonuniform flow in the Moscow Canal. The differential equations for nonuniform motion are presented, as is the integral expression arising from it. It is shown that the method of integration is permissible for changes with a positive bottom slope and evidently is not permissible for horizontal channels.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 8; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 8, 20-21(Aug 1994)

TITLE: Determination of the characteristics of river runoff
AUTHORS: Aliev, T A; Kartvelishvili, L N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; RIVERS; HYDROLOGY; RUNOFF; RUSSIAN FEDERATION; ANALYTIC FUNCTIONS
DESCRIPTION: In hydrology, one usually deals with statistical moments of positive orders not higher than third order. As a rule, therefore, three-parameter probability distributions of hydrologic characteristics are used. It is also possible to use moments of fractional or negative orders if the available observations are sufficient for their calculation. This article addresses the solution of the integral equation in which M(y) is a consistent and unbiased estimate of order y of the discharge coefficient x of a river, and y runs through all values for which calculation of M(y) is possible. Expressions for the second and third moments are determined, and methods for determining moments for 0 < y < 3 are also discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 8; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 8, 21-22(Aug 1994)

TITLE: Completing Rio Bobos
AUTHORS: Hennagir, T
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; GUATEMALA; ENERGY DEMAND; ELECTRIC POWER INDUSTRY; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; MICRO-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; CENTRAL AMERICA
DESCRIPTION: Small-scale hydropower projects remain an attractive target for equipment vendors active in Central America. Projects less than 20 MW in capacity continue to evolve as countries such as Guatemala work to meet a quickening energy demand. Regulatory change continues to shape Guatemala`s private power market. In December, a new decree was passed allowing third-party energy sales, a move that has restructured the country`s electrical sector.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; Journal Volume: 25; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jan 1995

TITLE: Developable resources
AUTHORS: Hunt, R T; Hunt, J M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; INTEREST GROUPS; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS
DESCRIPTION: In the United States, it has become the conventional wisdom that all developable conventional hydropower resources have been exhausted. Studies by the US Department of Energy (DOE) and other agencies find differently. The root of disagreement may lie in the definition of what is developable. Environmental special interest groups now define developable hydropower sites as those having zero effect on the environment. As a result they conclude there are no additional developable hydropower sites. By contrast, the definition used by DOE and others is broader as it balances economic, technical, and environmental factors in accordance with the Federal Power Act.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; Journal Volume: 25; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jan 1995

TITLE: An approach to the diagnosis and treatment of depleted Pacific salmon populations in Pacific Northwest watersheds
AUTHORS: Lichatowich, J; Mobrand, L; Lestelle, L; Vogel, T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; SALMON; HABITAT; BIOLOGICAL RECOVERY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; WATERSHEDS; AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS; ENDANGERED SPECIES
DESCRIPTION: We propose an approach to the development of restoration programs for Pacific anadromous salmon that recognizes the importance of an ecosystem perspective. Important concepts such as habitat complexity and self-organizing capacity of the stock are reviewed. A planning process comprised of six steps is described. The approach includes a comparison of historic and current habitat complexity and connectivity and intrapopulation life history diversity. Uncertainties are incorporated into the planning process through assumptions that are clearly identified. Risk of project failure is determined through a qualitative or quantitative weighing of the critical uncertainties. We emphasize the concept that restoration planning is an iterative process that must be continued after implementation. 60 refs., 2 figs., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Fisheries; Journal Volume: 20; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jan 1995

TITLE: Specific features of mercury migration in the Katun` River Basin
AUTHORS: Papina, T S; Artem`eva, S S; Temerev, S V
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; MERCURY; ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSPORT; DISTRIBUTION; RIVERS; WATER POLLUTION; SEDIMENTS; RUNOFF; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SITE CHARACTERIZATION
DESCRIPTION: A comprehensive study (1988-1991) of the mercury behavior features in the basins of the Katun` and the Upper Ob rivers in different hydrological phases is analyzed. The main observation objects were water, suspended matter, bottom sediments, and biota.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resources; Journal Volume: 22; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jan-Feb 1995; TN: Translated from Vodnye Resursy; 22: No. 1, 60-66(1995)

TITLE: Principles of special model construction in solving problems of heavy metal migration in natural waters
AUTHORS: Belevantsev, V I; Sukhenko, S A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 99 MATHEMATICS, COMPUTERS, INFORMATION SCIENCE, MANAGEMENT, LAW, MISCELLANEOUS; MERCURY; ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSPORT; ECOLOGICAL CONCENTRATION; RIVERS; WATER POLLUTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SITE CHARACTERIZATION; SEDIMENTS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS
DESCRIPTION: A system of methodological principles for constructing models of the heavy metal state in natural water solutions is formulated. It is based on the concepts of local and partial equilibria, as well as on the notions of {open_quotes}original{close_quotes} systems, completeness of description, degree of detailing, and expedient decompositions. The above principles are used to interpret a series of field data on the condition of surface water in the Upper Ob` Basin and, in particular, to analyze the forms of mercury occurrence in the water.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resources; Journal Volume: 22; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jan-Feb 1995; TN: Translated from Vodnye Resursy; 22: No. 1, 85-89(1995)

TITLE: Variations in the mercury content of the Katun` River water
AUTHORS: Vizhin, V V; Gogolev, A Z; Sagdeev, R Z; Saprykin, A V; Friezen, L F
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; MERCURY; ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSPORT; ECOLOGICAL CONCENTRATION; RIVERS; WATER POLLUTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SITE CHARACTERIZATION; SEDIMENTS; CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; GEOCHEMISTRY
DESCRIPTION: The scale of temporal variations in the mercury content of the Katun` River water is discussed. The correlation between the content of mercury in suspended form and the mineral and granulometric composition of suspended matter is analyzed. The process of transforming the spatial nonhomogeneity of the mercury distribution over the catchment area into the temporal nonhomogeneity of the mercury content in water is discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resources; Journal Volume: 22; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jan-Feb 1995; TN: Translated from Vodnye Resursy; 22: No. 1, 67-70(1995)

TITLE: The experimental study of the behavior of toxic elements in the water-rock and water-soil systems in connection with planning the Katun` Water and power project
AUTHORS: Ptitsyn, A B; Lemina, N M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; MERCURY; ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSPORT; ECOLOGICAL CONCENTRATION; RIVERS; WATER POLLUTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SITE CHARACTERIZATION; SEDIMENTS; CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; GEOCHEMISTRY
DESCRIPTION: The behavior of mercury and some other toxic elements during the interaction of rocks, bottom sediments, and soils of the Katun` River Basin with natural waters under different hydrodynamic and physicochemical conditions is discussed. It is shown that in experiments with common rocks and soils the Hg, Cd, Sb, and As concentrations in solution are no greater than the MPCs. The results of experiments for estimating the content of the mobile forms of heavy metals in soils are analyzed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resources; Journal Volume: 22; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jan-Feb 1995; TN: Translated from Vodnye Resursy; 22: No. 1, 71-77(1995)

TITLE: The probability of mercury methylation and bioaccumulation in the reservoir of the planned Katun` Hydropower Plant
AUTHORS: Sukhenko, S A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; MERCURY; ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSPORT; ECOLOGICAL CONCENTRATION; RIVERS; WATER POLLUTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SITE CHARACTERIZATION; WATER RESERVOIRS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; SEDIMENTS; CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; GEOCHEMISTRY
DESCRIPTION: The study is based on the findings of the comprehensive studies of the Katun` River Basin (in the Gornyi Altai Mountains) interpreted in the light of modern concepts of mercury migration patterns in water bodies to predict the mercury behavior in the Katun` Hydroelectric Power Plant reservoir. It is demonstrated that, under the specific reservoir conditions, including the relatively small flooded area, low organic matter content in the flooded soils, high water exchange rate and great depth, low temperatures and the hydrochemical regime features, substantial annual coverage of the bed with the river mineral suspended matter, possible ultra-oligotrophy, no intensive methylation processes, and mercury bioaccumulation are expected.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resources; Journal Volume: 22; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jan-Feb 1995; TN: Translated from Vodnye Resursy; 22: No. 1, 78-84(1995)

TITLE: The geochemical conditions of mercury migration in the ground water of the area of the planned Katun` Hydropower Plant
AUTHORS: Shvartsev, S L; Kuskovskii, V S; Vorotnikov, B A; Lukin, A A; Kopylova, Yu G; Laperdina, T G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; MERCURY; ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSPORT; GROUND WATER; GEOCHEMISTRY; ROCK-FLUID INTERACTIONS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SITE CHARACTERIZATION; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS
DESCRIPTION: The results of hydrogeochemical investigations in the Katun` River Basin are presented. The investigations were conducted under the program of the Siberian Division of the Russian Academy of Sciences to predict the environmental aftereffects of the construction of the planned Katun` Hydropower Plant. The hydrogeological conditions, ground-water chemical composition, and spatial and temporal regularities of mercury distribution in ground water are discussed. The mercury balance in the main components of the water-rock system (primary rocks, ground water, and secondary minerals) is determined, using a special technique; the mercury behavior after the probable construction of a reservoir is predicted.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resources; Journal Volume: 22; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jan-Feb 1995; TN: Translated from Vodnye Resursy; 22: No. 1, 50-59(1995)

TITLE: Making hydro sustainable
AUTHORS: Russo, T N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT
DESCRIPTION: Most electric utilities in the United States and abroad probably think of hydropower as a renewable energy resource-an ideal example of sustainable energy. But that assumption isn`t necessarily true, even though on a global scale hydro serves 20 percent of electric consumption and offsets 539 million metric tons of carbon equivalent annually, through avoided carbon dioxide (CO{sub 2}) emissions. In fact, many in the United States and international environmental community now classify hydro as the {open_quotes}unsustainable renewable{close_quotes}. This characterization is unfortunate. Hydropower still offers one of the most effective ways of achieving sustainability and accelerating the transition to renewable energy.
RELATION: Journal Name: Fortnightly; Journal Volume: 133; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: 1 Jan 1995

TITLE: Use of nonlinear models in soil mechanics
AUTHORS: Kushner, S G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; BUILDINGS; FOUNDATIONS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; SOIL MECHANICS
DESCRIPTION: The discussion about the expediency of presently using nonlinear soil mechanics in calculations of bases of industrial and residential buildings begun by B.I. Dalmatov in [1] is continued.
RELATION: Journal Name: Soil Mechanics and Foundation Engineering; Journal Volume: 31; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Jan 1995; TN: Translated from Osnovaniya, Fundamenty i Mekhanika Gruntov; No. 4, 11-13(Jul-Aug 1994)

TITLE: Use of static probing to determine the resistance of piles of circular cross section with an open lower end
AUTHORS: Mitkina, G V
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FOUNDATIONS; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOILS; SOIL MECHANICS; PROBES
DESCRIPTION: A method of evaluating the verticle-load resistance of circular piles with an open end from the results of static probing is cited. Limiting pile resistances, as determined by testing, are compared with consideration given to coefficients proposed by the author, which are given in Construction Rule and Regulation 2.02.03-85. The program {open_quotes}KOL `TsO{close_quotes}, which automates circulation of the bearing capacity of a circular pile from static-probe data, is developed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Soil Mechanics and Foundation Engineering; Journal Volume: 31; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Jan 1995; TN: Translated from Osnovaniya, Fundamenty i Mekhanika Gruntov; No. 4, 6-10(Jul-Aug 1994)

TITLE: Construction of low-volume sectional concrete dams
AUTHORS: Suleimanov, I A.G.; Sokolov, I B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; DESIGN
DESCRIPTION: The article first proposes categorization of dams based on volume of material in the dam body. Concrete dams containing up to 1000 cubic meters of concrete are the focus of the remainder of the article. Differences in construction between large and small dams are detailed, with emphasis on structural features. Labor outlays and construction schedules are also discussed. 8 refs., 3 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 7; Other Information: PBD: Jan 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 7, 37-40(Jul 1994)

TITLE: Three-dimensional seepage in the cores of rock-and-earth-fill dams
AUTHORS: Anakhaev, K N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; EMBANKMENTS; LEAKS; DAMS; SOILS; ROCKS; THREE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS
DESCRIPTION: A method of calculating three-dimensional seepage in rock and earth fill dams with cores of different profiles is presented. Since the permeability of the soil in the core is 100 or more times lower than that of the support prisms, the seepage calculation of the dam essentially reduces to determination of the required seepage parameters in the core of the dam. The proposed method is based on the analogy between traces of three-dimensional vertical seepage bands in the plane of the shore slope and streamlines with vertical plant-parrallel seepage in the core. Computational relationships for the determination of seepage parameters, such as height of leakage and position of depression surface, seepage rate, and discharge pressure gradients are given. 8 refs., 3 figs., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 7; Other Information: PBD: Jan 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 7, 24-29(Jul 1994)

TITLE: Organization of monitoring in structures of the Zagorsk pumped-storage power plant
AUTHORS: Smirnov, E A; Kuleshov, A P; Bykadorov, A A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; MONITORING; DAMS
DESCRIPTION: The Zagorsk pumped-storage power plant (PSPP) in Russia is sited on a geologically complex bed. The bed required new design structures for the PSPP. The class of structures, complex hydrogeological conditions, and new structural designs required the development of a system for operational monitoring during construction and operation. The system and its performance are detailed in this article. 6 refs., 2 figs., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 7; Other Information: PBD: Jan 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 7, 33-36(Jul 1994)

TITLE: Blasting aids in the reconstruction of a hydroelectric plant
AUTHORS: Benderskii, L F; Evlikov, A A; Stupel`, R O
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; REINFORCED CONCRETE; DEMOLITION; EXPLOSIVE FRACTURING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: The replacement of failed impeller chambers in a hydroelectric plant is described in this article. The emphasis of the article is on the use of a blast-generating unit (BGU) for crushing reinforced concrete. The BGU feeds kerosene and nitrogen tetroxide from separate tanks to form a jet of liquid explosive mixture. The BGU performed safely and efficiently, and has been recommended for use at other hydroelectric plants. 1 ref., 1 fig., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 7; Other Information: PBD: Jan 1995; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 7, 30-33(Jul 1994)

TITLE: Is hydropower an endangered species?
AUTHORS: Johansen, J A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; REGULATIONS; USA; ENERGY POLICY; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY
DESCRIPTION: This article attempts to answer critical questions about hydropower in the context of federal and state struggles over jurisdiction, social values of fisheries, wildlife, and restoration vs development, and finally the burden of complex licensing/relicensing. What role has hydropower played in the development of the electric utility industry and has societies attitude toward costs and benefits of hydropower changed drastically? Can the requirements of the Endangered Species Act be balanced with the mandate of the Energy Policy Act to address energy efficiency and global warming? Are there other innovative uses of hydropower? Can hydropower be cost-effective? Can federal agencies work cooperatively with other entities to effectively use hydropower.
RELATION: Journal Name: Natural Resources and Environment; Journal Volume: 8; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: Win 1994

TITLE: Winter diet and weights of Barrow`s and common goldeneye in southcentral Washington
AUTHORS: Fitzner, R E; Gray, R H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; COLUMBIA RIVER; BASELINE ECOLOGY; BIRDS; WEIGHT; DIET; POPULATION DYNAMICS; BIOLOGICAL STRESS; DATA
DESCRIPTION: Little data are available relative to diets and body weight dynamics of wintering Barrow`s and common goldeneyes in freshwater habitats, and no data exist for subadults. Diets of these birds were studied on the Columbia and Yakima Rivers in southcentral Washington from October through May 1955--1956 and 1956--1957. Trichopteran larvae accounted for more than 67% of common goldeneye and 81% of Barrow`s goldeneye food biomass. Mollusc and aquatic plant achenes were other important food items. Average weights of common goldeneye ranged from 599.3{+-}39.86 g for subadult females to 1,060.2{+-}33.36 g for adult males. Average weights of Barrow`s goldeneye ranged from 736.0{+-}44.73 g for subadult females to 1,330.5{+-}18.69 g for adult males. Body-weight dynamics of birds may reflect resource availability, competition, and bioenergetics, all of which may influence winter distribution, differential migration and habitat use by sexes.
RELATION: Journal Name: Northwest Science; Journal Volume: 68; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: 1994

TITLE: Using pre-cast concrete blocks to prevent erosion of dams and weirs
AUTHORS: Baker, R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; EROSION; EMBANKMENTS; CONCRETE BLOCKS; DESIGN; STABILITY
DESCRIPTION: Most hydro projects include a facility to allow water flow in excess of the turbine capacity to safely bypass the impounding structure and power station. For river schemes, a weir is typically used; for larger dams, a full spillway is required. Pre-cast concrete blocks can provide economical erosion protection for overflow sections of earth and rockfill dams and weirs. Wedge-shaped blocks, especially, can offer an efficient approach to providing needed protection. This article this option.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 2; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Sum 1994

TITLE: Bulletins examine dam issues
AUTHORS: Ervine, A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; STABILITY; EMBANKMENTS; FILLERS
DESCRIPTION: This month`s Tech Notes includes discussions of bulletins on upstream slope protection of embankment dams, dams and environmental geophysical impacts, rock materials for rockfill dams, and a scathing review of various hydro efforts accross the world.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 2; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Sum 1994

TITLE: Taming a {open_quotes}difficult{close_quotes} hydro plant
AUTHORS: Luraas, H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INTAKE STRUCTURES; FLOW RATE; NORWAY; STABILITY
DESCRIPTION: The dynamics of an individual project can unexpectedly challenge accepted engineering approaches. Engineers on the Jostedal project in Norway overcame {open_quotes}the impossible{close_quotes} by employing the non-traditional. Jostedal Power Station in western Norway was commissioned in late 1989. The 288-MW project has a five-jet, vertical Pelton turbine and maximum head of 1,186 meters. The intake consists of a 35-kilometer-long low-pressure tunnel from the main project reservoir. In addition to the main reservoir system, the waterway has 19 inlets from streams and rivers along its run. Some of the inlets have their own headrace tunnels; the remainder enter the main tunnel by short shafts. The main waterway empties into a 781-meter-long inclined penstock connected to the Jostedal powerhouse.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 2; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Spr 1994

TITLE: Reducing corrosion in underground powerhouses
AUTHORS: Bjark, T; Gurigard, K
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CORROSION; DEHUMIDIFICATION
DESCRIPTION: This article addresses the mitigation of corrosion in underground power houses. This is a persistent problem on pipes, valves, and mechanical equipment in underground hydroelectric powerhouses. Engineers with a Norwegian utility have installed absorption humidifiers in some of their facilites. This equipment has maintained relative humidity and has virtually eliminated corrosion on exposed metal surfaces in the plants.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 2; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: Fal 1994

TITLE: Using condition monitoring for maintenance, control of hydro plants
AUTHORS: Brown, N; Varo, R; Morras, F A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; MONITORING; MAINTENANCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ON-LINE SYSTEMS; SPAIN
DESCRIPTION: Electric utilities are actively seeking ways of optimizing the economics of their operations by improving productivity and reducing time and money spent on maintenance. Iberdrola, a Spanish utility, is using advanced machine condition-monitoring technology to centralize control and maintenance of its hydropower projects as a means of achieving those goals. The company is using a blend of technologies to supervise their projects from a regional control center. The monitoring scheme makes use of data from on-line, machine-condition monitors, displays from in-plant audio asnd video equipment, and analysis from the control center`s SCADA system.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 2; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Sum 1994

TITLE: Monitoring embankment dams in Hungary
AUTHORS: Gresz, I L; Nagy, I M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; EMBANKMENTS; DISPLACEMENT RATES; FLUID FLOW; MONITORING
DESCRIPTION: Owners of embankment dams in Hungary have been extensively monitoring their structures for several years. The result is a compilation of data that can be used to ensure the safety of the country`s dams for years to come. This article reviews the historical aspects of safety surveillance at dams in Hungary and makes note of the methodolody used for displacement measurements and hydraulic meaurements.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 2; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: Fal 1994

TITLE: Geotextile guide offered
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CROSSFLOW SYSTEMS; DESIGN; HYDRAULIC TURBINES
DESCRIPTION: This month`s Tech Notes includes: (1) a design and installation manual for a cross-flow tubine, and (2) a guide for the use of geotextiles in hydro engineering.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 2; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: Fal 1994

TITLE: Using automated equipment for cleaning trashracks
AUTHORS: Schneeberger, H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; INTAKE STRUCTURES; SCREENS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; AUTOMATION
DESCRIPTION: Cleaning trashracks on intakes of hydro plants is a common maintenance problem throughout the world. With automated equipment options now available, operators can clean racks and dispose of debris more economically, safer, and in a more environmentally compatible manner than ever before. Before selecting an option, plant owners should consider their specific situation, including the capacity of the plant, water flow and velocity, the amount and types of debris in the water, size of the tashracks, time taken to clean large intakes, and the physical setup of the intake when closing the machine. This article is a review of the several options available.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 2; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Sum 1994

TITLE: Using jacks to simplify generator repairs
AUTHORS: Horne, J V
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; STATORS; MAINTENANCE; REMOVAL; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: This article discusses the experiences of British Columbia Hydro personnel in their efforts to rewind the generator at a 60 MW facility. Without an overhead crane installed, it was necessary to use hydraulic jacks to lift the stator, thus saving $400,000 (US) over the costs of renting a crane. The details of their setup are dsecribed herein.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 2; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Sum 1994

TITLE: Practical approaches to minimizing capital costs
AUTHORS: Jagan, B R; Raj, S D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CAPITALIZED COST; CONTROL; INDIA
DESCRIPTION: Small hydro is an attractive electrical power resource option, especially when development costs are minimized. As part of its plan to develop several hundred small hydro plants in the next decade, the government of India has identified ways to reduce costs of these new plants. A critical element to the success of small hydro projects is minimizing capital costs. As part of a 1991 study of proposed small hydro plants, capital costs were divided into three areas: (1) hydro-mechanical equipment, (2) electrical equipment, and (3) civil structures. Based on their experiences, some practical ways of reducing capital costs for mechanical and electrical equipment in small hydroelectric projects.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 2; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Spr 1994

TITLE: Tech notes
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; MONITORING; ON-LINE MEASUREMENT SYSTEMS; RISK ASSESSMENT; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CAPITALIZED COST; THERMAL STRESSES; COMPUTER CODES; SOUTH AUSTRALIA
DESCRIPTION: This month`s Tech Notes include: (1) development of a monitoring system for the condition of generator windings, (2) issuance of a report on hydro opportunities in India and Pakistan and the rest of Asia, (3) discussion of a software program for 3-D modeling of thermal stresses, (4) bulletins and reports on structural aspects of dams, and (5) small hydro opportunities worldwide.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 2; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Spr 1994

TITLE: Gaining flexibility, value with adjustable-speed hydro
AUTHORS: Kita, Eizo; Ohno, Yasuteru
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; DESIGN; OPERATION; FREQUENCY CONTROL; POWER SYSTEMS; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: Electric power producers are being called on to provide both high quality and cost-effective service, while achieving an increasingly complex array of other economic and operational goals. A joining of pumped storage and adjustable-speed hydro technologies holds the promise of providing the power industry with a new tool for responding to the challenges of change. This paper outlines the experiences of Kansai Electric Power Company in the development and operation of the world`s largest adjustable speed unit...a 400 MWe pump-generator at Ohkawachi Power Station in Japan.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 2; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Win 1994

TITLE: Making the old better with new machines
AUTHORS: Byers, W
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; OPERATION; FREQUENCY CONTROL; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS
DESCRIPTION: To many hydroelectric professionals, the most interesting potential for the adjustable-speed generating equipment now operating at the Kansai Electric Power Company`s (KEPCO) Ohkawachi Power Station is Japan and at other sites lies in how the new machinery may improve old projects. They believe the capabilities of the equipment to operate efficiently under a wide range of conditions eventually may have broad application in modernization, rehabilitiation, and upgrading of existing hydro sites worldwide. Experts in the field also believe adjustable-speed generating and pumping equipment may make hydroelectric facilities economic at flood-control, water supply, and irrigation projects where power generation previously was not feasible.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 2; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Win 1994

TITLE: Ideas in Action: Keeping hydro units aligned
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; ALIGNMENT; MAINTENANCE; UGANDA
DESCRIPTION: Ongoing concrete growth in the powerhouse at the Uganda Electricity Board`s 150-MW Owen Falls Power Station created alignment problems in eight of the plant`s ten hydroelectric units and threatened to limit the effectiveness of an upgrade and life-extension program. Engineers for the board and its refurbishment consultant devised a method for periodic realignment with a minimum of downtime and expense. The Uganda Electricity Board (UEB) commissioned and ten 15-MW vertical Kaplan turbines at Owen Falls on the Victoria Nile River between 1954 and 1968. Cracks began to appear in the concrete powerhouse as early as 1964. In a 1991 investigation, the cracks were determined to have been caused by alkali-silicate reaction, in which the alkalis in the cement react with the silicate particles embedded in the coarse aggregate. After a number of years, the reaction causes the concrete to increase in volume, or {open_quotes}grow{close_quotes}, though it does not lose its ability to carry compression loads.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 2; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Win 1994

TITLE: State control over the destiny of hydropower development: PUD No. 1 v. Washington Department of Ecology
AUTHORS: Horton, C D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; LICENSING REGULATIONS; ECOLOGY; STATE GOVERNMENT
DESCRIPTION: The debate over hydropower development exemplifies an apparent environmental unrest as proponents of hydroelectric power generation battle advancing arguments about the omnipresent potential such development has on watershed hydraulics and the environment. However, most would agree that the debate over hydropower development revolves around jurisdictional distribution and the authority to regulate development. For all practical purposes, hydroelectric licensing has been the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission`s (FERC`s or Commission`s) exclusive domain. The prevailing assumption after the Supreme Court`s interpretation of the Federal Power Act (FPA) in First Iowa Hydro-Electric Cooperative v. FPC was that the Federal Power Commission (FPC), now FERC, possessed ultimate authority over the regulation of hydropower development. This presumption was reaffirmed in California v. FERC (Rock Creek), decided almost forty years later.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Law Journal; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: 1994

TITLE: States improve dam safety legislation and regulations
AUTHORS: Spragens, L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; SAFETY; STATE GOVERNMENT; LEGISLATION; LICENSING REGULATIONS; MASSACHUSETTS; MINNESOTA; NEW JERSEY; NEW YORK; SOUTH CAROLINA; WASHINGTON; WYOMING; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; NORTH AMERICA; REGULATIONS; USA; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 130800 - Hydro Energy- Health & Safety- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Several state dam safety agencies have helped their state governments pass new dam safety legislation of regulations during the past year. Improvements in the laws range from establishing or raising permit fees, to boosting requirements for professional licenses, to requiring emergency action plans for all significant and high-hazard dams. ASDSO tracks dam safety legislation and laws to help keep the association's members informed on progress in dam safety. In New Jersey, lawmakers passed legislation providing $1.7 million in loans for engineering studies on high-hazard dams. Similarly in Minnesota, lawmakers approved legislation providing $1.6 million for repair or removal of dams. In Colorado, new legislation creates an emergency dam repair cash fund for state engineers to cover costs of emergency actions. In South Carolina, the General Assembly passed major amendments to the Dams and Reservoirs Safety Act. The amendments require that dam owners notify the state within 30 days after title to a dam is transferred, and stipulate that owners of high-hazard and significant hazard dams prepare emergency action plans. The state also may require normal maintenance on a dam; previously, the dam had to be declared unsafe before and order could be issued. A number of other states are working on new legislation, guidelines, or regulations, including Massachusetts, New York, Washington, and Wyoming. Forty-eight states have dam safety legislation in place; Alabama and Delaware are without such legislation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:3

TITLE: DSM saves the dam. [Deep Soil Mix]
AUTHORS: Walker, A D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; FAILURES; STABILIZATION; CEMENTS; SLOPE STABILITY; BUILDING MATERIALS; MATERIALS; STABILITY; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: As US dams age and deteriorate, there is a growing need to upgrade them to meet new regulations and factors of safety. This article describes how, at Lockington Dam in Ohio's Miami Valley, construction of a deep-soil-mix soil-cement cutoff wall offered the best solution, both technically and economically, to prevent potential seepage-induced failure. Seventy-five years ago, the largest single constructing project in the US was the flood-control works of the Miami Conservancy District in Ohio. Begun in 1918 and completed in 1921 at a cost of $33 million, the project included five hydraulic-fill flood-control dams and 73 mi of levees constructed in response to 10 major floods, including a catastrophic 1913 flood in Dayton, that had caused more than 1,000 deaths and $100 million in damages over the previous century.
RELATION: Journal Name: Civil Engineering (New York, 1983); (United States); Journal Volume: 64:12

TITLE: Choosing a strategy to improve spillway crest control
AUTHORS: Kahl, T L; Ruell, S T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SPILLWAYS; FLUID FLOW; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONTROL
DESCRIPTION: Hydroelectric station owners are reaping substantial benefits from technical advancements in spillway modification. By replacing original, crest-mounted wooden flashboards with modern alternatives, owners have improved spillway crest control at different dam sites under widely varying conditions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 13; Journal Issue: 7; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1994

TITLE: Moving into the future with James Bay: Laforge-1 meets the challenges
AUTHORS: Rancourt, M; Parent, L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; CONSTRUCTION; QUEBEC
DESCRIPTION: Hydro-Quebec is commissioning the final unit of its 840-MW Laforge-1 hydropower facility. Faced with substantial logistical, technical, and environmental challenges, project managers have relied on extended and detailed planning, aggressive project management, and creativity from contractors to bring the giant project on-line within budget and more than a year ahead of schedule.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 13; Journal Issue: 7; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1994

TITLE: Achieving a 50-year stator winding life
AUTHORS: Lyles, J F
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; STATORS; ELECTRIC COILS; SERVICE LIFE; DIAGRAMS
DESCRIPTION: Rewinding the stator of a hydroelectric generating unit can be an expensive and time-consuming process. With proper attention, the life of windings can be extended to 50 years, delaying the need to rewind and producing substantial economic and operating benefits to the owner.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 13; Journal Issue: 7; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1994

TITLE: Quantifying the effects of hydro project relicensing proposals
AUTHORS: Putnam, M J; Sullivan, T J; Wamser, M J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; US FERC; REGULATIONS
DESCRIPTION: Hydro project relicensing creates significant demands for information on the costs and effects of proposed project enhancements and changes in operations. A comprehensive energy model helped one utility develop the needed information and identify other operating system improvements.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 13; Journal Issue: 7; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1994

TITLE: Standard dynamic certificate of hydraulic structures of electric power stations
AUTHORS: Baichikov, L N; Kalitseva, I S; Serkov, V S; Sheinin, I S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; DYNAMIC LOADS; RUSSIAN FEDERATION; SAFETY STANDARDS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SEISMIC EVENTS
DESCRIPTION: Russian requirements for seismic evaluation of hydraulic structures of hydroelectric power stations are described in some detail. The requirements are contained in The Power Station and Network Operating Rules. Evaluation is to be performed prior to operation and at five year intervals thereafter. Evaluation includes study of sources of dynamic actions, study of the structure`s dynamic characteristics, determination of the criteria of admissibility of dynamic phenomena in hydraulic structures, determination of parameters of dynamic phenomena in hydraulic structures, and evaluation of the admissibility of the parameters of dynamic phenomena. 15 refs., 1 fig.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 6, 3-6(Jun 1994)

TITLE: Dynamic strength of concrete
AUTHORS: Logunova, V A; Rudenko, V V; Radionov, A K; Sokolov, I B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; COMPRESSION STRENGTH; CONCRETES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DYNAMIC LOADS; SEISMIC EVENTS; SAFETY ANALYSIS
DESCRIPTION: Recommendations for evaluating the dynamic strength of concrete structures at hydroelectric power stations are given. Both existing and planned structures are addressed. Equations are provided for determing the design compressive and tensile strength of concrete. A formula is provided for determining design dynamic strength of concrete of various ages under uniform compression. 3 refs., 1 fig., 2 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 6, 11-13(Jun 1994)

TITLE: Methods of calculating reinforced-concrete members of power structures
AUTHORS: Nikolaev, V B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; REINFORCED CONCRETE; COMPRESSION STRENGTH; DAMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DYNAMIC LOADS; SEISMIC EVENTS; CONCRETE STRINGERS; CONFIGURATION; SAFETY ANALYSIS
DESCRIPTION: Failures of reinforced-concrete structures at hydroelectric power plants are reviewed with respect to safety calculation methods. An analysis method is proposed based on a determination of the limit stress state, accounting for existing cracks. Methods for determining breaking loads for secondary separation and shear with combined stress are very briefly described. A three-dimensional reinforcement method is proposed. 2 figs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 6, 13-16(Jun 1994)

TITLE: Parametric criteria of reliability and nondamageability for the dam of the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydroelectric station
AUTHORS: Gordon, L A; Sokolovskii, I K
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; DYNAMIC LOADS; PARAMETRIC ANALYSIS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SEISMIC EVENTS; SAFETY ANALYSIS
DESCRIPTION: Dam monitoring parameters are analyzed with respect to developing a predictive model. The first group of parameters include mechanical properties of the system, external actions on the structure, mechanical and seepage characteristics of the structure, operation time, upper pool level, and ambient air and water temperature. A second group of parameters includes various movements, strain tensor, concrete temperature, seepage discharges, and seepage discharge solute concentration. Criteria are examined for selecting the most effective monitoring parameters. 4 refs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 6, 16-19(Jun 1994)

TITLE: Strength of brittle materials of the concrete and rock type under triaxial compression
AUTHORS: Maizel`, I V; Sokolov, I B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; CONCRETES; COMPRESSION STRENGTH; STATISTICAL MODELS; ROCKS; BRITTLENESS; THREE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS
DESCRIPTION: Statistical analysis of the results of 180 experiments investigating the strength of brittle materials under triaxial compression is presented. The methods used and characteristics of the specimens, instruments, measuring equipment, and other variables were analyzed. Statistical analysis of results showed a logarithmic relation between the prism strength of the brittle materials and relative increase of the triaxial compressive strength. An empirical equation is developed which gives the maximum agreement with the experimental data. 5 figs., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 6, 22-24(Jun 1994)

TITLE: Filling temporary underground structures and workings at high-head hydro developments
AUTHORS: Ilyushin, V F
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; TUNNELS; BACKFILLING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; DAMS
DESCRIPTION: Examples of backfilling temporary underground structures and workings at hydroelectric stations in Russia are cited. Structures backfilled include temporary tunnels and auxiliary workings (shafts, chambers, etc.). Detail drawings illustrate many of the examples. Examples of backfilling at a number of hydropower plants are given; however, the main emphasis is on construction of Nurek Hydroelectric Station. 8 refs., 11 figs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 6, 31-38(Jun 1994)

TITLE: Current problems in providing strength of concrete dams
AUTHORS: Khrapkov, A A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; CRACKS; TENSILE PROPERTIES; CONCRETES; FRACTURE MECHANICS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DYNAMIC LOADS; SEISMIC EVENTS; SAFETY ANALYSIS
DESCRIPTION: The causes of discontinuity in four large concrete dams are briefly analyzed. The purpose of the analysis is to attempt to characterize problems involving strength of concrete hydraulic structures. For three of the dams, recorded seismic accelerations at the ground surface exceeded 0.5 gravities. Implications for calculation methods to predict tensile stresses are discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 6, 19-21(Jun 1994)

TITLE: Recommendations on the organization of dynamic tests of hydraulic structures of electric power stations
AUTHORS: Sheinin, I S; Kalitseva, I S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; MECHANICAL TESTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DYNAMIC LOADS; SEISMIC EVENTS; SAFETY ANALYSIS
DESCRIPTION: Recommendations are made for conducting seismic testing of hydraulic structures of hydroelectric power plants in accordance with certification requirements of the Russian Federation. For structures characterized by comparatively large dimensions and mass, the method of exciting vibrations, primarily by means of imbalance vibrators, is recommended. Guidelines in the article address general principles and method of dynamic testing, selection of measuring instruments, and selection of vibration-excitation means. Test conduction and analysis of the results are also discussed. 7 refs., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 6, 7-11(Jun 1994)

TITLE: Prediction of snowmelt infiltration into frozen soils
AUTHORS: Tao, Y X; Gray, D M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; AIR POLLUTION; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; SOILS; HEAT TRANSFER; HYDRAULIC CONDUCTIVITY; DRAINAGE; GREENHOUSE EFFECT; GROUND WATER; SOIL MECHANICS; CLIMATIC CHANGE; ENERGY TRANSFER; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MECHANICS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POLLUTION; WATER; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 540120 - Environment, Atmospheric- Chemicals Monitoring & Transport- (1990-); 010900 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: A numerical model is presented, based on the local volume averaging formulation of transport phenomena in porous media, for simulating meltwater infiltration into unsaturated, frozen soil. With the defined flow and freezing boundary conditions at the snow-soil interface, using the concept of a surface local averaging volume, the time variation in profiles of temperature, liquid/ice content, infiltration/percolation rates, and rate of phase change in upper soil layers are predicted. In addition to a parametric analysis, model estimates of infiltration are compared with quantities calculated from field measurements of soil moisture changes and temperature during snow cover ablation, showing a reasonable agreement.
RELATION: Journal Name: Numerical Heat Transfer. Part A, Applications; (United States); Journal Volume: 26:6
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ISSN 1040-7782; CODEN: NHAAES; TRN: 95-006686
JOURNAL_NAME: Numerical Heat Transfer. Part A, Applications; (United States)

TITLE: Refinement of cross-flow turbine design parameters
AUTHORS: Totapally, H G.S.; Aziz, N M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; DESIGN; EFFICIENCY; CROSSFLOW SYSTEMS; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PERFORMANCE; TURBINE BLADES; EQUIPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: This paper discusses experiments that were conducted to refine some of the key cross-flow turbine runner parameters for better performance. The parameters studied were identified by previous studies as key design parameters. The research included narrowing the range of the number of blades, the determination of the impact of the first-stage exit angle, and the effect of flow stream spreading on the performance of the cross-flow turbine. The results indicate an optimum number of blades that would produce maximum efficiency of the turbine, and a clear trend of the effect of the first-stage exit angle and flow stream spreading on the efficiency. For the best nozzle-runner combination, the maximum efficiency closest to the discharge averaged maximum efficiency is determined to be 92%, with an uncertainty of [+-] 2.4%. This result is an improvement over the reported maximum efficiency of any cross-flow turbine.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Energy Engineering; (United States); Journal Volume: 120:3

TITLE: Reliability applied to slope stability analysis
AUTHORS: Christian, J T; Ladd, C C; Baecher, G B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; FAILURE MODE ANALYSIS; SLOPE STABILITY; EMBANKMENTS; FAILURES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RELIABILITY; SOILS; STABILITY; SYSTEM FAILURE ANALYSIS; SYSTEMS ANALYSIS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: Formally probabilistic methods for the analysis of slope stability have had relatively little impact on practice. Many engineers are not familiar with probabilistic concepts, and it has been difficult to incorporate concepts of reliability into practice. Also, there is confusion over what reliability and probability of failure mean. The most effective applications of probabilistic methods are those involving relative probabilities of failure or illuminating the effects of uncertainties in the parameters.
