Attempts to determine the absolute probability of failure are much less successful. The paper describes how probabilistic descriptions of soil parameters can be derived from field and laboratory data and applied in stability analysis. The first-order, second-moment approach is explored and applied to the design of embankment dams. The example illustrates the relative contributions of uncertainties about different parameters to the reliability of the embankment. Reliability analysis is especially useful in establishing design values of factors of safety representing consistent risks for different types of failure.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Geotechnical Engineering; (United States); Journal Volume: 120:12

TITLE: Calculating methods of solution of boundary-value problems of mathematical physics
AUTHORS: Skopetskii, V V; Deineka, V S; Sklepovaya, L I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 MATHEMATICS, COMPUTERS, INFORMATION SCIENCE, MANAGEMENT, LAW, MISCELLANEOUS; DAMS; FOUNDATIONS; DIFFUSION; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; BOUNDARY-VALUE PROBLEMS; PERMEABILITY; ALGORITHMS; RIVERS
DESCRIPTION: A new mathematical model is developed for unsteady seepage in a pressure gradient through a compressible foundation of a gravity dam with an antiseepage curtain. High-accuracy discretization algorithms are developed for the corresponding initial boundary-value problem with a discontinuous solution.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Mathematical Sciences; Journal Volume: 72; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: 10 Nov 1994; TN: Translated from Vychislitel`naya i Prikladnaya Matematika; No. 74, 32-38(1992)

TITLE: Reinventing the process
AUTHORS: Hunt, R; Hunt, J M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING AND POLICY; LICENSING REGULATIONS; INTERAGENCY COOPERATION; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING
DESCRIPTION: Reinventing the government is the avowed goal of the Clinton administration. Making the federal government work for the people is the intended product of Vice President Al Gore`s National Performance Review. All federal agencies are expected to participate. How would the world of hydropower licensing look if the goal of all state and federal resource agencies and FERC was a cooperative effort to license good hydropower projects in the best interest of the nation? FERC is working to reinvent the licensing process, but progress is limited by the lack of a clear customer focus and lack of a cooperative attitude and common goal among the resource agencies.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; Journal Volume: 24; Journal Issue: 9; Other Information: PBD: Nov 1994

TITLE: Determining the reliability of concrete dams through diagnosis of their bedrock
AUTHORS: Kalustyan, E S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; REINFORCED CONCRETE; FAILURES; DAMS; RELIABILITY; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; BASEMENT ROCK; INSPECTION; STABILITY
DESCRIPTION: ***JILL: USE THE 1ST 2 PARAGRAPHS FOR THE ABSTRACT. CDR***
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Nov 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stoitel`stvo; No. 5, 20-25(May 1994)

TITLE: Effect of geodynamics on the reliability of the dam behind the Chirkey hydroelectric power plant
AUTHORS: Marchuk, A N; Misrikhanov, M S; Abakarov, A R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; REINFORCED CONCRETE; FAILURES; DAMS; RELIABILITY; INSPECTION; SEISMIC EFFECTS; MONITORING
DESCRIPTION: The chirkey hydraulic facility is located in the territory of one of the most seismically active sections of the Caucasus - the Dagestan wedge seismofocal region (SFR). Large-scale paleoseismodeformations have been observed here, and a series of destructive earthquakes with magnitudes of 5.3-6.7 and intensities of 7-8 ponts occurred in 1970 through 1976.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Nov 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stoitel`stvo; No. 5, 30-35(May 1994)

TITLE: Permanent deformation on preexisting sliding surfaces in dams
AUTHORS: Gazetas, G; Uddin, N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; EMBANKMENTS; RESPONSE FUNCTIONS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; DEFORMATION; EARTHQUAKES; LANDSLIDES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SLOPE STABILITY; FUNCTIONS; SEISMIC EVENTS; STABILITY; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: A finite-element model capable of computing permanent deformations along preexisting sliding surfaces in dams and embankments is used to evaluate the error in the current state-of-practice two-step procedures that are based on the simplifying assumption that the computation of dynamic response and of the resulting sliding displacements can be decoupled. Both sinusoidal and real earthquake ground motions are used as excitation, and Coulomb's friction law governs sliding along any point of the rigid-plastic tensionless interface. It is found that only when the dominant excitation frequencies lie in the proximity of the fundamental dam frequency will the permanent deformation from the decoupling assumption exceed appreciably the single-step value. As a validation of the single-step procedure, an analysis is performed and shown to successfully explain the nonsymmetric response of La Villita Dam recorded in the 1985 Mexico Earthquake.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Geotechnical Engineering; (United States); Journal Volume: 120:11

TITLE: Field tests to validate hydro turbine-governor model structure and parameters
AUTHORS: Hannett, L N; Feltes, J W; Fardanesh, B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; TURBOGENERATORS; SPEED REGULATORS; POWER SYSTEMS; STABILITY; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ENERGY SYSTEMS; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: A test procedure was developed to obtain accurate governor models for hydroelectric stations owned by the New York Power Authority to improve the accuracy of stability simulations of the New York State system. Tests were performed on units at three stations and values for parameters of previously available model structures were derived from the information obtained during these tests. However, it was found that the model structures were not adequate to represent the entire range of operating conditions. Additional examination of test measurements and model structures indicated that the model structure needed to be refined. This paper reports on the refinements made to the hydro turbine-governor models which enabled reproduction of the physical system responses. Simulation results indicate that the refined models with the corresponding identified parameters produce responses which closely fit those recorded from the tests performs on three hydro units.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 9:4
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Hydro turbine model for system dynamic studies
AUTHORS: De Jaeger, E; Janssens, N; Malfliet, B; Van De Meulebroeke, F
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; HYDRODYNAMICS; INCOMPRESSIBLE FLOW; EQUIPMENT; FLUID FLOW; FLUID MECHANICS; MACHINERY; MECHANICS; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: A non-linear model for dynamic studies of hydro turbines is proposed. The model of a single turbine and its water supply conduit is given in the first section of the paper, together with a parameter estimation from field tests. The second section is devoted to the modeling of multiple turbines supplied from a common tunnel, taking into account the hydraulic coupling effects. Comparisons between simulation results and experimental data are presented.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 9:4
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Application of multivariable optimal controller to real power systems
AUTHORS: Morioka, Y; Tanaka, H; Kojima, T; Suzuki, T; Hanada, S
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; ELECTRICAL TRANSIENTS; ENERGY SYSTEMS; POWER PLANTS; TRANSIENTS; VOLTAGE DROP; 240100* - Power Systems- (1990-); 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: An adaptive, multivariable optimal control system, which coordinates the excitation and governing system of a generator, has been studied by the authors. This paper describes the applicability of the new control system to a hydro-power generator connected with a long-distance transmission line, and includes results of an extensive field study. This paper also describes test results obtained with a large-scale analog simulator on the controllability of the new control system applied to a longitudinal power system. Study results verify the reliable control performance of the new control system during various disturbances in a real power system, and the advantages of the new control system with respect to power system stability in a long-distance transmission system. The results also show that the new control system improves low frequency oscillation damping of longitudinal power systems.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 9:4
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: The Clean Water Act and federally licensed utilities
AUTHORS: Behnke, J; Dondis, H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING REGULATIONS; LAWSUITS; STATE GOVERNMENT; LEGAL ASPECTS; US FERC; AESTHETICS; FISHES
DESCRIPTION: A recent decision by the US Supreme Court, in PUD No. 1 of Jefferson County v. Washington Department of Ecology, 128 L. Ed. 29 716 (1994), seriously threatens to erode the traditional federal jurisdiction over interstate utilities, and to accrete a substantial, if not predominant, role for the states in the authorization of projects that may discharge into navigable waters. In Jefferson County, the petitioner, a city and local utility district, proposed to build a hydroelectric project along the Dosewallips River in Washington State. The project was to be licensed by the FERC under the FPA, but the license could not be granted without a water quality certification issued by Washington State under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, better known as the Clean Water Act, 33 USC 1251 et seq. (CWA). The petitioner applied for a water quality certification from the State of Washington Department of Ecology, which issued the certification but imposed a number of conditions, including a minimum stream-flow requirement. The petitioner appealed the conditions through the state courts to the US Supreme Court, taking the position that under the CWA and the FPA, states can impose water quality standards that can be numerically quantified, but cannot regulate stream flows. The Supreme Court rules that the State Department of Ecology`s action in imposing water flow conditions fell within its powers under the CWA, and that the state therefore had imposed proper conditions for issuance of a license under the FPA.
RELATION: Journal Name: Fortnightly; Journal Volume: 132; Journal Issue: 20; Other Information: PBD: 1 Nov 1994

TITLE: Reaction of the dams behind the Toktoguol and Kurpsa hydroelectric power plants to repeated earthquakes
AUTHORS: Marchuk, A N; Umralin, K B; Moldebehov, Z I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; REINFORCED CONCRETE; FAILURES; DAMS; RELIABILITY; INSPECTION; SEISMIC EFFECTS; MONITORING
DESCRIPTION: The region where the chain of Naryn hydroelectric power plants are located in the Kyrgyzstan Republic is a seismically active area of Central Tien-Shan and is comparatively well known in seismological respects. No means of measuring the dams themselves, however, were ever incorporated as an instrumental base of investigation. The seismometric possibilities of embedded monitoring-measuring apparatus were disclosed by O.Yu. Schmidt Institute of Earth Physics and have made is possible to evaluate the reactions of dams to seismic effects and of excited seismicity, when residual deformations due to repeated tremors of different force and direction are accumulated over an extended period of time.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Nov 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stoitel`stvo; No. 5, 26-30(May 1994)

TITLE: Severe earthquakes in the Krasnodar reservoir region - new evaluations
AUTHORS: Nikonov, A A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; REINFORCED CONCRETE; FAILURES; DAMS; RELIABILITY; INSPECTION; SEISMIC EFFECTS; MONITORING
DESCRIPTION: Information about earthquakes in the region began to be collected only since the time of settling there of the Cossacks and placing of the territory under Russian control, that is, since the end of the 18th Century. Over this two-century period, several intense local earthquakes have been recorded. The most intense and latest of them was the Kuban earthquake of April 19, 1926, which took place when the period of instrumental observations had already begun; however, the instrumental information that it was possible to detect and process was scarce and of low quality. Subsequently, intense earthquakes in the lower course of the Kuban River were not recorded; for this reasons, it is necessary to be based on the macroseismic information from historical times.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Nov 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stoitel`stvo; No. 5, 35-38(May 1994)

TITLE: Finding solutions for preventing leaks in concrete penstocks
AUTHORS: Bhat, P D; Mazza, M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PENSTOCKS; LEAKS; REPAIR; CONCRETES
DESCRIPTION: Ontario Hydro had a severe water leakage problem in several of its concrete penstocks. The Canadian utility appointed an investigating team to study the problem and offer solutions. The team identified several potential rehabilitation options, including post-tensioning, grouting, installation of liners, and surface repair. This article is a review of these methods and their implementation at several hydroelectric projects.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 8; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1994

TITLE: Reducing costly zebra mussel infestations at power plants
AUTHORS: Smythe, G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; MUSSELS; CONTROL; BIOLOGICAL FOULING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: The fast-spreading-zebra mussel has significant potential to foul intakes and other water systems at North American hydro projects. Chemical controls can be effective in reducing infestations, but most have environmental and other drawbacks. Several non-chemical methods promise to help project operators reduce problems associated with the mussels.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 8; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1994

TITLE: Bringing pumped storage on line: A look at the issues
AUTHORS: Beggs, S L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; CONSTRUCTION
DESCRIPTION: Pumped-storage hydroelectric facilities on drawing boards today offer many features that make the facilities distinct from other generating plants. Along with unique features, the projects also bring forth a whole new set of questions - Who will buy the power? Can the project compete with other technologies? Is there a way to push the FERC licensing process along at a faster pace? As projects advance, developers are discovering answers to the questions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 8; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1994

TITLE: Alleviating pulsations in turbines
AUTHORS: Wedmark, A B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PULSATIONS; MITIGATION; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: Pressure pulsations resulting from vortices in the draft tube are a persistent problem with Francis turbines. Air injection through the turbine shaft often can solve the problem, but this approach may not be possible after the turbine unit has been manufactured. In such cases, new and innovative solutions may be required.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 8; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1994

TITLE: State of the outlet works of the Sayano-Shushenskow hydroelectric station and problems of their operation
AUTHORS: Moroz, A Ya; Shatravskii, A I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SPILLWAYS; MAINTENANCE; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: The hydroelectric station and service spillway are part of the outlet works of the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydrostation in Russia. With ten 640 MWe units, the discharge capacity of the turbines is 3400-3600 cubic meters/second. This substantial discharge rate places a severe burden on the outlet works, and this article reviews the effects of this high discharge rate and maintenance activities to deal with these effects.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 4, 9-12(Apr 1994)

TITLE: Removal of floating timber from the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydrostation reservoir
AUTHORS: Popov, A V; Shatravskii, A I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; WATER RESERVOIRS; WOOD WASTES; REMOVAL; RUSSIAN FEDERATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: This article discusses the removal of floating timber from the Sayano-Shushenkoe reservoir in Russia. Within the impound area of this 621 square kilometer reservoir, there was a forest area of 3.7M cubic meters. A portion of it was removed before impoundment, but approximately 2.2M cubic meters was left standing when impoundment began. This has led to substantial quantities of floating timber within the reservoir. To clear the reservoir of this debris, several timber-retaining booms were designed and constructed. These booms work reliably under conditions of fluctuations of the reservoir level with an amplitude of 40 meters, and since the installation of the booms, the arrival of driftwood at the dam has ceased.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 4, 12-15(Apr 1994)

TITLE: Characteristics of the behavior of the Sayano-Shushenskoe dam during filling of the reservoir to the normal pool level
AUTHORS: Bulatov, V A; Shakhmaeva, E Yu
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FOUNDATIONS; STRESSES; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: This article reviews efforts to evaluate the performance of the dam-foundation-abutment system of the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydroelectric plant in Russia. After undergoing four complete filling-drawdown cycles, the state of the dam was evaluated by an independent panel convened by the Engineering Academy of the Russian Federation. This panel concluded that: (1) processes of variations of the dam-foundation-abutment system are not fading away and the operating regime of the structure has not stabilized, (2) the unsteady and inelastic work of the bank abutments is one of the causes of irreversible radial movements and developing of fracturing in the first column of the dam, (3) cracking on the upstream face and progressive seepage through the concrete of the first column worsen the state of the concrete. Polymer injections do not improve the work of the structure, but if the cracks are not healed promptly, the volume of necessary repair work will increae with time, (4) to evaluate the stress state of the dam, it is necessary to make calculations with consideration of the large stress raisers: water intakes, gate grooves, etc, and (5) it is required to evaluate the fact of the excess by a factor of 2-3 of the increments of the maximum arch stress over the design values in various load stages.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 4, 21-25(Apr 1994)

TITLE: Generators of the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydroelectric station
AUTHORS: Beloborodov, V A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; DESIGN; OPERATION; TESTING; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: This article is a discussion of the technical characteristics of the generators that are installed at the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydroelectric station in Russia. Items covered include: (1) stator, (2) stator winding, (3) rotor, (4) stator cooling system, (5) temperature monitoring, (6) excitation system, (7) test results, (8) efficiency, (9) short circuit regimes, and (10) operating experience.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 4, 35-37(Apr 1994)

TITLE: Experience in operating and reconstructing the turbine bearings of units of the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydroelectric station
AUTHORS: Nikitenko, G I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROSTATIC BEARINGS; OPERATION; MAINTENANCE; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: This article reviews some of the operations and maintenance experiences at the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydroelectric sstation in Russia. In particular, the experiences gained in the operation of the turbines and the reconstruction of the turbine bearings are noted. The compact layout of this facility did not permit the traditional babbitt bearing or rubber ring bearing with water lubrication. Instead, a rubber sugmented bearing with water lubrication was used. The design and construction of this bearing, as well as the operation and maintenance of this bearing, is discussed in this article. The operating experiences have shown that the component is highly reliable.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 4, 32-34(Apr 1994)

TITLE: Some results of fifteen years of operation of the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydropower complex
AUTHORS: Bryzgalov, V I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; OPERATION; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: The Sayano-Shushenskoe hydroelectric station reflects the best that was gained by experience in hydropower construction both in Russia and abroad. This article reviews a number of aspects of the design, construction, and operation of the facility, including the environmental impact of the project.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 4, 1-3(Apr 1994)

TITLE: Effect of the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydropower complex on the environment
AUTHORS: Stafievskii, V A; Romov, L Ya
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; WASTE WATER; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; CHEMICAL WASTES; BIOLOGICAL WASTES; RUSSIAN FEDERATION; WATER RESERVOIRS
DESCRIPTION: This article reviews the environmental impacts of the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydroelectric complex in Russia. Hydrochemical and hydrobiological characteristics of both the reservoir and the Enisei River are discussed, in particular the effects of submerged/floating timber and wastewater. There has also been an effect on the climatic conditions in the area, and this is also discussed in the article.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 4, 3-9(Apr 1994)

TITLE: Effective fastening of the bottom of the stilling basin of a high-head dam by prestressed anchors
AUTHORS: Zhivoderov, V N; Tupikov, N I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SPILLWAYS; ANCHORS; DESIGN; FABRICATION; INSTALLATION; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: The Sayano-Shushenskoe hydroelectric plant is a major high-head, high generating capacity hydroelectric station in the Russian Federation. During discharge operations, there are considerable flow-induced vibrations in the bottom of the stilling basin. This was investigated, and it was decided to install pre-stressed anchors. This article discusses a number of aspects of their effort, including: (1) manufacture of elements of the anchor, its assembly, and bench testing, (2) preparation of the borehole, (3) transport of the anchor, (4) grouting, standing, and tensionin of the anchor, and (5) release of tension and cutting of the anchor.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 4, 40-46(Apr 1994)

TITLE: Problems of operating the 500-kV outdoor electrical equipment of the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydroelectric station
AUTHORS: Mitrofanov, A N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; CIRCUIT BREAKERS; DESIGN; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: The Sayano-Shushenskoe hydroelectric station is part of the Siberian interconnected power system. Power is transmitted to the grid by two 500 kV transmission lines. The site characteristics made nearby placement of conventional 500 kV switchyard equipment impossible. The original plans were to place the switchyard 35 km away, but the 500 kV lines to the yard would have passed through mountain regions with intense thunderstorm activity. Because of the unique design of the generators, the number of lightning-induced disconnects was substantial. For greater reliability, 500 kV equipment suitable for placement at the sight was designed, and the overall electrical layout of the yard was revised by reconstructing the middle network of the 4/3 scheme to three networks with two switches per connection. Sectioning of the collecting bus systems was necessary for a further increase in the reliability of the yard.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 4, 37-39(Apr 1994)

TITLE: Seepage regime of the foundation of the Sayano-Shushenskoe dam during the first years of permanent operation
AUTHORS: Permyakova, L S; Reshetnikova, E N; Epifanov, A P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FOUNDATIONS; LEAKS; RUSSIAN FEDERATION; SOIL MECHANICS; DIAGRAMS
DESCRIPTION: This article examines the seepage regime of the foundation of the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydroelectric power plant during the first few years of operation. This facility was constructed in the central part of the relatively monolithic Dzhoi-Kibik structural-tectonic block. The rock foundation of the facility is inhomogeneous in its seepage characterisitcs, and individual stretches in zones of tectonic crushing of the rock are the most permeable. The depth of opening of the rock-concrete contact does not exceed 27 meters. Each subsequent filling of the reservoir intensified the degreee of decompression of the foundation, involving the deep curtain in this process. Signs of cracking of the middle part of the grout were detected.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 4, 16-21(Apr 1994)

TITLE: Evaluation of the reliability of a hydrostation machine hall during operation of the outlet
AUTHORS: L`vov, A V; Shul`man, S G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HIGH-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; STRUCTURAL BEAMS; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: Considerable dynamic actions related to the turbine-generator units, especially during discharge of floodwaters, are usually transmitted to the structures of hydrostation machine halls. During operation of outlets, considerable hydrodynamic loads occur on the bottom and walls of the stilling basin, and as a result, stress waves causing vibrations of the structures of the hydro development form and propagate in the foundation of the structure. Vibrations of the dam, the unit blocks, baffle platforms, and other structures are the source of additional disturbances causing a complex interference pattern of wave phenomena in the foundation. This article discusses an experimental-mathematical method of investigating the structural vibrations of the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydro facility in Russia. Included in the article are discussions of: (1) vibrations of the frame section of the machine hall with kinematic excitation of the support, (2) random vibrations of the frame, and (3) the evaluation of the reliability of the structure and its elements.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 4, 25-31(Apr 1994)

TITLE: When FERC and states collide
AUTHORS: Lagassa, G K
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING REGULATIONS; STATE GOVERNMENT
DESCRIPTION: The requirement that hydroelectric projects secure a state water quality permit pursuant to Section 401 of the federal Clean Water Act is long-standing. Equal in age is the recognition of the conflict which this requirement creates. In one example, a Maine company spent more than 30 months in the process. After several court cases in which a favorable appeal was overturned, the company chose not to pursue further legal action. This is the kind of challenge hydropower project owners are facing under current conditions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; Journal Volume: 24; Journal Issue: 8; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1994

TITLE: Protecting fish
AUTHORS: Francfort, J; Rinehart, B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; US DOE
DESCRIPTION: The United States Department of Energy`s Hydropower Program has recently completed a study of fish passage and protection mitigation practices at conventional hydroelectric projects. The report, Environmental Mitigation at Hydroelectric Projects, Volume II. Benefits and Costs of Fish Passage and Protection (Volume II), provides information describing both historical and current mitigation efforts in the United States. The study used 16 projects as case studies to provide detailed illustrations of mitigation practices, allowing a better understanding of the resource and economic requirements, and the ramifications of mitigation choices.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; Journal Volume: 24; Journal Issue: 8; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1994

TITLE: Database launched to help evaluate structural safety
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SAFETY ANALYSIS; DAMS; RISK ASSESSMENT; DATA BASE MANAGEMENT; FAILURES
DESCRIPTION: State officials have {open_quotes}christened{close_quotes} a National Performance of Dams Program that they expect eventually will provide a huge statistical database helping to evaluate safety of structures and prevent their failure. Members of the Association of State Dam Safety Officials also expect that the program will become a vehicle for affecting political policy decisions. The program actually grew out of a nearly 10-year data collection effort by the civil engineering department at Stanford University, Palo Alto. The Center on the Performance of Dams, located there, has accumulated more than 6,000 documents on all aspects of dams in the U.S., including incidents and failures.
RELATION: Journal Name: ENR; Journal Volume: 233; Journal Issue: 12; Other Information: PBD: 19 Sep 1994

TITLE: RCC for seismic design. [Roller-Compacted Concrete]
AUTHORS: Wong, N C; Forrest, M P; Lo, S H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; DAMS; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; STABILIZATION; CONCRETES; BUILDING MATERIALS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; MATERIALS; NORTH AMERICA; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: This article describes how the use of roller-compacted concrete is saving $10 million on the seismic retrofit of Southern California's historic multiple-arch Littlerock Dam. Throughout its 70-year existence, the Littlerock Dam in Southern California's Angeles National Forest has been a subject of the San Andreas Fault, could this 28-arch dam withstand any major movement from that fault line, much less the big one'' Working with the state's Division of Safety of Dams, Woodward-Clyde Consultants, Oakland, Calif., performed stability and stress analyses to find the answer. The evaluation showed that, as feared, the dam failed to meet required seismic safety criteria, principally due to its lack of lateral stability, a deficiency inherent in multiple-arch dams. To provide adequate seismic stability the authors developed a rehabilitation design centered around the use of roller-compacted concrete (RCC) to construct a gravity section between and around the downstream portions of the existing buttresses. The authors also proposed that the arches be resurfaced and stiffened with steel-fiber-reinforced silica fume. The alternative design would have required filling the arch bays between the buttresses with mass concrete at a cost of $22.5 million. The RCC buttress repair construction, scheduled for completion this fall, will cost about $13 million.
RELATION: Journal Name: Civil Engineering (New York, 1983); (United States); Journal Volume: 64:9

TITLE: An experimental investigation of cross-flow turbine efficiency
AUTHORS: Desai, V R; Aziz, N M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CROSSFLOW SYSTEMS; EFFICIENCY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; EQUIPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINERY; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: An experimental investigation was conducted to study the effect of some geometric parameters on the efficiency of the cross-flow turbine. Turbine models were constructed with three different numbers of blades, three different angles of water entry to the runner, and three different inner-to-outer diameter ratios. Nozzles were also constructed for the experiments to match the three different angles of water entry to the runner. A total of 27 runners were tested with the three nozzles. The results of the experiments clearly indicated that efficiency increased with increase in the number of blades. Moreover, it was determined that an increase in the angle of attack beyond 24 deg does not improve the maximum turbine efficiency. In addition, as a result of these experiments, it was determine that for a 24 deg angle of attack 0.68 was the most efficient inner-to-outer diameter ratio, whereas for higher angles of attack the maximum efficiency decreases with an increase in the diameter ratio from 0.60 to 0.75.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Fluids Engineering; (United States); Journal Volume: 116:3

TITLE: Voltage dips due to direct connection of induction generators in low head hydro electric schemes
AUTHORS: Hammons, T J; Lai, S C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; INDUCTION GENERATORS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS; VOLTAGE DROP; ELECTRICAL TRANSIENTS; EQUIPMENT PROTECTION DEVICES; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; TRANSIENTS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 240100 - Power Systems- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: This paper analyzes phenomena which affect voltage dip due to direct connection of induction generators running close to synchronous speed to electrical distribution systems in low head hydro electric schemes. The paper examines transient phenomena on connection of induction generators at close to synchronous speed in determining whether costly system reinforcement may be avoided thus making many uneconomic developments viable while satisfying constraints of permissible voltage dip if the transient phenomena is taken duly into account. More use of renewable energy in electricity supply thus receding greenhouse gas emissions from fossil plant will therefore result. Parameters of significance in evaluating voltage dip due to direct connection of induction generators running at close to synchronous speed which are studied include (1) effective resistance of stator together with system resistance and reactance of effective infinite supply, (2) rotor circuit parameters, (3) speed of generator on connection, and (4) equivalent inertia of rotor and turbine. Results depicted in Tables an din Time Response demonstrate relative importance of the parameters on voltage dip. It is concluded that costly system reinforcement may be avoided if detailed simulations are performed where dynamics and transients are fully modeled in assessing magnitude and duration of voltage dip. The analysis is based on a detailed induction generator model with single and double rotor bar simulation using Park's equations with simulation of rotor dynamics on connection of the generator to the electrical supply.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 9:3
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Gaining capacity through FERC`s Efficiency Upgrade Program
AUTHORS: Fulton, E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPTIMIZATION; PERFORMANCE; CAPACITY; US FERC
DESCRIPTION: In 1991, FERC introduced the Efficiency Upgrade Program, streamlining the approval process for license amendments. A survey of hydro operators suggests that, without the program, needed mechanical and electrical upgrades would never have been attempted because of regulatory constraints.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 13; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1994

TITLE: A big step toward improving FERC`s relicensing process
AUTHORS: Padula, S D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; US FERC; REGULATIONS
DESCRIPTION: Relicensing the 157 {open_quotes}Class of `93{close_quotes} hydro projects is in many cases proving to be cumbersome, inefficient, and expensive. The process needs to be improved toward maintaining hydropower as a vital part of the U.S.`s energy mix. In response to this situation, the National Hydropower Association has launched a relicensing reform initiative, toward simplifying and expediting the process.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 13; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1994

TITLE: Creating new life in aging hydro plants
AUTHORS: Mitchell, A; Wood, M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SERVICE LIFE; AUGMENTATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EQUIPMENT
DESCRIPTION: Recognizing the importance of hydro in its diverse generation mix, PECO Energy Company is combining long-range rehabilitation plans with a new management style to ensure future generation at its hydro facilities.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 13; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1994

TITLE: Adding value with well-planned O&M
AUTHORS: Bloom, J E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; MAINTENANCE; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS
DESCRIPTION: Hydroelectric power producers benefit when downtime is limited and the use of available water is maximized. Cost-effective operations, maintenance, and plant upgrading can help battle {open_quotes}Murphy`s Law{close_quotes} and add substantially to a hydro plant`s bottom line.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 13; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1994

TITLE: Using surveys to document effects of streamflows on white-water rafting
AUTHORS: Shelby, B; Brown, T C; Baumgartner, R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; STREAMS; FLOW RATE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RECREATIONAL AREAS; DIAGRAMS
DESCRIPTION: Surveys of experienced river users are one effective way for developers and owners of hydropower projects to determine the effects of flow releases on recreation activities such as white-water rafting. This type of survey was used for determining the effects of flow changes on white-water boating on the Colorado River in the Grand Canyon.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 13; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1994

TITLE: Determining design floods more accurately with state-of-the-art computer models
AUTHORS: Rutledge, J L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FLOODS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN BASIS ACCIDENTS
DESCRIPTION: Engineers increasingly are using sophisticated computer analysis methods to more accurately determine flood levels. As a result, many dam owners are reducing the need for upgrading flood handling capacity of dams. By using a state-of-the-art computerized flood routing model, the Lower Colorado River Authority saved about $30 million in dam rehabilitation costs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 13; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1994

TITLE: Measuring flow with pressure-time, current meter methods
AUTHORS: Levesque, J M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FLOW RATE; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; TESTING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: Efficiency testing plays an important role in providing data from which turbines can be designed and modified to provide improved performance. Faced with conducting tests at a challenging project site, Hydro-Quebec engineers used a combination of methods to explain previously unsatisfactory test results and establish a sound basis for future trials.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 13; Journal Issue: 5; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1994

TITLE: Physical characteristics of the performance and increase of the reliability of functioning of overflow dams with a {open_quotes}second limit state{close_quotes} of the rock foundation
AUTHORS: Khlopenkov, P R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 42 ENGINEERING NOT INCLUDED IN OTHER CATEGORIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; SAFETY; DAMS; STRESS ANALYSIS
DESCRIPTION: The main danger for the stability of high-head overflow dams having large safety factors is related to unfavorable processes in two zones of the foundation - near the upstream and downstream sides of the dam - due to fracturing of the rock foundation next to the dam by flood discharges. Fracturing of the toe of a dam, especially a gravity-arch dam, is accompanied by an increase of shear stresses in the rock under it to values exceeding the design values, and owing to fracturing of the rock below the dam foundation deformation movements of the dam toward the lower pool increase markedly, moreover, the greater amount, the more considerable the depth of fracturing below the dam foundation. As a result the tensile stresses in the rock in front of the dam increase to values exceeding the allowable, which intensifies cracking of this rock zone to a greater depth, the deeper the fracturing of the rock beyond the dam. Owing to this, the stress state of the foundation directly under the dam, accompanied by a decrease of the bearing capacity of the rock and increase of its deformation with loss of the required seepage strength, worsens.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 2, 27-34(Feb 1994)

TITLE: Evaluation of the state of the dam and foundation of the Sayano-Shushenskoe Hydroelectric Station and measures to ensure its reliability (based on materials of the expert commission formed by the Engineering Academy of the Russian Federation)
AUTHORS: Rozanov, N P; Kubetskii, V L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 42 ENGINEERING NOT INCLUDED IN OTHER CATEGORIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SAFETY; RELIABILITY; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; CONSTRUCTION; DATA BASE MANAGEMENT
DESCRIPTION: During the first years of operation of the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydrostation deviations from the design premises were detected in the {open_quotes}dam-foundation{close_quotes} system, and some of them can be assigned to the second group of limit states. In connection with this, P.R. Khlopenkov sent a letter to the State Committee for Emergency Situations about the emergency, in his opinion, state of the Sayano-Shushenskoe hydrostation. The indicated letter was the cause for creating an independent expert commission formed by the Engineering Academy of the Russian Federation at the request of O.V. Britvin, vice-president of the Russian Power and Electrification joint-stock company, the task of which included an objective evaluation of the reliability of that structure and, when necessary, giving recommendations aimed at ensuring its further normal operation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 2, 34-49(Feb 1994)

TITLE: Information-analysis support of the reliability and safety system of hydraulic structures of hydroelectric stations
AUTHORS: Dobrynin, S N; Kuznetsov, O M; Tikhonova, T S; Artyukhina, T S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 42 ENGINEERING NOT INCLUDED IN OTHER CATEGORIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SAFETY; RELIABILITY; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; CONSTRUCTION; DATA BASE MANAGEMENT
DESCRIPTION: The problem of ensuring the reliability and safety of construction, reconstruction, and operation of hydraulic structures is a most important technical, economic, ecological, and social problem. Its significance increases markedly for high-head structures or structures operating for a long time, disturbance of the performance of which is related to enormous material losses, human victims, and disruption of the ecology of the region.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 2, 13-15(Feb 1994)

TITLE: Mathematical models for predicting the state of hydraulic structures from data of on-site observations
AUTHORS: Dobrynin, S N; Kuznetsov, O M; Tikhonova, T S; Yurinova, T N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 42 ENGINEERING NOT INCLUDED IN OTHER CATEGORIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SAFETY; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; CONSTRUCTION; MATHEMATICAL MODELS
DESCRIPTION: Prompt and high-quality processing of large arrays of on-site observations on structures of hydro developments is a necessary conditions for obtaining an objective prediction of the behavior of the object. Therefore, to supplement and develop works a system of statistical processing and prediction of time series of on-site observations was created which makes it possible to use data processing and analysis methods represented in a certain way for obtaining ultimately an evaluation of the state and reliability of the structure being monitored. The applications programs for processing primary information are described. In the present work representations of algorithms and system of applications programs for processing and prediction of time series of observations, considering them to be stochastic processes, are proposed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 2, 15-20(Feb 1994)

TITLE: State of the arch dam and foundation of the Inguri Hydroelectric Station
AUTHORS: Bronshtein, V I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 42 ENGINEERING NOT INCLUDED IN OTHER CATEGORIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; SAFETY; FOUNDATIONS
DESCRIPTION: The Inguri hydroelectric station (HES) is a cascade of hydroelectric stations including, in addition to the dam - diversion installation of the Inguri HES proper, the near-dam installation of the Perepad HES-1 and three similar channel installations of the Perepad HESs-2, -3, and -4 located on the tailrace emptying into the Black Sea. The HESs of the cascade use the fall of two rivers, the Inguri and Eristskali, by diverting the waters of the Inguri into the Eristskali.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 2, 20-26(Feb 1994)

TITLE: Hydro development of Greece's Acheloos and Aliakmon rivers
AUTHORS: Kalkani, E C; Stefanakos, J; Moutafis, N J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; GREECE; IRRIGATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; PLANNING; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; EUROPE; POWER PLANTS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: This article describes how several hydroelectric projects operate in series to satisfy downstream irrigation needs in water-short western and northern Greece. Two areas of Greece have experienced substantial and unusual hydroelectric development in recent years. In the west, three hydroelectric projects--Kremasta, Kastraki and Stratos--function as a series and are operated to satisfy the needs of downstream entities that require water for irrigation. Public Power Corp. of Greece operates the power plants. Similar active growth in hydroelectric development has taken place in northern Greece. In this area, the Polyphyto, Sfikia and Assomata projects also operate in series with consideration for downstream irrigation during the summer. In western Greece, the hydropower development of the Acheloos river includes six major dams and reservoirs. The Tavropos, Kremasta, Kastraki and Stratos systems are in operation, Messochora is under construction and Sykia is in the final design. The diversion scheme of the Acheloos river to the eastern part of Greece will require the Pyli and Mouzaki dams and the Pefkofyto, Mouzaki and Mavromati power plants in the Thessaly plain. A layout of the dams on the Acheloos river is presented.
RELATION: Journal Name: Power Engineering; (United States); Journal Volume: 98:7

TITLE: Industry safety inspection of hydraulic structures of electric power stations under conditions of the development of market relations and transformation of organizational and legal forms of power enterprises
AUTHORS: Serkov, V S; Vasilevskii, A G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ON-SITE INSPECTION; REGULATIONS; ELECTRIC POWER INDUSTRY; REGULATORY GUIDES; USSR ORGANIZATIONS; LEGISLATION; HYDRAULICS; JOINT VENTURES; SAFETY ENGINEERING; OPERATION; USSR
DESCRIPTION: Under present day conditions in the Commonwealth of Independent States (Russia), the system for the state`s safety inspection of hydraulic structures is still being formulated. The USSR Ministry of Power and Electrification, organized more than 20 years ago, was responsible for the inspection of pressure hydraulic structures; but their approach based on administrative order principles can no longer provide acceptable results in this age of power enterprises owned by joint stock companies. Therefore, the level of responsibility for pressure hydraulic structures should be increased accordingly to the new owners and operators. The owners of hydraulic structures are obliged to conform to the `Operating rules of electric power stations and networks`, to equip the structures with monitoring and measuring equipment, to enlist specialists with the necessary skills, and to operate and maintain the structures. The owner`s activity needs to be checked on site, which should be done either by state management agencies or any large industry association. The main result of a inspection should be a conclusion about the correspondence of the organization to the guidelines in effect in the country and in the industry. In addition to such monitoring, their should exist a system of scientific support to help solve a wide range of scientific and technical problems associated with hydraulic structures.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jul 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 1, 4-7(Jan 1994)

TITLE: Experience in constructing the Zagorsk pumped-storage station
AUTHORS: Plotnikov, V M; Bykadorov, A A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; POWER GENERATION; DESIGN; USSR; PUBLIC UTILITIES; USSR ORGANIZATIONS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; GEOLOGIC SURVEYS; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; ELECTRIC POWER INDUSTRY
DESCRIPTION: The Zagorsk pumped storage station (PSS) is the first large power installation of a new type in Russia with a 800,000 kw capacity after put into operation. The design life of the hydro development is 80 years. The year 1994 marks the 20th year since beginning construction, which doubled the original estimates in time while the cost has been 2.5 times more than expected. Unfortunately, the Zagorsk PSS was built in an area of moist climate and moraine loam, where it is not advisable to build dikes. In 1993 unit number five will be started in a synchronous capacitor regime, with the conduit for number five completed in 1994. A sixth unit with be put into operation after the filling of the second phase of the upper reservoir is completed not earlier than 1996. The following tasks are required to finish the structure: drainage system of the dikes of the upper reservoir and slopes, restoration of disrupted measuring and monitoring equipment, completion of the roof of the PSS powerhouse with fire protection, and bringing the groutstops of the shutoff structures to the design elevations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jul 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 1, 18-23(Jan 1994)

TITLE: Dam safety legislation in the United States of America
AUTHORS: Danilevskii, A A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; USA; REGULATIONS; LEGISLATION; DAMS; ON-SITE INSPECTION; SAFETY ENGINEERING; OPERATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRIC POWER INDUSTRY
DESCRIPTION: In the register of International Commission on Large Dams, there are 1200 dams with a height of more than 30 m in the territory of the United States of America. Of them, 480, or 40% were constructed and are being operated by federal or national agencies such as the Army Corps of Engineers, Bureau of Reclamation, Tennessee Valley Authority, etc. These dams make up only a small percentage of the 67,000 dams in the USA. The majority of these dams are not under federal jurisdiction, therefore the dams are managed under city, state, or federal decrees pertaining to nonfederal dams. For the federal dams, the federal government gives clear guidelines pertaining to safety service; surveys and design; construction; operation and maintenance; and a model program for dam safety staffs. The author states that inspection of dams by national institutions or staffs is necessary from the start of design and during their entire time of their existence, and should be established by law.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jul 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 1, 26-30(Jan 1994)

TITLE: Problem of unity of measurements in ensuring safety of hydraulic structures
AUTHORS: Kheifits, V Z; Markov, A I; Braitsev, V V
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENGINEERED SAFETY SYSTEMS; DAMS; FAILURE MODE ANALYSIS; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; ON-LINE MEASUREMENT SYSTEMS; TRANSDUCERS; MONITORING; USSR ORGANIZATIONS; REGULATORY GUIDES; USSR; FAILURES
DESCRIPTION: Ensuring the safety of hydraulic structures (HSs) is not only an industry but also a national and global concern, since failure of large water impounding structures can entail large losses of lives and enormous material losses related to destruction downstream. The main information on the degree of safety of a structure is obtained by comparing information about the actual state of the structure obtained on the basis of measurements in key zones of the structure with the predicted state on basis of the design model used when designing the structure for given conditions of external actions. Numerous, from hundreds to thousands, string type transducers are placed in large HSs. This system of transducers monitor the stress-strain rate, seepage, and thermal regimes. These measurements are supported by the State Standards Committee which certifies the accuracy of the checking methods. To improve the instrumental monitoring of HSs, the author recommends: Calibration of methods and means of reliable diagnosis for each measuring channel in the HS, improvements to reduce measurement error, support for the system software programs, and development of appropriate standards for the design and examination of HSs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jul 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 1, 14-17(Jan 1994)

TITLE: Organization of monitoring the safety of hydraulic structures of the Volga-Lenin hydroelectric station
AUTHORS: Petrov, Yu A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; USSR; DAMS; HYDRAULICS; ON-SITE INSPECTION; SAFETY ENGINEERING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; SAFEGUARD REGULATIONS; VOLGA RIVER; JOINT VENTURES; LEGISLATION; ELECTRIC POWER INDUSTRY; EMBANKMENTS; SPILLWAYS
DESCRIPTION: The Volga-Lenin hydroelectric station on the Volga River forms a reservoir with a total storage of 58 square km and a maximum head of 26 m. The operating safety of the hydraulic structures is monitored on the basis of the `Regulations for the industry safety inspection system of hydraulic structures of electric power stations.` On the basis of the procedural instructions of the Regulations and recommendations of specialized institutes, the hydraulic engineering department worked out a five year and annual plans of instrumental measurements, inspection, and visual observations of the structures. The results of the inspections detail the condition and improvements needed on the Volga-Lenin station`s hydrostation powerhouse, the earth dam, the overflow dam, the hydromechanical equipment, plunge basins, turbines, and measuring/monitoring equipment.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 28; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jul 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 1, 23-25(Jan 1994)

TITLE: Implications of recent EIA changes in Thailand
AUTHORS: Tongcumpou, C; Harvey, N
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; ROADS; THAILAND; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT STATEMENTS; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; ASIA; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; DOCUMENT TYPES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; POWER PLANTS; 290300* - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The practice of environmental impact assessment (EIA) was implemented in Thailand after the revision of the National Environmental Quality Act in 1978. This led to more than 3,000 EIA documents being prepared and officially submitted up to 1992. More recently, a new act, the Enhancement and Conservation of National Environmental Quality Act, was introduced in 1992. As a consequence, some aspects of environmental legislation have been improved including the EIA process, which is expected to be more effective under the new act. This article examines the development and implementation of the EIA process in Thailand and its effectiveness in the context of its performance as an environmental management tool. The strengths and weaknesses of the EIA process under the original act are analyzed and compared to the new act, using two case studies in order to gain an insight into the EIA system. The first is the Second Stage Expressway in Bangkok, and the second is the Pak Mun Hydroelectric Dam project in Ubon Rachathani, a northeastern province of Thailand. EIAs for these projects were originally submitted according to the requirements of the old act. Both are public projects that have aroused controversy for different environmental reasons, although final decisions have been made facilitating the implementation of these projects. Finally, the article presents some suggestions for improving the content and procedures for the EIA system in Thailand.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environmental Impact Assessment Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 14:4

TITLE: Headcut advance threshold in earth spillways
AUTHORS: Moore, J S; Temple, D M; Kirsten, H A.D.
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; SPILLWAYS; DESIGN; EROSION; SAFETY ANALYSIS; SAFETY ENGINEERING; STABILIZATION; ENGINEERING; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: The USDA, Soil Conservation Service (SCS) has been involved with the design and construction of approximately 25,600 dams (Federal Emergency Management Agency, 1992) in the US. A major portion of these structures utilize earth auxiliary spillways to pass major flood flows around the dam. Despite their widespread successful use, the processes by which these spillways resist failure are only imperfectly understood. Design procedures and criteria (US Department of Agriculture, Soil Conservation Service, 1956, 1973, 1985) have tended to be empirical and based on limited data. Therefore, the USDA, SCS and Agricultural Research Service (ARS) developed a research and field data acquisition program with the goals of improving the understanding of the erosional processes involved and developing new criteria for design and analysis. This paper's analysis considers the attack threshold above which the headcut advance would be expected to take place. This analysis represents a portion of the DAES team effort carried out by the authors in consultation with other team members. The relations developed may be used to estimate conditions under which headcuts would be expected to become unstable.
RELATION: Journal Name: Bulletin of the Association of Engineering Geologists; (United States); Journal Volume: 31:2
JOURNAL_NAME: Bulletin of the Association of Engineering Geologists; (United States)

TITLE: Water pumping and electricity from a river flow turbine
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; DESIGN; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; WATER PUMPS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; ELECTRIC POWER; HORIZONTAL AXIS TURBINES; PHOTOVOLTAIC CONVERSION; POWER GENERATION; CONVERSION; DIRECT ENERGY CONVERSION; ENERGY CONVERSION; EQUIPMENT; EVALUATION; MACHINERY; POWER; PUMPS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; WIND TURBINES; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: The Tyson Turbine can generate electricity and pump water powered by the energy of flowing streams of water. Due to its design it is ideal for use in developing countries and isolated areas. The author describes the design and finds that the turbine compares favourably to an equivalent PV system.
RELATION: Journal Name: Sunworld; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:2

TITLE: Aquatic systems a concern as the government relicenses dams
AUTHORS: Baker, B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; LICENSING REGULATIONS; US FERC; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; REGULATIONS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 290300 - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety
DESCRIPTION: Changes in Washington may give new life to the nation's rivers as federal regulators begin the massive relicensing of hundreds of hydropower projects. FERC may be able to mitigate decades of damage by vigorously enforcing 1986 legislation that protects fisheries and wildlife. This article discusses the possible actions of FERC in this respect.
RELATION: Journal Name: Bioscience; (United States); Journal Volume: 44:6

TITLE: Sediment and water discharge rates of Turkish Black Sea rivers before and after hydropower dam construction
AUTHORS: Hay, B J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; RIVERS; FLOW RATE; SEDIMENTS; ECOLOGICAL CONCENTRATION; BLACK SEA; TURKEY; ASIA; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; MIDDLE EAST; POWER PLANTS; SEAS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Presently, the water discharge rate to the Black Sea by Turkish rivers is approximately 41 km[sup 3]/yr. The sediment discharge rate of Turkish rivers to the Black Sea is 28 x 10[sup 6] t/yr. Before construction of the hydroelectric dams, the sediment discharge rate was approximately 70 x 10[sup 6] t/yr. The sharp reduction in sediment load is largely a result of the dams near the mouths of the Yesil Irmak and Kizil Irmak rivers. Before the construction of dams, Turkish rivers contributed approximately one third of the total amount of sediment received by the Black Sea from all surrounding rivers. The life-span of the major reservoirs varies from approximately only one century (Yesil Irmak river reservoirs) to several thousand years (Sakarya river reservoirs). Life-span for the large Altinkaya Dam reservoir is estimated with approximately 500 yr.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environmental Geology and Water Sciences; (United States); Journal Volume: 23:4
JOURNAL_NAME: Environmental Geology and Water Sciences; (United States)

TITLE: Peasant agriculture and global change: A maya response to energy development in southeastern Mexico
AUTHORS: Collier, G A; Mountjoy, D C; Nigh, R B
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 02 PETROLEUM; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; MEXICO; AGRICULTURE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OIL FIELDS; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; LATIN AMERICA; MINERAL RESOURCES; NORTH AMERICA; PETROLEUM DEPOSITS; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCES; 290200* - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics & Sociology; 020700 - Petroleum- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: This article combines data and perspectives from anthropology, agricultural economics, and landscape ecology to study how peasant activity mediates the influence of global economic driving forces on land-use patterns. Southeastern Mexico underwent rapid energy development during the 1960's and 1970's. The state used oil revenues to complete projects such as two major new hydroelectric power projects. As energy development went into high gear, the southeastern region, which had been primarily agrarian, began to supply Mexico with 50% of its energy and much of its export oil and the agricultural base declined. Discussed in this article are the following related areas: sectoral changes under the energy development boom; landscape dynamics; off-farm activities of peasants during the energy boom; Ainacanteco agriculture transformed after 1982; off-farm peasant production and agrarian transformation; peasant versatility and environmental policy. 28 refs., 7 figs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Bioscience; (United States); Journal Volume: 44:6

TITLE: A generic DSP-based real-time simulator with application to hydrogenerator speed controller development. [Digital Signal Processor]
AUTHORS: Throckmorton, P J; Wozniak, L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; SPEED REGULATORS; SIMULATORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; REAL TIME SYSTEMS; ANALOG SYSTEMS; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; FUNCTIONAL MODELS; POWER PLANTS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 990200 - Mathematics & Computers
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents the features and evaluation of a digital signal processor/personal computer-based simulator which allows the simultaneous simulation of two linear systems in real time. A desire to gain the ability to evaluate hydrogenerator governors (speed controllers) in forms completely equivalent to that which could be used to control actual hydrogenerators is the primary motivation for this work. The simulator is designed so that one linear system nay be conceptualized as an error controller while the second system may be thought of as a plant under control. The simulator is specialized in that it allows direct entry of the hydrogenerator system parameter values of one of two linearized hydrogenerating system plant models. An option to enter the gains of a generic PID controller also exists. This PID controller may be utilized to simulate a governor for a hydrogenerator, thus allowing the real-time simulation of a closed-loop speed-controlled hydrogenerating system. Simulation accuracy is established by comparing computed results to those computed by an accepted standard'' software package. An IBM-compatible personal computer and a modified Texas Instruments TMS320C30 digital signal processor evaluation module are the primary hardware used.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 9:2
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 42 ENGINEERING NOT INCLUDED IN OTHER CATEGORIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SAFETY ANALYSIS; INSPECTION; UNDERWATER FACILITIES; FAILURES; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; DAMAGE
DESCRIPTION: The industry safety inspection system of hydraulic structures of electric power station was created in 1971. At first (1972) the Provisional regulations on safety inspection of hydraulic structures of electric power stations and Standard technical program of inspecting hydraulic structures of operating electric power stations were drawn up and introduced. Subsequently (1978) the List of electric power stations of the USSR Ministry of Power and Electrification (Minenergo) subject to centralized safety inspection of hydraulic structures was drawn up and introduced. All inspection documents were drawn up by the All-Union State Trust for Organization and Rationalization of Regional Power Stations and Networks (ORGRES), which also revised them in 1980-1982 and 1988. In the latest revision the Standard program became an integral part of the basic document.

AUTHORS: Bryzgalov, V I; Stafievskii, V A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 42 ENGINEERING NOT INCLUDED IN OTHER CATEGORIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; AGING; MONITORING; UNDERWATER FACILITIES; SAFETY ANALYSIS; FAILURES; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; DAMAGE
DESCRIPTION: Engineering art when reference is to the reliability of an engineering structure should not depend on the political situation in the country. For example, in stagnant years it was decided to replace the type of dam at the Krasnoyarsk hydroelectric station (HES). Despite the insistence of the design organization for a so-called buttress dam, the engineering corps of like-minded persons - the construction engineers and customer headed by the chief of the construction project - categorically objected to the proposed design: in the construction industry the technology was not ready for openwork construction under harsh climatic conditions, and, what really matters, millions of people living downstream of the dam should be safeguarded against disasters. As a result a gravity dam was adopted.

TITLE: A retrospective view of the quality of the fauna component of the Olympic Dam Project Environmental Impact Statement
AUTHORS: Read, J L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; ANIMALS; BASELINE ECOLOGY; SPECIES DIVERSITY
DESCRIPTION: The merits of the fauna section of the Olympic Dam Project Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) are discussed. The values of different survey methods and monitoring organisms used in this document are evaluated following 10 years of fauna monitoring and research subsequent to the preparation of the EIS. The pilot fauna reconnaissance was found to be of little value, although the associated literature review formed an integral part of the EIS. Over 95% of all amphibian, reptile and bird species recorded at Olympic Dam were confirmed or predicted to occur in the EIS. Mammal predictions were less accurate because of the sparse populations and irruptive nature of several arid-zone species. Prediction and monitoring of rare species were demonstrably difficult. The Olympic Dam Project EIS was found in general to be an accurate and useful document. However, it is suggested that more emphasis be placed on establishing monitoring programmes for future EISs, particularly for invertebrates. 35 refs., 1 fig., 3 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Environmental Management; Journal Volume: 41; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Jun 1994

TITLE: A simulation of fishway design: An example of simulation in environmental problem solving
AUTHORS: Karisch, S E; Power, M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; EVALUATION; DAMS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; SALMON; MIGRATION; COLUMBIA RIVER BASIN
DESCRIPTION: This paper agrees that modelling provides a convenient and cost-effective means of characterizing and predicting the behaviour of environmental systems disturbed by man. A series of modeling criteria are suggested that aim at compelling modelling work with current data, explicitly represent the current understanding of a system, include considerations of variability, and address predictive uncertainty. Models which do so provide a rigorous framework for the comparison of alternative courses of action. As an example of the methodology, the problems associated with the fishway design, highlighting the required statistical analysis and insights, are discussed. Comparison of the modelling results to those gained from operational experience with real fishways were used to validate model results and ensure model credibility. The models were then used to examine the effect of design on interactions between pools in fishways as a means of selecting the designs which minimized migration stress. 15 refs., 2 figs., 2 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Environmental Management; Journal Volume: 41; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: May 1994

TITLE: Reporting survival results of fish passing through low-head turbines
AUTHORS: Matousek, J A; Wells, A W; Hecht, J H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISHES; MORTALITY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES
DESCRIPTION: Findings from investigations at four Michigan hydroelectric plants indicate low to moderate mortality rates among fish passing through turbines. A fish passage study recently completed at four hydroelectric facilities on the Muskkegon and Au Sable rivers found that over 83% of the fish survive turbine entrainment. This study provides answers to questions about entrainment mortality of resident cool water fish species in the Midwest passing through turbines of various configurations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 8; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: May 1994

TITLE: An emerging entitlement program
AUTHORS: Hunt, R; Hunt, J M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; US FERC; LICENSING REGULATIONS; HABITAT; POPULATION DENSITY; POPULATION DYNAMICS; SALMON; ANADROMOUS FISHES; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; FISHES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; REGULATIONS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Recent hydropower licensing experiences emphasize the need for a reasoned fish resource protection approach, one that is based upon feasibility and sound objectives. Recently, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) required a hydropower project in Virginia to install a $400,000 fishway as a condition of receiving its license. The noteworthiness of this event lies in the fact that there is currently no possibility of anadromous fish reaching the project. The project is located at the third dam upstream from the mouth of the river, above two dams with no fishway facilities to allow fish to bypass these dams. FERC's apparent concern was that fishways might one day be built at the intervening dams. In the end, FERC authorized the mothballing of this fishway until such time as anadromous fish could reach the dam, if ever. Everyone recognizes the need for fishways that allow the movement of anadromous fish, such as salmon, upstream and downstream past hydropower dams. However, recent hydropower licensing experiences emphasize the need for a reasoned approach based upon feasibility and sound objectives for fish resources. When single projects are made to install expensive fishways in circumstances not supported by objectives or when fishway requirements appear to be limited only be the project's ability to bear the cost, these requirements take on the guise of a penalty to make up for perceived past damage to the resource. Congress and the public will want to pay close attention to any such tendency because such a penalty raises the cost of electricity generated by hydropower facilities with questionable gain.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 24:4

TITLE: CAD for small hydro projects
AUTHORS: Bishop, Jr, N A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COMPUTER-AIDED DESIGN; ENGINEERS; POWER RANGE 01-10 MW; TRAINING; ANIMALS; DESIGN; EDUCATION; MAMMALS; MAN; MEGAWATT POWER RANGE; PERSONNEL; POWER PLANTS; POWER RANGE; PRIMATES; PROFESSIONAL PERSONNEL; VERTEBRATES; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Over the past decade, computer-aided design (CAD) has become a practical and economical design tool. Today, specifying CAD hardware and software is relatively easy once you know what the design requirements are. But finding experienced CAD professionals is often more difficult. Most CAD users have only two or three years of design experience; more experienced design personnel are frequently not CAD literate. However, effective use of CAD can be the key to lowering design costs and improving design quality--a quest familiar to every manager and designer. By emphasizing computer-aided design literacy at all levels of the firm, a Canadian joint-venture company that specializes in engineering small hydroelectric projects has cut costs, become more productive and improved design quality. This article describes how they did it.
RELATION: Journal Name: Civil Engineering (New York, 1983); (United States); Journal Volume: 64:4

TITLE: Fighting for economic survival
AUTHORS: Lagassa, G
