SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; MAINE; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; NEW HAMPSHIRE; SOCIAL IMPACT; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; USA; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 290200 - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics & Sociology
DESCRIPTION: Licensing entanglements and challenges could end up hurting the local economies of several Northeastern states, as well as several companies looking to hydropower as a capacity source. From its headwaters deep in the north words of Maine, through New Hampshire's northernmost Coos County, to the Atlantic Ocean in Brunswick, Maine, the Androscoggin River constitutes about 3,500 square miles of drainage area. Of the basin's 50 dams, 47 have hydroelectric generators totaling about 250 megawatts, and the remaining three are at headwater lakes which play a key role in the hydroelectric feasibility of the downstream sites. With five separate regulable lakes in its headwaters, the Androscoggin constitutes one of the best rivers for hydroelectric production in the United States. This article describes the hydropower projects on the river, and their link to local companies and the economy. Environmental challenges to relicensing of projects may damage the local economy if plants are not relicensed or are forced to spend too much to comply with regulations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 24:4

TITLE: The performance perspective. [Hydro power plant equipment]
AUTHORS: Hennagir, T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; MARKET; PERFORMANCE; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; ENERGY EFFICIENCY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EFFICIENCY; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Competition and over-capacity continue to shape the market equation for hydropower equipment manufactures. One variable is the increasingly cost-conscious client, searching for a supplier that can squeeze every available megawatt out of an upgrade; another is the lure of overseas projects and the continued confirmation the North American market will remain sluggish. Balancing this equation is a tall order for equipment suppliers, as they search for success in domestic and global markets. Competition is accelerating technical developments in the industry, especially turbine efficiency and cavitation performance. Several equipment suppliers were interviewed about their perspectives on this changing marketplace.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 24:4

TITLE: Monitoring ozone for hydro plant safety, maintenance
AUTHORS: Franklin, D E; Macdonald, J A; Laakso, J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; OZONE; MONITORING; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ELECTRIC COILS; OPERATION; MAINTENANCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: B.C. Hydro is testing a system for monitoring the presence of ozone in air-cooled generators at one of its hydroelectric plants. The system provides a warning for potentially dangerous gases in the powerhouse and is expected to help plant maintenance personnel assess the deterioration of generator windings.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 13; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1994

TITLE: Evaluating the behavior of dams during earthquakes
AUTHORS: Duron, Z H; Aagaard, B; Fischer, B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SEISMIC EFFECTS; EVALUATION; DAMS; DIAGRAMS; NUMERICAL DATA
DESCRIPTION: The severe earthquake that killed dozens of people and resulted in billions of dollars in economic loss in southern California in January 1994 provides a sobering reminder of the potential damage such events can cause... and the need to ensure that structures can withstand them. A team of California-based researchers is working on a program to give dam owners better tools for understanding their structures` response to earthquakes.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 13; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1994

TITLE: Looking to liners for reduced canal maintenance at hydro projects
AUTHORS: Pegan, D J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DISCHARGE CANALS; INTAKE CANALS; MAINTENANCE; LINERS; CONCRETES
DESCRIPTION: Aging canals and waterways cost Pacific Gas and Electric Company millions of dollars a year in maintenance expense and lost water. A plan to line the canals with high-density plastic shows promise for eliminating those problems and increasing waterway capacity.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; Journal Volume: 13; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Apr 1994

TITLE: Parametric evaluation of cross-flow turbine performance
AUTHORS: Desai, V R; Aziz, N M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; PERFORMANCE; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENERGY EFFICIENCY; PARAMETRIC ANALYSIS; EFFICIENCY; EQUIPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: The present paper discusses an experimental investigation of the key parameters influencing cross-flow turbine efficiency. The experiments included measurements of torque, rotational speed, flow rate, and total head in physical models of turbines and nozzles. One physical parameter (flow rate) and six geometric parameters of the turbine were investigated: the angle of water entry to the runner, diameter ratio, number of blades, flow-stream spreading, runner aspect ratio, and blade exit angle. A total of 39 runners and 11 nozzles were tested in 75 different combinations. Analysis performed on the results identified the impact of the different parameters on the turbine efficiency. The results indicate that with careful selection of the cross-flow turbine parameters, efficiencies as high as 88.0% with an uncertainty of [+-]2.4% can be achieved. This is considered an improvement over the claimed maximum efficiency reported in the literature.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Energy Engineering; (United States); Journal Volume: 120:1

TITLE: Boost in generating planned
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EXPANSION; CAPACITY; BRITISH COLUMBIA
DESCRIPTION: This article is a review of an innovative agreement by which a British Columbia mining firm will finance an expansion by selling rights to increase the capacity of two hydroelectric plants. These rights are being sold to the province. The agreement would add 500 MWe of capacity at Waneta Dam and at brilliant Dam.
RELATION: Journal Name: ENR; Journal Volume: 232; Journal Issue: 12; Other Information: PBD: 21 Mar 1994

TITLE: Pumped storage job is a rocky challenge
AUTHORS: Setzer, S W
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; FINANCING; GEORGIA
DESCRIPTION: Georgia mountain lives up to its rugged name as excavators fight some unexpected ground conditions. When settlers pushed into the remote valleys of far northwestern Georgia, they had no idea just how apt the name given one odd geologic formation would become to a new generation of pioneers. Rocky Mountain`s 700 ft of diagonally upthrusting limestone, shale and sandstone layers have become the main antagonists in a decade-long struggle to place an 848-Mw pumped storage power project in and around the mountain.
RELATION: Journal Name: ENR; Journal Volume: 232; Journal Issue: 10; Other Information: PBD: 7 Mar 1994

TITLE: Hydro-Quebec projects hit by high court ruling
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; QUEBEC
DESCRIPTION: In a decision that may set back Hydro-Quebec`s plans for billions of dollars worth of new hydroelectric installations, the Canadian Supreme Court ruled in late February that the National Energy Board of Canada may require extensive environmental assessments of new projects if any part of the power to be generated is bound for the U.S.
RELATION: Journal Name: ENR; Journal Volume: 232; Journal Issue: 10; Other Information: PBD: 7 Mar 1994

TITLE: Improving T D reliability. How pumped storage can boost network security
AUTHORS: Llodra, J; Depenbrock, F
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 25 ENERGY STORAGE; POWER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; RELIABILITY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; USES; POWER TRANSMISSION LINES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MANAGEMENT; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 240201* - Power System Networks, Transmission & Distribution- AC Systems- (1990-); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 250000 - Energy Storage
DESCRIPTION: The key to improving transmission-network security is faster response to contingencies. Now a new breed of pumped-storage plant - designed for ultra-fast response - may soon provide a tool dispatchers can use to improve network security. This type of plant can also substantially increase the effective capacity of existing transmission lines and improve the performance of thermal generating units. The Mt. Hope Waterpower Project, planned for Rockaway Township, NJ, 35 miles west of New York City, lies strategically adjacent to major load centers at the eastern end of the PJM control area and near the interconnection point with the New York Power Pool (NYPP). This location also is in an area deficient in significant generating facilities. Maximum design capacity of the project is 2000 MW, provided by six reversible pump/turbines, each with a nominal 340-MW rating. The upper reservoir, with a surface area of only 60 acres, provides 5000 acre-ft of active storage volume - equivalent to 10 GWh of nominal energy storage. The Mt. Hope plant will also have the capability (intended for a limited number of emergency occurrences) to change from full pumping to full generation - a 4000 MW swing - in one minute. 6 figs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electrical World; (United States); Journal Volume: 208:3

TITLE: South America consortia
AUTHORS: Hennagir, T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; ARGENTINA; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SALES; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; LATIN AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; SOUTH AMERICA; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: Privatization of hydropower assets is creating new consortia opportunities throughout South America. This is particularly true in Argentina, where recent operating concession and ownership arrangements with CMS Generating Co. and Duke Energy Corp. for the country's two largest hydropower projects are the latest developments in Argentina's effort to develop private power. By the end of last year, Argentina had opened more than 7,000 MW of generation assets to privatization. In July, Hidroelectrica Norpatagonia S.A. (Hidronor) sold the 1,320 MW El Chocon project located on the Limay River in southwestern Argentina to the Hidroinvest S.A. consortium composed of CMS Generating Co., Chilean electric company Empressa Nacional de Electridad (Endesa), the Argentina province of Neuquen, BEA Associates and Sawgrass Limited of Spain. CMS holds about 15 percent of the ownership interest in El Chocon, a two-unit facility consisting of the 1,200 MW El Chocon station and the 120 MW Aroyito station on the Limay River. The plants will be operated by CMS according to a 30-year concession agreement. The other Argentine consortium that made financial headlines at the end of 1993 was Hidronenquen S.A., an international group of investors consisting of Duke Energy, Chilgener S.A. of Chile and TransAlta Energy of Canada. This consortium was awarded majority ownership and operation of Hidroelectrica Piedra del Aguila S.A., a 1,400 MW facility also on the Limay River, 62 miles upstream from the El Chocon station. The Emerging Marks Growth Fund Inc. and the New World Investment Fund, based on Los Angeles, Calif., are financial investors for the consortium's $272 million bid, which was selected in November by the government. Hidronenquen S.A. assumed ownership and operation of the complex in December 1993.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 24:3

TITLE: Managing complexity in large system models
AUTHORS: Bloom, J; Clark, C; Wildberger, M
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; ECONOMICS; PLANNING; SYSTEMS ANALYSIS; ATMOSPHERIC PRECIPITATIONS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SCHEDULES; STREAMS; WEATHER; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; SIMULATION; SURFACE WATERS; 296000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 990200 - Mathematics & Computers; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Many complex utility systems, such as power grids and hydroelectric networks, involve so many interacting considerations that comprehensive analysis or simulation for planning or control purposes is at present impractical or impossible, using even the largest computers. EPRI has sponsored exploratory research to develop systematic procedures for managing complexity in large system models - procedures designed to enhance the ability of utility planners to optimize current operations while hedging against uncertainties that could significantly influence future costs. Related procedures are being applied to optimize hydroelectric scheduling under uncertainties associated with weather and other factors. And in ongoing exploratory work, additional computational and conceptual approaches for managing complexity in utility planning and control applications are being investigated. 1 fig.
RELATION: Journal Name: EPRI Journal (Electric Power Research Institute); (United States); Journal Volume: 19:2
JOURNAL_NAME: EPRI Journal (Electric Power Research Institute); (United States)

TITLE: Damage mechanisms and influence of gradation for steep riprap
AUTHORS: Rohan, K; Belfadhel, M B; Lefebvre, G; Dascal, O
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 58 GEOSCIENCES; DAMS; EROSION CONTROL; RESPONSE FUNCTIONS; STABILITY; EMBANKMENTS; EROSION; WAVE FORCES; CONTROL; FUNCTIONS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 540250 - Environment, Terrestrial- Site Resource & Use Studies- (1990-); 580000 - Geosciences
DESCRIPTION: Model tests in a laboratory flume were performed to verify certain hypotheses put forward to explain steep riprap behavior observed in the field at several embankment dam sites. The laboratory study has focused on riprap degradation under wave attack, and on the influence of fine blocks incorporated into riprap. Unlike flatter riprap, steep riprap is characterized by a low rate of damage until a point of acceleration, after which damage progresses rapidly. At that stage, damage is characterized by sliding and crumbling, which results in an upward propagation of damage toward the crest. The inclusion of a portion of small blocks into the riprap significantly reduces the stability of seep riprap. This detrimental effect is gradually reduced as the riprap slope becomes flatter.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Geotechnical Engineering; (United States); Journal Volume: 120:3

TITLE: Electrical features of the Rocky Mountain Pumped-Storage Project
AUTHORS: Fostiak, R J; Davis, H R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; CONTROL SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; GEORGIA; OPERATION; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; EQUIPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NORTH AMERICA; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The Rocky Mountain Pumped Storage Project is scheduled for full commercial operation on the Georgia Interconnected Transmission System (ITS) in May, 1995. This paper describes the significant features of the major electrical equipment. Particular emphasis is placed on the considerations which led to the selection of static, variable-frequency starting of the units as pumps and to the use of a distributed control system (DCS) for full manual and automatic operation of the power station.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 9:1
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Adaptive hydrogenerator governor tuning with a genetic algorithm
AUTHORS: Lansberry, J E; Wozniak, L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; SPEED REGULATORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ALGORITHMS; OPTIMIZATION; PERFORMANCE; STABILITY; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; POWER PLANTS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: An important aspect of a good control algorithm is robustness with respect to changing plant parameters. Adaptive control strategies attempt to address the robustness issue by optimizing control parameters as changes occur in the plant. This paper investigates the genetic algorithm as one possible means of adaptively optimizing the gains of a proportional-plus-integral hydrogenerator governor. Previous work has shown that the genetic algorithm can effectively optimize the control parameters for a fixed plant. An enhanced version of the genetic algorithm, using the notions of diploidy and dominance, can be used to address the robustness issue. Here, changes in the conduit time constant as well as load constant are considered. It is shown that the genetic algorithm can effectively follow changes in the plant parameters, producing optimal control parameters in an adaptive environment.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 9:1
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Metal pollution loading, Manzalah lagoon, Nile delta, Egypt: Implications for aquaculture
AUTHORS: Siegel, F R; Slaboda, M L; Stanley, D J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; METALS; ECOLOGICAL CONCENTRATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; EGYPTIAN ARAB REPUBLIC; AQUACULTURE; SEDIMENTS; CONTAMINATION; INDUSTRIAL WASTES; DAMS
DESCRIPTION: High cultural enrichment factors are found for Hg (13 x), Pb (22.1 x), and other potentially toxic metals (e.g., Sn, Zn, Cu, Ag) in the upper 20 cm of sediment cores from the southeastern Ginka subbasin of Manzalah lagoon, Nile delta, Egypt. Cores from other areas of the lagoon show little metal loading. Metal loading followed the closure of the Aswan High Dam, the availability of abundant cheap electricity, and the development of major power-based industries. Industrial wastes containing potentially toxic metals are dumped into the Nile delta drain system. The load carried by Bahr El-Baqar drain discharges into the Ginka subbasin, which acts as a sink and results in metal loading of the sediment deposited there. Further development of aquaculture in this subbasin, of food-stuff agriculture on recently reclaimed lagoon bottom, or where irrigation waters come from Bahr El-Baqar drain or its discharge should be halted or strictly limited until potentially toxic metals in the drain waters and sediment are removed and polluted input drastically reduced. This environmental assessment of heavy metals in aquaculture or agriculture development should extend to other waterbodies in the northern Nile delta, particularly Idku lagoon and Lake Mariut, where industrial metal-bearing wastes discharge into the waterbodies. 21 refs., 7 figs., 3 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environmental Geology and Water Sciences; Journal Volume: 23; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Mar 1994

TITLE: Hydropower's information highway
AUTHORS: Lagassa, G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DATA ACQUISITION SYSTEMS; INFORMATION SYSTEMS; COMPUTER NETWORKS; INFORMATION DISSEMINATION; POWER PLANTS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 990300 - Information Handling
DESCRIPTION: In the hydropower industry, the ability to acquire information, to analyze it, and to manage it has already improved dramatically and continues to do so. The benefits of computerized hydroelectric operating systems for automatic generator control and supervisory control and data acquisition are already known. While embryonic in form, use of the same technology for the acquisition and management of information external to daily operational concerns seems poised for a major expansion. Electronic information services for hydropower fit well with a world that is entering an era dominated by new technologies for information processing and data analysis. The possibilities for data acquisition, transmission and sharing seem almost unlimited. Because the ability to manage and analyze information after it is acquired is also improving, one is not bridled by technology but only by standards of relevance which shift and expand with improvements in technological capabilities. The demand for information and the ability to acquire it seem to go hand in hand, and there is little doubt the development of the promised information superhighway will further expand the standards of relevance.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 24:2

TITLE: What's [open quote]Smart[close quote] about improving what you have
AUTHORS: Nielsen, N; Keir, G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; RETROFITTING; ECONOMIC IMPACT; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; SOCIAL IMPACT; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; POWER PLANTS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The 1980s changed the lens through which many North American electric utilities view the future. Reduced load growth, forecasting uncertainty, and growing concerns about the economic, environmental, and social effects of energy decisions encouraged changes in the way system planning is conducted. At BC Hydro, the focus has shifted from development of large, capital-intensive hydroelectric projects toward options that provide smaller, less expensive, and more flexible additions to its system. Under a program called Resource Smart, existing hydro plants - which produce more than 95 percent of the utility's annual generation - are being rehabilitated and upgraded. Operating procedures also are being overhauled, and a variety of other measures are being implemented to gain more energy out of current resource inventories. BC Hydro does plan to add new generating units - but only at existing power plants or dams without hydroelectric facilities. The guiding principle is: every cost-effective project at an existing facility should be at least underway before the utility applies for regulatory approval to build its next major hydroelectric project at an undeveloped site. Since Resource Smart began, BC Hydro has added more than 920,000 megawatt-hours-per-year in energy gains. These additions have cost an average 0.7 cent per kilowatt-hour, just one-eighth of the marginal cost of acquiring that same supply from new hydro plants.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 8:1

TITLE: Evaluating the economics of new hydropower capacity
AUTHORS: Fargo, J M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; US FERC; LICENSING PROCEDURES; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; ECONOMICS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission's Office of Hydropower Licensing uses the results of two economic analysis methods for deciding whether proposed hydro capacity is economically feasible. These two methods are net present value and rate-of-return. This article describes the details of how these methods are applied and their role in the licensing of new hydro projects, and for new licenses for existing projects.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 8:1

TITLE: Mining [open quote]Energy Gold[close quote] in the Colorado mountains
AUTHORS: Meredith, K T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COLORADO; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Developers had a can't-miss plan for tapping the hydropower potential of Crooke's Falls in southwestern Colorado. All they had to do was last long enough to make it happen. This article describes the development of a small hydro plant on Crooke's Falls by a minister from southern California, using provisions of PURPA.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 8:1

TITLE: Experiences with embankment dam overtopping protection
AUTHORS: Powledge, G R; Pravdivets, Y P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; EROSION CONTROL; SAFETY; CONCRETE BLOCKS; BUILDING MATERIALS; CONTROL; MATERIALS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Several methods are available for use in protecting embankment dams that may be over-topped. This article focuses on the successful use of two of those methods - cellular concrete mats and wedge-shaped blocks - on existing dams.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 8:1

TITLE: Swan Falls: Bringing new lift to an old site
AUTHORS: Groff, E O
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DECOMMISSIONING; RETROFITTING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Idaho Power Company is adding a new hydroelectric project to its system in the spring of 1994. The utility anticipates that the new development will extend the life of an existing hydro site for another century. This article describes the development of the new hydroelectric project at the existing Swan Falls plant south of Boise. The design of the new powerhouse and the decommissioning of the old powerhouse are described.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 8:1

TITLE: Draft tube surging times two: The twin vortex phenomenon
AUTHORS: Wahl, T L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; SURGES; VORTICES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; STRUCTURAL MODELS; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Draft tube surging has long been a problem in hydraulic reaction turbines, causing vibrations, power swings, noise, and penstock pressure surges. Although the majority of draft tube surging research has examined single vortices, some recent studies at Grand Coulee focused on a twin vortex formation. Continued research is needed to learn more about the various types of draft tube surging.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 8:1

TITLE: A new method for estimating extreme rainfall probabilities
AUTHORS: Harper, G A; O'Hara, T F; Morris, D I
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; EPRI; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; RAIN; PREDICTION EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; ATMOSPHERIC PRECIPITATIONS; EQUATIONS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: As part of an EPRI-funded research program, the Yankee Atomic Electric Company developed a new method for estimating probabilities of extreme rainfall. It can be used, along with other techniques, to improve the estimation of probable maximum precipitation values for specific basins or regions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 8:1

TITLE: Postearthquake deformation analysis of wildlife site
AUTHORS: Gu, W H; Morgenstern, N R; Robertson, P K
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; DAMS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; EMBANKMENTS; STRESSES; DEFORMATION; GROUND MOTION; INTERSTITIAL WATER; NATURE RESERVES; PORE PRESSURE; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; GROUND WATER; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MOTION; NORTH AMERICA; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; RESOURCES; USA; WATER; 580000* - Geosciences; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: Postearthquake deformations of the Wildlife site, Imperial Valley, Calif., following the 1987 Superstition Hills earthquake, have been interpreted by finite-element deformation analyses. The analyses consider the stress redistribution and reconsolidation caused by the development of liquefaction. The stress redistribution analysis was conducted under fully undrained condition to consider the effects of strain-softening behavior of liquefied materials. The reconsolidation analysis was conducted using Biot's theory to consider the effects of dissipation of excess pore-water pressures. The results reveal that the delayed pore-water pressure response and deformation may be due to the redistribution of stresses and pore-water pressures.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Geotechnical Engineering; (United States); Journal Volume: 120:2

TITLE: A study on required reservoir size for pumped hydro storage
AUTHORS: Nanahara, T; Takimoto, A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; POWER SYSTEMS; RELIABILITY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; WATER RESERVOIRS; SIZING; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; ENERGY SYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes a methodology to examine reservoir size of pumped storage. In studying required characteristics of pumped storage such as required reservoir size, careful analysis is indispensable on its future operation. This paper presents a Monte Carlo simulation method that incorporates uncertainty in demands and supply capability and deals with both weekly and daily operations of pumped storage. The method examines required reservoir size form the viewpoint of power system reliability. A sample study discusses the sensitivity of required reservoir size on load profiles and generation mix.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 9:1
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Short term operation and power exchange planning of hydro-thermal power systems
AUTHORS: Rakic, M V; Markovic, Z M
SUBJECT: 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; INTERCONNECTED POWER SYSTEMS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; CALCULATION METHODS; SCHEDULES; ENERGY SYSTEMS; POWER PLANTS; POWER SYSTEMS; 240100* - Power Systems- (1990-); 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 200100 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Power Plants & Power Generation
DESCRIPTION: This paper considers a unified problem of short-term operation planning and power exchange scheduling of large hydro-thermal power systems including: unit commitment, hydro power plant operation planning, pumped-storage hydro power plant operation planning and scheduling of power exchange with other power utilities. The criterion function is the total variable profit incurred by energy production, sales of energy to the users inside the power system, sales of energy to other power companies and purchase of energy from them, or from other sources. The overall problem is solved using Lagrangian relaxation method. Decomposition technique is applied to solve the dual (mixed-integer) and primal (continuous programming) problem. Dynamic programming, feasible direction method and linear programming method are used for the solution of subproblems. The results of the application of the method to a numerical example are given in the end of the paper.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 9:1
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Prospects of development of the power industry in the zone of influence of the transcontinental railroad
AUTHORS: Fel`dman, B N; Luk`yanov, V A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; USSR; RAILWAYS; POWER SYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; PLANNING; POWER TRANSMISSION LINES
DESCRIPTION: The authors examine the possibilities of developing a power industry in the zone of influence of the transcontinental railroad (TCR). Two aspects of development are studied in particular: (1) the electric power supply for construction and subsequently for the operating railroad in coordination with simultaneous provision for the needs of adjacent regions; (2) the construction of a transcontinental transmission line with the use of a tunnel and railroad for its construction and with the creation of a unified transport--power corridor. Of great interest are the possibilities of constructing hydrostations in regions of the Sakha Republic (Yakutia), Chukchi Peninsula, and in the southern part of the Magadan region. The route of the proposed main line is located in the zone of influence of a number of prospective hydropower installations. 2 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 27; Journal Issue: 8; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 8, 22-24(Aug 1993)

TITLE: Utilization of the world`s potential water resources by hydropower installations
AUTHORS: Pretro, G A; Fedorov, M P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; WATER RESOURCES; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; GLOBAL ASPECTS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; FORECASTING
DESCRIPTION: This article discusses the development potential of water resources by constructing hydropower installations. The world theoretical, technical, and economic hydropower potential of rivers is evaluated. Global aspects of interest in construction of hydroelectric stations and actual construction of pumped-storage stations is discussed. It is concluded that: (1) A comparable evaluation of hydropower resources for continents and countries should be made on the basis of the technical hydropower potential and not the economic potential, which depends to a greater extent on the specific economic development for each country at a given time. (2) Works on developing hydro resources are being actively carried out in a number of developed and developing countries by constructing small hydroelectric stations, but the main role in their development is played by the construction of large and medium hydroelectric stations. (3) Due to the active construction of pumped-storage stations in a number of countries, the number of hours of use of the installed capacity has a clear tendency toward a decrease. 11 refs., 4 figs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrotechnical Construction; Journal Volume: 27; Journal Issue: 8; Other Information: PBD: Feb 1994; TN: Translated from Gidrotekhnicheskoe Stroitel`stvo; No. 8, 1-8(Aug 1993)

TITLE: Venezuelan Dam tests builder's skills
AUTHORS: Stussman, H B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; POLITICAL ASPECTS; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; TECHNOLOGY IMPACTS; VENEZUELA; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; LATIN AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; SOUTH AMERICA; 130000* - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: Given half a chance, Venezuela's Macagua II hydroelectric project would have been finished by now. Handed less than half a chance by the cash-strapped owner, the builder of this nearly $1-billion, 2,540-Mw power development has pushed the project to the 80% complete mark anyway. This article summarizes the status of their project in terms of construction progress, financing, and socio-economic factors in Venezuela.
RELATION: Journal Name: Engineering News-Record; (United States); Journal Volume: 232:1

TITLE: Zebra mussel monitoring
AUTHORS: Hennagir, T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; BIOLOGICAL FOULING; COST; MONITORING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MUSSELS; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; FOULING; INVERTEBRATES; MOLLUSCS; POWER PLANTS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: In less than a decade, zebra mussels have become the latest environmental scourge to plague the North American power industry. Infestations in the Great Lakes region have already reached natural disaster proportions. The invasion shows little sign of subsiding; Michigan's inland waters are the next most likely threatened area. In the southern United States, the mussles' migration has extended about 50 miles deeper than experts had originally predicted. By the year 2000, zebra mussel monitoring and control efforts will cost business and industry $5 billion, according to the federal Aquatic Nuisance Prevention and Control Act of 1990. Estimates of more than $1 million to control mussel fouling are projected for the Great Lakes area alone. While small independent hydropower stations are not as susceptible to zebra mussles as coal or nuclear facilities, there is cause for concern. Infestations can quickly foul hydropower plant components, hampering equipment operation and reducing facility efficiency. In extreme cases, leaving the mussels unchecked can result in stoplog gate flow blockage or false water level gauge readings. Advance prevention is often an effective first-line of defense against this troublesome, rapidly spreading and extremely prolific mollusk. Mussel monitoring efforts should begin a year in advance of when zebra mussels are expected to appear in a given location. Hydropower facility components that come into contact or rely exclusively on raw water are at greatest risk, as are other external components such as embayment walls, screens, trashracks and fish ladders.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 24:1

TITLE: Hydropower '93: The year in review
AUTHORS: Barnes, M J; Smith-Noggle, L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CANADA; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; USA; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; RETROFITTING; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: During 1993, 43 hydropower projects began operating in North America, adding 970 MW of hydroelectric capacity to electrical grids in the US and Canada. Owners include the US federal government, provincially owned Canadian utilities, municipalities, irrigation and water conservation groups, rural electric cooperatives, and private developers. Taken together, these new projects offer a telling commentary on trends and issues in the North American hydroelectric industry. A pervasive theme among the 1993 projects is one of making the most of what's available; that is, developing new hydropower capacity at existing structures - existing dams, irrigation canals, water supply conduits. Another is attention to environmental protection and incorporation of power facilities into the natural surroundings. A third is blending the old with the new through redevelopment of abandoned sites and refurbishing used equipment. In addition to these themes, another observation can be made: there is an abundance of diversity in hydro development in North America-diversity in approach, diversity in equipment, and diversity in the developers themselves.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:8

TITLE: Redeveloping utility plants
AUTHORS: Gottlieb, J W
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; FINANCING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RETROFITTING; LICENSING REGULATIONS; US FERC; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; REGULATIONS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: In 1987, Adirondack Hydro Development Corp., a Glens Falls, NY-based developer of independent hydropower projects, successfully won Niagara Mohawk's bid for proposals to redevelop the Middle Falls project. The benefits Adirondack Hydro offered Niagara Mohawk included savings in revenue requirements for the utility and its ratepayers, savings in avoided cost payments, avoidance of the risk associated with redeveloping the project, an increase in the generation and capacity of the project, and additional revenues for the utility through payments for the lease of the site. In return, Adirondack received a 40-year power purchase contract at competitive prices for any electricity generated by the project and a long-term source of income for the company and its shareholders. The redeveloped Middle Falls project has been generating electricity and providing benefits to Adirondack Hydro, Niagara Mohawk and its ratepayers since 1990. This example demonstrates an alternative for hydropower developers who are finding new project development problematic at best - especially in the United States. Federal regulatory initiatives and new state activism are combining to make greenfield development more difficult. Nevertheless, developers and utilities are exploring market niches for the deployment of new technologies and the opportunities for redevelopment and expanded operation of existing hydroelectric projects. At the same time, the new competitive utility marketplace has caused investor-owned utilities to explore ways to reduce or eliminate operating expenses on their systems in an effort to increase shareholder earnings while decreasing the cost of service. These elements have combined to create opportunities for the redevelopment of utility-owned hydroelectric projects such as was done with the Middle Falls Project.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 24:1

TITLE: Money-saving model
AUTHORS: Mettel, C; McGraw, D; Strater, S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; AU SABLE RIVER; FLOOD CONTROL; FLOODS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; WATERSHEDS; CONTROL; DISASTERS; RIVERS; SIMULATION; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: This article addresses refinements in computer models and satellite images that allowed for the reduction of costs for upgrading the dams and spillways on the Au Sable River. The upgrades were for increasing the capacity of the dams and spillways to accommodate a probable maximum flood. The topics of the article include a description of the basic watershed model, refining the calculations, verifying the results, and costs savings realized.
RELATION: Journal Name: Civil Engineering (New York, 1983); (United States); Journal Volume: 64:1

TITLE: Thermal effects of hydroelectric power stations on the environment
AUTHORS: Safonov, I P; Kovalenko, A N
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; THERMAL ANALYSIS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE
DESCRIPTION: The problem of {open_quotes}thermal contamination{close_quotes} of the atmosphere around active hydroelectric power stations is investigated. Using the energy and material balance equations for a steady-state incompressible liquid flow, it is shown that natural heat release from a water discharge is comparable with and, occasionally, exceeds the heat discharge of a thermal power station with an output equal to that of the HPS.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Engineering Physics and Thermophysics; Journal Volume: 65; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jan 1994; TN: Translated from Inzhenerno-Fizicheskii Zhurnal; 65: No. 1, 95-97(Jul 1993)
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of Engineering Physics and Thermophysics

TITLE: Planning and design of the transfer tunnel for the Lesotho highlands water projects
AUTHORS: Boniface, A; McKelvey, J G; Nthako, S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 42 ENGINEERING; TUNNELS; DESIGN; PLANNING; BASALT; CONCRETES; EXCAVATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LESOTHO; RIVERS; SHAFTS; VENTILATION; AFRICA; BUILDING MATERIALS; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; IGNEOUS ROCKS; MACHINE PARTS; MATERIALS; POWER PLANTS; ROCKS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; UNDERGROUND FACILITIES; VOLCANIC ROCKS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 422000 - Engineering- Mining & Underground Engineering- (1980-)
DESCRIPTION: The Transfer forms part of Phase 1A of the Lesotho Highlands Water Project. The tunnel has a length of 45 km, an excavated diameter of 5 m, and is situated at an altitude of nearly 2000 m above sea level. Directly connected to an underground power station, it is probably the longest headrace tunnel in the world. The tunnel is being excavated through basalt and runs in a northerly direction from an intake structure sited on the Malibamatso River, approximately 100 km east of Maseru. The paper describes the planning and design of the tunnel from the Project Optimization stage to the present. 5 refs., 6 figs., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Tunnelling and Underground Space Technology; (United Kingdom); Journal Volume: 9:1
JOURNAL_NAME: Tunnelling and Underground Space Technology; (United Kingdom)

TITLE: Turbine-passage mortality of juvenile American shad at a low-head hydroelectric dam
AUTHORS: Mathur, D; Heisey, P G; Robinson, D A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISHES; MORTALITY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; TURBINES; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; EQUIPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBOMACHINERY; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The immediate (1-h) turbine-related mortality of juvenile American shad Alosa sapidissima at the Hadley Falls Hydroelectric Station on the Connecticut River, Holyoke, Massachusetts, was estimated to be 0% [+-] 14.5% (95% confidence interval) at the 35% wicket gate opening and 2.7% [+-] 16.2% at the 100% opening. We used the HI-Z Turb'N tag-recapture technique, which helped minimize control mortality and maximize recapture rates. Earlier literature estimates of turbine-related mortality (up to 82%) of juvenile alosids in passage through Kaplan turbines, in our view, were substantially overstated due to either low recapture rate, high control mortality, or both. 5 refs., 1 fig., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society; (United States); Journal Volume: 123:1
JOURNAL_NAME: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society; (United States)

TITLE: Hydro research: A status report
AUTHORS: Byers, W
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; DAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; FORECASTING; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; NORTH AMERICA; OPERATIONS RESEARCH; PLANNING; WATER CURRENT POWER GENERATORS; WATER QUALITY; WEATHER; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Members of the North American hydro community are turning to research and development to address challenges facing the industry as it approaches the twenty-first century. A review of current efforts indicates producers, consultants, suppliers, and government agencies are involved in many research-related activities.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:8

TITLE: Checking concrete growth
AUTHORS: Newell, V A; Tanner, D T; Wagner, C D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CONCRETES; EXPANSION; DAMS; SAFETY; SPILLWAY; BUILDING MATERIALS; MATERIALS; 130800* - Hydro Energy- Health & Safety- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: This article examines corrective actions being taken by the Tennessee Valley Authority to minimize stresses developing in Hiwassee Dam due to concrete growth from alkali-aggregate reaction. The topics of the article include a description of the problem, corrective actions taken to reduce stress, continuous monitoring, post-tensioning, cutting the slots, abutment slots, and adjustments to spillway gates.
RELATION: Journal Name: Civil Engineering (New York, 1983); (United States); Journal Volume: 64:1

TITLE: Access to hydro information: Reviewing new releases
AUTHORS: Fulton, E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; INFORMATION; REVIEWS; CONCRETES; DAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; HYDRAULICS; INFORMATION DISSEMINATION; PROGRAMMING; PUBLIC INFORMATION; REGULATORY GUIDES; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; STREAMS; VIDEO TAPES; BUILDING MATERIALS; DOCUMENT TYPES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUID MECHANICS; MAGNETIC STORAGE DEVICES; MAGNETIC TAPES; MATERIALS; MECHANICS; MEMORY DEVICES; POWER; SURFACE WATERS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: A number of books and publications, software programs, and videotapes have been released recently, offering a myriad of facts, figures, and solutions to the hydro professional. This article reviews some of these information resources.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:8

TITLE: Progress in China
AUTHORS: Hennagir, T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CHINA; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; MARKET; ASIA; EQUIPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINERY; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: China's peaking power need continues to drive a highly competitive market for pumped storage turbines. Two contract awards in this growing Far East region have increased visibility of Kvaerner Energy a.s. and Voith Hydro Inc. In October, Kvaerner was awarded a $150 million contract for six 300 MW reversible pump turbines for the 1,800 MW Tianhuangping Pumped Storage Project near Zhejing (Shanghai). The equipment and the contract have been lauded for their significance: The award is the largest of their kind in the world. Voith Hydro's contract to furnish and install four 204 MW pump turbines for the 816 MW Shisanling PUmped Storage Project north of Beijing has drawn attention as well. Not only was the July 1992 contract signing ceremony conducted inside the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, but Chinese Premier Li Peng officiated at the project's groundbreaking ceremony.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 24:1

TITLE: Hydro-Quebec is at it again
AUTHORS: Hamilton, G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; QUEBEC; DAMS
DESCRIPTION: When New York governor Mario Cuomo pulled the plug on a purchase of 1,000 megawatts of power from Hydro-Quebec last June, the provincial utility talked tough. The cancellation, a senior Hydro-Quebec official claimed, would not jeopardize the future of its controversial Great Whale hydro project in the North. Bu Hydro-Quebec has quietly shoved Great Whale onto the back burner while an environmental review is underway. In the meantime the utility is barreling ahead with another mega-dam. The Ste. Marquerite project planned for north-eastern Quebec is modest by Hydro-Quebec standards, generating less than a third the power of Great Whale. Still, with an 880-megawatt power station and 190 square miles of reservoirs, it is one of the largest hydro projects on any drawing board in North America. Environmentalists say it is being pushed ahead without a serious study of its impacts. This article details the environmental impacts of the project, and the extended impacts, not yet accounted for.
RELATION: Journal Name: Amicus Journal; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Spr 1993

TITLE: Taming the dragon
AUTHORS: Magagnini, S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; CHINA; DAMS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; CONSTRUCTION
DESCRIPTION: Can China be persuaded to stop construction of the world`s biggest dam? On its 3,500-mile journey from Tibet to Shanghai, the Yangtze River carves its way through the Three Gorges, a mystical 120-mile long gallery of fog-enshrouded peaks, sheer cliffs, and huge whirlpools. Three Gorges, which has inspired Chinese poets from Li Po (701-762 A.D.) to Chairman Mao, is so revered that its dramatic beauty appears on Chinese $5 and $10 bill. Despite its beauty and cultural significance, however, the gorges area could be destroyed should the Chinese carry out their plans to construct he world`s most powerful hydroelectric dam, and a war is being waged on three continents to keep the steel-and-concrete behemoth from going ahead. If built, the dam will electrify remote areas of China and supply power to 150 million Chineses as far away as Shanghae and hold back the floodwaters of the Yangtze which have killed millions. However critics content it will be an environmental and social disaster of epic proportions. The dam will also force the relocation of more than a million Chinese, the largest resettlement in world history.
RELATION: Journal Name: Amicus Journal; Journal Volume: 15; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Sum 1993

TITLE: Investigating syphon hydro intake installations
AUTHORS: FitzPatrick, J B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INTAKE STRUCTURES; MICRO-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: Hydroelectric power facilities can be installed at existing lowhead dams to produce economical, environmentally sound electricity. The key to success is finding low-cost development and equipment approaches. A syphon intake configuration is one option that reduces the need for dam modification.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 1; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Fal 1993

TITLE: Tech notes: Ongoing or planned hydro research, results of recent studies, and reviews of new books, publications, and software
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 16 TIDAL AND WAVE POWER; DAMS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; CONSTRUCTION; INFORMATION; MANAGEMENT; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; WAVE POWER; CHINA
DESCRIPTION: Ongoing or planned hydro research, results of recent studies, and reviews of new books, publications, and software. Items covered this month include: (1) a recommendation that dam designers give more consideration to earthquake resistance, (2) the development of a new wave rotor design, (3) the development of a small hydro database in China, and (4) an ICOLD bulletin on the optimization of constuction costs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 1; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Fal 1993

TITLE: Using technology as a tool of system management
AUTHORS: Scott, J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; OPERATION; UNITED KINGDOM; PEAKING POWER PLANTS
DESCRIPTION: Pumped-storage technology and electricity suppliers` understanding of its potential continue to evolve. As the twenty-first century approaches, pumped storage has become a powerful and dynamic tool for utilities to provide the high quality of electricity supply demanded by modern society. This article reviews the electrical distribution system in England and Wales and the role of the large Dinorwig station and Ffestinoig station pumped storage projects. A brief description of the development and design of the Dinorwig station is included.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 1; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: Win 1993

TITLE: Floating intake reduces pump damage
AUTHORS: Kronig, A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INTAKE STRUCTURES; SWITZERLAND
DESCRIPTION: The solution to a costly sand erosion problem at the Grande Dixence hydroelectric project in Switzerland turned out to be as simple as a floating pump. The 726-MW Grande Dixence project drains a 350-square-kilometer reach of the Zermatt and Herens valleys in the southwestern Swiss Alps. About half of the drainage area is covered by active glaciers. Because the glaciers in Zermatt Valley are so low in altitude, their water is collected in Z`mutt Reservoir at the base of the Matterhorn, then pumped up 500 meters for transport to the main Grande Disence Reservoir near Sion. The glacier water is heavily laden with sand. In spite of a gravel pass and a desilter, the 700,000-acubic-meter Z`mutt Reservoir receives large quantities of sand. The sand tends to remain in solution because of the low water temperatures (1 to 2 degrees Centigrade). In the original intake system, the sand would be sucked into the pump intakes, causing extensive erosion to the pump wheels and an expensive yearly program of repair. (Pump damage averaged 200,000 Swiss Francs ($284,000 U.S.) per year between 1980 and 1985.)
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 1; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: Win 1993

TITLE: Tech notes: Ongoing or planned hydro research, results of recent studies, and reviews of new books, publications, and software
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; WATER RESERVOIRS; SILT; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; HISTORICAL ASPECTS; EL SALVADOR; RECOMMENDATIONS; RUSSIAN FEDERATION
DESCRIPTION: Ongoing or planned hydro research, results of recent studies, and reviews of new books, publications, and software are covered. This month`s Tech Notes include: (1) a study linking development and reservoir silting in El Salvador, (2) publication of a guide for small hydro operatos, and (3) publication of a text outlining the development of hydroelectric power in Russia.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 1; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: Win 1993

TITLE: Rehabilitation: Upgrading hydroelectric plants for more efficient operation
AUTHORS: Bergeret, A E; Mazzocco, M R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EFFICIENCY; MODIFICATIONS; AUGMENTATION
DESCRIPTION: Achieving substantial gains in plant efficiency is a desirable goal for most hydro plant operators. Electricite de France offers ideas useful in seeking this goal. During their long lives, hydropower plants must endure both economic cycles and technological revolutions. To survive, hydro plants designed and built in one era must eventually be re-rationalized within the parameters of another era. At Electricite de France (EDF), we have studied methods for adapting hydropower plants to changing economic and technological conditions. We have undertaken a vast hydro plant refurbishing program, adapting facilities to new criteria dictated by the increased value of peak load generation and by the need for increased power. Lessons learned from the challenges encountered in implementing these renovation projects may be applicable to other hydro situations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 1; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Fal 1993

TITLE: Ozone detection system provides operating benefits
AUTHORS: Laakso, J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; OZONE; DETECTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; BRITISH COLUMBIA
DESCRIPTION: Ozone plays a paradoxical part in a hydro plant. On the one hand, the colorless gas is a potent threat to safe and efficient operation of generating units. Even small quantities of ozone can hurt plant workers` respiratory systems and corrode generator windings. Looked at from another perspective, however, ozone is a potentially valuable tool for monitoring the condition of generating machinery. Ozone (O{sub 3}) is produced when molecular oxygen (O{sub 2}) decomposes, freeing single oxygen atoms to combine with paired ones. In air-cooled generators, this reaction is triggered by slot discharge, arcing brushes, and other forms of corona activity. Whatever the specific cause, it`s a safe assumption that if any significant level of ozone is present in a hydroelectric plant, something is wrong.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 1; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Fal 1993

TITLE: Strategic planning for hydro maintenance and life extension
AUTHORS: Tychsen, R C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; OPERATION; MAINTENANCE; SOUTH AUSTRALIA
DESCRIPTION: Faced with aging plants and an increasingly complex operating environment, management at the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority in southeast Australia turned to strategic planning in 1987. Today`s strategic planning is increasingly driving all aspects of operations, maintenance, and development. And it has become more than a valuable management tool-it is becoming a way of life. It has given management more control over prioritizing, timing, and optimizing the scope of maintenance, life extension, and improvement of its hydroelectric stations and associated works. This article reviews the specific process utilized by this organization.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 1; Journal Issue: 3; Other Information: PBD: Win 1993

TITLE: Using computers for analyzing dam stability during floods
AUTHORS: Lau, S C; Cecilio, C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; STABILITY; FLOODS; COMPUTER CODES
DESCRIPTION: Determining the required spillway capacity during a flood for a single dam is relatively straightforward using present-day computer-based tools. However, the analysis becomes more challenging when several dams form a series on the same river. Computer models are available to assist in this task. This paper is a discussion of one of these models...the DAMBRK computer code. This program consists of three parts: (1) A description of the failure, (2) Computation of the time-history of the outflow through the breach, and (3) Routing of the outflow through the downstream valley to determine the resulting water stages and wave travel times of the flood. A case study is presented.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 1; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Sum 1993

TITLE: Ideas in action: System keeps brake dust off generator windings
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC COILS; DUSTS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; REMOVAL
DESCRIPTION: Long life of generator windings depends on keeping them clean. Throughout their operational history, the three units at Portland General Electric Co.`s Pelton-Round Butte Plant in Oregon, USA, were plagued by a combination of oil vapor from thrust bearings and brake dust being exhausted into the generator air cooling paths and collecting on the windings. The buildup would lead to electrical corona and subsequent deterioration of the windings. This could lead to eventual failure and a $1 million rewind job. This article briefly discusses one method to protect the generator windings through removal of dust.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 1; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Sum 1993

TITLE: Increasing the value of hydro through research and development
AUTHORS: Ziegler, T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MAINTENANCE; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; POWER DISTRIBUTION; CONTROL; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; WATER RESOURCES; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; NORWAY
DESCRIPTION: In Norway-where more than 99 percent of electricity comes from hydro-the government and private companies are cooperatively funding a multimillion dollar rehabilitation research program toward making the existing power system more valuable. Results form the research will be applicable to hydro facilities throughout the world. This paper outlines the Norwegian EFFEN program to rehabilitate existing hydro facilities. Overall strategy is outlined, and several current projects are discussed. These include: (1) Condition-based maintenance project, (2) Turbine runner wheel project, (3) Integrated control center project, and (4) River simulator project.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review Worldwide; Journal Volume: 1; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Sum 1993

TITLE: British Columbia's utility may add generating units
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; BRITISH COLUMBIA; COLUMBIA RIVER; CONSTRUCTION; DAMS; PLANNING; CANADA; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: As competition in power marketing heats up on the West Coast, British Columbia Hydro and Power Authority is considering a long-range plan to add four generating units with a total capacity of 1,770 Mw to two large Columbia River dams. Before making a decision to go ahead, the provincial utility will conduct environmental studies on the impact of the added units to the river system. The new units would be installed in existing powerhouses at Revelstoke and Mica dams, which now have a combined capacity of 3,579 Mw. The program would cost about $270 million. each dam has four generating units installed, although each of the powerhouses was designed to accommodate six units.
RELATION: Journal Name: Engineering News-Record; (United States); Journal Volume: 231:23

TITLE: Harry Seed, liquefaction and the gravel drain
AUTHORS: Sonu, C J; Ito, Katsuhiko; Oishi, Hiroshi
SUBJECT: 22 GENERAL STUDIES OF NUCLEAR REACTORS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; EARTHQUAKES; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; SEISMIC ISOLATION; SOIL MECHANICS; SOILS; MECHANICS; SEISMIC EVENTS; 220900* - Nuclear Reactor Technology- Reactor Safety; 220200 - Nuclear Reactor Technology- Components & Accessories; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: This article examines the results of implementing the recommendations of engineer Harry Seed to prevent liquefaction in the event of an earthquake in Japan. The topics of the article include the cause and effects of liquefaction, the design of gravel drains, damage from liquefaction, examples of gravel drain success, and improvements to the method that have been developed by the Japanese.
RELATION: Journal Name: Civil Engineering (New York, 1983); (United States); Journal Volume: 63:12

TITLE: Procuring small hydro equipment: Ways to ensure satisfactory performance
AUTHORS: Koseatac, A S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; PERFORMANCE; WARRANTIES; HYDRAULIC EQUIPMENT; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; WATER CURRENT POWER GENERATORS; EQUIPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Ensuring satisfactory performance of a new hydro plant's generating equipment is essential, but for small hydro developers, the cost of a full performance test can be prohibitive. Certain contract provisions can help protect against substandard equipment performance, using a full performance test only as a last resort. These provisions have proven useful in protecting the project developer against substandard equipment performance. They are: (1) Request detailed information from the equipment supplier on how the guaranteed performance figures were determined; (2) Require the equipment supplier to submit a model test report; (3) Require the equipment supplier to submit quality control and inspection procedures, operation and maintenance manuals, and start-up and testing procedures, with delivery of these items tied to liquidated damages; (4) Require the equipment supplier to perform an index test for the installed turbine(s); (5) Specify, as an option to the owner, full performance tests for the equipment to be used as a last resort; and (6) Establish liquidated damages for deficient equipment performance.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:7

TITLE: Are you prepared Protecting your hydro plant from lightning strikes
AUTHORS: Clemen, D M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; LIGHTNING ARRESTERS; DESIGN; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: A properly designed lightning protection system requires a basic understanding of the physics of lightning and the means available to both divert and conduct lightning stroke energy around structures. Once the basics are understood, an engineer can using existing codes and standards to design an effective protection scheme for a given structure. A well-implemented scheme ensures that direct or close-proximity lightning strokes will not cause forced outages of hydroturbine-generator units. Lightning protection should be a part of the design of any new hydroelectric plant. If protection was not provided when the project was constructed, rehabilitation projects and activities offer opportunities to make corrections.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:7

TITLE: Seismic remediation for earth dams
AUTHORS: Marcuson, III, W F; Hadala, P F; Ledbetter, R H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; SAFETY ENGINEERING; EARTHQUAKES; SEISMIC EFFECTS; EMBANKMENTS; RISK ASSESSMENT; WATER RESERVOIRS; ENGINEERING; SEISMIC EVENTS; SURFACE WATERS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: There are hundreds of earth dams in the US, many of them old and some in need of seismic remediation to operate safely. This article is a look at the current state of the practice and at two US Army Corps of Engineers remediation projects now under way. Public safety demands that earth dams retain their reservoirs in an earthquake, or, at worst, release them without posing a threat to life. Dams have long been designed with this requirement in mind, but over the last 30 years or so, new analysis methods and case histories of dam performance in earthquakes have significantly changed the understanding of the severity of the earthquake hazard in many regions. Existing dams, especially older ones, are being reexamined using more severe earthquakes than their designers envisioned, with evaluation methods unavailable to them -- leading, in some cases, to the determination that a seismic hazard exists.
RELATION: Journal Name: Civil Engineering (New York, 1983); (United States); Journal Volume: 63:12

TITLE: Focusing on the environment in Canada
AUTHORS: Collins, S J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CANADA; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; PUBLIC UTILITIES; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Taming rivers and conquering handicaps of location, climate, and terrain may have been the priorities for hydroelectric developers in the past. Today, though, the focus is on preserving, sustaining, mitigating, enhancing ... developing power projects by respecting the environment, not conquering it. This change in focus has much to do with changing attitudes and priorities in both the public and private sectors in Canada. The non-power uses of water -- such as fish and wildlife protection, mitigation, and enhancement; protection of recreational opportunities; preservation of other aspects of environmental quality; and traditional uses of the resource by aboriginal peoples -- are important considerations today. They must be accounted for along with the power use. Most people working in hydro in Canada agree that any project development or rehabilitation plan should address aesthetics, fish habitat, compatible land use, and social responsibility -- together with how many kilowatt-hours of electricity will be generated. This emerging emphasis on the environment in the hydroelectric industry is affecting traditional ways of doing business and, at the same time, creating new opportunities for service and product providers.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:7

TITLE: How can hydro get a fair shake
AUTHORS: Byers, W
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; LICENSING PROCEDURES; LICENSING REGULATIONS; LIFE-CYCLE COST; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; STATE GOVERNMENT; US FERC; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; COST; ECONOMICS; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; REGULATIONS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: There is no arguing that hydroelectric power has enormous assets. In a period of concern about air quality, it is clean; in a time of results-oriented management, it is cost-effective and efficient to operate; in an era of limited resources, it is sustainable. To a true believer in hydro and its worth, these attributes say enough. The value of hydropower may be less clear outside the realm of the faithful...in the executive suite of an electric utility with multiple types of generation, for example. The utility's system planners, financial officers, and chief executive may concede the theoretical benefit of being clean, efficient, and renewable but also may need more information before they agree the qualities are valuable. In the end, a generating plant has to be valued in the [open quotes]currency[close quotes] of the utility that needs the power, its customers, and its regulators. The fact that hydropower's benefits and costs are not always accurately weighed against those of other generating resources is both a testament to the inadequacies of traditional costing approaches and a challenge to those who want to see the analysis process improved.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:7

TITLE: Building a hydroelectric project at a fishway
AUTHORS: Bagnall, C L; Haake, H E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COLUMBIA RIVER; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: It's not unusual to hear about a fishway being installed at a hydro facility. However, the reverse -- installing a hydro plant at an existing fish passage facility -- is unique. Northern Wasco County People's Utility District (PUD) in Oregon has proved the validity of the idea. For decades, the Pacific Northwest has relied upon hydropower as a reliable and economic means of generating electricity. In recent years, however, in the Columbia River Basin, efforts to protect diminishing salmon stocks have taken precedence over the development of new hydropower plants. With that in mind, the Northern Wasco County PUD in Oregon set out to develop a hydroelectric project that not only provided for fish passage, but also took advantage of an existing fishway. The Dalles Dam North Fishway Project began operating in 1991. The project site is a fishway at the US Army Corps of Engineers' The Dalles Lock and Dam. The 5-MW project received intense scrutiny from state and federal fishery agencies and Indian tribes. All of the parties worked together to settle differences and to develop a feasible project that meets multiple needs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:7

TITLE: Honey, let's start a power company
AUTHORS: Kamberg, M L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FINANCING; RETROFITTING; WISCONSIN; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; USA; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The 1978 Public Utilities Regulatory Policies Act (PURPA) required utilities to buy renewable energy generated by independent producers. This article describes the development of an abandoned small-scale run-of-the-river hydro plant as a retirement investment for a retired utility plant superintendent.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:7

TITLE: Seeking solutions for icing at dams and hydro plants
AUTHORS: Haynes, F D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; ICE; REMOVAL; US CORPS OF ENGINEERS; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOD; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Hydroelectric plant operators in the northern US and Canada often encounter icing problems that interfere with normal operations. Icing can cause problems in machinery, valves, and gates, and frazil ice can block water intakes. (Frazil ice is a slightly super-cooled, slush-type ice commonly formed on northern rivers in a rapids area or any area without an ice cover.) Icing problems, especially blockage of water intakes, can shut down a hydropower plant and cause a considerable loss of power generation. The US Army Corps of Engineers' Cold Regions Research and Engineering Laboratory (CRREL) surveyed hydro plant operators about icing problems experienced at their facilities and solutions to these problems. By sharing the survey results, CRREL researchers hope to spread solutions among operators and to identify those problems for which no solutions are currently known that require more research. CRREL researchers also are developing promising technology that may help to alleviate icing problems.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:7

TITLE: Repair and upgrade of a 1950 vintage hydro plant
AUTHORS: Casey, R C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; MEDIUM-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; REPAIR; OUTAGES; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; LIGHTNING
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes the step-by-step process of repair and upgrade which restored a damaged 40-year-old plant to service after nearly size years of downtime. Detailed information is provided on the approach to the restoration work taken by the Massachusetts Water Resources Authority. Hidden damage, outdated protective relaying, and inadequate surge protection are discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 8; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1993
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITCNE4; ISSN 0885-8969; TRN: IM9412%%351

TITLE: Reducing the effect of penstock pressure pulsations on hydro electric plant power system stabilizer signals
AUTHORS: Nettleton, L D; Gurney, J H; Bollinger, K E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 24 POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ON-LINE CONTROL SYSTEMS; AC SYSTEMS; STABILIZATION; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE
DESCRIPTION: A characteristic trait of Francis turbines operating at low-head is pressure pulsations that occur during certain load levels of the generator. These stem from pressure variations across the turbine due to pulsating flow in the draft-tube. This surging action of the water column is related to draft-tube geometry and flow-rate of water in the penstock. The pressure pulsations cause torque variations on the turbine and corresponding electric power pulsations.
