If electric power is used as a feedback signal to the Power System Stabilizer (PSS), then Mvar and terminal voltage pulsations will occur when the generator is operating in the ``rough zone``. This paper describes field test results for investigating feedforward control from the penstock, draft tube and spiral case pressure to reduce the effects of Mw pulsations on PSS output signals. This investigation involved a PSS with generator power as the feedback signal and the PSS tuned for local and inter-area damping.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion; Journal Volume: 8; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Dec 1993
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ITCNE4; ISSN 0885-8969; TRN: IM9412%%350

TITLE: Implicit environmental costs in hydroelectric development: An analysis of the Norwegian Master Plan for Water Resources
AUTHORS: Carlsen, A J; Wenstop, F; Strand, J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; DECISION MAKING; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; WATER RESOURCES; ENERGY POLICY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; NORWAY; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; EUROPE; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; SCANDINAVIA; WESTERN EUROPE; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 290400 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources; 290300 - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety
DESCRIPTION: The ranking of hydropower projects under the Norwegian Master Plan for Water Resources is used to derive implicit government preferences for a number of environmental attributes described by ordinal scores for each project. We apply ordinal logistic regression to the ranks using the scores of the attributes as explanatory variables. As expected, we find that higher negative scores are generally associated with greater implicit willingness to pay to avoid the environmental damage tied to the attribute, caused by hydropower development. We derive total (ordinary economic and implicit environmental) costs for each project and find that environmental costs per capacity unit generally are lower than economic costs for projects ranked for early exploitation and higher for projects ranked for later development. Our derived implicit long-run marginal cost curve for Norwegian hydropower development is generally upward sloping, but not uniformly so. 14 refs., 3 figs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Environmental Economics and Management; (United States); Journal Volume: 25:3
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of Environmental Economics and Management; (United States)

TITLE: Centrifuge study on volume changes and dynamic stability of earth dams
AUTHORS: Arulanandan, K; Seed, H B; Yogachandran, C; Muraleetharan, K K; Seed, R B; Kabilamany, K
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 58 GEOSCIENCES; DAMS; FAILURE MODE ANALYSIS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; DEFORMATION; DYNAMIC LOADS; DYNAMICS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RESPONSE FUNCTIONS; RISK ASSESSMENT; SHEAR; SITE CHARACTERIZATION; SOIL MECHANICS; STABILITY; FUNCTIONS; MECHANICS; SYSTEM FAILURE ANALYSIS; SYSTEMS ANALYSIS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 540210 - Environment, Terrestrial- Basic Studies- (1990-); 580000 - Geosciences
DESCRIPTION: A simplified method of analysis for determining the permanent displacement of a clay core in a heterogeneous earth dam subjected to dynamic excitation is discussed. Centrifuge studies on three identical models were used to determine the deformation characteristics of earth dams subjected to earthquakes large enough to produce flow slides. These studies suggest that the failure mode is considerably influenced by the reduction in shear strength caused by the void-ratio increase and the subsequent decrease in effective stress at the sand-clay interface. Conventional sliding block analysis does not consider this phenomenon. A simplified method using the concepts of critical-state soil mechanics is presented that may be used to estimate both the reduced shear strength and the redistributed void-ratio at the interface. Values predicted using this method were found to agree well with those observed in the centrifuge experiments. By integrating these quantities into Newmark's sliding block analysis, a better estimate of the permanent displacement of an earth dam may be obtained.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Geotechnical Engineering; (United States); Journal Volume: 119:11

TITLE: Earth dam-canyon interaction effects for obliquely incident SH waves
AUTHORS: Dakoulas, P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 58 GEOSCIENCES; DAMS; RESPONSE FUNCTIONS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; EMBANKMENTS; EARTHQUAKES; FOUNDATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RISK ASSESSMENT; SEISMIC S WAVES; SITE CHARACTERIZATION; SOIL MECHANICS; SOILS; FUNCTIONS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; SEISMIC EVENTS; SEISMIC WAVES; SUPPORTS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 540210 - Environment, Terrestrial- Basic Studies- (1990-); 580000 - Geosciences
DESCRIPTION: Dam-canyon interaction effects on the response of earth and rock fill dams built in narrow canyons are considered. An analytical closed-form solution is used for a dam in a semicylindrical canyon, subjected to obliquely incident harmonic SH waves. The dam is idealized as linearly hysteretic elastic body deforming only in shear, while the canyon is modeled as an elastic half-space. The model accounts in a rigorous way for the wave reflection and diffraction phenomena caused by the presence of the dam-canyon system. It is shown that the motion amplification is considerably less for a dam in flexible canyon than for, a dam in a rigid canyon and that the effects of radiation damping and asynchronous base motion may be very important. For oblique SH waves, the presence of antisymmetric terms in the solution may lead to response substantially higher than that induced by vertically propagating waves. Finally, as the canyon narrowness increases, the amplification at higher frequencies increases significantly for a rigid base, but it may decrease for a flexible base.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Geotechnical Engineering; (United States); Journal Volume: 119:11

TITLE: Assessing the need to negotiate'' in FERC licensing consultations: A study of two hydropower projects
AUTHORS: Coughlan, B A.K.; Burkardt, N; Fulton, D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING PROCEDURES; AGREEMENTS; NEGOTIATION; OPERATING LICENSES; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; LICENSES; POWER PLANTS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: The authors investigated the need to negotiate'' in a comparative case study of multi-agency negotiations in the FERC licensing process. Researchers interviewed participants in two cases involving environmental consultations and asked about parties' level of need to negotiate throughout the process. Participants identified a need to negotiate, and when this need was strongly felt, there was an increased opportunity for an agreement to be reached. An intense need to negotiate by all parties is not a prerequisite to successful agreements. When key participants have a strong need to negotiate, they can instigate negotiations and encourage the involvement of other parties.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environmental Impact Assessment Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 13:6

TITLE: How does hydropower compare
AUTHORS: Hunt, R; Mohsberg Hunt, J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; NATIONAL GOVERNMENT; LICENSING REGULATIONS; USA; CAPACITY; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; COAL; FOSSIL-FUEL POWER PLANTS; CARBONACEOUS MATERIALS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; FOSSIL FUELS; FUELS; MATERIALS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; REGULATIONS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130400 - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: Despite the success of major conservation efforts, the need for electricity continues to grow in the United States. The nation's economic growth and competitiveness depends upon an electricity supply that is adequate, dependable and affordable. If all existing accessible and licensable hydropower resources were developed today, an additional 41 billion kWh a year of generation could be achieved immediately from hydropower. However, development of much of the available hydropower resource is not likely to occur. New development is discouraged by the sheer magnitude of regulation and the length and cost of the licensing process. New license applications have fallen from 83 in 1986 to 30 in 1991, and they are still declining. Since 1986, less than one-half of the applications filed resulted in approved licenses and only about 60 percent of the approved licenses were completed to become operating projects. Thus, the probability of a project with a filed license application actually beginning operation is only about 25 percent. During the next 20 years, it is anticipated that coal will meet 86 percent of the additional electricity needed in the United States, with nuclear facilities contributing a small amount of this. Despite hydropower's regulatory and economic impediments, scant research and development support for the technology, and the steady decline in applications for hydropower development over the past 10 years, it is projected that hydropower will continue to contribute as much as wind and solar combined to meet the future US electricity needs, according to the DOE. Creating a level playing field for hydropower and other renewable technologies with respect to regulatory treatment and research support would encourage the immediate development of the hydropower potential that is presently economic and feasible.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 23:9

TITLE: Aggressive development plans
AUTHORS: McCandless, D H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; PHILIPPINES; PRICING REGULATIONS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; ASIA; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; ISLANDS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; REGULATIONS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Hydropower developments are capital-intensive, are subject to uncertainty in water availability, and have a somewhat higher construction-cost risk than thermal projects. However, a developer who selects an attractive site, arranges a good financial package, and designs and constructs a well-conceived hydropower project can earn an attractive long-term return while providing a dependable, low-cost source of energy to consumers. In the Philippines, many attractive hydropower sites are now available. As demonstrated by the attendance at the US Trade and Development Agency-sponsored Symposium on Power Development and Investment Opportunities in the Philippines, in Washington, D.C., on Sept. 21 and 22, 1993, there is a growing interest in private hydropower. Following its successful record in implementing thermal private power developments, the Philippines now offers many attractive opportunities to exploit its tremendous potential in the hydropower sector.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 23:9

TITLE: The hazard in using probabilistic seismic hazard analysis
AUTHORS: Krinitzsky, E L
SUBJECT: 22 GENERAL STUDIES OF NUCLEAR REACTORS; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; EARTHQUAKES; RISK ASSESSMENT; ERRORS; GROUND MOTION; SEISMIC EFFECTS; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; MOTION; SEISMIC EVENTS; 220900* - Nuclear Reactor Technology- Reactor Safety; 220200 - Nuclear Reactor Technology- Components & Accessories; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: Earthquake experts rely on probabilistic seismic hazard analysis for everything from emergency-response planning to development of building codes. Unfortunately, says the author, the analysis is defective for the large earthquakes that pose the greater risks. Structures have short lifetimes and the distance over which earthquakes cause damage are relatively small. Exceptions serve to prove the rule. To be useful in engineering, earthquakes hazard assessment must focus narrowly in both time and space.
RELATION: Journal Name: Civil Engineering (New York, 1983); (United States); Journal Volume: 63:11

TITLE: Courts and Commissions: Fish or foul
AUTHORS: Radford, B W
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; US FERC; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; ANADROMOUS FISHES; LEGAL ASPECTS; RECREATIONAL AREAS; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; FISHES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; VERTEBRATES; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Hydropower is under attack everywhere you look. It started back in the sixties during the battle over Arizona's Glen Canyon Dam. That case purportedly ended in a compromise with the Sierra Club to save the Grand Canyon from hydro development. But once built, the dam played havoc with Colorado River levels, disrupting rafting trips for Grand Canyon tourists. Even Barry Goldwater was later heard to rue the Glen Canyon project. Marc Reisner's 1986 book, Cadillac Desert, galvanized the antihydro faction. A few years later, calls arose for the City of San Francisco to dismantle its O'Shaughnessy Dam across the Hetch Hetchy Valley in the Sierra Nevada, just 15 miles north of famed Yosemite. That move failed. (Maybe San Francisco's oddball reputation had something to do with the result). But now we hear of plans underway to tear down dams on the Elwah River in Washington State's Olympic National Park, to reclaim lost salmon spawning grounds and return the parks to its natural state. This time the dam busters may win. These events are not unconnected. Strung together, they reveal a change in the popular opinion of how rivers, streams, and coastlines contribute to our economic well-being, and how the federal government should manage those economic resources. Federal hydropower control was born to govern our navigable waterways. It grew up as a tool to speed electrification and develop mining and logging. But forces today are seeking to make federal hydropower law more sympathetic to wildlife preservation. They argue that wildlife represents a national economic resource - no less so than timber, minerals, and shipping. This view is winning support from those in high positions, including the Chair of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, Elizabeth Moler.
RELATION: Journal Name: Fortnightly; (United States); Journal Volume: 131:19

TITLE: Variable-speed hydro evolves
AUTHORS: Hennagir, T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; EFFICIENCY; SPEED REGULATORS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MARKET; PUMP TURBINES; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Success in improving hydropower project efficiency has opened more global markets for variable-speed generator technology. Manufacturers continue to test the markets as the technology evolves. The potential of variable-speed application becomes evident considering that more than 150 pumped storage plants, with a combined capacity exceeding 100,000 MW, are in operation globally.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 23:8

TITLE: Water rights in the states
AUTHORS: Lagassa, G K
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; STATE GOVERNMENT; WATER RIGHTS; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; LEGAL ASPECTS; NATIONAL GOVERNMENT; REGULATIONS; US FERC; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: Though the final world in hydropower project decisions is made by the FERC, the issue of states gaining more water use rights is an important issue for the hydroelectric power industry. Activism by the states has increased their influence over hydropower licensing in recent years.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 23:8

TITLE: Dam safety's future: What will the headlines say
AUTHORS: Byers, W
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; SAFETY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SAFEGUARD REGULATIONS; US BUREAU OF RECLAMATION; US CORPS OF ENGINEERS; US FEMA; US FERC; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; REGULATIONS; US DOD; US DOE; US DOI; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130800* - Hydro Energy- Health & Safety- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The U.S. dam safety program is entering a critical period. Decisions made during the next several years will set the program's course for years to come. This article examines how the program looks and will look at the end of the decade, using assessments by four men with important roles in the dam safety community.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:6

TITLE: Learning to run a hydro plant from the top of a desk
AUTHORS: Savin, D; Slack, B; Sagherian, R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; PERSONNEL; TRAINING; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; COMPUTER GRAPHICS; PERSONAL COMPUTERS; ANIMALS; COMPUTERS; DIGITAL COMPUTERS; EDUCATION; MAMMALS; MAN; MICROCOMPUTERS; POWER PLANTS; PRIMATES; SIMULATION; VERTEBRATES; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: No matter how well designed, equipped, and maintained, a hydroelectric power plant ultimately operates only as effectively as the personnel who control it. Skillful hands at the controls can bring out the best in a plant; clumsy, or uncertain, ones can produce the worst. Ontario Hydro, which operates 69 hydro plants scattered over hundreds of thousands of square miles in central Canada, has committed to a comprehensive program of training and refresher courses designed to polish the skills of its hydro plant operators. To hold down costs without limiting effectiveness, the utility is using desktop computer simulations that allow operators to experience a full range of operating situations without leaving their home plants.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:6

TITLE: A look at the advantages of determining regional probable maximum precipitation
AUTHORS: Morris, D I; Tomlinson, E M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ATMOSPHERIC PRECIPITATIONS; FORECASTING; GEOGRAPHICAL VARIATIONS; DAMS; SAFETY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; FLOOD CONTROL; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; STORMS; CONTROL; DISASTERS; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; POWER PLANTS; VARIATIONS; 130800* - Hydro Energy- Health & Safety- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Examining a particular part of a whole can yield specific, unique results. For example, in general, the cost of living may be higher in one region compared to another, but for specific cities, that generalization may not always hold true. The same can be said of determining probable maximum precipitation (PMP) values for use in dam safety analyses. PMP values established for a large region (such as the eastern US) may not be appropriate when applied to a specific location within that region. The PMP is determined using observed storms together with meteorological conditions feasible in the geographic area of interest. Knowledge and understanding of the factors that control precipitation in the particular affected region are important. With this in mind, members of the Hydro Users Group in the states of Wisconsin and Michigan teamed with the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) to fund a regional probable maximum precipitation study. The goal was to minimize the subjectivity and reduce the margins of conservatism in determining PMP values for a particular area. The study provided a new approach to characterizing storm inflow moisture and area climatology that resulted in reduced PMP values for most areas and storm durations of interest. By using these reduced values in dam safety analyses, the requirements for dam owners to strengthen structures and expand spillways are either being reduced or eliminated, amounting to an estimated savings of $35 million in Wisconsin and Michigan.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:6

TITLE: Stalking cavitation in the lab
AUTHORS: March, P A; Jones, R K
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ACOUSTIC MONITORING; BENCH-SCALE EXPERIMENTS; CAVITATION; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; MONITORING; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: This article describes laboratory equipment for acoustic monitoring of cavitation in hydraulic turbines. The system uses acoustic transducers. The signals from the transducers are filtered and amplified, then analyzed and recorded with a computer using an 8-bit analog-to-digital waveform acquisition board. The signal are also provided to a wideband converter chip. The chip produces an directly related to the power of the signal. Erosion rates are determined from the signal output.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:6

TITLE: Combining technology, ingenuity to upgrade controls
AUTHORS: O'Connor, J P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; FLOW RATE; COMPUTER NETWORKS; WATER CURRENT POWER GENERATORS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; ON-LINE CONTROL SYSTEMS; ON-LINE SYSTEMS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Pennsylvania Power Light Company's Holtwood Hydroelectric Station has been generating electricity from the flow of the Susquehanna River for most of this century. The 102-MW plant's first unit was installed in 1910; the newest turbine is nearly 70 years old. Until recently, much of the control system was dated by time and use, requiring repeated repairs and adjustment. Soon, owing to a blend of modern technology and old-fashioned Yankee ingenuity, flows to all of Holtwood station's generators will be controlled by a state-of-the art digital system. The upgraded controls will give plant operators more precise control over the varying flow rates required by the ten turbine-generator units and eliminate the extended outages required to keep the mechanical wicket-gate controls in tune.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:6

TITLE: Improving efficiency, saving money by monitoring turbine cavitation
AUTHORS: March, P A; Jones, R K
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; ACOUSTIC MONITORING; CAVITATION; OPERATING COST; MINIMIZATION; REPAIR; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; COST; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; MONITORING; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Cavitation-erosion costs electric utilities money for turbine repair and lost generation. Tennessee Valley Authority experience indicates real-time monitoring systems can be a valuable tool for determining hydro unit operating levels that reduce cavitation and improve efficiency. The monitoring systems are generating long-term data on operating conditions, efficiency, and cavitation level. The effects of accumulated cavitation damage and repair on operating efficiency also are under study. Improved techniques for cavitation monitoring will provide input to analyses for predicting damage from operating parameters, and should result in more efficient operation, decreased cavitation damage, lower maintenance costs, and longer equipment life. Information from the cavitation and efficiency monitoring systems will provide additional input to probabilistic models for maintenance scheduling to minimize repair costs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:6

TITLE: What's new in cavitation repair
AUTHORS: Fulton, E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CAVITATION; REPAIR; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; ALLOYS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; STAINLESS STEELS; WELDING; EQUIPMENT; FABRICATION; HIGH ALLOY STEELS; IRON ALLOYS; IRON BASE ALLOYS; JOINING; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; STEELS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Repairing pits and cracks on a hydroturbine runner in place is, perhaps, the most difficult maintenance task at many plants. Over the years, hydro operations and maintenance staff have created new techniques and tools for making the job easier. Responses to an informal survey of O M staff at a sampling of North American hydro plants suggests that the move to all stainless steel runners and the virtually universal use of stainless steel welding alloys in repairs has had a significant positive effect. Specifically, the interval between repairs has widened dramatically, often giving crews the opportunity to repair cavitation damage during routine maintenance of the entire turbine rather than being forced to shut down the unit for emergency work only on the runner.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:6

TITLE: Fighting aging in concrete dams
AUTHORS: Brighton, R; Lampa, J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CONCRETES; AGING; INSPECTION; REPAIR; DAMS; SAFETY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; BUILDING MATERIALS; MATERIALS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation; 130800 - Hydro Energy- Health & Safety- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The years extract an ugly toll from concrete dams: surface cracking, leaking joints, erosion, ineffective drains. Sometimes, these and other products of aging affect only the appearance of a dam and the routine maintenance expense associated with it. Other times, aging can raise significant questions about dam performance, reliability, and safety. BC Hydro has a comprehensive program to monitor the effects of aging on its network of hydropower dams, and implement the right repair and rehabilitation measures. The program, which involves dozens of members of the utility's engineering staff and millions of dollars in expenses, has proven that techniques are available to compensate for the effects of time on the structure and reliability of dams. However, they are most effective when applied after careful analysis and with good judgment.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:6

TITLE: Karstification at Beskonak dam site and reservoir area, southern Turkey
AUTHORS: Degirmenci, M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SITE CHARACTERIZATION; CONSTRUCTION; TURKEY; GEOLOGIC SURVEYS
DESCRIPTION: Beskonak dam and hydroelectric power plant are planned to be constructed on the Koepruecay river, 40 km east of the Antalya city. In the dam site and reservoir area, Koepruecay Conglomerates of Miocene age and the Beskonak Formation (sandstone-claystone) alternating with each other crop out vertically. Koepruecay conglomerates, with the components of limestone fragments and carbonate texture, are karstic and permeable, whereas the Beskonak Formation is impermeable. At the northern edge of the reservoir area, the Olukkoeprue karst springs discharge at a minimum of 30 m{sup 3}/s. These springs discharge mainly through vertical and subvertical joint systems. Intensive superficial karstification developed along the joint systems and the terrane reveals columns of rocks, called {open_quotes}fairy chimneys.{close_quotes} Olukkoeprue springs represent the discharge point for a large and continuous system of underground solution cavities. In the Koepruecay basin, there are numerous karstic features within the conglomerates. Within the reservoir area, Kurukoeprue cave, with a length of 530 m, is an example of these caves developed within the conglomerates. In some parts of the reservoir area, where the groundwater level is lower than the surface-river elevation, a highly developed karstification zone is present within the fluctuation range of groundwater between depths of 40 and 50 m. The above-mentioned Kurukoeprue cave is an active cave developed in the dam site and its vicinity. The solution conduits developed along the system of mostly vertical fractures and joints are interconnected, thus giving rise to a three-dimensional conduit network. On the other hand, a majority of these conduits have clay and calcite filling materials. Karstification in the dam site varies with depths exponentially. Data suggest that karstification has a vertical extention as deep as -220 m. 4 refs., 9 figs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environmental Geology and Water Sciences; Journal Volume: 22; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Oct 1993

TITLE: Projects in eastern Canada encounter strong opposition. [Hydroelectric power plants planned]
AUTHORS: Carr, F H
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT STATEMENTS; HEARINGS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; PUBLIC OPINION; DOCUMENT TYPES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: At the end of August, Quebec's provincial utility submitted a long-awaited environmental impact statement on its proposed Great Whale project near Hudson Bay. It faces opposition, as does a big project planned in Labrador. Hydro-Quebec's EIS says its $10-billion, 3,210-Mw project [open quotes]would have impacts that are generally moderate and localized, and that can be mitigated,[close quotes] according to a utility spokeswoman. But environmental and Native American groups opposed to the project say its three powerhouses on the Great Whale River and 600 sq miles of new impoundments would destroy hunting and fishing areas and mar the environment. Five federal and provincial review panels will determine over the next several weeks if the EIS meets their requirements.
RELATION: Journal Name: Engineering News-Record; (United States); Journal Volume: 231:11

TITLE: Mt. Hope moves forward
AUTHORS: Koch, A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; LICENSING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; LICENSING PROCEDURES; NEW JERSEY; PUMPED STORAGE; REGULATIONS; WATER RESERVOIRS; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY STORAGE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NORTH AMERICA; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; STORAGE; SURFACE WATERS; USA; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: Developing a pumped storage project takes a long time, more than seven years and still counting in the case of the Mt. Hope project in New Jersey. Nevertheless, such plants are expected to offer new services to the electric utility industry. The licensing process for this project is reviewed and a brief description of the project is provided.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 23:7

TITLE: Identification of exciter constants using a coherence function based weighted least squares approach
AUTHORS: Liu, Chuanshen; Hsu, Yuanyih; Jeng, Linher; Lin, Chiajen; Huang, Chiangtsung; Liu, A H; Li, Taihsiung
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; EXCITATION SYSTEMS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; POWER SYSTEMS; STABILITY; ENERGY SYSTEMS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 200107 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Off-Peak Energy Storage- (1980-)
DESCRIPTION: Experience with exciter modeling at Ta-Kuan pumped storage plant in Taiwan is reported in this paper. To identify exciter parameters, frequency response data are first obtained by injecting wide bandwidth signals into the system. Then a modified weighted least squares (WLS) approach using a coherence function is developed to determine exciter constants. A novel feature of the proposed coherence function based WLS method is that it can eliminate measurement dependent inaccuracies by placing less weights on the measurements that more severely corrupted by noises. Based on the established excitation system model, computer simulations are performed to examine the dynamic responses of the generating unit under small disturbance conditions and large disturbance conditions. Field test results are also provided.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 8:3
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Hydro turbine transfer functions with hydraulic coupling
AUTHORS: Vournas, C D; Zaharakis, A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PENSTOCKS; PULSES; STABILITY; TRANSFER FUNCTIONS; EQUIPMENT; FUNCTIONS; MACHINERY; PIPES; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: This paper deals with the development of transfer functions for hydraulic turbines connected to a common penstock. These turbines tend to be hydraulically coupled. Both the solid mass approximation and the pressure wave modeling approach are applied for the development of diagonal ([Delta]P[sub mi]/[Delta]g[sub i]) and coupling ([Delta]P[sub mi]/[Delta]g[sub j]) transfer functions. This modeling approach is applied to the Stratos hydro power station of PPC. It is shown that the solid mass approach gives relatively simple rational transfer functions that represent accurately the hydraulic coupling between turbines for a wide frequency range.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 8:3
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: A novel self-excited self-regulated single phase induction generator
AUTHORS: Murthy, S S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 17 WIND ENERGY; MICRO-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INDUCTION GENERATORS; WIND TURBINES; CAPACITORS; EXCITATION SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 170603 - Wind Energy Engineering- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes a newly developed single-phase capacitor self-excited induction generator with self-regulating features, suitable for engine-driven portable gen-sets for autonomous/standby power generation. The system is also suitable for microhydro and wind energy systems. The generator has two specially designed stator windings in quadrature, connected externally to a shunt and a series capacitor respectively. It employs a standard die-cast squirrel cage rotor. Special features, advantages and theoretical concepts of the system are highlighted in this part of the paper, detailed experimental results being presented in Part 2.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 8:3
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Entrainment of ichthyoplankton by a warmwater hydroelectric facility
AUTHORS: Travnichek, V H; Zale, A V; Fisher, W L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; EGGS; ABUNDANCE; ENTRAINMENT; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; FISHES; LARVAE; ICHTHYOPLANKTON; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; PLANKTON; POWER PLANTS; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 540350 - Environment, Aquatic- Site Resource & Use Studies- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The authors examined entrainment of ichthyoplankton associated with hydropower generation in 1988 and 1989 at the Pensacola Dam hydroelectric facility on Grand Lake in northeastern Oklahoma. To provide a basis for evaluating the effects of entrainment on the fish assemblage, the authors also estimated the total abundance of fish eggs and larvae in the top 10 m of the reservoir. Entrainment totaled about 10 million larval fish in 1988 and almost 100 million in 1989. Only nine taxa of larval fish were entrained during the study. Entrained eggs were almost exclusively those of freshwater drum Aplodinotus grunniens. Although estimates of entrainment were large, they were generally low compared with the estimates of total abundance of ichthyoplankton in Grand Lake. 32 refs., 5 figs., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society; (United States); Journal Volume: 122:5
JOURNAL_NAME: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society; (United States)

TITLE: A novel self-excited self-regulated single phase induction generator; Part II: Experimental investigation
AUTHORS: Murthy, S S; Tandon, A K; Rai, H C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 17 WIND ENERGY; MICRO-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INDUCTION GENERATORS; WIND TURBINES; CAPACITORS; EXCITATION SYSTEMS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; DATA; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; INFORMATION; MACHINERY; NUMERICAL DATA; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems; 170603 - Wind Energy Engineering- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Part 1 of this paper presents the basic system, theoretical modeling and typical test results of a novel Self-Excited Regulated Induction Generator. In this part the results of a detailed experimental investigation are presented to assess its suitability for practical applications. The steady state performance of the self-excited single phase induction generator (SEIG), maintaining the terminal voltage within a close range is investigated under realistic loading conditions in the laboratory. Detailed experimental results are presented and discussed. Necessary tests to obtain machine parameters for theoretical modeling are also developed and relevant results of the prototype presented. The effects of series and shunt capacitors, prime mover speed, load and load power factor are investigated. It has been shown to exhibit better voltage waveform as compared to commercially available sets. The experimental results confirm that this new generating system can be favorably employed for use as a small portable generator driven by nearly constant speed prime movers such as oil engines or Hydro Turbines.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 8:3
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Developing a comprehensive hydro public safety program
AUTHORS: Hildebrand, L G; Ayres, D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC INFORMATION; SAFETY; EDUCATIONAL TOOLS; INFORMATION DISSEMINATION; PUBLIC RELATIONS; WASHINGTON; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; INFORMATION; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; USA; 130800* - Hydro Energy- Health & Safety- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Many hydropower producers devote much time and effort toward educating the public about potential hazards on and around their facilities. A long-term commitment to a program of safety information, education, and training potentially can save lives. This article describes the public safety program of Washington Water Power Company. The program contains four parts: an interactive school program; public safety plans (signs, warning devices, etc.); television and radio commercials; and brochures, articles, and other printed matter.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:5

TITLE: RCC: rehab results. [Roller Compacted Concrete]
AUTHORS: McLean, F G; Hansen, K D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; SAFETY; SPILLWAY; CONSTRUCTION; CAPACITY; CONCRETES; EMBANKMENTS; ROLLING; BUILDING MATERIALS; FABRICATION; MATERIALS; MATERIALS WORKING; 130800* - Hydro Energy- Health & Safety- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Thirty U.S. dams have been modified with roller-compacted concrete to provide additional spillway capacity and for safe overtopping of embankment dams. Here the authors summarize design, construction and mix-proportion data for these projects and relate some lessons learned from dams that have experienced overtopping flows. In the national dam safety inspection performed by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers from 1977 to 1981, hydraulic deficiencies led the list of major problems--specifically, the inability of a dam to retain or safely pass the probable maximum flood (PMF). Common solutions for solving a hydraulic deficiency include raising the dam to increase storage, increasing spillway capacity, providing for safe overtopping, breaching the dam, or some combination of the first three choices. Site conditions or high costs frequently make the first two methods infeasible, and functional needs usually make breaching unacceptable. Providing for overtopping protection may be the only reasonable solution. Use of roller-compacted concrete (RCC) for overtopping protection has proven to be an economical and effective way to increase the hydraulic safety of a dam.
RELATION: Journal Name: Civil Engineering ASCE; (United States); Journal Volume: 63:8

TITLE: Field efficiency testing: A tool for maximizing performance
AUTHORS: Voigt, Jr, R L; Gulliver, J S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; EFFICIENCY; PERFORMANCE TESTING; CALCULATION METHODS; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; FLUID FLOW; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; TESTING; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Knowing the efficiency characteristics of turbines is key to getting the most out of hydropower plants. Yet, without this critical information, many owners are operating in the dark. Some relatively simple yet affordable tests can be used to overcome this deficiency. Acceptance, absolute efficiency, and index testing are described. A flow chart is provided to aid in determining types of tests to perform. Approximate costs are given for each. Methods for calculating efficiency and measuring flow are presented.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:5

TITLE: Fish protection screen enters next phase
AUTHORS: Vansant, C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; DESIGN; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; EPRI; FIELD TESTS; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Few technical issues are of greater importance in the hydroelectric industry today than those pertaining to fish protection. Many hydro plants are being required to improve protection of fish migrating downstream. This improved protection will be needed at both existing plants and newly developed facilities. By effectively screening fish from hydro plant intakes, fish mortality can be reduced, in many cases, to negligible (less than 3 percent) levels. The Modular Inclined Screen (MIS) and its predecessor, the Eicher Screen, are devices that offer promise for providing needed improvements in fish protection. The Electric Power Research Institute has conducted research on these devices since 1985-from proof-of-principle research to field testing toward commercialization. The MIS is [open quotes]modular[close quotes] so as to provide the design flexibility necessary for applications involving a broad range of water flows. The installed cost of an MIS is estimated to be less than half that of screens designed to meet conventional screening criteria such as a vertical traveling screen. The MIS and the Eicher Screen work on an entirely different principle compared to traditional methods of diverting fish. Traditional methods rely on the fish's ability to sense and to avoid barriers in the water. Consequently, velocities perpendicular to the screen are restricted to a maximum of 0.4 feet per second to accomodate for the fish's swimming ability. With the MIS and Eicher Screen, fish are screened past a hazard and swept through a bypass at high velocity. Swimming ability is not a prerequisite for passage.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:5

TITLE: Flexible stainless steel hose liner used to rehab drain pipe for seal gates and outlet tubes
AUTHORS: Sauer, S J; Monsanto, R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DRAINAGE; LEAKS; REPAIR; PIPES; LINERS; OUTLET STRUCTURES; STAINLESS STEELS; ALLOYS; HIGH ALLOY STEELS; IRON ALLOYS; IRON BASE ALLOYS; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; POWER PLANTS; STEELS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Not unlike other dams, the Bureau of Reclamation's 6,500-MW Grand Coulee Dam in Washington State has a large amount of embedded piping, conduits, and drains. Typically, these features were constructed of ductile iron, cast iron, or carbon steel materials. Over the years, excessive internal corrosion of the drains for 102-inch ring seal gates and outlet tubes created leaks that required attention. Reclamation performed a number of temporary repairs before it became evident that the drain system must be rehabilitated. After considering several alternatives for rehabilitation, Reclamation selected stainless steel flexible hose liners for the job. Reclamation is satisfied with the performance of the stainless steel flexible hose liner. The total cost for installing the liners for nine drain lines (for three outlet tubes) was $15,000. Of that, materials cost $7,500, and labor and overhead cost $7,500. The inserts themselves cost from $640 for an 18-foot by 6-inch section. While this was not the least expensive option, it was the best choice for this job. The procedure will be repeated for other outlet tubes at Grand Coulee. Information used in this rehabilitation is being made available to other Reclamation projects.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:5

TITLE: Hard work, good fortune generate monks' mini-hydro success in Quebec
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; HISTORICAL ASPECTS; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; QUEBEC; WATER CURRENT POWER GENERATORS; CANADA; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: A monastery in Canada's Laurentian Mountains that needed an economical source of power has developed a modern, efficient 300-kW hydro plant to produce electricity for the order's self-contained electrical system. This article describes the history of the power plant and its development up to this time. Most of the work was performed by the monks themselves with donated equipment and money. The cost of developing the plant was less than $35,000, due to donated services and parts.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:5

TITLE: Water Watch
AUTHORS: Gruber, N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CAPACITY; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; STREAMS; FLOW RATE; USA; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: This issue of [open quotes]Water Watch,[close quotes] focusing on streamflow, is based on reports and data provided by the National Weather Service Office of hydrology and River Forecast Centers, US Department of Agriculture, the Bureau of Reclamation, Soil Conservation Service, California Department of Water Resources, and the US Geological Survey. Ninety-day outlooks are through August. For purposes of reporting, the US is divided into six regions. The data presented can be used to observe how weather conditions affected hydro generation in May.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:5

TITLE: Finding ways to make crossflow turbines more efficient
AUTHORS: Desai, V R; Aziz, N M; Fiuzat, A A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; DESIGN; EFFICIENCY; LOW-HEAD HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CROSSFLOW SYSTEMS; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; EQUIPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: New research has put a fresh slant on an old technology, opening the way for wider use of cost-effective crossflow turbines in small-capacity and low-head hydropower sites. Researchers at Clemson University are focusing on three key aspects of turbine design and operation to improve crossflow turbine efficiency: the relative efficiency of the two stages of the runner; the nozzle and runner parameters that produce the best efficiency; and the effect of flow stream spreading and runner submergence on turbine efficiency.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:5

TITLE: Rehabilitating and upgrading Hydro-Quebec's Manic 5 station
AUTHORS: Gay, L B; Mahe, B; Giguere, J G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; RETROFITTING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; WATER CURRENT POWER GENERATORS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Although modernizing the Manic 5 turbine-generator units would mean more capacity for Hydro-Quebec's electrical grid, the utility was concerned about extended downtime of the plant. Consequently, several innovative concepts were developed to make the rehabilitation feasible. This article describes some of those innovations, such as designing a portable machine for precision machining of the discharge ring to reduce the discharge ring tolerance, and increasing the stroke of servomotors to increase output by 20 MW.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:5

TITLE: Software systems simplify river management puzzle
AUTHORS: Schimpff, M; Wright, L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RESOURCE MANAGEMENT; POWER GENERATION; OPTIMIZATION; RIVERS; MANAGEMENT; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; ON-LINE CONTROL SYSTEMS; ON-LINE SYSTEMS; POWER PLANTS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Increasing demands on water resources are challenging hydro operators. Modular river management systems can make it easier to resolve water demands while generating the most electricity possible. The modular approach allows various departments and individuals to participate in building the system. Development becomes an interactive process with ideas and suggestions coming from all sources. The model becomes a function of the user rather than having the user adapt to the model. This ability eases acceptance of the module into the daily operation. As confidence in the program is gained, expansion becomes easier. The modular approach also requires a relatively small initial amount of funding. Small steps can be taken as capital is available. This approach puts system models within the reach of many small system owners and operators. Finally, the modular approach allows the user to begin realizing a range of benefits relatively quickly from the system. Those in turn, help him/her justify the economics of future development and expansion.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:5

TITLE: Understanding the phenomenon of drought
AUTHORS: Wilhite, D A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DROUGHTS; FORECASTING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RESOURCE MANAGEMENT; WATER RESOURCES; MANAGEMENT; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCES; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: As the demands placed on water resources increase, society and industry become more vulnerable to the effects of drought. Having a better understanding of drought can enable hydroelectric project owners, operators, and developers to improve their planning for future drought risks. This article describes drought in general as part of the climate, causes and predictability of drought, and the effects of drought.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:5

TITLE: Planting the [open quote]seeds[close quote] for increased water availability for hydro
AUTHORS: Griffith, D A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; RESOURCE MANAGEMENT; RAIN; PRODUCTION; SNOW; CALCULATION METHODS; CLOUDS; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; SILVER IODIDES; STREAMS; ATMOSPHERIC PRECIPITATIONS; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; IODIDES; IODINE COMPOUNDS; MANAGEMENT; POWER PLANTS; SILVER COMPOUNDS; SURFACE WATERS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Cloud seeding programs are providing some hydro producers with a way of increasing their water reserves on short notice and with relatively low cost. The fundamental formula has been known for half a century: clouds plus cold plus solid particles equal precipitation. What was not certain until more recently is how that relationship could be effectively used to alter the weather in positive ways. Research and practical experience now show that cloud seeding -- adding tiny solid particles to the right clouds at the right temperature -- works. More pertinent, evidence is mounting that hydropower producers can use well-designed, carefully times seeding programs to increase the amount of water available to their systems and thus enhance electricity generation. Cloud seeding has several advantages as a tool to augment hydroelectric production. Seeding programs typically require no capital investment by the utility or other power producer, and can be started and stopped on relatively short notice. Operating costs usually are less than $10 per acre-foot of additional streamflow. More broadly, the additional water produced for hydro generation has the environmental and community relations benefits of being reusable and less expensive than thermal power alternatives. There also normally are the additional benefits of increased water supplies for other users.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:5

TITLE: Resolving problems of high vibration in hydroelectric machinery
AUTHORS: Franklin, D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; MECHANICAL VIBRATIONS; REPAIR; WATER CURRENT POWER GENERATORS; BEARINGS; CLEARANCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: High vibrations in hydroelectric machinery often will necessitate derating of a unit's capacity so that it remains in acceptable operating condition. Such was the case at B.C. Hydro's 700-MW Peace Canyon Generating Station. At this station, a 175-MW turbine-generator experienced high stator split-phase currents on cold starts and high turbine bearing vibration at high loads. The vibration, measured at 24 mils (0.024 inch) peak to peak, exceeded the as-set turbine bearing clearance of 14 mils (0.014-inch) diametrical. Consequently, the utility derated the machine by 25 MW for a period of approximately seven months. B.C. Hydro contacted Powertech Labs Inc., the utility's applied technology subsidiary, and assigned the task of resolving the problem and restoring the unit to design capacity. Using vibration amplitude and phase vibrations as functions of the unit's rotational speed and load, Powertech investigators concluded that the problem of high vibrations on both the generator and turbine bearings were the result of mechanical unbalance on the generator, an enlarged turbine bearing clearance, and a hydraulic unbalance on the Francis turbine. The first step Powertech investigators took to improve the vibration readings on the generator and turbine was to [open quotes]compromise balance[close quotes] the generator. In this approach, the machine is mechanically unbalanced to counter magnetic unbalance. With the generator unbalance corrected, Powertech investigators recommended that the turbine bearing be inspected and reset to the design clearance of 14 mils (0.014 inch) diametrical. Resetting of the bearing resulted in significantly lower turbine vibration readings at high loads (less than 10 mils).
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:5

TITLE: Capturing the power potential on the Arkansas at existing dams
AUTHORS: Warner, C Q
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; ARKANSAS; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; ARKANSAS RIVER; COOPERATIVES; POWER GENERATION; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: Low energy prices stopped the first wave of hydro development on the Arkansas River short of the waterway's full potential. Arkansas' electric cooperatives, sparked by new energy economics and an interest in clean, renewable power sources, are helping to finish the job. One 32-MW hydro plant came on-line in 1988 and another is scheduled to begin operating in October, 1993. When the entire program is complete, hydroelectric power will supply 12% of the cooperatives' total generating capacity.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:5

TITLE: Learning from hydro relicensing: Lessons for all involved
AUTHORS: Barnes, M J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LICENSING PROCEDURES; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; LICENSE APPLICATIONS; LICENSING REGULATIONS; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; US FERC; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; REGULATIONS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: To discover lessons learned and trends established through the current licensing effort, the situation with the 1993 relicense applications was examined, and comments were gathered from various affected parties. In this article, the author reports significant findings and suggestions that can be useful in future relicensing work. 1 fig., 2 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:5

TITLE: Dealing with a penstock rupture: A success story
AUTHORS: Siminski, D R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ACCIDENTS; PENSTOCKS; REPAIR; RUPTURES; LOS ANGELES; CALIFORNIA; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; FAILURES; NORTH AMERICA; PIPES; POWER PLANTS; URBAN AREAS; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Speed and safety are important considerations when repairing damaged penstocks. When the Control Gorge penstock in southern California ruptured, quick, successful action prevented complications. In the winter of 1991, a break occurred in the lower portion of the 8-foot-diameter Owens River Gorge penstock. The rupture created a vacuum, which caused about 1,500 feet of the pipe upstream of the break to collapse. Investigations by the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power (LADWP) indicate that pressure surges in the penstock caused by rapid opening and closing of a turbine bypass-relief valve at the Control Gorge hydro plant and a defective weld at a manway (a small access that leads into the penstock) led to the rupture. Quick emergency repairs were required owing to the limited bypass capability around the penstock, the need for water flow for fish habitat in the lower sections of the Owens River, and water needs for Los Angeles. Within ten days, LADWP employees had temporarily repaired the penstock. In less than five months, workers had replaced the collapsed and ruptured sections, and returned the penstock to full service. The penstock rupture at Owens Gorge caused LADWP to recognize that older hydro plants may have hidden defects that would not have been left in place with current construction and inspection methods. Therefore, additional care should be taken during operation of these plants to avoid placing any unnecessary stresses on plant equipment.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:5

TITLE: Detecting leaks in geomembranes
AUTHORS: Laine, D L; Darilek, G T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; LINERS; LEAKS; WATER RESERVOIRS; ELECTRIC MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; QUALITY ASSURANCE; SANITARY LANDFILLS; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; MANAGEMENT; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; SURFACE WATERS; WASTE DISPOSAL; WASTE MANAGEMENT; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: This article reports on an electrical method can detect and locate leaks in geomembrane liners at new landfills and surface impoundment, even though the leaks may be pin-sized holes. A field-tested leak-locations survey, now commercially available, can provide construction quality assurance or solve a leakage problem in lined landfills, impoundments or tanks. A linear leak in a waste containment facility can be costly. The facility owner may face environmental cleanup costs and a loss of revenue while the leakage problem is being solved. Also, a new facility that exceeds the allowable leak rate, as defined in the design/operating permit, may not be accepted by the facility owner until the leakage problem is solved. This start-up delay may cause additional expenses or penalties for the general contractor, liner installer, and design engineering firm. This leak-location method involves connecting an electrical power supply to electrodes placed above and below a geomembrane to detect areas of localized electrical-current flow through leaks in the liner. If there are no leaks in the geomembrane, a very low current will flow across the liner producing relatively uniform voltage distribution in the material above the liner. If the liner has a leak, the current flows through the leak, causing an anomaly in the electrical distribution. Leaks are located by searching for these areas.
RELATION: Journal Name: Civil Engineering ASCE; (United States); Journal Volume: 63:8

TITLE: Effects of winter inundation on tundra vegetation in Iceland: Implications for hydroelectric development in the arctic
AUTHORS: Thorhallsdottir, T E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ARCTIC REGIONS; TUNDRA; FLOODS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ICELAND; PLANTS; SPECIES DIVERSITY; ECOSYSTEMS; ICE; LAKES; SEASONAL VARIATIONS; CRYOSPHERE; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; DISASTERS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; EUROPE; ISLANDS; POLAR REGIONS; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SURFACE WATERS; VARIATIONS; WESTERN EUROPE; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The diversion of part of the Thjorsa river created a series of lakes and waterways in the central highland of Iceland. Every winter, ice jams have formed, raising lake levels and inundating upshore vegetation. At five sites by two lakes, the vegetation has remained flooded for about 160 d from mid-winter until spring. To monitor the effects of inundation, species frequency in 10- [times] 10-cm quadrats was recorded on permanent on permanent transects prior to disturbance and again after periods of up to 8 yr. At one site, measurements were made annually for the first 6 yr and again 8 yr after disturbance. Two types of response to winter inundation were distinguished: (1) species showing a steady decrease in frequency and (2) species apparently little affected for a number of years, then suddenly collapsing. Combining the five sites, the common species were classified according to the strength and nature of their response into four groups: (1) nine sensitive species that rapidly declined or disappeared with repeated submergence, (2) six species showing variable negative response, (3) five species showing little response, and (4) one species showing a positive response. The results show that arctic species which are characteristic of dry or moist habitats are intolerant of inundation, even when it occurs outside of the growing season. This conclusion has implications for hydroelectric development in other arctic areas. 24 refs., 3 figs., 4 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Arctic and Alpine Research (Boulder, Colorado); (United States); Journal Volume: 25:3
JOURNAL_NAME: Arctic and Alpine Research (Boulder, Colorado); (United States)

TITLE: Architecture of the Sierra Ladrones Formation, central New Mexico. Depositional controls on the permeability correlation structure
AUTHORS: Davis, J M; Lohmann, R C; Phillips, F M; Wilson, J L; Love, D W
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; RIO GRANDE RIVER; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; HYDROLOGY; AQUIFERS; MAPPING; WATER RESERVOIRS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 580000* - Geosciences; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: Statistical models of hydrogeological heterogeneity are often used in aquifer and reservoir characterization. The number of data required to estimate objectively the spatial correlation structure of permeability, however, is often prohibitive. The objective of this study was to develop a better understanding of how information about depositional processes can be used to characterize hydrogeological heterogeneity. An outcrop of the fluvial/interfluvial Sierra Ladrones Formation of New Mexico was studied for this purpose. On the basis of previous studies of paleogeography and our own field observations, deposits of the Sierra Ladrones Formation are interpreted as marginal ancestral Rio Grande flood-plain and tributary deposits. Architectural elements were mapped over a 0.16-km[sup 2] peninsular outcrop of Pliocene-Pleistocene deposits of the central Albuquerque Basin. Geostatistical analysis of the architectural-element map data indicates non-orthogonal anisotropy in the horizontal direction. The orientations of the strongest (N30[degree]W) and weakest (N90[degree]E) correlation correspond to the orientation of the tributary system and the ancestral Rio Grande flood plain, respectively. In the vertical direction, the correlation structure exhibits exponential behavior corresponding to the average-element thicknesses. The results demonstrate that information about depositional environment can be used to help to quantify statistically subsurface heterogeneity. 28 refs., 9 figs., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geological Society of America, Bulletin; (United States); Journal Volume: 105:8
JOURNAL_NAME: Geological Society of America, Bulletin; (United States)

TITLE: Role of slope stability in cumulative impact assessment of hydropower development: North Cascades, Washington
AUTHORS: Lee, R R; Staub, W P
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; SLOPE STABILITY; EVALUATION; PIPELINES; DAMAGE; LANDSLIDES; SKAGIT RIVER; WASHINGTON
DESCRIPTION: Two environmental assessments considered the potential cumulative environmental impacts resulting from the development of eight proposed hydropower projects in the Nooksack River Basin and 11 proposed projects in the Skagit River Basin, North Cascades, Washington, respectively. While not identified as a target resource, slope stability and the alteration of sediment supply to creeks and river mainstems significantly affect other resources. The slope stability assessment emphasized the potential for cumulative impacts under disturbed conditions (e.g., road construction and timber harvesting) and a landslide-induced pipeline rupture scenario. In the case of small-scale slides, the sluicing action of ruptured pipeline water on the fresh landslide scarp was found to be capable of eroding significantly more material than the original landslide. For large-scale landslides, sluiced material was found to be a small increment of the original landslide. These results predicted that hypothetical accidental pipeline rupture by small-scale landslides may result in potential cumulative impacts for 12 of the 19 projects with pending license applications in both river basins. 5 refs., 2 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environmental Geology and Water Sciences; Journal Volume: 21; Journal Issue: 4; Other Information: PBD: Aug 1993

TITLE: Variable-speed generation enhances hydro operation
AUTHORS: Kaelin, B
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBOGENERATORS; EFFICIENCY; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; PERFORMANCE; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; EQUIPMENT; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Two major developments have given impetus to wider adoption of variable-speed turbine/generators in hydroelectric plants, both essentially environmental: (1) the need for stream-bed stability below river dams, and (2) the need to minimize fish damage. Also, the need to stabilize pumped-storage and generating efficiencies to match extreme changes in head levels has been a driving force. Variable-speed operation in hydro applications is relatively new to North America. In other parts of the world, it has been used in pumped-storage plants since 1971. In the US, and increasing potential exists for variable-speed hydro, considering the 30 pumped-storage plants already in operation and several river plants struggling with high head fluctuations--including four at stations operated by the Bonneville Power Administration. Several modifications to hydro-plant hardware and operating procedures are actively being considered at Bonneville--all of them practical but costly. The question becomes: How to preserve efficiency in power generation when water levels change the way generating machinery functions This article addresses three options for dealing with fluctuating water head: Pole-switching generators, Variable-speed generators, and Static-frequency converters.
RELATION: Journal Name: Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 137:7

TITLE: The sizes of salmonid spawning gravels
AUTHORS: Kondolf, G M; Wolman, M G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; SALMON; POPULATION DYNAMICS; REPRODUCTION; SEDIMENTS; PARTICLE SIZE; SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION; TROUT; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; NESTS; STREAMS; ANADROMOUS FISHES; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; DISTRIBUTION; FISHES; SIZE; SURFACE WATERS; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 540210 - Environment, Terrestrial- Basic Studies- (1990-); 540310 - Environment, Aquatic- Basic Studies- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The availability of suitably sized spawning gravels limits salmonid (salmon and trout) populations in many streams. The authors compiles published and original size distribution data to determine distinguishing characteristics of spawning gravels and how gravel size varies with size of the spawning fish. Median diameters of 135 size distributions ranged from 5.4 to 78 mm, with 50% falling between 14.5 and 35 mm. All but three spawning gravel size distributions were negatively skewed (on a log-transformed basis), with 50% of the skewness coefficients falling between [minus]0.24 and [minus]0.39. Fewer than 20% of the distributions were bimodal. Although tending to be coarser, spawning gravels had sorting and skewness values similar to other fluvial gravels reported in the literature. The range of gravel sizes used by fish of a given species or length is great, but the relation between fish size and size of gravel can be described by an envelope curve. In general, fish can spawn in gravels with a median diameter up to about 10% of their body length. 53 refs., 8 figs., 2 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resources Research; (United States); Journal Volume: 29:7

TITLE: Status of fish passage facilities at nonfederal hydropower projects
AUTHORS: Cada, G F; Sale, M J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; COMMERCIAL SECTOR; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; PERFORMANCE; EVALUATION; MONITORING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DEVELOPERS; MITIGATION; POWER PLANTS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The status of direct mitigation practices for fish passage was assessed as part of an ongoing, multi-year study of the costs and benefits of environmental mitigation measures at nonfederal hydroelectric power plants. Information was obtained from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, hydropower developers and state and federal resource agencies involved in hydropower regulation. Fish ladders were found to be the most common means of passing fish upstream; elevators/lifts were less common, but their use appears to be increasing. A wide variety of mitigative measures, including spill flows, narrow-mesh intake screens, angled bar racks and light- or sound-based guidance measures, is employed to prevent fish from being drawn into turbine intakes. Performance monitoring and detailed, quantifiable performance criteria were frequently lacking. Fifty-two of the 66 projects (82%) with operating downstream fish passage measures had no performance monitoring requirements; 50 of 71 project operators (70%) indicated that no performance objectives had been specified for the mitigative measures. The authors found that comprehensive field studies needed to evaluate the effectiveness of fish passage devices have been rare. 16 refs., 8 figs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Fisheries; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:7

TITLE: Successful Hydro overhauls: They're planned that way
AUTHORS: Johnson, R C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; MAINTENANCE; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; PLANNING; PERSONNEL MANAGEMENT; QUALITY ASSURANCE; RETROFITTING; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; MANAGEMENT; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Making investments in total quality planning before beginning major maintenance projects will result in scheduling, safety, and efficiency benefits that far outweigh the costs. Hydro project owners that begin major maintenance programs with comprehensive, sharply focused planning are doing their best to ensure that quality work will be performed. Just as important, those owners can expect better scheduling, improved employee performance and morale, reduced risks, and lower long-term costs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:4

TITLE: Enhancing fire safety at Hydro plants with dry transformers
AUTHORS: Clemen, D M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SAFETY; TRANSFORMERS; FIRE HAZARDS; FIRE RESISTANCE; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; COST ESTIMATION; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; HAZARDS; POWER PLANTS; 130800* - Hydro Energy- Health & Safety- (1990-); 130700 - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Hydroelectric plant owners and engineers can use dry-type transformers to reduce fire hazards in auxiliary power systems. The decision to replace a liquid-immersed transformer with a dry-type product has a price: higher unit cost and a need to be more vigilant in detailing transformer specifications. But, whether the change affects only one failed transformer or is part of a plant rehabilitation project, the benefits in safety can be worth it. Voltages on hydroelectric plant auxiliary power systems can range from a 20 kV medium-voltage system to the normal 480-208/120 V low-voltage system. Dry transformers typically are used in such systems to reduce the fire hazard present with liquid-filled transformers. For a hydro plant owner or engineer seeking alternatives to liquid-filled transformers, there are two main kinds of dry-type transformers to consider: vacuum pressure impregnated (VPI) and cast coil epoxy resin. VPI transformers normally are manufactured in sizes up to 6,000 kVA with primary voltage ratings up to 20 kV. Cast coil transformers can be made in sizes from 75 to 10,000 kVA, with primary voltage ratings up to 34,500 V. Although the same transformer theory applies to dry transformers as to liquid-filled units, the cooling medium, air, required different temperature rise ratings, dielectric tests, and construction techniques to ensure reliability. Consequently, the factory and field tests for dry units are established by a separate set of American National Standards Institute (ANSI)/Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) standards. Cast coil transformers have several important advantages over VPI units.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:4

TITLE: Computer model uses outside stator core temperatures to predict internal winding temperatures
AUTHORS: Ghate, A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ARMATURES; TEMPERATURE MONITORING; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; WATER CURRENT POWER GENERATORS; FINITE ELEMENT METHOD; HEAT TRANSFER; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; STATORS; CALCULATION METHODS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ENERGY TRANSFER; MONITORING; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Hydroelectric generator armature windings often fail in the area of the greatest winding temperature. To avoid premature failures, hydro plant owners operate generators so that the maximum winding temperature (hot spot) is limited to a pre-determined value. In order for operators to monitor winding temperature, generator manufacturers embed several resistance temperature detectors (RTDs) in the armature winding. RTDs typically are placed from one to three elevations in the generator core. However, these elevations may not coincide with the locations of maximum winding temperatures during actual operation. It normally is impractical to embed additional RTDs at other elevations in the winding. A more practical alternative is to measure iron temperatures and air velocities at the outside (back) of the stator core to ensure that generators are being adequately monitored for maximum winding temperature. In a study for the New York Power Authority (NYPA), Power Engineering developed a finite element computer model that allows the use of back-iron temperature and air velocity data to predict internal winding temperatures. The model demonstrates that back-iron temperatures can be used to determine the location of the maximum winding temperature (hot spot). Furthermore, by changing the value of the convective coefficients based on measured air velocities, the model could be updated to determine the hot spot(s) in the pre-upgrade turbine-generators. Generator loading then could be controlled accordingly. Finally, if required, the model could be tailored further by accounting for end turn cooling effects. With changes in geometry, this kind of modeling can be used to predict winding temperatures in other generators.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:4

TITLE: Group prepares guidelines for documenting dam performance
AUTHORS: McCann, Jr, M W
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; PERFORMANCE; REPORTING REQUIREMENTS; RECOMMENDATIONS; SAFETY REPORTS; EARTHQUAKES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; US FEMA; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; SEISMIC EVENTS; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
