SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; CONSTRUCTION; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CAPACITY; BIDS; COLUMBIA RIVER; MONTANA; POWER; PROPOSALS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; USA; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Montana Power Co. has chosen Kvaerner Hydro Power Inc., Stamford, Conn., to supply a turbine-generator to increase capacity to 90 MW at the utility's 40-MW Thompson Falls project on Clark's Fork of the Columbia River. Kvaerner was the chosen vendor, according to utility spokesman Cort Freeman, who said that a letter of intent to purchase the turbine-generator for $15 million was being prepared. Kvaerner Hydro Power's Swedish affiliate, Kvaerner Turbine, will manufacturer the Kaplan turbine with a runner diameter of 6.65 meters. Montana Power proposed upgrading its Thompson Falls and Ryan projects to compete with utility and non-utility bids responding to its request for proposals for 150 MW of new resources. The hydro upgrades are among 11 projects Montana Power short-listed. Freeman said the choice of Kvaerner did not signify that the Thompson Falls did not signify that the Thompson Falls upgrade had been chosen over other bids, although the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has approved the Thompson Falls addition. He explained that Montana Power is attempting to coordinate deadlines for construction specified in its FERC license with the RFP and its least-cost resource plan.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: NYPA starts overhaul work at Blenheim-Gilboa project
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; RETROFITTING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONTRACTS; COST; NEW YORK; POWER; WATER WHEELS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; USA; WHEELS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The New York Power Authority has begun an overhaul of the 1,040-MW Blenheim-Gilboa Pumped-Storage Power Project. Each of the project's four generators will be refurbished, at a rate of one each year. The final unit is to be completed in January 1996. With one unit out of service, the maximum power output from the 20-year-old project will be 780 MW. Voith Hydro has a contract to oversee the renovation. General Electric Co. will replace the stator winding on each pump-generator. NYPA crews will refurbish the water wheels on each unit. Each overhaul will cost about $4.5 million.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: TVA signs partnering pact with Voith Hydro; awards contract for Norris Dam
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; RETROFITTING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CAPACITY; TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY; CONTRACTS; AIR; AWARDS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; OXYGEN; VERIFICATION; WATER; ELECTRIC POWER; ELEMENTS; ENERGY SOURCES; EQUIPMENT; FLUIDS; GASES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MACHINERY; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NONMETALS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The Tennessee Valley Authority has signed a partnering agreement worth about $200 million with Voith Hydro, Inc., Voith will upgrade and refurbish all of TVA's major hydroturbines as part of the power producer's hydro modernization program. The program will add 240 MW of generating capacity to the TVA system by the year 2000. Under the terms of the agreement, Voith will supply approximately 75 replacement turbine runners and other components. The ten-year agreement requires renewal every two years. Separate from their partnering agreement, TVA awarded Voith a major runner replacement contract that calls for the turbine manufacturer to supply two 65-MW Francis runners for TVA's Norris Dam hydro plant. The runners will be equipped with methods of air admission previously tested on a model scale at Voith's laboratory. In 1991, TVA and Voith completed a joint developmental effort in that laboratory, where researchers tested various means of introducing atmospheric air into the water passing through a hydraulic turbine to increase the level of dissolved oxygen. The research program yielded promising results - results that now need verification on a full-size prototype basis. The first of these two runners will be installed in the summer of 1994.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: How will the US Energy Policy Act of 1992 affect hydro
AUTHORS: Beggs, S L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; BUSINESS; REGULATIONS; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; LICENSING PROCEDURES; PERMITS; PUBLIC LANDS; US ENERGY POLICY AND CONSERVATION ACT; US FERC; US NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY ACT; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; LAWS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: In October 1992, the US Congress approved the National Energy Policy Act, which included measures that affect the hydroelectric industry. Reaction to the Energy Policy Act of 1992 is mixed among industry leaders. Some see sections of the act as a menace to the hydro industry. Others, however, see glimmers of hope in the passage of the act - not so much for what was included in the final bill, but for what was omitted from the legislation, and the industry's unified effort to eliminate those onerous provisions. Similarly, there are differing views on how this act will affect the industry, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), and the licensing of hydro projects. Major provisions of the act that will affect the hydro industry include: Amendment of the Federal Power Act (FPA), Section 18, vacating FERC's fishway definition. A reversal of a recent federal court ruling (the Henwood case) that exempted FERC-licensed projects from obtaining right-of-way permits for projects on federal lands. A broadening of the existing ban on development of hydro projects within national parks. Streamlining of the regulatory process to allow project applicants to contract with a third party to complete documents required under the National Environmental Policy Act. Amendment of the FPA to allow state and federal resource agencies to get reimbursed - from annual charges collected by FERC - for studies and reviews completed as part of the licensing process.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Water watch
AUTHORS: Gruber, N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; STATISTICS; SOILS; MOISTURE; STREAMS; USA; WATER; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MATHEMATICS; NORTH AMERICA; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: This issue of Water Watch focuses on soil moisture and winter streamflow development, particularly in the western U.S. Ninety-day outlooks are through March 1993. Hydropower generation statistics for the U.S. for December 1991 and '92 and December 10 year average are also provided.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Federal government report looks at electric power
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC POWER; CAPACITY; PLANNING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; CANADA; COOPERATION; ELECTRIC POWER INDUSTRY; ELECTRICITY; PRICES; REGULATIONS; STANDARDS; TRADE; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ENERGY SOURCES; INDUSTRY; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 296000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power; 130500 - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Energy, Mines and Resources Canada, in cooperation with utilities and the Canadian Electrical Association, has published a new report on electric power in Canada that includes sections on electrical generation, trading of electricity, and non-utility generation. The report, published in large 1992, looks at the electric power industry in Canada during 1991. Regulatory structures, generating capacity and reserve, and the future of the electric power industry also are discussed in Electric Power in Canada 1991. Although hydro's share of total installed capacity has declined from 81 percent in 1960, hydro remains the most important source of electrical energy in Canada. In 1991, hydro's capacity share accounted for more than 58 percent of total installed capacity. The report also identifies a planning potential for sites totaling 43,886 MW that are likely candidates for development. The 165-page report includes tables on: installed generating capacity, 1960-1991; Canada's largest hydro stations; Canada's hydroelectric capacity; installed generating capacity by fuel type and province; and Canadian-US electricity trade. It also includes figures on electricity generation and installed generating capacity by fuel type. The document features appendices on remaining hydroelectric potential, by province, federal environmental standards and guidelines, and prices paid by major utilities for non-utility generation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: New tool assesses condition of rotor and stator windings
AUTHORS: Stone, G C
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ROTORS; STATORS; EVALUATION; COMPUTER CODES; PERSONAL COMPUTERS; COMPUTERS; DIGITAL COMPUTERS; MICROCOMPUTERS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: A new computer program can help nonexperts accurately determine the condition of rotor and stator windings in hydroelectric generators. The Electric Power Research Institute provided partial funding for development of the MICAA software, which guides nonspecialist maintenance personnel through the process of selecting the most appropriate tests and inspections to perform on generators. After operators enter past and present test and inspection data, the program will interpret results within the context of machine ratings, insulation materials, and operating environment. The program then calculates an overall indication of the condition of the rotor and stator windings and identifies the most likely cause of winding deterioration. Identifying the cause of winding deterioration is especially helpful in planning maintenance.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Using a closed loop system to cool generator and lubricating oil
AUTHORS: Hudson, E E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; COOLING; LUBRICATING OILS; BEARINGS; CLOSED-CYCLE COOLING SYSTEMS; HEAT EXCHANGERS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PUMPS; COOLING SYSTEMS; LUBRICANTS; OILS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OTHER ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; POWER PLANTS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Operators at the 12-MW Koma Kulshan Project in northern Washington State have come up with an innovative way to cool the generator and bearing lubrication oil in the hydro plant. The new cooling system works much like an automobile's cooling system. Koma Kulshan is owned by Koma Kulshan Associates, a partnership that includes Pacific Energy and Utilico Group. The project is operated by another partner, Independent Hydro Developers Inc. Electricity generated is sold to Puget Sound Power and Light Co. In the fall of 1991, workers installed a closed loop system at the project that uses water form the tailrace to cool the generator and the bearing lubrication oil. The new cooling water system features keel coolers (of the same standard design as those mounted to the outside of boat hulls) anchored in the project's tailrace and a dual pump system for circulating the water.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Court refuses to reconsider Hydro-Quebec case
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; SOCIAL IMPACT; AMERICAN INDIANS; BIRDS; CONSTRUCTION; CONTRACTS; DAMAGE; ENVIRONMENT; LEGAL ASPECTS; VERMONT; ANIMALS; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; HUMAN POPULATIONS; MINORITY GROUPS; NORTH AMERICA; POPULATIONS; POWER PLANTS; USA; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: A US court has denied a request that it reconsider a decision upholding Hydro-Quebec's $4 billion sale of 340 MW to 16 Vermont utilities. The Vermont Supreme Court issued the decision in October, rejecting arguments that the contract would result in construction of Hydro-Quebec's giant Grande Baleine (Great Whale) hydroelectric development, flooding Creek Indian lands and harming waterfowl. The Vermont Public Service Board endorsed the 340-MW sale - the continuation of a previous sale - to 24 utilities in 1990, but rejected sale of an additional 110 MW without more proof that the power is needed and that its generation would not cause undue environmental damage. Since 1990, one utility merged with another, and seven withdrew from the contract, leaving 16 buyers. The New England Coalition for Energy Efficiency and the Environment and the Grand Council of the Cree appealed the Public Service Board approval. The high court agreed with the Public Service Board that the 340-MW purchase - a fraction of Hydro-Quebec's total 24,000-MW output - is a continuation of an earlier purchase and that no new construction at James Bay is necessary to supply the power. That finding undercut arguments about Grande Baleine's effects on the Cree.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Utilities plan fish lifts for Susquehanna River Dams
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES; CONSTRUCTION; COST; DAMS; DESIGN; PENNSYLVANIA; SPILLWAY; SUSQUEHANNA RIVER; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; NORTH AMERICA; RIVERS; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Pennsylvania Power Light Co., Baltimore Gas Electric Co., and Metropolitan Edison Co. will install fish lifts at three dams on the Susquehanna River to aid the spawning of American shad. The utilities estimate the lifts will cost a total of $15 million. PP L will install two lifts at its 108-MW Holtwood Dam, according to the utility's Bob Domermuth, a project scientist. One will be located at the spillway and the second in the tailrace. The two lifts will cost approximately $8 million. At the 417-MW Safe Harbor Dam, which PP L and BG E jointly own, one lift costing $5 million to $6 million will be built on the west side of the powerhouse. Met Ed will install a lift at its 20-MW York Haven Dam, the farthest upstream, at a cost of $3 million. Lifts at Holtwood and Safe Harbor will be completed in time for the spring 1997 shad run; York Haven's passage is to be completed no later than the spring of the year 2000. In 1991, Philadelphia Electric Co. completed a lift at its 512-MW Conowingo Dam, the first dam shad encounter as they swim upstream from the ocean. The utilities agreed with state and federal fish and wildlife agencies to build the lifts, after a decade of studying shad population and rebuilding stocks. Although the agreement is only in draft form, the utilities have begun studying fish movement to determine the best lift designs. While American shad is the species targeted by the effort, the lifts will open the river to all species, Comermuth said. The utilities also are preparing a bid package soliciting design and construction proposals.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Hydro-Quebec will accept new proposals; extends deadline for agreements
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; QUEBEC; CONTRACTS; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PROPOSALS; AGREEMENTS; CAPACITY; DEVELOPERS; RESOURCES; CANADA; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Hydro-Quebec is accepting proposals from developers of renewable energy projects up to 25 MW interested in selling power to the utility. The projects can include hydroelectric sites released for development by Quebec's Ministry of Energy and Natural Resources. Hydro-Quebec said it will accept renewable projects for contract negotiations until June 1, 1993, to a maximum of 200 MW. That revises an earlier announcement to accept for contract talks all renewable energy projects with a total capacity of less than 10 MW, up to a total of 100 MW. Additionally, Hydro-Quebec has extended its deadline for signing contracts with hydroelectric projects responding to a 1991 request for proposals (RFP) from non-utility generators. Projects still must be on line by the end of 1996, as initially stipulated. Hydro-Quebec said delaying the deadline to June 1 should give projects a greater chance of materializing. As the new year began, the utility said it had signed or was conducting negotiations with projects totaling 1,185 MW, all but two responding to its 1991 RFP. Forty-nine hydroelectric projects totalling 225 MW are among projects signed or in negotiations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Federal government program provides funds for R D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; US FEDERAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS; COMMERCIALIZATION; FINANCIAL INCENTIVES; SMALL BUSINESSES; BUSINESS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Small businesses looking for funding to support research and development projects may be interested in the US government's Small Business Innovative Research Program. The program, overseen by the Small Business Administration, is a competitive award system for businesses with 500 or fewer employees interested in proposing innovative ideas that meet the government's needs. Projects are funded through the SBIR Program, not agency budgets. The SBIR Program, created by the Small Business Innovation Development Act of 1982, is designed to assist participating federal agencies in meeting their respective research needs. While stimulating technological innovation, the program also provides qualified small businesses with opportunities to compete for a greater share of federal R D awards. Federal agencies have awarded more than $3.2 billion for more than 25,000 research projects since the program started. The Department of Energy (DOE), National Science Foundation, and the Environmental Protection Agency are among 11 agencies participating in the program. Agencies designate topics upon which SBIR proposals will be sought; release at least one SBIR solicitation annually; receive and evaluate SBIR proposals; and award SBIR funding agreements, based upon technical and scientific merit and how well the proposals meet the agencies needs. Before leaving office, President Bush signed legislation extending the program to the year 2000 and tripling the federal government's commitment to the program to $1.6 billion annually by 1997. The measure also requires federal agencies with external R D budgets greater than $100 million to allocate an amount - equal to 2.5 percent of the funds they award - to small businesses. That is double that required before the new legislation became law.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Outlook for hydropower in Latin America and the Caribbean
AUTHORS: Sanchez-Sierra, G
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; DEMAND; LATIN AMERICA; WATER RESOURCES; BUSINESS; ELECTRICITY; FORECASTING; FOSSIL FUELS; INDUSTRY; WATER USE; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; FUELS; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: In the last two decades, the Latin America/Carribean region has become increasingly dependent on electricity to meet growing demands for energy. Hydropower is the prevailing source for meeting this need. Hydroelectric generation increased at an annual average rate of nearly 9% between 1971 and 1989. HYdro now provides more than two-thirds of total electric power generated in Latin America and the Caribbean. The only other predominant source used for electric generation is fossil fuels. In this region there are several trends developing. They include: developing more small hydro facilities, opportunities for sharing water resources, an interest in changing the approach to water use regulation, and possibilities for more participation by the private sector. Overall, hydro appears to have a favorable competitive position in the power industry in the Latin America/Caribbean region.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Dam safety program spared; dam safety act extended
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; LEGISLATION; SAFETY; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; NATIONAL GOVERNMENT; US FEMA; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130400* - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: Before leaving office, President Bush signed a bill that included funding of $612,000 to continue the Federal Emergency Management Agency's Dam Safety Program for the fiscal year that ends September 30, 1993. This amount includes funding for Association of State Dam Safety Officials programs. Bush signed the bill October 6, despite his administration's earlier attempt to terminate the program. Loss of funding for the 1993 fiscal year could have proven devastating to state dam safety programs, as states take their lead from the federal government. Ninety-five percent of the nation's dams are regulated by state dam safety programs, including 2,500 unsafe, high-hazard dams. Funding for the federal program was included in the Veterans Administration, Housing and Urban Development, and Independent Agencies Appropriations Bill (HR 5679). The appropriation included approximately $250,000 to renew a research grant ASDSO will use to fund its popular public awareness workshop program, regional technical seminars, and annual research projects. In addition to urging Congress to fund FEMA's Dam Safety Program, ASDSO is pursuing a long-term plan to see that new federal dam safety legislation is authorized. The 102nd Congress chose not to revise existing dam safety legislation and instead passed a watered-down version of the Water Resources Development Act of 1992, extending the Dam Safety Act of 1986 from 1992 to 1994.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Skimming' a reservoir for trash
AUTHORS: Shenman, L E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; POLLUTION CONTROL EQUIPMENT; DESIGN; EFFICIENCY; TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY; WATER RESERVOIRS; EQUIPMENT; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Several hydropower facilities are using a new technology for removing floating trash in reservoirs. Representatives from the facilities say the boat, called a trashskimmer, is efficient, easy to maneuver, and transportable. Designed by United Marine International, Inc., the pontoon boat features an operators cab that straddles an open hull between the skis of the pontoon, and uses dual propellers to maneuver through the water. The Marineskimmer allows the operator to approach the trash from the water side upstream of the plant. The Tennessee Valley Authority has used the boat since 1990.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Fishin' for balance: Selecting minimum flow at hydro projects
AUTHORS: Franc, G M
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; OPERATION; STREAMS; FLOW MODELS; HABITAT; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTIMIZATION; PRESERVATION; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Finding an optimal minimum flow for a hydroelectric project can be compared to a fishing outing at an untested pond - you often have to fish around to locate the best spot. Selecting the amount of flow to release downstream of a hydro plant that will provide the maximum habitat protection at the minimum cost can indeed be a guessing game. At Niagara Mohawk, we've developed a computer program called FISHN that gives the user information and insight needed for making reasonable, logical minimum flow decisions. The program gives consideration to both hydrological and biological data when recommending a flow, and does not require the user to intuitively judge the value of habitat.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Using computers to find the optimal river system operation strategy
AUTHORS: Feild, C T; Morgan, S A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; RIVERS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; CONTROL; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; OPTIMIZATION; WATER QUALITY; WISCONSIN; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ECONOMICS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SIMULATION; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: One approach to finding the optimal operation is to use a computer model for simulating various river system operating strategies. These simulations then can be used to calculate the costs and benefits of each strategy. The Wisconsin Valley Improvement Company (WVIC) used one such computer model to simulate its operation of the Wisconsin River. With the model and other computer spread-sheet programs, WVIC was able to estimate the economic value of hydro-power, recreation, and water quality benefits provided by particular river system operation strategies. This information was useful for WVIC as it prepared an application for a new license (relicense) from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC).
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Numerical model computes dam-break flows on dry beds
AUTHORS: Kahawita, R
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; FAILURES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; FLOODS; DAMAGE; DEPTH; EMERGENCY PLANS; ENGINEERING; EVACUATION; HYDRODYNAMICS; PLANNING; SYSTEM FAILURE ANALYSIS; VALLEYS; WATER; DIMENSIONS; DISASTERS; FLUID MECHANICS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MECHANICS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SYSTEMS ANALYSIS; 130800* - Hydro Energy- Health & Safety- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Most regulatory agencies insist that dam-break studies be performed before they will grant approval to a project. For such studies, engineers use numerical models to determine maximum water depths and discharges that sites downstream of the dam are likely to experience, and when the surge wave will reach those sites. Knowing the maximum water depths and discharges are useful when evaluating potential damage. Knowing when the surge wave will reach a site is useful for planning procedures for emergency evacuation. Researchers at Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal (the University of Montreal's Engineering School) have developed a numerical model that can be used to solve the spread of the surge wave for areas downstream of the dam that initially may be dry (not yet flooded). For computations involving an advancing or receding wave front on a dry bed, the model guards against values of water depth becoming physically unrealistic, such as a negative value. It also avoids difficulties in computing the flow field when zero water depths are involved, such as when the flood plain is dry. The research group first verified the model by comparing numerically computed results with analytical solutions that are available when certain restrictive assumptions are made. Additionally, satisfactory results were obtained when the model was tested against measurements from an experimental US Army Corps of Engineers' flume in Vicksburg, Miss., and data from the university's Hydrodynamics Laboratory. Even though the measurements were made in flat bed channels, the researchers emphasize that the scheme is not restricted to flat beds. The researchers subsequently tested the model on cases involving terrain with hills and valleys and reported satisfactory results.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: A primer on draft tube surging
AUTHORS: Falvey, H T
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; PERFORMANCE; SURGES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; DESIGN; DIFFUSERS; EFFICIENCY; SCALE MODELS; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; STRUCTURAL MODELS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: The draft tube surge is a significant factor to consider when operating hydropower plants at other than the maximum efficiency point. The magnitude of the surge and its effect on the electrical and hydraulic systems can be predicted by combining model investigations with a mathematical model that incorporates the system characteristics. Multiple vortices and multiple mode shapes complicate the prediction of the draft tube surge characteristics. The transition from one mode shape to another is a function of the swirl in the draft tube. The transition between mode shapes often produces large pressure pulses. Air injection and appurtenances in the draft tube throat can be effective in ameliorating the effects of the draft tube surge. However, these modifications frequently have adverse side effects, such as reduced efficiency of the turbine, and may not function properly at both part load and full load conditions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Harza Northwest will review operating alternatives
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DRAWDOWN; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; ECONOMIC IMPACT; SALMON; MIGRATION; BONNEVILLE POWER ADMINISTRATION; COLUMBIA RIVER BASIN; ENGINEERING; ENVIRONMENT; OPERATION; PLANNING; PROPOSALS; STORAGE; WATER; ANADROMOUS FISHES; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; FISHES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; VERTEBRATES; WATERSHEDS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Harza Northwest will conduct an independent review of federal drawdown proposals in the Columbia River Basin. Several operating alternatives, outlined by the US Army Corps of Engineers, the Bureau of Reclamation, and the Bonneville Power Administration in the Columbia River System Operation Review, call for reservoir drawdowns. Drawdowns have been proposed as a method to help salmon move to sea more quickly, improving their chances of survival. Harza Northwest will oversee the study of those options, looking at engineering, operations, and economical and biological effects. It will submit a final report to the Northwest Power Planning Council in late 1993 or early 1994. BPA is funding the $500,000 contract. The Corps of Engineers already has issued its own final report on the March 1992 drawdowns of two Snake River reservoirs. That report concluded that drawdowns could adversely affect the environment. The Northwest Power Planning Council's fish recovery plan calls for drawdowns, starting as early as 1995. However, the council may reconsider if the concept proves to be too costly or does not benefit fish. Harza Northwest will look at all methods of improving fish survival, including storage of additional water to increase flows, and diverting, barging, and trucking fish around dams.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Utility stresses environmental programs, research projects
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; AUDITS; BRITISH COLUMBIA; DUSTS; FISHES; FLOODS; HABITAT; PLANTS; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; SOCIAL IMPACT; WATER QUALITY; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; CANADA; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; DISASTERS; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: B.C. Hydro, the provincial electric utility of British Columbia, views environmental programs and research projects as an important part of its business. Many of these activities stem from some aspect of hydroelectric generation as the utility relies on 39 reservoirs and 30 hydro stations for the bulk of its electricity production. These programs and research projects are featured in B.C. Hydro's first annual Report on the Environment, which summarizes the utility's work to minimize the effects of operations on the natural and social environment. Some programs and research projects were initiated some years ago, while others are new. B.C.'s environmental programs include environmental audits and fish and wildlife compensation (mitigation) programs. In 1988, the utility and the province's Ministry of Environment, Lands and Parks began developing compensation programs to address water license requirements for B.C. Hydro's hydroelectric developments. Today, compensation programs for the Peace and Columbia river area serve as models for future programs. The utility also reports it is reviewing all operating orders for its water system to identify opportunities to make operations more sensitive to environmental concerns. Additionally, work is under way on a preliminary strategy for addressing fish and water quality issues and setting minimum flow requirements. And in an effort to control dust storms, B.C. Hydro reports it is studying native perennial plants that can endure the flooding/drawdown cycle typical of a water storage reservoir.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Scholarship program to benefit future engineers
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; SAFETY ENGINEERING; ENGINEERS; EDUCATION; CIVIL ENGINEERING; ENGINEERING; GEOLOGY; ANIMALS; MAMMALS; MAN; PERSONNEL; PRIMATES; PROFESSIONAL PERSONNEL; VERTEBRATES; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: ASDSO this year launched a new scholarship program for undergraduate students interested in dam safety engineering as a career. Two scholarships of $2,500 each will be granted to one junior and one senior, beginning with the 1993 school year. Students taking a full college course load and majoring in civil or agricultural engineering, geology, or a related field, were elgible. ASDSO, which plans to name the recipients by May 1993, received about two dozen applications for the scholarships.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Ontario Hydro cancels pact with Manitoba Hydro; Conawapa project shelved
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRICITY; CONTRACTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; CANCELLATION; CAPITAL; CONSTRUCTION; ENERGY; EXPENDITURES; MANAGEMENT; MANITOBA; ONTARIO; CANADA; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Ontario Hydro has canceled a contract to purchase electricity from Manitoba Hydro, paying a penalty fee of less than $150 million. The utility says the cancellation will enable it to save as much as $11 billion. Ontario Hydro canceled the contract in December after first seeking a five-year delay in implementing an agreement that called for Ontario Hydro to buy 1,000 MW of power for 20 years, beginning in the year 2000. The agreement had helped justify plans for construction of Manitoba Hydro's proposed 1,390-MW Conawapa generating station, once scheduled for operation in 2001. Ontario Hydro's decision to cancel the agreement, signed in 1989, puts Conawapa on the shelf for the time being, said Glenn Schneider, manager of public affairs for Manitoba Hydro. The project could proceed eventually if other export options emerge, or if domestic needs for additional energy develop within the province, he said. Schneider added it was not immediately known how the decision to shelve the Conawapa project would affect the review of the facility. An environmental review panel has already issued draft guidelines for how the utility should conduct an environmental impact assessment of the project. Ontario Hydro decided to cancel the contract after it learned it would be more costly to postpone the agreement than to terminate it. Ontario Hydro said Manitoba Hydro had sought concessions worth more than $300 million to defer the agreement by five years. In addition, Ontario Hydro has placed all non-utility generation contracts not yet approved on hold, pending the outcome of a review of short- and long-term supply needs and commitments. Ontario Hydro's Board of Directors earlier approved a plan proposed by the utility's senior management to reduce capital expenditures by more than $7 billion over the next ten years.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Private developers submit 31 proposals for Quebec sites
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; QUEBEC; CONTRACTS; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PROPOSALS; ABANDONED SITES; BIDS; DEVELOPERS; CANADA; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The Quebec Ministry of Energy and Natural resources received 31 proposals for hydro projects at seven sites. Offers were submitted in response to an announcement in July 1992 making eight sites available for private development. Bids were received for seven of the sites. Chute Martine on the Metabetchouane River was the most popular of the sites. Ten proposals were submitted for the 6.3-MW site. The flow of the river and the falls' height made this site very interesting for proposers,' said Ronald Gignac, of Quebec's Ministry of Energy and Natural Resources. One bid was made for 12 km de Waltham, a 9.9-MW site on the Noire; the 1.5-MW Saint-Elzear site on the Hall received two; and Chute Burroughs, 1.6 MW on the Nigger, received three bids. Four to six bids were made for each of the remaining sites: Saint-Alban, 3 MW, on the Sainte-Anne-de-la-Perade; Marches naturelles, 1.3 MW, Montmorency River; and Jean-Guerin, 1.2 MW on the Etchemin River. No proposals were submitted for the 1-MW Farnham site on the Yamaska River. Gignac said the ministry hopes to notify winning developers in February. Quebec's ongoing program is to open about 100 abandoned sites to private developers. In 1991, the province opened 13 sites for development and selected ten proposals totaling 28.4 MW. Hydro-Quebec subsequently chose the developers for contract talks.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Rodney Hunt supplies gates to Idaho Power's Swan Falls
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RETROFITTING; CAPACITY; CONSTRUCTION; CONTRACTS; DIFFUSERS; IDAHO; POWER; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; USA; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Rodney Hunt Co. shipped two 30-foot by 28-foot fabricated steel roller gates to Idaho Power Co.'s Swan Falls Dam Project, where they will be installed as draft tube gates. Rodney Hunt said the gates, each weighing approximately 55 tons, are the largest roller gates the company has manufactured. The company supplied the gates under the terms of a contract worth more than $500,000. The gates were ordered as part of Idaho Power's rehabilitation of Swan Falls Dam, which will double the power plant's capacity to 25 MW. New units will begin producing power in 1993, and the project will be completed in 1994. Elsewhere on the Snake River, Idaho Power intends to increase the capacity of its Twin Falls project to 52 MW from 10 MW. Construction is scheduled to start in June 1993.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Direct shear loading leads to failure of generator bolts, rotor
AUTHORS: Flanagan, P J; Knittel, D
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; FASTENERS; FAILURES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ROTORS; SHEAR; POWER PLANTS; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Direct shear loading can result in the failure of bolts clamping the rotor flange to the shaft flange of a hydroelectric generator. Such was the case at the California Department of Water Resources 440-MW Gianelli Pumping-Generating Plant. The incident occurred July 5, 1991, when operators were bringing Unit 1 into service for generation. Tremendous forces on one of the unit's two rotors sheared ten 3 1/2-inch-diameter spider flange assembly bolts (ASTM A193-B16 steel) on the rotor, deforming bolt holes in both the spider flange and the shaft flange. The flanges, which allow the generator to transmit power through friction, rubbed and galled before the unit came to rest. The sudden shock load also slightly twisted the spider of the rotor, which during normal operation turns at 120 revolutions per minute at head of 190 to 245 feet. During normal operation, operators open a butterfly valve, allowing water to rush from a penstock to turn an impeller, which is connected to the generator rotor. Each of the plant's eight units is equipped with two rotors mounted on the same shaft. As the butterfly valve is gradually opened, speed of the unit increases. When the generator rotor is spinning at 90 percent of synchronous speed, the main unit breaker closes, energizing the stator windings with 13,800 volts. This rapidly accelerates the generator to approximately 98 percent of synchronous speed. The field breaker then closes, energizing the rotor poles with DC current. The rotor current reaches full strength in 2 to 5 seconds. During this time, the poles on the rotor are attempting to fall into step with the stator's rotating magnetic field.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Canadian and US agencies use bubbles to aid salmon
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SALMON; MIGRATION; WATER RESERVOIRS; COOLING; BUBBLES; COMPRESSED AIR; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; HABITAT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; AIR; ANADROMOUS FISHES; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; COMPRESSED GASES; FISHES; FLUIDS; GASES; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; SURFACE WATERS; VERTEBRATES; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: B.C. Hydro, Canada's federal Department of Fisheries and Oceans, and the Bureau of Reclamation in the US have implemented unique bubbler systems that release compressed air to aid fish migration and improve spawning habitat. In each case, compressed air equipment produced bubbles that lifted cool water from a lake bottom to displace warmer water on top. An experimental project during the summer of 1992, involving BC Hydro and the Department of Fisheries and Oceans, succeeded in reducing the mortality rate of sockeye salmon on their migration up the Somass River from the Alberni Inlet to Great Central Lake on Vancouver Island. The bubbler system cooled the water to aid the migration of hundreds of thousands of fish who were reluctant to continue upstream due to exceptionally warm water temperatures. Participants in the project suspended a large lead-weighted plastic curtain (more than 12 meters tall and extending the length of three football fields) from a series of floats across the outlet of Grand Central Lake. Compressed air equipment was installed behind the curtain to produce bubbles to lift cool water from the lake bottom. Water flowing into the river ranged from 1 to 3 degrees cooler than water on the other side of the curtain.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Voith will supply runners to Bay D'Espoir
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; CONTRACTS; DELIVERY; NEWFOUNDLAND; TESTING; CANADA; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; EQUIPMENT; ISLANDS; MACHINERY; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; TURBOMACHINERY; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Newfoundland and Labrador Hydro, a crown provincial utility, has awarded a contract to Voith Hydro, Inc., to supply six 75-MW Francis-type runners for the utility's Bay D'Espoir hydroelectric plant. Following model testing in Voith's York, Pa., laboratory, the company said it will begin delivery of the new runners over a period from August 1993 through June 1996. Newfoundland and Labrador Hydro previously selected Voith to furnish one of the runners - an upgraded 110-inch, 16-ton stainless steel Francis runner - for Bay D'Espoir in Milltown, Newfoundland. Voith said that turbine, to be recommissioned later this year, will provide a significant increase in effficiency' and alleviate pressure pulsation problems.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Private developer expands pumped-storage project plans
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; CAPACITY; ENGINEERING; GROUND WATER; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NEW YORK; TRANSMISSION; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; NORTH AMERICA; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; USA; WATER; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: A developer investigating the feasibility of a pumped-storage project on Grant Brook in Essex County, N.Y., is expanding its plans for the venture. Vineyard Road Associates, which already holds a Federal Energy Regulatory Commission preliminary permit for a 75-MW project at that site, has gone back to FERC and asked that the permit be amended to boost the project's capacity to 450 MW. In its application to amend the preliminary permit, Vineyard Road Associates said it wants to increase capacity and change the project's boundaries to encompass greater reservoir sizes. It noted that engineering studies determined the site has greater potential than originally thought. The larger project would produce an average annual generation of 1.3 gigawatt-hours. The closed-loop system will feature a lower pool made from a kettle-hole, left by a retreating glacier, that initially will be filled with ground water or water from Lake Champlain. The project also will include two upper reservoirs, a powerhouse, and a 115-kilovolt transmission line. The developer plans to build the project in stages, with the first stage to generate 200 MW.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Ebasco leads team for Southern California project
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; CONTRACTS; DAMS; CONSTRUCTION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSULTANTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; USA; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California has awarded a $37.6 million contract to Ebasco Services Inc. to construct the Domenigoni Valley Reservoir Project in Riverside County, Calif. Ebasco leads a project team that includes Black Veatch, Wahler Associates, and Woodward-Clyde Consultants. The project will feature two earthfill dams, a 40-MW pump-generating plant, and a 22-MW conventional hydro plant. The dams will be 180 and 280 feet tall and 2.2 miles and 1.8 miles long. Combined, the dams will contain more than 84 million cubic yards of earthfill and large rock. They will impound a 4,410-acre reservoir holding 800,000 acre-feet. Work began in November and will be completed by 2000.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Producing more power from existing hydro resources
AUTHORS: O'Connor, J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; CAPACITY; COST; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; RETROFITTING; BUSINESS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; EQUIPMENT; INDUSTRY; MAINTENANCE; MARKET; NEW YORK; POLLUTION; ROADS; TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY; TURBINES; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; MACHINERY; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; TURBOMACHINERY; US ORGANIZATIONS; USA; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Rehabilitation is big business in the North American hydropower industry. Hydropower producers are replacing or rehabilitating turbines, uprating old hydro generators, and installing advanced control systems. Estimates indicate that as much as 15,000 MW of new electricall generating capacity can be obtained by rehabilitating existing hydro facilities. The cost of developing this capacity is far less than for building new power projects. In most rehabilitation projects, the existing dam, powerhouse, and access roads are retained; only new mechanical and electrica equipment is required. As a result, these projects often can be accomplished for about half the cost of developing a new thermal plant to provide an equivalent amount of capacity. This new power does not contribute to atmospheric pollution, cause increases in operations and maintenance costs, or create uncertainties about fuel sources. The Bureau of Reclamation, the Salt River Project, the New York Power Authority, and the Tennessee Valley Authority all are either in the midst of major hydro rehabilitation projects or gearing up for future work. This activity indicates a healthy market of hydro products and services for years to come.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Superplasticized concrete for hydroelectric projects
AUTHORS: Hasan, N
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; CONCRETE-PLASTIC COMPOSITES; EVALUATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; CONCRETES; DAMS; PLASTICIZERS; SPILLWAY; TUNNELS; BUILDING MATERIALS; COMPOSITE MATERIALS; MATERIALS; POWER PLANTS; UNDERGROUND FACILITIES; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Design engineers for concrete structures often specify admixtures (ingredients added to mixtures of concrete) for reducing demand for water by up to 5 percent. By reducing the amount of water needed to make concrete, engineers can improve the properties of the hardened product. One group of admixtures known as plasticizers has been used since the 1950s. In the 1970s, a new group of plasticizers known as superplasticizers emerged in North America. Superplasticizers, also known as high-range, water-reducing admixtures (HRWRAs), tend to disperse cement particles in the concrete mix and, therefore, impart extreme flowability (fluidity) to the concrete. Typically, HRWRAs reduce the demand for water beyond that of standard water-reducing admixtures by up to 20 percent. Not only are the superplasticized admixtures used for structural concrete in conventional structures such as bridges and building foundations, increasingly engineers specify their use in concrete for hydroelectric projects, including dams, spillways, prefabricated powerhouses, and tunnels.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Washington rancher trades calves for kilowatts
AUTHORS: Hopkins, J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; SMALL-SCALE HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; FINANCING; EFFICIENCY; OPERATION; WASHINGTON; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; USA; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: A Washington state rancher has gone from raising cattle to producing kilowatts. He has completed a 1.6 MW hydro facility on Big Sheep Creek in northeastern Washington. The site was earlier rejected by utilities as a nonprofitable operation. The facility achieves 83% efficiency with a 1.3 MW turbine and 77% with the 300 kW unit also in operation. The project will make a profit for the first time in 1993 after going on line in 1986. Design and financing of the plant are described.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: Automating a 1900s vintage hydro plant
AUTHORS: Beedy, J L; Maas, E H; Lewitzke, H; Purzycki, D L; Jagodinski, T E
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; AUTOMATION; RETROFITTING; COMPUTERIZED CONTROL SYSTEMS; CONTROL; DESIGN; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; LABOR; PERSONAL COMPUTERS; COMPUTERS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; DIGITAL COMPUTERS; EQUIPMENT; MICROCOMPUTERS; ON-LINE CONTROL SYSTEMS; ON-LINE SYSTEMS; POWER PLANTS; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: A project to automate the controls and upgrade related electrical equipment at the world's largest horizontal-shaft hydroelectric plant is complete. Manual controls, some of which date back to 1916, have been replaced with what is believed to be the largest programmable logic controller (PLC)-based distributed control system ever assembled. The plant is the primary generating facility of Edison Sault Electric Company. Automation will ultimately cut labor costs by more than $400,000/year. The PLC-based control system uses Modicon 984-120 Compact PLCs at each turbine-generator unit linked together over a Modicon Modbus PLus high-speed local area network. All PLCs can be programmed from one location. The plant also uses a Most Economic Dispatch (MED) computer program as part of the automation package. The software is intended to maximize plant revenue per allotment of water and to minimize the need for operator input in assigning units. The program runs on a hierarchichal personal computer on the local area network. Other design elements of the plant are described.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:1

TITLE: A real-time model of the synchronous machine based on digital signal processors
AUTHORS: Do, Vanque; Barry, A O
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; TURBOGENERATORS; PARALLEL PROCESSING; PENSTOCKS; REAL TIME SYSTEMS; SPEED REGULATORS; VOLTAGE REGULATORS; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; EQUIPMENT; MACHINERY; PIPES; PROGRAMMING; SIMULATION; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130700* - Hydro Energy- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: A real-time digital model of a complete hydraulic synchronous machine is presented. The model is based on parallel processing using digital-signal processors (DSP) for fast calculation. The paper describes the modeling of the machine using block diagrams to represent the generator, voltage regulator, stabilizer, turbine, penstock and governor. Details of the hardware and software used to implement the real-time model of the machine are given. A first series of tests has been done and results are shown to evaluate the steady-state and transient performance of the model.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 8:1
JOURNAL_NAME: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: Progressive failure of lower San Fernando dam
AUTHORS: Gu, W H; Morgenstern, N R; Robertson, P K
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; DAMS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; SITE CHARACTERIZATION; EARTHQUAKES; SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTIONS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; BOUNDARY-VALUE PROBLEMS; DEFORMATION; FAILURES; FINITE ELEMENT METHOD; FOUNDATIONS; GEOLOGIC MODELS; GROUND MOTION; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SHEAR PROPERTIES; SOILS; STABILITY; CALCULATION METHODS; GEOLOGY; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; MECHANICAL STRUCTURES; MOTION; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; POWER PLANTS; SEISMIC EVENTS; SUPPORTS; 130200* - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology; 580000 - Geosciences
DESCRIPTION: Postearthquake deformation analyses of the lower San Fernando dam were conducted using an incremental finite-element method. In the analyses, an undrained elastoplastic model was used to simulate the collapse of liquefied materials. The model is developed based on the critical-state boundary-surface theory, the concept of steady-state strength, and the undrained behavior of liquefiable soils. A triggering condition in terms of a collapse surface was considered in this model. The hyperbolic strain-softening relationship has been introduced to simulate the postpeak behavior of liquefied materials. The analyses have shown that a progressive failure under undrained conditions may explain the observed response of the lower San Fernando dam following the 1971 earthquake. Stress redistribution initiated by the strain softening of liquefied materials is the main reason for undrained flow failures of dams, slopes, and foundations and can occur in a short period ranging from a few seconds to a few minutes. The liquefied zone after stress redistribution may be much larger than the initial liquefied zone caused directly by an earthquake. Therefore, a postearthquake deformation analysis may be essential in liquefaction stability evaluations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Geotechnical Engineering; (United States); Journal Volume: 119:2; Journal Issue: 2

TITLE: Independent developer plans Wyoming project
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; DAMS; DRAWDOWN; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; WYOMING; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ENGINEERING; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NORTH AMERICA; PEAKING POWER PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; USA; 130100* - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Little Horn Energy Wyoming, Inc. is proposing a project on the Dry Fork of the Little Big Horn River. The lower reservoir would be impounded by a roller-compacted concrete dam and an outlet tower on the upstream face of the dam would have multilevel intakes to allow selective temperature discharges into the Dry Fork. The asphalt-lined upper reservoir on an adjacent ridge would be contained by a 100 foot high rockfill embankment. Maximum planned daily drawdown is 45 ft. Preliminary plans call for water to drop through a 21 ft. diameter shaft to a manifold. Then ft. diameter penstocks would feed a four unit underground power house.
RELATION: Journal Name: Engineering News-Record; (United States); Journal Volume: 230:4

TITLE: Hydroelectric dams need billions for rehab
AUTHORS: Carr, F H; Soast, A
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; REPAIR; CAPACITY; CAPITAL; CAPITALIZED COST; DAMS; US CORPS OF ENGINEERS; COST; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; US DOD; US ORGANIZATIONS; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Many of the Corps of Engineers older hydroelectric dams will require major rehabilitation over the next ten years. Preventive maintenance, repair work, and major rehabilitation of the Corp's hydro dams in inadequate because the revenue generated by sales of electricity, by law, is returned to the Treasury. Most multimillion dollar rehabilitation projects require specific approval for funding by Congress and securing it is a long and difficult process. It is hoped the funding problem will soon be addressed by the Clinton administration. Already, nearly one-sixth of the 2,154 Mw of hydro is unavailable because with hydro units are either out of service or operating at less than full capacity.
RELATION: Journal Name: Engineering News-Record; (United States); Journal Volume: 230:2

TITLE: Commercial options for energy storage multiply
AUTHORS: Collins, S
SUBJECT: 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ENERGY STORAGE; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; COMPRESSED AIR ENERGY STORAGE; ELECTRIC BATTERIES; PUMPED STORAGE; SENSIBLE HEAT STORAGE; ELECTROCHEMICAL CELLS; HEAT STORAGE; STORAGE; 250000* - Energy Storage; 130300 - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Utilities have used pumped-storage hydroelectric plants for decades. Now, as described in this article independently developed pumped hydro and several advanced technologies are emerging to help respond to the long-term need for managing peak demand. Not long ago, large, utility-owned, pumped-storage hydroelectric plants were the only commercially viable means of storing electric energy during off-peak hours and boosting output during periods of high demand. Benefits of these facilities include: (1) They allow utilities to operate large base-load stations more economically: (2) they help regulate system-wide frequency and power factor; and (3) they can be activated immediately to supply backup power for short periods when unplanned shutdowns occur. Several factors have combined to drive up the cost and hamper the development of large, utility-owned, pumped-hydro plants, including: (1) lack of readily available sites, (2) more stringent siting and permitting requirements, (3) opposition from environmental groups, (4) scaling back of plans for large, base-load nuclear stations, and (5) the availability of relatively inexpensive gas-turbine-based peaking units. Despite these challenges, independent power developers are now leading a miniresurgence in pumped-hydro planning. The latest projects include several novel design concepts--such as modular and underground units--aimed at overcoming the drawbacks of more conventional facilities. A corresponding trend is the emergence of several other load-leveling options including: (1) compressed-air energy storage (CAES), (2) combustion-turbine inlet-air cooling, and (3) battery energy storage.
RELATION: Journal Name: Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 137:1

TITLE: Hydro resources: What's new from 1992
AUTHORS: Smith-Noggle, L
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; INFORMATION; COLUMBIA RIVER BASIN; DESIGN; DIRECTORIES; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; ENGINEERING; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; HISTORICAL ASPECTS; LICENSING REGULATIONS; MANUALS; NATIONAL GOVERNMENT; PROGRAMMING LANGUAGES; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; DOCUMENT TYPES; ECONOMICS; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; REGULATIONS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; WATERSHEDS; 130000* - Hydro Energy
DESCRIPTION: Hydro Review presents a selection of recently released hydro books, publications, and software, complete with information about to obtain these useful items. Each year, many new technical and informational resources-both printed and electronic-become available to the hydro industry. These resources are useful in a number of ways: they provide instructional and practical information, they can help solve problems, and they are helpful in understanding hydroelectric technology. In this article, the author summarizes recently released books and other publications and software packages that are useful as well as interesting. This summary will acquaint the reader with a varied selection of resources. For each resource, quoted the publisher's retail price is (in US dollars except where noted). There may be additional postage and handling charges. Information is provided about how to order books and software featured in this article.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:8

TITLE: In the spotlight: New hydro development in North America
AUTHORS: Barnes, M J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; NORTH AMERICA; ALBERTA; ARKANSAS; CALIFORNIA; IDAHO; MAINE; MANITOBA; MASSACHUSETTS; NEW HAMPSHIRE; NEW YORK; ONTARIO; OREGON; QUEBEC; TEXAS; UTAH; WASHINGTON; WISCONSIN; CANADA; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; USA; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: 1992 was a year of progress for many segments of the hydropower industry as developers worked to bring new projects on line. This industry overview features several of these projects and offers a preview of 1993 activity. The only operating privately owned hydroelectric project in Texas. The largest hydro plant in the province of Manitoba. The world's largest submersible hydroturbine-generator. These projects and others-completed and placed in service in 1992-can claim a special place in the history books. For each of the 31 hydro projects in North America that began operating in 1992, there's a unique story to tell. Each called upon the time, talent, commitment, ingenuity, and perseverance of those involved in their development. In aggregate, these projects contribute nearly 3,800 MW of clean, renewable electrical capacity that can be used efficiently and cost-effectively to help meet the power demands of customers in the US and Canada. Utilities, state agencies, municipalities, and independent power developers played roles in developing new hydro in 1992. We offer a sampling of their work to illustrate progress made in the past year.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydro Review; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:8

TITLE: Will the Commission's hydropower program revive in the '90s
AUTHORS: O'Connor, G C
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ENERGY POLICY; LEGISLATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; LICENSING REGULATIONS; LEGAL ASPECTS; CONSUMER PROTECTION; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; FORECASTING; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; INTEREST GROUPS; LAWSUITS; POWER POTENTIAL; US FERC; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER; REGULATIONS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; US DOE; US ORGANIZATIONS; 293000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Policy, Legislation, & Regulation; 130400 - Hydro Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 296000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power
DESCRIPTION: Prior to the enactment of the Electric Consumer Protection Act of 1986 (ECPA), the Commission for 66 years oversaw the nation's water power potential with uncompromising authority. Since ECPA, the Commission has been very slow and tentative in its approach to licensing hydropower projects under Part I of the Federal Power Act. In that time, the hydropower industry has found itself in an almost impossible situation. It has been burdened with heavy regulatory requirements laden with a consulation process that frequently engenders adversarial conflicts with public interest groups and state and federal agencies. The process leads to a license with too much uncertainty to generally proceed with construction of the proposed project. This article assesses the current status of the hydropower industry so that the industry's future may be realistically assessed. The analysis begins in 1978 when Congress enacted landmark energy legislation that initiated, among other things, a [open quotes]hydro gold rush.[close quotes] What immediately follows is a historical review of this period, which includes a discussion of the response of the environmental community and the consequent legal battles fought in the 1980s. The analysis concludes with some comments on how the Energy Policy Act of 1992 affects the prospects of hydropower continuing as a viable energy source in the next century.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Law Journal; (United States); Journal Volume: 14:1

TITLE: Small-dam rehabs
AUTHORS: Denning, J
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; DAMS; REPAIR; ACCIDENTS; COST; DAMAGE; ECONOMICS; FAILURES; HUMAN FACTORS; LEAKS; MODIFICATIONS; SAFETY; SPILLWAY; 130300* - Hydro Energy- Plant Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: This article examines the economics of maintenance, rehabilitation and improvement for small, aging, high-hazard dams. The topics of the article include raising the height of the spillway and repairing deteriorated concrete in the spillway of Fellows Lake Dam, emergency repair of the outlet conduit and replacement of riprap on the upstream slope of Storrie Lake Dam, and extensive rehabilitation of Reeves Lake Dam.
RELATION: Journal Name: Civil Engineering (New York, 1983); (United States); Journal Volume: 63:1

TITLE: Tapping upgrade potential
AUTHORS: Gill, H S
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; REPAIR; AGING; EFFICIENCY; EQUIPMENT; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; RETROFITTING; MACHINERY; POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 130500* - Hydro Energy- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Modernizing aging hydropower stations presents plant owners with a unique opportunity for improving efficiency and plant output. But several factors should be considered before undertaking a turbine upgrade project.
RELATION: Journal Name: Independent Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 23:1

TITLE: An irresistible force
AUTHORS: Hoffman, G J
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; WATER RESOURCES; GLOBAL ASPECTS; CLIMATIC CHANGE; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS
DESCRIPTION: Water resources are of critical importance to both natural ecosystems and human development. Societal pressures on these resources are increasing as population grows and industrial development continues. The existing infrastructures for our water supply systems are generally both robust and resilient within the context of past hydrologic events, but their capacity for dealing with events that might result from a future climate change is questionable. Of the various potential hydrologic consequences of climate change, variability in terms of higher peak flood flows, more persistent and severe droughts, and greater uncertainty of the timing and intensity of the rainy season will be among the most difficult to handle.
RELATION: Journal Name: Agricultural Engineering; Journal Volume: 74; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: Jan 1993

TITLE: Effect of flow diversions on contaminant transport modeling in the Niagara River
AUTHORS: Blair, S H; Atkinson, J F
SUBJECT: 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 99 GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS//MATHEMATICS, COMPUTING, AND INFORMATION SCIENCE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; PUMPED STORAGE; NIAGARA RIVER; CONTAMINATION; WATER POLLUTION MONITORS; NUMERICAL ANALYSIS; SAMPLING; TRACER TECHNIQUES; ENERGY STORAGE; ISOTOPE APPLICATIONS; MATHEMATICS; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; MONITORS; POWER PLANTS; RIVERS; STORAGE; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 130600* - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 130100 - Hydro Energy- Resources & Availability; 990200 - Mathematics & Computers
DESCRIPTION: A numerical model is formulated to simulate one-dimensional transport of a conservative tracer through the Niagara River, from Fort Erie to Niagara-on-the-Lake. The model accounts for flow splits at Grand and Navy islands and, more significantly, incorporates the operations of the New York Power Authority and Ontario Hydropower. These involve large-scale diversions and temporary storage of water for power production, resulting in a dispersion-like effect on the breakthrough curves for the tracer at Niagara-on-the-Lake. In comparison with straight through-flow calculations, the model results indicate an increase in mean residence times by up to 25% and decreases in peak concentrations by up to 50%, depending on the time of day the contaminant release occurs. In addition, the model shows the distribution of tracer mass remaining in the system after a typical sampling program, as currently followed in the Niagara River Toxics Management Plan. This allows a determination of optimal timing for sampling in order to maximize mass recovery. The model provides a tool to help understand transport in this complex hydraulic system. 10 refs., 13 refs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Great Lakes Research; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:1
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of Great Lakes Research; (United States)
